mods:titleInfo.mods:title: How White-Presenting Latina Undergraduate Students Make Sense of and Experience Their Racial Identity

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: How Latinas experience their racial identity is unique when viewed through the Black and white racial dichotomy that exists in the United States. In Latin America, race is understood to be phenotypical and determined based off the color of your skin, whereas in the United States, race is often understood to be genotypical (Darity et. al, 2005), and designed to classify its citizens as "white" and "nonwhite." These classifications force Latinas to select a racial grouping that they might not fully feel represents them. For Latinas who racially appear as white, but ethnically identify with their family's country of origin, a certain dissonance can arise that can blur their perception of self. Living and learning in the United States as someone who presents racially as white but is a member of a marginalized community can provide insight to how whiteness shows up in certain spaces and functions as epidermic capital (Herring & Hynes, 2017). This study is inspired by Anzaldúa's (1987) work on hyphenated-identities, in which she described as making her feel as if she is "ni de aquí, ni de allá." [not from here, nor from there]. Focusing on the hyphenated identity of being both white-presenting and Latina allows for richer discussions surrounding race to occur. Using testimonios as the methodology, with intersectionality (Crenshaw, 1997) through theory in the flesh (Anzaldúa & Moraga, 1981) as a conceptual framework, this study sought to understand how six white-presenting Latina students experienced and made sense of their racial identity at an emerging Hispanic Serving Institution in the state of Florida. Data for this study was collected from participants through a screening tool, and two semi structured interviews which took the form of pláticas. Based on the themes of the study, participants experience with colorism, and racism informed how they made meaning of their identity which led to an actualization of their identity in college as they embarked on a quest for belonging. Some external factors that influenced meaning making of their racial identity ranged from notions of femininity and beauty, to navigating presumptions surrounding the Latina stereotype, to prioritizing being bilingual to feel connected to their Latina culture. The study concludes with a discussion on the findings in connection to the conceptual framework, and implications for practice and future discussions. Despite being socially constructed, race is socially significant and enacted in everyday life (Bonilla-Silva, 2015; Ray, 2022). It is the hope of this study that in learning how undergraduate white-presenting Latina students experience and make sense of their racial identity, higher education intuitions can become more intentional in creating physical spaces where all Latinas are able to feel "de aquí y de allá" [from here and from there].
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Higher Education.
colorism, Latina, racial identity, testimonios, whiteness
Lara Perez-Felkner, Professor Directing Dissertation; John Reynolds, University Representative; Ayesha Khurshid, Committee Member; Tamara Bertrand Jones, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: George and the Dragon

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This novel is a mashup and retelling of the story of St. George and the Dragon, with such other influences as Anna Burns's Little Constructions, Kathyn Davis's The Thin Place, Kathy Acker's Blood and Guts in High School, the Dudley Moore film Arthur (Steve Gordon, 1981), and the body of media documenting early aughts party girls like Amy Winehouse, Lindsay Lohan, Paris Hilton, Kate Moss, and the Olsen twins. It's a book about (among other things) addiction and recovery, interpersonal cruelty, God, and true love.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Mark D. Winegardner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Colleen Marie Ganley, University Representative; Ravi Y. Howard, Committee Member; Bruce M. Horack, Jr., Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Hadrian's Villa

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Set in the months following the American invasion of Iraq, the novel tells the story of a group of expat neighbors in a Rome, Italy. The novel is narrated by Polly, who receives a letter from Florence, informing her of her father's death. Polly secretly drops out of Penn and travels to Florence, where she meets her cousin, Antero, who is waiting for his inheritance to materialize. Polly moves to Rome with Antero, believing she's found an escape from her family's growing troubles at home. Antero installs Polly in an eighteenth-century palazzo near the Colosseum, where she meets Giuseppe, her upstairs neighbor, and soon gets caught in Rome's surfeit of pleasures and distractions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Mark Winegardner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lisa Ryoko Wakamiya, University Representative; Bruce Horack, Jr., Committee Member; Elizabeth Stuckey-French, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Teacher Burnout School Working Conditions and Leadership Characteristics in Mastery School District

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This quantitative exploratory study examined the degree to which teachers in Mastery School District (MSD) are experiencing burnout and the extent to which working conditions and leadership characteristics contribute to burnout. A district-wide survey of 251 teachers was conducted using the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Educator Survey (MBI-ES) to measure burnout and additional subscales were used to measure working conditions and leadership characteristics. Descriptive statistics examined the level of teacher burnout, and multiple regression analyses were used to examine the relationships between working conditions, leadership characteristics, and teacher burnout. Results indicated that teachers in MSD are experiencing a moderate degree of emotional exhaustion, which is one key attribute of burnout. Teachers reported a mild degree of the two other dimensions, depersonalization and reduced personal accomplishment. Teacher workload was the strongest predictor of emotional exhaustion, while school safety was the strongest predictor of depersonalization. Grade level taught was the strongest predictor of reduced personal accomplishment. Leadership characteristics were negatively associated with all three dimensions of burnout. These findings suggest that addressing teacher workload, school safety, and leadership characteristics may be effective strategies for reducing teacher burnout in MSD.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Microfluidic Platform for Islet Quality Evaluation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Diabetes, a global epidemic with no known cure, presents a complex pathophysiology that remains incompletely understood. Patients with diabetes rely on medications or exogenous insulin administration to regulate blood glucose levels. Extensive scientific research is dedicated to unraveling the pathophysiology and developing therapeutic interventions. Notably, islet transplantation has emerged as a promising treatment for type 1 diabetes, involving the infusion of purified islets from deceased donors into a patient's portal vein. The effectiveness of islet transplantation hinges on the quality and functionality of the islets, typically assessed through the stimulation index (SI), a measure of insulin secretion in response to varying glucose concentrations in static cell culture. However, this method may not accurately reflect in vivo islet function. Microfluidic platforms have been proposed as a potential solution, yet their development is ongoing and requires refinement for widespread adoption. This dissertation explores the development of microfluidic platforms for islet quality assessment. One approach to enhancing throughput in microfluidic systems is vacuum-driven flow, which can simultaneously drive flow across multiple channels using a single pressure source. However, the lack of active control over individual channels poses challenges in delivering different stimulant solutions to islets on a chip. To address this issue, we integrated 4-layer pneumatic valves into perfusion lines to automate and control stimulant delivery, although this led to flow spikes and abnormal insulin secretion profiles. Incorporating fluidic capacitors after the valves effectively eliminated these spikes, resulting in automated collection of insulin secretion profiles from single murine islets, mirroring previously reported results. These integrated fluidic components may facilitate the use of more complex channel designs with a straightforward flow control solution. To improve temporal resolution and decrease dispersion, segmented flows were applied to measure cellular secretions on integrated microfluidic platforms. A fluorescence anisotropy insulin immunoassay method was developed for microfluidic droplets, significantly enhancing binding rates and temporal resolution compared to continuous flow assays. The improved temporal resolution is a step towards approaching the time scale required for resolving specific signaling events in pancreatic islet biology. Efforts to enhance the sensitivity of fluorescence anisotropy assays for low-abundance peptides secreted from the islets of Langerhans, with a focus on insulin as the model analyte, were explored. Introducing an anti-mouse IgG antibody to increase the molecular volume of the binding assay product did not yield the expected sensitivity enhancement. Additional research and optimization are required to develop a more effective strategy for detecting low-abundance peptides secreted from pancreatic islet
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bioanalysis, Diabetes, Immunoassay, Insulin, Islets of Langerhans, Microfluidics
Michael G. Roper, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Bertram, University Representative; Alan G. Marshall, Committee Member; Qing-Xiang Sang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Advanced Bayesian Methods and Applications in Biomedical Data

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Bayesian statistics is a powerful technique for flexibly modeling complex data generation processes. In recent decades, Bayesian methods have gained increased popularity in analyzing biological and spatial data. However, there is much scope for their application in analyzing biomedical data, especially in neuroimaging studies and infectious disease modeling. In Chapter 1, we have focused on Alzheimer's Disease (AD), a leading cause of dementia, and proposed a 'Patient-specific Abnor- mal Region Detection' (PARD) algorithm to identify the heterogeneous abnormal regions in AD patients by solving a Bayesian latent-space variable selection problem. Using Bayesian hierarchical modeling, we have accounted for the heterogeneity as a large-scale variability and incorporated the inherent spatial dependence among the brain cells using Ising and spike-and-slab priors into the latent space. We have conducted an extensive simulation study showing PARD's superiority over competing methods. Finally, we applied PARD to identify subject-specific diseased regions using the MRIs collected from ADNI and constructed sub-group level abnormality maps. In Chapter 2, we have moved our attention to infectious disease modeling, where we have proposed a Bayesian function-on-function regression model to detect abnormal jumps in infection trends. Using three simulation studies, we have shown that the proposed framework can outperform the traditional change-point detection methods by a large margin in terms of detecting significant change points in both linear and non-linear trends while accounting for the effects of functional covariates and ignoring spurious jumps. The proposed framework has been applied to the US COVID-19 trends to identify abnormal jumps that are solely attributable to the infectious disease. In Chapter 3, we applied causal mediation analysis via a Bayesian framework to analyze the causal effects of genetic variations on cognition in AD patients and identify how different brain regions may mediate these effects. Our simulation study validated the effectiveness of the Bayesian framework. Finally, we have implemented the framework for the imaging-genetic and cognitive data collected from ADNI.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Rongjie Liu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Nowakowski, University Representative; Elizabeth Slate, Committee Member; Jonathan Bradley, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Science Teachers' Instructional Practices and Vision for Promoting Students' Intellectual Engagement in Science Classrooms

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Research in science education and current instructional reforms emphasize students' intellectual engagement in science classrooms as they use disciplinary ideas and practices to make sense of phenomena and solve problems. Reform-oriented science instruction that fosters such intellectual engagement for all students is possible. However, it is not yet prevalent in many science classrooms. To gain more insight into how to design and enact such science instruction supporting students' intellectual engagement, this dissertation study consists of an interrelated set of three investigations conducted in the context of a larger professional development project focused on promoting teachers' learning about and enacting reform-oriented science instruction. Each investigation builds on one other and contributes to the existing knowledge. The first investigation explores how teachers' instructional practices and features of classroom tasks work together to shape opportunities for students' intellectual engagement in science lessons. Specifically, we aimed to unpack instructional practices that can help to enhance students' engagement in rigorous intellectual work in science lessons and explore the consequences of these practices. Our data were drawn from the classrooms of science teachers who co-designed lessons promoting productive science talk. Working from recordings and work products from four different lessons for these teachers, we found that the potential demand on students' thinking was declined, maintained, or enhanced from what the lesson design afforded. Through a closer examination of instances of science instruction where placing a high demand on student thinking was a norm, we found that instructional practices associated with promoting students' engagement in rigorous intellectual work were consequential for promoting students' epistemic agency. Thus, we argue that maintaining and enhancing demand on students' intellectual work in cognitively demanding tasks creates opportunities for students to learn science-as-practice by acting as epistemic agents. The second and third investigations centered on understanding science teachers' instructional practices in relation to their instructional vision to gain insights into factors shaping science instruction. Through interviews and extended classroom observations, we examined the intersection between four teachers' instructional practices, instructional visions, and their student's engagement with a specific focus on either productive science talk or demand on students' thinking. Instruction promoting students' integration of science content and practices as they worked to figure out phenomena was observed in classrooms of teachers who had a sophisticated instructional vision of classroom tasks and the role of the teacher in instruction. In contrast, science instruction promoting students' intellectual work that involved isolated engagement in science practices or content was evident in the classrooms of teachers with a developing instructional vision. In addition, productive science talk was observed in the classrooms of teachers with a sophisticated instructional vision of classroom talk, while teachers with a developing instructional vision of productive talk struggled in facilitating such talk. Taken together with these findings, we argue that instructional vision can illuminate teachers' thinking about their work and exploring the intersection between teachers' instructional practice and vision can help to reveal teachers' understanding and reaction to reform efforts. Overall, the three investigations contribute to the field's understanding of teachers' instructional practices and vision of science instruction that can foster students' intellectual engagement. For professional development efforts that seek to develop teachers' capacity for reform-oriented instruction in science classrooms, this dissertation suggests concurrently attending the development of teachers' instructional practices and instruction vision.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of School Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cognitively Demanding Classroom Task, Demand on Students' Thinking, Instructional Vision, Productive Science Talk, Rigorous Science Instruction, Students' Epistemic Agency

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Motion in Glass Formers

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The vast realm of glass forming materials (GF) encompasses a diverse range of substances from the versatile polymers to the renowned silicates. These materials possess the ability to transform into amorphous solids with no structural order at their glass transition temperature, Tg, which is usually preceded by a many-body cooperative relaxation process. The consensus on Tg is that while it mirrors some aspects of a thermodynamic phase transition, it is mainly defined by a timescale taken by the material to establish the equilibrium state (~ 100 s for example). Many polymers are often associated with the glass transition because of their amorphous structure as solids. When polymers are made to hold a charged group, the result is a polyelectrolyte, and when two polyelectrolytes of opposite charges are mixed in solution, the result is a polyelectrolyte complex (PEC). PECs are unique because unlike neutral polymers, they can be made to retain a significant amount of water. This makes PECs remarkably versatile due to their pliability, hence potential applicability. PECs can also help us bridge some fundamental gaps on the nature of relaxation in GFs since the dynamics of the smallest length scale (the cross-link here described to be a sticker bond between one Pol+ and one Pol- monomer segment) can be quantitatively studied. In this Dissertation, liquid-like PECs are probed to determine their key mechanical properties described by their viscoelastic response as a function of salt, temperature, and polymer chain size. Many characterization techniques such as, but not limited to, 1H-NMR, radiolabeling, ATR-FTIR and ionic conductivity were used to evaluate the stoichiometry and the environment of the PEC and its constituents. Light and neutron scattering techniques were utilized to determined molecular weights and size of statistical segments in our complexes. Ultimately, rheology was used to dissect the dynamics in PECs across different length scales and at various temperatures. A mechanism for structural relaxation is proposed wherein two dynamic units drive overall relaxation by a simple pair exchange. This is backed up with ionic conductivity measurements and an analytical expression which was successful in reproducing relaxation frequencies in not only PECs but also neutral polymers. Finally, microscopic "Aufbau" was used to build up a picture of unit motion in GFs, including but not limited to PECs, incorporating concepts that have provided a consistent thread of understanding over the last several decades. Such concepts pertain to an evolution a dynamic heterogeneity which cooperatively re-arranges. This is usually paralleled with a striking change in the material's properties such as viscosity, relaxation time, fractional free volume, and entropy. This picture describes the molecules or atoms in GFs as single units arranged in a disordered 3D structure. Correlated motion occurs among a minimum number of units, nmin, which ranges from 1 to 5 in an actual landscape of potential maxima and minima. The time taken for a GF to relax depends on the time it takes for an assortment of nmin units to relax throughout the material. At high temperatures (Arrhenius region), the motion of nmin units is not restricted to its nearest next neighbors. The time it takes for the GF to relax will only depend on an exponential term which describes a Boltzmann probability distribution of units as a function of temperature. Upon cooling, GFs lose free volume. Near Tg, in the supercooled region, neighboring units provide additional free volume for nmin units to relax. This introduces an extra probability term that recognizes the volume contribution to the overall relaxation. In recognition of the long-held belief that an equation describing glass dynamics in one material should be able to describe glass dynamics in all glass formers, wide variety of glassy materials, and materials with glassy response, were analyzed using literature data and tested the results against the analytical expression derived for relaxation frequencies in polymers.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Glass transition, Polyelectrolyte complexes, Polymers, Relaxation time, Temperature, Viscosity
Joseph B. Schlenoff, Professor Directing Dissertation; Subramanian Ramakrishnan, University Representative; Justin Kennemur, Committee Member; Biwu Ma, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring Urban-Rural Differences in Disaster Vulnerability among Minority Populations in Florida Panhandle Area

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: During times of disasters, minority populations often experience disproportionate vulnerabilities, encountering significant obstacles and enduring long-term consequences compared to other racial groups. This research aims to investigate how the responses to disaster issues of minority populations vary across rural and urban areas in the Florida Panhandle. The study examines differences in disaster needs and vulnerabilities among minority populations by analyzing their evacuation status, choices of evacuation destinations, and preferred modes of transportation during previous hurricanes. The research focuses on 18 counties in the north-west region of Florida, USA, encompassing 75 rural zip codes and 59 urban zip codes. A two-target groups approach was employed to sample minority populations for the survey. The first target group comprised minorities of all ages residing in urban areas, while the second target group consisted of minorities in rural areas. A total of 160 responses were collected, evenly distributed between the two target groups. The survey was conducted using Pollfish, a reputable online survey platform that specializes in administering surveys through mobile applications, offering researchers the capability to target specific population groups based on various eligibility criteria for enhanced precision and relevance. Various regression models, including binary logistic regression and multinomial logistic regression, were used to analyze the collected data. Eighteen logistic regression models were developed, focusing on evacuation status, evacuation destination, and evacuation mode choice as dependent variables. The independent variables encompassed socio-economic factors, health-related variables, and variables related to the consequences of disasters. The findings reveal that 61.3% of urban minority populations and 81.3% of rural minority populations in the Florida Panhandle were compelled to evacuate due to the disasters they faced. The study identifies statistically significant socio-economic, health, and disaster consequence variables, highlighting the differences in evacuation behavior between urban and rural minorities. The findings of this research have practical implications for emergency management. They shed light on the evacuation decisions of vulnerable populations, assisting in the incorporation of the evacuation needs of marginalized populations. By addressing the disparities in disaster vulnerabilities among minority populations, this research strives to promote more effective and inclusive emergency response strategies in the Florida Panhandle and potentially in other similar regions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Geography in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Florida Panhandle, Hurricane Evacuation, Logistic Regression Analysis, Minority Population, Urban- Rural Difference
Mark W. Horner, Professor Directing Thesis; Christopher Uejio, Committee Member; Tingting Zhao, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Mission Feel!
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Feeling Emotions, Enhancing Life: A Novel Emotional Understanding Intervention for Preschoolers

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Emotion understanding (EU) is an important competency that children begin to develop during the first years of life and serves as an essential building block for life-long learning. EU is linked to a host of developmental outcomes including academic, cognitive, and social-emotional skills. Not surprisingly, a number of efficacious interventions to promote children's social-emotional learning, including EU, have been developed. Scale-up of these interventions is challenging because they are time and resource intensive. Brief, fully automated interventions that can be accessed at the convenience of participants are a promising alternative for overcoming barriers to implementation of EU interventions. Mission FEEL! is a two-session, fully automated intervention to promote EU among preschool children using a cognitive-behavioral framework. The current proof-of-concept study examined the user acceptability and feasibility of Mission FEEL! to provide an evidence-base for deciding whether to proceed with more rigorous testing of the intervention. I recruited 52 preschool children and their parents/guardians across the state of Florida. Participants completed four virtual study visits consisting of a baseline assessment to measure children's pre-treatment EU, two intervention sessions, and a one-month follow-up assessment. Following each intervention session, parents answered three questions to assess intervention feasibility. At the end of Session 2, parents completed a more thorough acceptability and feasibility assessment. I established a priori benchmarks for evaluating the intervention's feasibility, acceptability, and clinical meaningfulness (80% = excellent; 70% = good; and 60% = adequate). The study results provided support for both the acceptability and feasibility of Mission FEEL!. All outcomes met the benchmarks for good or excellent, apart from two that fell in the adequate range. The clinical meaningfulness of the intervention was supported by parental perceptions of the program's influence on emotion-related parent-child interactions, the perceived value of the program in children's daily lives, and the observed difference in EU scores between baseline and follow-up. Additional factors supporting the intervention's clinical meaningfulness were the low cost and the relative ease of scale-up (i.e., translating the intervention from a local level to a regional and national level). Taken together, the findings from this proof-of-concept study suggest that Mission FEEL! merits advancement to the next phase of intervention development testing.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Christopher J. Patrick, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sylvie Naar, University Representative; Jesse Cougle, Committee Member; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Ashby Plant, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Past the Gardenia Bush, Beyond the Basketball Hoop
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Hybrid Memoir and an Embedded Fictional Narrative of the Medieval Saint Rabiaa Al-Adawiyyah

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Past the Gardenia Bush, Beyond the Basketball Hoop is a post-9/11 memoir of meaning-making where Sufism and literature claim agency against extremism and family relations. I use two techniques: magical realism and metafictional imagining of the life of Rabiaa Al-Adawiyyah, born in the 8th century and the first female Sufi in Islam. The nested story is a fictionalized narrative of Rabiaa that shows her enslavement, working as a singer in brothels, and her transition to mysticism. I use magical realism in allowing Rabiaa to transcend time, seeking her wisdom in a world fractured by political rifts and my family's disapproval of Sufism. In a rhizomatic narration of events, the book illustrates how I found Sufism and why it resonates with my perspective on harmony. It brings forth the journey from the "false self," seeking immediate gratification, to the "essential self" of internal peace, answering the question, "Who am I?" that has set Don Quixote on his quest. The first chapter theorizes storytelling as a way to claim an identity. In the second chapter, conflict arises between the first instance of Sufism in the narrator's home, love of literature vs. censorship, and sympathy with the second intifada. It also historizes the root of extremism in Saudi Arabia. The third chapter introduces in a vignette the evolution of Sufism in the narrator's life and presents Barbie as a model of cultural-in-betweenness. It compares the extremist Zainab Al-Ghazali to the medieval Sufi Abu Hamid Al-Ghazali and introduces Ibn Arabi's "four pegs theory." The fourth section deepens the identity crisis at the cusp of family relations, 9/11, cultural exchange, and imaginary dialogue with Rabiaa Al-Adawiyyah. The fifth section bolts the narrator's identity in storytelling and the world of letters. It shows the narrator's personality through further exchanges with the imaginary saint. My dissertation answers the troubling identity question: "Who am I?" reflecting on graven images, novels, songs, portraits, and other paraphernalia the Sahwa Movement prohibited after the 1979 Grand Mosque attack in Mecca. It reflects on Charlotte Bronte's Jane Eyre and weaves into the narrative the understanding of how a young woman develops a sense of self. Past the Gardenia Bush makes the case that multiplicity is an option, that writing fiction, not wearing the hijab, and encouraging my son's piano skills do not strip me of spirituality—that losing myself in remembering the Divine is compatible with writing stories and interacting with people of different cultures.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
identity, metafiction, post 9/11, Rabiaa Al-Adawiyyah, storytelling

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Parallelizing Complexity
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Strategies for Accelerating AI Algorithms and Scientific Simulations in Heterogeneous Computing Environments

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation presents an in-depth analysis of using heterogeneous computing to improve the performance of AI algorithms and scientific simulations. This study focuses on two critical project approaches: 1) novel approaches in parallelization of high-compute large matrix multiplications with complex values, including large Hermitian matrix multiplications and complex SVD (Singular Value Decomposition) computations, with the results of SVD computations were used in machine learning tasks, and 2) the parallelization of Shapley value computation for Explainable AI (XAI) applications. These approaches are thoroughly benchmarked across multiple hardware configurations, not limited to consumer-grade hardware but also high-performance data center GPUs and CPUs. The first study focuses on parallelization methods within CUDA and DPC++ SYCL programs. This study also illustrates the benefits of transitioning from vendor-specific programming models to more universal standards like C++ SYCL. These parallelization techniques were implemented on diverse hardware platforms and comprehensively benchmarked to evaluate the impact of parallel programming on optimizing performance. The second study applies Shapley values in the field of XAI to deliver a crucial understanding of the decision-making processes of deep learning models trained on image datasets. This research highlights how connecting advanced hardware architectures with sophisticated algorithms can revolutionize heterogeneous computing to handle some of the most demanding tasks in modern AI and scientific research.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
AI, CUDA, Heterogeneous Computing, HPC, Parallelization, SYCL
Simon Y. Foo, Professor Directing Dissertation; Adrian Barbu, University Representative; Shonda Bernadin, Committee Member; Rodney Roberts, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Processing of Ambiguous Relative Clauses in Early Spanish-English Bilingualism
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Impacts of Language Mode and Individual Differences

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation studies the role of language activation on ambiguous relative clause attachment. Specifically, it explores attachment preferences of early Spanish-English bilinguals. Ambiguous relative clauses are syntactically ambiguous, as in (1):(1) Someone called [DP the [NP1 lawyer of [the [NP2 defendant]]]] that was by the elevator. The relative clause in (1) attaches to one of two possible constituents, NP1 or NP2. NP1 attachment is called high attachment because it is higher structurally; NP2 attachment is called low attachment. Languages exhibit distinct attachment preferences (Carreiras & Clifton, 1999, Cuetos & Mitchell, 1988, Grillo & Costa, 2014, Mitchell & Cuetos, 1991). Previous research on attachment focuses on unilingual contexts of language use. However, it is unclear how attachment preferences manifest when languages are proportionately active. Bilingual language activation fluctuates, and it is crucial to develop a comprehensive theoretical account of ambiguity processing to accurately understand bilingual sentence processing. As such, this project bridges this gap, examining relative clause attachment in three language modes (Grosjean, 1998): unilingual Spanish, unilingual English, and Spanish-English codeswitching, the use of multiple languages in the same dialogue. Codeswitching is practiced by several Spanish-English bilingual communities. Codeswithcing was operationalized by embedding ambiguous relative clauses into alternations, as in (2): (2) a. Someone called the lawyer of the defendant QUE ESTABA POR EL ASCENSOR. '...THAT WAS BY THE ELEVATOR." b. Alguien llamó al abogado del acusado THAT WAS BY THE ELEVATOR. xi 'Someone called the lawyer of the defendant...' Moreover, this dissertation examines effects of individual differences on attachment. This includes language dominance (Fernández, 2003), codeswitching use and exposure (Beatty- Martínez and Dussias, 2017), working memory (Kim & Christianson, 2012), and cognitive control(Adler et al., 2020). As such, this project is interdisciplinary, considering sociolinguistic and cognitive variables. This dissertation touches on multiple theoretical perspectives. First, sociolinguistic variables such as codeswitching use and exposure test whether language experience shapes processing, predicted by the Linguistic Tuning Hypothesis (Mitchell & Cuetos, 1991) and the Production-Distribution-Comprehension (PDC) model (Macdonald, 2013). Further, variation in working memory and cognitive control test relationships between processing and cognition described in the Sausage Machine Model (Frazier & Fodor, 1978) and the Adaptability Control Hypothesis (Green & Abutalebi, 2013). Finally, research on codeswitching effects predict distributional variation of linguistic structures between language modes on the grounds of convergence (Toribio, 2004), priming (Torres Cacoullos & Travis, 2011), simplification (De Prada Pérez et al, 2021), or a combination (De Prada Pérez, 2018). This dissertation assesses if language mode effects extend to comprehension. Two experiments were conducted. First, in a pilot experiment, 23 Spanish-English codeswitching bilinguals completed three forced choice tasks, one for each language mode. Participants listened to sentences containing ambiguous relative clauses and answered a question prompting attachment. Also, participants completed The Bilingual Language Profile (BLP) (Birdsong et al., 2012) and portions of the Assessment of Code-Switching Experience Survey (ACSES) (Blackburn, 2013) to observe differences in language dominance, self-rated proficiency, and codeswitching use and exposure. Results revealed significant differences in attachment preference between unilingual Spanish and other language modes, but not between unilingual English and codeswitching. Moreover, increased Spanish proficiency strengthened language mode effects. In the primary experiment, a separate group of 36 U.S Spanish-English codeswitching bilinguals completed three visual-world eyetracking tasks, one per language mode. Participants listened to ambiguous relative clauses and looked at images of attachment options. Participants then answered a question prompting attachment. Participants completed the BLP and ACSES for language dominance and codeswitching use and exposure, formal measures of proficiency (the MELICET (English Language Institute, 2001) and DELE (Ministry of Education, Culture, and Sport of Spain, 2006) tests), a running span task (Bunting et al., 2006) for working memory, and an AX continuous performance task (Beatty-Martínez et al., 2020) for cognitive control. Results revealed the same language mode effects as the pilot on eye fixations and attachment preferences, but with different effects of individual differences. Specifically, effects of codeswitching exposure on language mode effects weakened with decreased cognitive control. Findings suggest early Spanish-English bilinguals demonstrate distinct processing and resolution of ambiguous relative clauses between unilingual modes, but in bilingual mode, patterns converge with unilingual English and diverge from unilingual Spanish. Moreover, effects of code-switching exposure and cognitive control support the ideas that language experience influences processing and code-switching exposure interacts with cognitive control. Finally, results reveal language mode effects on processing and resolution of ambiguous relative clauses, but may be attributed convergence, priming, or simplification, and more research is needed to make further distinctions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Antje Muntendam, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Kaschak, University Representative; Gretchen Sunderman, Committee Member; Lara Reglero, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Determinants of State and Local Preemption Behavior

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation consists of three essays examining the role of state preemption on local government in the U.S. and Canada. The papers broadly examine why states choose to preempt local governments, and how local governments respond to their power being taken away. Paper one is an observational analysis of over 1,200 gubernatorial executive orders, examining what strategies governors used to preempt local governments during the COVID-19 pandemic. Paper two contains two survey experiments examining when and how U.S. local officials oppose and resist state preemption. Paper three contains a survey experiment examining whether Canadian municipal officials oppose intervention into their affairs at higher rates when it comes from an ideologically incongruent provincial government. Below I include a brief abstract of each. Chapter one, "Preemption in the Intergovernmental Trenches: Explaining Gubernatorial Preemption Style During the COVID-19 Pandemic," examines what institutional and political factors influenced governors' preemption style during the pandemic by analyzing a dataset of over 1,200 COVID-19 executive orders, classified by their style of preemption: ceiling, floor, or vacuum. Governors in states with high local autonomy, as well as Republican governors, rely on ceiling preemptions, which ban local governments from enacting any regulations stricter than their state. Governors in states with ideologically dissimilar local governments tend to issue vacuum preemptions, in which a state bans local governments from regulating a policy area, while also failing to set regulations of its own. When non-preempting provisions – which empower local governments – are dropped from the analysis, local autonomy does not significantly affect issuing one type of preemption over another. On the other hand, Republican governors are more likely to issue both ceiling and floor preemptions over vacuum preemptions. Governors in states with high ideological asymmetry are less likely to issue ceiling and floor preemptions over vacuum preemptions. Chapter two, "Concede or Resist Preemption? Experimental Evidence from U.S. Local Officials," examines whether partisanship and policy type affect local officials' opposition and resistance to state preemption. To do so, I conduct two original pre-post, between-subject survey experiments – one on environmental regulations and the other on traffic regulations – on over 1,000 local officials throughout the U.S. In both the environment and traffic experiments, I find that local officials are substantially more opposed to preemption from an out-party governor, while those in the in-party treatment are far more supportive of preemption. This paper incorporates a novel "pushback index," which asks local officials whether they are willing to fight state preemption through legal action, defiance, local legislation, and advocacy efforts. Here, in the environment experiment, local officials were more willing to resist preemption from an out-party and less willing to resist preemption from an in-party. A sentiment analysis of respondents' open-ended experiences with preemption corroborates the experimental results. Chapter three, "Are Municipal Politics Ideological? Experimental Evidence from Canadian Municipal Officials," examines whether ideology shapes Canadian municipal politics even in a non-partisan and ostensibly non-ideological context. Scholars continue to debate whether municipal politics are characterized by ideological battles, yielding mixed results. To test this argument further, I conducted a survey experiment on a representative sample of over 700 municipal officials through the Canadian Municipal Barometer. Based on their self-reported ideology on a ten-point scale, respondents were assigned to one of three groups: an ideologically congruent province, an ideologically incongruent province, and a control group in which the ideology of the provincial government is omitted. Respondents then read a hypothetical prompt explaining that a newly elected provincial government plans to pass a series of environmental laws prohibiting municipalities from passing their own. I find that municipal officials facing intervention from an ideologically incongruent province are more opposed to intervention, while those facing intervention from an ideologically congruent province were more supportive of intervention. Moreover, municipal officials were more likely to support being consulted – or being required to give their consent – when facing policy intervention from an ideologically incongruent province.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Amanda Driscoll, Professor Directing Dissertation; Frances Berry, University Representative; Lonna R. Atkeson, Committee Member; Hans Hassell, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Relationship between Social Networking Sites Behavior and Use and Psychological Well-Being among Emerging Adults

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study is to examine the association between social networking sites behavior and use and psychological well-being problems among emerging adults. Under the theoretical framework of the need to belong theory (Baumeister and Leary, 1995), I proposed a conceptual model of behaviors and the use of four mainstream social network sites (SNSs, e.g., Facebook, Snapchat, Instagram, and X) and problems in psychological well-being among emerging adults. Specifically, I hypothesized that 1) passive behaviors on SNS will relate to psychological well-being problems (depression, anxiety, and stress); whereas active behaviors will relate to lower psychological well-being problems among emerging adults (H1), and 2) compared with the other platforms (Facebook, Instagram, and Snapchat), the length of time using X (Twitter) will be related to more problems in well-being among emerging adults (H2). Using a sample of 144 emerging adults, I conducted multiple linear regression analyses to test the hypothesized models. Results did not support my hypotheses. The non-significant findings could have several implications. This study calls for future research to continue explore the role of SNSs in emerging adults' psychological well-being.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Ming Cui, Professor Directing Thesis; Melinda Gonzales-Backen, Committee Member; Myriam Rudaz, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cantos De Mi Tierra
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Sonic Exploration of La Paz, Bolivia

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The multiethnic and sonically diverse city of La Paz, Bolivia, is home to unique festivities such as Entrada Gran Poder [a dancing parade] or Alasitas [miniature festival] that draw thousands of people from across the city to La Paz's city center. The musical interactions at these celebrations contribute to social and artistic forms and provide a space for rural musicians to contribute to the city's musical life, allowing the musical heritage of Bolivia's rural towns to become a part of the city's identity. Because the city center is also the headquarters for the Bolivian government and multinational businesses, people from across the city visit this area, contributing to a unique conglomeration of sounds. Many performance venues and academic and professional musical institutions are also in this location, such as the Teatro Municipal, Conservatorio, and the Escuela de Folklore. Although urban sounds are like other metropolitan cities, this mix of cultures makes this location's distinctive soundscape. As a case study, I take sound as a point of departure to explore how the city center of La Paz, Bolivia, has been sonically experienced, remembered, and recreated by Paceños [residents of La Paz]. Based on ethnographic, musicological, and sound studies research conducted since 2017, I explore the tensions in urban sounds, the global spread of music and possible effects on local cultures, and the value of sonic communities in developing identity. I also engage in broader conversations about how place affects how people listen and relate to the world, through themes such as the role of women in Paceño society and immigration, and the possible ways in which soundscapes can inform government officials.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Area of Musicology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Dance, Decolonization, Indigeneity, Popular Music, Sound studies
Sarah Eyerly, Professor Directing Dissertation; Antje Muntendam, University Representative; Jane Clendinning, Committee Member; Frank Gunderson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Tasks Offloading for Time-Sensitive Workloads in Fog-Cloud IoT-Based Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Throughout recent years, the Internet of Things (IoT) has grown rapidly. A concept called Fog Computing (FC) has been developed in response to IoT demands for the processing of massive volumes of data and the availability of substantial computational resources. In order to eliminate network latency, FC attempts to bring the computation resources closer to the IoT devices. An essential part of FC is an offloading mechanism, which can be utilized to make the most efficient use of FC nodes, especially when dealing with applications that require high throughput and low latency. In general, offloading policies can be classified as centralized or decentralized. Because of the growing number of IoT devices, which results in the expansion of the FC layer beyond the initial configurations, centralized scheduling solutions for time-sensitive tasks face two significant challenges: first, increasing complexity, and second, non-fault tolerating. To address these issues, scalable decentralized/distributed approaches have been developed to schedule tasks through the autonomous collaboration of a small number of nodes (neighbors). However, designing algorithms that make optimal decisions is difficult without a thorough understanding of the network or nodes' state. This paper presents a scalable algorithm for offloading time-sensitive tasks through a semi-network aware distributed scheduling mechanism. Based on the evaluation results obtained for acceptance rate, response time, and network resource usage, the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art on average.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Daniel G. Schwartz, Professor Directing Dissertation; Fang Peng, University Representative; Mike Burmester, Committee Member; Michael Mascagni, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding Barriers to Full Civic Participation by the LGBTQ+ Community
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Queer Reading of Inclusive City Politics

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
Department of Urban and Regional Planning

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this research I examine LGBTQ+ inclusion in formal decision making processes through Advisory Boards across Global North and South, and research the motives and operations of these processes through the utilization of a queer lens. I focus on Global North and South because this comparison provides me the opportunity of analysis of a similar process in two starkly different contexts; Atlanta being shaped as an entrepreneurial, neo-liberally restructured city valuing diversity and inclusion vs Istanbul as a city being shaped under the Islamic neoliberal agenda far from the LGBTQ+ inclusion. I apply semi-structured in depth interviews with board members, city officials including city planners, and the local LGBTQ+ community on issues about civic engagement, involvement in the city politics and decisions, urban services, LGBTQ+ inclusion, representative power of the board, queer spaces as well as researching secondary data resources such as related news reports, local LGBTQ+ magazines and blogs.I argue that since LGBTQ+ individuals in the Global South still fight in a more challenging environment, they have that queer side that challenges the existing concepts and structures (Jagose, 1996) through resistance and insurgency (Holston, 1998; Miraftab, 2009). Although they are 'included' in participatory processes, they still need to come up with creative strategies such as informal negotiations, creating and collecting their own data, finding alternative ways of gathering as well as the use of courts and legal. As we see in the case of LGBTI+ Working group in Istanbul, Turkey, they utilize both invited spaces that are sanctioned by the formal, governmental authorities (Miraftab, 2009, 2012) and invented spaces as arenas of contestation against the organization structures whenever one is required or advantageous. From a comparative perspective, I assert that such insurgent strategies emerging from Global South, have critical value for the Global North, for instance Atlanta Advisory Board, to learn from because Atlanta may be prioritizing the interests of private investors, businesses, and the "creative class" over the needs and rights of marginalized social groups inclusive and representative of these diverse communities using diversity as a tool to enhance their image rather than promoting social inclusion. Therefore what Istanbul case tells Atlanta is that the board should 1) be able to move across and between different spaces of participation being tightly connected to bottom-up, grassroots activism on the ground so 'selective participation process' is eliminated and no one is left behind, 2) transcend acting according to the expectations of the staff at the key positions and formal structures that try to straighten LGBTQ individuals out. I argue that as queers we need to sustain our existing radical solidarity strategies while also penetrating the mechanisms of formal decision making without falling to the co-optation trap of the so called inclusive and collaborative processes. On the other hand, what Atlanta tells Istanbul case is that when resources and support are available inclusive spaces can be created in the built environment. Therefore, utilization of governmental structures is also valuable as much as insurgent acts.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Urban and Regional Planning in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
advisory boards, inclusive planning, insurgent citizenship, LGBTQ, LGBTQ+ planning, queer spaces
Petra L. Doan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Will Hanley, University Representative; William Butler, Committee Member; Ralph Brower, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Anti-Inflammatory Effect of H2S on Atherosclerosis and Erectile Function

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve and maintain an erectile penis capable of adequate sexual intercourse; it affects more than half of men over the age of 45. Atherosclerosis, a cardiovascular disease that involves the build-up of fat, cholesterol, inflammatory materials, and other debris in the blood vessels, is one of the major causes of erectile dysfunction, as it affects the blood flow to the penis. Hydrogen sulfide is a vasodilator with the ability to improve blood flow. PURPOSE: In the current study, we investigated the potential protective effect of hydrogen sulfide against atherosclerosis and erectile dysfunction. METHODS: Male ApoE knockout mice were randomly divided into three groups: ApoE Knockout mice (ApoE-/-) fed a standard diet, ApoE knockout mice fed an atherogenic diet, and ApoE-/- fed an atherogenic diet with SG1002, a Hydrogen sulfide releasing a prodrug. A fourth group of ApoE and Cystathionine  lyase (CSE) double knockout mice (ApoE-/-/CSE-/-) fed an atherogenic diet was added. All the mice were fed a standard diet with water ad libitum until eight weeks, when groups 2 and 4 were switched to an atherogenic diet, and group 3 was switched to an atherogenic diet with SG1002 for eight weeks. All the mice were sacrificed, and experiments were done subsequently. Vascular functional studies were assessed using wire myography experiments, and the cytokines in both the Serum and CC were measured using Luminex cytokine assays and western blot. RESULTS: There was an increased contraction and reduced endothelium-dependent, endothelium-independent, and NANC-mediated relaxation in the internal pudendal artery (IPA) and corpus cavernosum (CC) of ApoE-/-/CSE-/- mice. Treatment with SG1002 enhanced parasympathetic effects and reduced sympathetic effects in ApoE-/- mice fed an atherogenic diet. Additionally, CSE deletion led to elevated levels of p-ERK, ASC/TMS1, and cleaved GSDMD, which are responsible for inflammation in the CC. CONCLUSION: CSE deficiency led to endothelial dysfunction, while CSE protected against inflammation following atherosclerotic stimuli via the ERK/NLRP3/GSDMD pathway.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Atherosclerosis, Corpus Cavernosum, Erectile Dysfunction, Hydrogen sulfide, Internal Pudendal Artery, SG1002
Justin La Favor, Professor Directing Dissertation; Zhibin Yu, University Representative; Gloria Salazar, Committee Member; Michelle Parvatiyar, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sparse Methods for Latent Class Analysis, Principal Component Analysis and Regression with Missing Data

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Latent Class Analysis (LCA) are multivariate methods commonly used as exploratory data analysis tools in an unsupervised setting. Two difficulties often encountered in applying these methods are high-dimensionality and missingness in data. Here we propose and test approaches to missingness and feature selection for PCA, and feature selection for LCA. Comparisons with current methods are made on simulated and real data.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Adrian Barbu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Anke Meyer-Baese, University Representative; Yiyuan She, Committee Member; Jinfeng Zhang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Fitness Consequences of Density, Spatial Arrangement, and Relatedness of Neighbors in a Dispersal Limited Invertebrate

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In plants and sessile animals, the density, spatial arrangement, and genetic relatedness of conspecific neighbors differentially affect multiple components of fitness. However, the directions and magnitude of these effects are unclear due to differences between systems in the types of resources, the ways resources are acquired, how neighbors affect the local environment, and the mechanisms by which gametes are exchanged. In sessile marine invertebrates, much of the biodiversity contains species with relatively short (i.e., minutes to hours) larval durations and dispersal on relatively small spatial scales (i.e., meters). Limited dispersal in sessile animals potentially increase the chance that neighbors are kin, and decreases the chance of escaping conspecific competition. Using an experimentally tractable species (the bryozoan Bugula neritina), I performed a series of manipulative field experiments in which I tested the hypothesis that the density and relatedness of neighbors affects individual survival and growth across multiple time points, that relatedness of neighbors affects survival, growth, and reproductive output, and that the distance the nearest neighbor affects female reproductive output, paternity within broods, and competition among males. I found that: 1) increased density reduced survival but not growth rate, 2) there was no effect of relatedness on any component of fitness, in contrast to previous studies, 3) colonies produced more settlers without neighbors, and distance to the nearest neighbor did not affect the number of settlers produced or the degree of paternity. Only 12 out of 615 offspring were sired by colonies in the experiment, suggesting that sperm dispersal is greater than previously thought. In all cases where offspring were assigned to a candidate father, the paternal colony was always the closest colony. These results suggest that settling next to kin through limited planktonic dispersal may have limited consequences for individual fitness, and highlight the importance of not generalizing relationships between density, spatial arrangement, relatedness of nearest neighbors between taxa in different environments and mating systems or even within species.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Scott C. Burgess, Professor Directing Thesis; Don Levitan, Committee Member; Alice Winn, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: "I'm 100% That Bitch" the Feminism and Feminist Rhetorical Strategies of Lizzo

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In my dissertation, I take up Cheryl Glenn's call to feminist scholars in rhetoric to "widen who and what can be defined as rhetorical" (2018, p. 210). Glenn pushes us to study not only the often-overlooked rhetorical contributions of women outside of the oral and written rhetorical traditions but also overlooked genres. Feminist rhetoricians have begun studying feminist musicians like Lauryn Hill (McGee, 2019) and Beyoncé (McGee, 2024; Fain, 2021), and I want to add to this new area of inquiry by analyzing how another feminist artist, Lizzo, performs her feminism within her feminist anthems—the songs themselves and their music videos. Tita Baumlin (1998); Rich Lane (1997); Patricia Sullivan (1998) studied the implications of using music videos in the composition classroom in the 1990s; other than that, music videos remain largely understudied in rhetoric and composition. My work broadens our understanding of music and music videos as rhetorical texts. I argue that, through her music videos, Lizzo seeks to enhance agency for her listeners, practice activism, and change the social order by expressing critical subjectivity, resisting and critiquing patriarchal gender norms, subverting sexual norms, and enacting feminist circulation. I write about the ways in which Lizzo's identity as a Black, self-proclaimed fat woman affects the feminist rhetorical strategies she takes up in her music videos, focusing on: "Truth Hurts" (2017), "Fitness" (2018), and "Rumors" (2021). I argue that through the employment of linguistic and visual modes of communication that evoke feminist rhetorical strategies—including but not limited to pathos, material experience as evidence, and queer ethos—Lizzo's feminist anthems work to challenge pernicious narratives often inscribed on Black women's personalities and bodies, like the angry Black woman, the Jezebel, and Hottentot Venus. My dissertation expands what we identify as sites for potential feminist rhetorical inquiry, and it illuminates how the contemporary feminist icon Lizzo defines her feminism and employs feminist rhetorical strategies in her songs and music videos.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
activism, feminism, feminist anthems, feminist rhetorics, Lizzo, music videos
Michael Neal, Professor Directing Dissertation; Alysia Roehrig, University Representative; Ronisha Browdy, Committee Member; Leigh Edwards, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Synthetic Controland Optical Characterization of Low Dimensional Organic Metal Halide Hybrids

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Ionically bonded materials, namely, perovskites and perovskite-related materials established of organic cations and metal halide anions hold great promise for the next generation functional materials. For instance, beyond the traditional three-dimensional (3D) perovskite, low dimensional organic metal halide hybrids with two-dimensional (2D), one-dimensional (1D), and zero-dimensional (0D) structures at the molecular level are acquired. These hybrid materials benefit from the large range of available organic cations and metal halide building blocks offering them exceptional compositional and structural flexibility. Hence, low dimensional organic metal halide hybrids surpass the 3D perovskites in terms of stability, photoluminescence quantum efficiency and tunable optical properties. In most cases, these structures display the intrinsic properties of the inorganic framework due to quantum and dielectric confinement of excitons. Recently, more efforts are devoted to exploring and investigating approaches to control and tune the properties of this class of material through organic cation control. It is found that the geometry, steric characteristics, charge, and charge bearing groups of the organic cations play a critical role in molding the structure and functionality of the inorganic framework. In this dissertation, solid state synthesis of 0D highly luminescent metal halide hybrids with bulk organic cations is established. Afterwards, organic cations with singular geometries and functionalities are explored in layered 2D structures and revealed a structure-property relationship. Finally, a novel distinctive 1D structure templated by chiral organic cations is reported. In chapter 2 of this dissertation, mechanochemical synthesis is employed to prepare ionically bonded organic metal halide hybrids with a zero-dimensional (0D) structure. (Ph4P)2SbCl5 and (Ph4P)2MnCl4 were synthesized by milling appropriate ratios of bulk organic halide salt Ph4PCl with inorganic metal halide salts SbCl3 and MnCl2, respectively. The structural and photophysical properties of synthesized 0D structures are almost identical to those of single crystals prepared by slow solution growth. A blend of organic metal halide hybrid with dual emission is reported. In addition to the synthetic control of this class of materials, in chapters 3 and 4, the structure-property relationship is investigated in 2D layered perovskites. First, the impact of organic cations is explored in a model system featuring phenethyl ammonium PEA+ and its derivates MeOPEA+ with an electron-donating group and FPEA+ containing an electron withdrawing group in para-substitution. Single crystals of 2D layered perovskites are reported along with their photophysical and structural characterization. Although, (PEA)2PbBr4, (MeOPEA)2PbBr4, and (FPEA)2PbBr4 have almost identical crystal structures with similar room temperature blue emissions. Their emissions at low temperature are distinct with the presence of self-trapped broadband redshifted emissions. It is found that the organic spacers influence the distortions within the inorganic layers which impact the broadband emissions at low temperature. In chapter 4, we proceed with the efforts to manipulate the structural distortions through organic cation alteration. Chiral organic cations R-FMBA+ and S-FMBA+ along with FBA+, which is achiral due to the absence of methyl group at the α-carbon position, are used to prepare 2D layered perovskites. Interestingly, warm white photoluminescence is observed at room temperature in the chiral systems (R-FMBA)2PbBr4 and (S-FMBA)2PbBr4 contrarily to the achiral (FBA)2PbBr4 that exhibits deep blue photoluminescence. The tuning of the emissions at room temperature stems from the significant structural distortions in the chiral crystals. Furthermore, (R-FMBA)2PbBr4 and (S-FMBA)2PbBr4 inherit chirality from the organic cations and display chiroptical properties observed through the distinct opposite circular dichroism signals in the 275−400 nm range. The combination of interesting photophysical and chiroptical properties is promising for numerous applications. In chapter 5, the critical structural distortions generated from the introduction of chiral organic cations in low dimensional organic metal halide hybrids are explored to template unique structures that bridge between 2D and1D hybrids. Novel structures of (R-FMBA)5Pb2I9 and (S-FMBA)5Pb2I9 adopting nanoribbon 1D structure are reported for the first time. The Nanoribbons consist of 4 corner-sharing PbI6 octahedra isolated by the R-FMBA+ and S-FMBA+ cations. The synthesized crystals exhibit chiroptical activity demonstrated by circular dichroism response covering the range of 275 to 550 nm. Therefore, the incorporation of chirality, alongside the flexible structure of organic metal halide hybrids is considered as one of the pathways to create new unique structures that are useful for electronic and spintronic applications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
2D Perovskites, Chiral 2D perovskites, Molecular low-dimensional organic metal halide hybrids, photoluminescence, Synthesis
Biwu Ma, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric Hellstrom, University Representative; Michael Shatruk, Committee Member; Lea Nienhaus, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Socratic Wisdom in the Apology and Charmides

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Vlastos presents a paradox of Socratic ignorance: if Socrates disavows all knowledge, great and small, then how is he confident he has lived a moral life? I propose Socrates is wise not because of what secrets of the gods he knows, or even what things he does not know, but because he has second-order knowledge of what he knows and awareness that he does not know. I will examine the Apology for both the negative content of first-order Socratic knowledge—Socrates does not suppose what he does not know—as well as positive content of second-order knowledge—Socrates is aware of not being wise in things great or small. I will then examine the Charmides for another kind of positive content of second-order Socratic knowledge—Socrates knows what he himself does know. The question of what comprises Socratic wisdom is an extant problem in the literature. Reeve issued a challenge: if awareness of ignorance is the negative content of Socratic wisdom, what is the positive content? In Apology, what Reeve terms "negative content" of Socratic wisdom a conflation of both negative content of first-order knowledge—Socrates does not suppose he knows what he does not—and positive content of second-order knowledge—Socrates is aware he is not wise in things great or small. In Charmides, the virtue sophrosunê is second-order knowledge of what Socrates does know. This self-knowledge of what he knows is another answer to Reeve's search for "positive" content of Socratic wisdom. The intersection of "negative" and "positive" content is Socratic wisdom. This therefore solves for Vlastos's paradox of Socratic ignorance as well, because Socrates' second-order knowledge of his own knowledge and lack thereof is distinct from knowledge of the gods, either great or small. Therefore Socrates can disavow godly wisdom, while at the same time assured that he has lived a virtuous life, as he is the exemplar of virtuous self-knowledge (of what he knows and does not).
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Philosophy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Nathanael Stein, Professor Directing Dissertation; Svetoslava Slaveva-Griffin, University Representative; Mark Lebar, Committee Member; Jack Justus, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Para Mi Familia
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Role of Familism and Other Cultural Factors in the Academic Adjustment and Well-Being of First Generation Latinx College Students

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: As the Latinx population in the United States continues to increase, so does the enrollment of Latinx students in higher education. However, the growth in enrollment is not matched with graduation and retention rates due to a general lack of support from the institutions and barriers including experiences of discrimination and struggling with conflicting norms. Additional stressors are experienced by first-generation students (i.e., neither of their parents attended college) and students who experience financial strain. The intersection of financial strain and adhering to the value of familial obligation may also increase feelings of role overload as students try to balance their responsibilities, which may explain variability in mental health and academic outcomes among Latinx students. Moreover, cultural factors associated with ethnic-racial minority individuals such as the value of familism and the development of ethnic-racial identity (ERI) can serve to promote positive development or protect Latinx individuals from negative outcomes. The current study evaluated the association between financial strain and mental health (i.e., depressive symptoms, anxiety) and academic outcomes (i.e., motivation, achievement, expectations, aspirations), respectively, both directly and indirectly via role overload. Familial obligation and ERI were also included in the analysis as moderators of this association. Lastly, the associations between the respective components of familism and the proposed outcomes were analyzed. Analyses were conducted using various multigroup regression models with a sample of 200 Latinx undergraduate students (Mage = 20.36, 75.5% female) from higher education institutions across the United States. Results indicated that there are differences across first-generation student status regarding the association between financial strain and anxiety. Financial strain was a consistent predictor of role overload, and role overload significantly mediated the association between financial strain and depressive and anxiety symptoms. Academic outcomes remained largely unaffected by any of the predictor variables. Furthermore, the influence of the respective components of familism varied. Familial obligation and ERI were not significant moderators. The findings of the current study have implications for culturally informed practices and policies that would serve to support Latinx students and promote positive well-being and academic outcomes.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Academic Adjustment, Ethnic-Racial Identity, Familism, Financial Strain, Latinx College Students, Role Overload
Melinda Gonzales-Backen, Professor Directing Dissertation; Felecia Jordan Jackson, University Representative; Thomas Ledermann, Committee Member; Lenore McWey, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rational Approach to High Entropy Materials from First Row Transition Metal Prussian Blue Analogue (PBA) Single Source Precursors

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Chapter 1: Introduces the field of nanoscience including key concepts like important structure property – relationships, how nanomaterials are categorized, how nanomaterials are made, how nanoparticles are characterized, and what these nanomaterials can practically be used for. This chapter serves to provide foundational knowledge for the understanding of the remainder of this work. Chapter 2: This chapter pertains to the bimetallic iron – cobalt carbide (FexCo1-xCy) system. Specifically, this chapter serves to understand the effect of the iron and cobalt ratios on material properties (phase composition, size, and morphology), electrochemical performance of the FexCo1-xCy nanomaterials in the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and material transformations under OER conditions. Chapter 3: This chapter pertains to the bimetallic iron – nickel carbide (FexNi1-xCy) and trimetallic iron – nickel – chromium carbide systems. Particularly, this chapter aims to gain insight into the effect of tuning iron and nickel ratios on material properties, electrochemical performance of the FexNi1-xCy nanomaterials in the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and material transformations under OER and alkaline conditions. Furthermore, the addition of Cr to the bimetallic system is investigated for the enhancement of OER performance. Chapter 4: This chapter pertains to the bimetallic iron – cobalt carbide (FexCo1-xCy) system. As a follow up to the work completed in chapter 2, chapter 4 takes a closer look at synthetic control in the FexCo1-xCy system. Chapter 2 reveals a complex phase range that exists in these materials. In this chapter the effect of halide species, halide concentrations, and metal concentrations on FexCo1-xCy phase composition is investigated by coupling theoretical (density functional theory) and experimental data to gain insight on how phase and metal compositions can be leveraged to produce targeted materials. Chapter 5: This chapter expands the work from previous chapters by implementing Prussian Blue Analogues (PBAs) as single source precursors for the formation of nanocarbides from first row transition metals (Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) including monometallic (Ni3C), bimetallic (FeNi), trimetallic (FeCoNiC), tetrametallic (CrFeCoNiC), and pentametallic (CrMnFeCoNiC) systems. This chapter focuses primarily on comparing these materials to the pentametallic (high entropy) PBA – derived materials as they are of increasing interest for applications in catalysis. We take a closer look at how the distribution of first row transition metals, the morphology, size, lattice planes, and crystal structure evolve from the monometallic carbide to the pentametallic carbide. Additionally, the nanocarbides are tested for water splitting performance under alkaline conditions. Chapter 6: This chapter expands the work from chapter 5 by implementing Prussian Blue Analogues (PBAs) as single source precursors for the formation of nano MX-ides (oxides, sulfides, phosphides) from first row transition metals (Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) including monometallic, bimetallic, trimetallic, tetrametallic, and pentametallic systems.
