Preliminary pXRD and XRF data is reported showing the capability to expand this synthetic technique to other highly sought-after materials. This work serves to highlight the versatility of our synthetic approach as well as opportunities that exist to actualize PBA – derived nanomaterial synthesis. Chapter 7: This chapter summarizes the findings reported in this thesis and describes future opportunities for further understanding of how PBAs can be implemented as robust, rational, scalable, cost effective, and tunable single source precursor for the production of next generation high entropy materials.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Geoffrey Strouse, Professor Directing Dissertation; Bruce Locke, University Representative; Mykhailo Shatruk, Committee Member; Robert Lazenby, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cardiac Activity and Risk for Antisocial Behavior
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Intergenerational Transmission and Psychosocial Moderation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Among the most prominent risk factors for criminal behavior in children is parental criminal history. In addition to this familial risk factor, low resting heart rate (RHR) has been documented as a biological marker for criminal behavior. Research has shown RHR to be moderately heritable. Despite these risk factors being well established as individual predictors of criminal behavior, further research is needed to clarify RHR's role in the intergenerational transmission of crime. Additionally, it remains unclear to what extent intergenerational transmission of crime reflects genetically based biological characteristics as compared to environmental influences. The current study was undertaken to clarify the roles of RHR and socioeconomic status (SES) in the intergenerational transmission of crime in a large Swedish population-based sample (N ~ 265,000) of fathers and their sons. In addition to replicating the low RHR–antisocial behavior relationship and the intergenerational transmission of crime, the current study was the first to demonstrate an indirect role of sons' RHR on the relationship between fathers' RHR and sons' criminal behavior. There was no evidence of the aforementioned relationships as being stronger among sons from low SES backgrounds. The current work adds to growing support for the inclusion of RHR as a key indicator in a biomarker-based protocol for assessing risk for criminality. Incorporating neurobiological measures in future work will be paramount in our evolving understanding of criminal behavior, and will help to inform the development of novel risk assessment and prevention programs for crime-prone individuals.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Antisocial, Biological, Crime, Heart rate, Intergenerational, Psychosocial

Christopher J. Patrick, Professor Directing Dissertation; Joseph Schwartz, University Representative; Colleen Ganley, Committee Member; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Thomas Joiner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Plastic Morphology and Trophic Flexibility
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Understanding Environmental Drivers and Evolutionary Implications of Intraspecific Variation in Gorgonian Octocorals

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Sessile marine organisms often exhibit intraspecific variation in response to their environment as a result of genetic differences or phenotypic plasticity. Common visible intraspecific variation includes color, morphology, and trophic ecology. Some of the most colorful marine organisms are sessile, with bright coloration and an abundance of color polymorphisms. The asymbiotic octocoral Leptogorgia virgulata is one species with strong color polymorphisms, existing predominantly in yellow, orange, and magenta morphs. Coloration in L. virgulata is genetically determined and is hypothesized to be controlled by one gene with at least four alleles. We documented the distribution of color morphs at inshore and offshore sites in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico and found differential color distribution. All three color morphs inhabit inshore sites, although colonies in these populations are predominately magenta and yellow, while offshore populations consist nearly entirely magenta morphs. We documented differences in micromorphological traits between yellow and magenta color morphs, including an increase in polyp density and a decrease in sclerite width in yellow morphs. However, through a laboratory spawning experiment and genetic analyses, we verified that the color morphs at inshore and offshore sites show genetic similarity with no observed barriers to cross-fertilization. Using a transplant experiment, we determined that both magenta and yellow colonies respond plastically in relative growth rate when transplanted between inshore and offshore sites. Within each location, magenta and yellow morphs did not differ from one another in relative growth. However, there was a significant interaction between color morph and location, as magenta morphs decreased their relative growth significantly more than yellow morphs, regressing on average, when transplanted offshore. We hypothesize that the differential distribution in color morphs between environments may be due to fitness tradeoffs between morphology and compound composition linked with color morphs. We suspect that the nearly 20% increase in polyp density associated with the yellow morph requires increased energy demands, which may be costly under lower nutrient levels at offshore sites. Because inshore and offshore sites show considerable differences in environmental variation, we investigated whether populations of L. virgulata exhibit phenotypic plasticity genotype-by-environment interactions. Phenotypic plasticity is one mechanism by which organisms can quickly respond within a generation to changing or variable environmental conditions, which can especially be beneficial for sessile organisms. Most studies examining phenotypic plasticity in sessile cnidarians have focused on species that host obligate, photosynthetic algal symbionts, such as hard corals, octocorals, and anemones. Symbiotic octocoral species have been shown to vary across depth, where nearshore individuals often have higher branch and polyp densities. These plastic traits are often attributed to variation in light availability and hydrodynamics across depth. However, to understand the evolutionary drivers of plasticity in symbiotic organisms, it is important to consider the influences of both host and endosymbiont. Previous studies on phenotypic plasticity in octocorals have uncovered some general trends in morphological responses to changes in depth that are often attributed to changes in light availability. However, these studies examined plasticity in octocoral species that host endosymbiotic algae, yet many species of octocorals are asymbiotic. Asymbiotic species, therefore, may not respond in similar ways due to the lack of reliance on endosymbiont photosynthesis. We documented intraspecific variation in L. virgulata in response to inshore and offshore sites to investigate changes displayed by a cnidarian outside of the demands of photosynthetic symbionts. Because of the difference in color distribution and the associated morphological differences between magenta and yellow morphs, we investigated intraspecific variation between inshore and offshore sites using magenta morphs only. We found that L. virgulata, similar to symbiotic octocoral species, exhibits increased branching at inshore sites, indicating that variation in branching can occur in the absence of reliance on light availability for photosynthesis. In contrast, we did not find variation in polyp density. Using a reciprocal transplant of magenta morphs across three sites varying in their distance from shore, we uncovered phenotypic plasticity for both relative growth rate and branching. Additionally, we found significant genotype-by-environment interactions that varied based on both the origin and transplant destination of the L. virgulata genotypes. Our findings highlight the ways in which octocorals can respond plastically to the environment and the potential of drivers that influence the evolution of plasticity. Morphological variation in response to the environment can result in shifts in trophic ecology. Trophic strategy can vary both inter- and intraspecifically in response to changes in the morphology, behavior, or the environment. In several endosymbiotic scleractinians and octocorals, having larger polyps is often correlated with increased reliance on heterotrophic feeding across species; species with smaller polyps are more reliant on their autotrophic endosymbionts. However, little is known about whether this relationship between polyp morphology and trophic strategy exists intraspecifically in octocorals. We quantified variation in polyp tentacle length within the endosymbiotic octocoral genus Pseudoplexaura across depth on reefs in the U.S. Virgin Islands and found a significant positive relationship between depth and tentacle length. Using tissue samples from P. porosa and P. wagenaari, we compared trophic ecology in relation to variation in polyp size using a Bayesian analysis of stable carbon and nitrogen isotopes. We found that across tentacle lengths, P. wagenaari is principally heterotrophic. However, P. porosa exhibits trophic strategy variation associated with tentacle length, shifting from mainly autotrophy to mixotrophy with increased tentacle length. Our study documents species-specific trophic strategies linked with variation in morphology and trophic flexibility within the same environmental conditions, uncovering potential niche differentiation both within and between species in tropical octocorals.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Ecology, Evolution, Genotype-by-environment Interaction, Octocoral, Phenotypic Plasticity, Trophic Ecology

Don R. Levitan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Amy Baco-Taylor, University Representative; Brian D. Inouye, Committee Member; Sophie J. McCoy, Committee Member; Andrew Rassweiler, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Toward Novel Active Learning Algorithms for Computer Vision Applications

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Machine Learning, and in particular deep learning has become an extremely effective tool in tasks that require knowledge of an underlying data distribution and prediction of data from such distribution. ML/DL models have widespread uses in various interdisciplinary areas, from detecting objects in images, to intent understanding of texts, to more complicated tasks such as scene understanding and answering questions. However, as ML/DL models attempt to learn more complex tasks, they require more and more amount of data. While unlabeled data pertinent to a specific task is relatively easy to find, the cost of expertly annotating such data is very high. Active Learning is a tool that can be used by ML/DL models to restrict unlabeled annotations to only those samples that can help the model the most. Active Learning allows the model to query a small set of samples from a large unlabeled pool which in turn, reduces the cost of annotation greatly, while not hampering the performance of the model. While active learning has a rich literature on different query strategies, there still remains certain areas where research is lacking; more specifically, there are a lot of situations where the human annotator may not be able to give an exact label of a sample, but can provide with an indirect label (such as age range instead of the exact age of a person given their image). There are other scenarios where active learning may be of immense help, such as when the underlying data is multi-class, and is heavily imbalanced. Our aim in this document is to identify some such areas, primarily from a computer vision based perspective, and attempting to generate novel query sampling strategies that may aid such situations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Shayok Chakraborty, Professor Directing Thesis; Adrian Gheorghe Barbu, University Representative; Xiuwen Liu, Committee Member; Sonia Haiduc, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding of Observed Tropical Cyclone Wind Profiles from Effective Absolute Angular Momentum Perspective
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Case Studies

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Low and mid-latitude coastal communities face significant threats from the severe damage caused by tropical cyclones (TCs). Beyond the critical factor of TC track, the intensity and size of these storms play crucial roles in determining the severity of damage due to their substantial impacts on wind destruction, storm surges, and flooding. While TC track forecasting has seen substantial improvements over the past few decades, advancements in predicting TC intensity and size, which together form the radial profile of TC surface winds, remain limited. Enhanced understanding of TC intensity, size, and the radial profile of TC surface winds is essential for coastal communities to better prepare for potential maximum damage. Based on the effective absolute angular momentum model (eAAM, Sun et al., 2022), the radial profile of tropical cyclones' (TC) surface wind can be largely determined from their eAAM values. The effective absolute angular momentum combines the absolute angular momentum (AAM) and its loss due to surface drags as a radial invariant quantity of a given observed instance TC. This study uses the observation data of four TCs to demonstrate how the eAAM values determine the radial profile of TC surface winds. The four observed TCs are Hurricane Ian (2022), Hurricane Ida (2021), Hurricane Julia (2022), and Hurricane Fiona (2022). We estimate eAAM values of the four observed TCs from their radial profiles of surface winds by varying the parameters for the loss AAM rate such that the resultant eAAM values satisfies the radial invariant condition closely. It is found that as long as radial invariant condition of eAAM is satisfied, the eAAM model can reproduce the observed radial profiles of TC surface winds from the radius of maximum wind outward to the radius of a few meters in all four cases. Different TCs would have different values of eAAM because of differences in their AAM loss rate, which is modeled as different combinations of model parameters in the eAAM model. The case study also demonstrates that different TCs can have the same AAM loss rate, but different eAAM values. Under the same AAM loss rate, a larger TC (such as Hurricane Ian) has a larger value of eAAM whereas a smaller TC (such as Hurricane Ida) has a smaller value of eAAM. Again, the difference in their radial profiles can be explained by the difference in their eAAM values. It remains an open question how different combinations of model parameters are related to the environmental conditions which impact TCs' eAAM values and thereby their radial wind profiles.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Ming Cai, Professor Directing Thesis; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member; Michael Diamond, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Valorization of Pelagic Sargassum Spp. to Study the Effect of Non-Thermal Processing on Extraction and Characteristics of Alginate

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Introduction: Pelagic Sargassum blooms have emerged as a global environmental concern, necessitating innovative approaches for their sustainable management. This thesis delves into the valorization of pelagic Sargassum by investigating the impact of non-thermal processing techniques on the extraction and characterization of alginate, a valuable biopolymer. The methodology encompasses acid and alkali treatments, varied heat applications, and a final step of ethanol precipitation. Characterization techniques such as FTIR, NMR, and rheometer analyses were employed to evaluate the properties of the extracted alginate. Methodology: This work seeks to optimize the extraction process (temperature 40 – 80 °C, alkali concentration 0.1 – 0.3 M, time of heat treatment 1 – 5 hours) using a Response Surface Methodology- Box-Behnken Design (RSM-BBD) to obtain higher product yield and combined it with bleaching with sodium hypochlorite, multistage extraction, and dialysis to obtain a more attractive and high-purity product, as well as giving insights into physicochemical properties of the extracted alginate from pelagic Sargassum biomass. Results: The optimization process revealed that the highest extraction yield of sodium alginate from pelagic Sargassum was achieved under specific conditions: a temperature of 80 °C, an alkali concentration of 0.3 M, and a heat treatment duration of 5 hours, resulting in an impressive 44% w/w crude yield. A second-order polynomial equation was developed, predicting the yield with a deviation of 2.4% from the experimental value. Furthermore, the bleaching process using sodium hypochlorite resulted in significant improvements in the characteristics of the extracted alginate by exhibiting a 49% increase in whiteness index compared to the control sample. Additionally, there was an 80% decrease in fluorescence intensity, indicating an enhancement in the purity of the alginate product. The effects of high-pressure processing (HPP) and sonication treatments on purified seaweed-extracted alginate were compared. The purified yield of alginate was not significantly affected by either treatment. However, the M/G ratio and viscosity showed considerable differences. HPP treatment decreased the M/G ratio at higher pressures, while sonication treatment increased the M/G ratio with longer treatment times. FTIR analysis showed decreased COO- peak intensity in both treatments, but sonication-treated samples had a higher carboxyl group content. HPP treatment resulted in a decrease in viscosity with an increase in pressure, while sonication treatment increased viscosity with longer treatment times. Conclusion: This research is paramount in addressing the environmental challenges of pelagic Sargassum blooms. By employing non-thermal processing techniques, the study demonstrates enhanced alginate extraction efficiency from pelagic Sargassum, presenting a sustainable solution for its valorization. In light of the results obtained, it can be concluded that both high-pressure processing (HPP) and sonication treatments exhibit unique impacts on the properties of alginate extracted from seaweed. The treatment selection, however, depends on the specific requirements of the intended application. If a higher Mannuronic (M) to Guluronic (G) ratio and increased viscosity are desired, sonication treatment for 30 minutes is likely to be more advantageous. Conversely, if a lower M/G ratio and a more Newtonian behavior are preferred, HPP treatment at 600 Mpa would be more conducive.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Qinchun Rao, Professor Directing Thesis; Prashant Singh, Committee Member; Leqi Cui, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Developing an Accessible and Adaptable Drum Set Curriculum for Classical Percussion Professors

mods:mods.mods:abstract: For many professors of classical percussion, drum set instruction is considered a crucial component of a thorough curriculum, as it generally presents percussion students the most frequent opportunities for employment and involves the honing of skills that benefit all facets of percussion performance. However, for percussion students at many universities, whose private lessons and performance activity are primarily focused on orchestral percussion performance, practical and thorough drum set instruction is not provided. This is typically due to limited drum set experience of the instructor(s); insufficient funding for instruments, facilities, or additional faculty members to provide drum set instruction; or a lack of time to address drum set instruction due to the variety of standard classical percussion instruments that must be taught. In this treatise, input from current university percussion professors, collected via a survey and interviews, has been synthesized to determine learning objectives for classical percussionists studying drum set. An accessible and adaptable drum set curriculum for classical percussion students has been proposed, along with suggested augmentations to assist with providing instruction of drum set concepts within existing classical percussion curricula. These contributions aim to illustrate the most necessary areas of drum set instruction so that classical percussionists can increase their employability, overall musicianship, and involvement in their percussion studio and university music department.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
accessible, adaptable, classical, curriculum, drum set, percussion
John W. Parks, IV, Professor Directing Treatise; Evan A. Jones, University Representative; Karen M. Large, Committee Member; Christopher R. Moore, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Childhood Maltreatment and Adult Romantic Relationship Outcomes
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Social Support and Resilience as Protective Factors

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Childhood maltreatment is a pervasive and common occurrence within the United States, with an estimated 1/7 children experiencing child abuse or neglect per year (CDC, 2022) and 60% of adults reporting at least one traumatic event related to abuse or family dysfunction (CDC, 2010). A link between childhood maltreatment and negative mental health outcomes (e.g., depression, anxiety, PTSD, substance abuse) and physical health concerns (e.g., diabetes, heart disease, obesity) have been well established in the literature (Lang et al., 2020; Teicher et al., 2016). However, the pervasive impact of childhood maltreatment also expands to romantic relationship difficulties (Labella et al., 2018). While the connection between childhood maltreatment and poorer adult romantic relationship outcomes is well established in the literature (e.g., Cao et al., 2020; Friesen et al., 2010; Testa et al., 2005), identification of protective factors, such as social support and resilience, remains understudied. Protective factors are important to identify because not everyone with childhood maltreatment histories develop poorer romantic relationships in adulthood (Leonard & Follette, 2002). Since social support (Gao et al., 2021b; Folger & Wright, 2013) and resilience (Campbell-Sills et al., 2006; Edwards et al., 2014; Wingo et al., 2010) have been identified as general protective factors against childhood maltreatment, these were chosen to be examined within the context of childhood maltreatment and later adult romantic relationship outcomes. Literature examining social support's (Godbout et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2006; Nguyen et al., 2017) and resiliency's (Kimmes et al., 2018; Rellini et al., 2012) protective abilities for childhood maltreatment and adult romantic relationship outcomes is scarce. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to directly examine if social support and resilience had a moderation (i.e., protective) effect on the relationship between childhood maltreatment and adult romantic relationships. A secondary goal was to examine if these relationships differed by sex (i.e., male or female) as this was a major limitation within the cited literature (e.g., Campbell-Sills et al., 2006; Edwards et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2006). A sample of 203 adult participants"(ages 18 to 25 years old) were recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk (Mturk). A correlational cross-sectional design was employed to investigate the following research questions: 1) Does current social support protect against childhood maltreatment's impact on adult romantic relationships outcomes while controlling for age, mental health, partner support, sex, and revictimization?, 2) Does current social support's protective ability differ depending on the source of support (i.e., family members vs friends) while controlling for age, mental health, partner support, sex, and revictimization?, 3) Does current social support protect against the negative impact of childhood maltreatment on adult romantic relationships outcomes to the same degree for men and women while controlling for age, mental health, partner support, and revictimization?, 4) Will current resiliency be protective against childhood maltreatment's impact on adult romantic relationships while controlling for age, mental health, partner support, sex, and revictimization?, and 5) Does current resiliency protect against the negative impact of childhood maltreatment on adult romantic relationships outcomes to the same degree for men and women while controlling for age, mental health, partner support, and revictimization? Measures included the Comprehensive Childhood Maltreatment Scale (CCMS; Higgins & McCabe, 2001), The Adult Attachment Questionnaire (AAQ: Simpson et al., 1996), Short Form Health Survey—Emotional Wellbeing Subscale (SF-36; Ware & Sherbourne, 1992), Dyadic Adjustment Scale (DAS; Spanier, 1976), Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS; Zimet et al., 1988), Adult Resilience Measure-Revised (ARM-R; Jefferies et al., 2019), Revictimization Questionnaire, and a demographics questionnaire. Control variables within the analyses included age, sex, partner support, adult revictimization, and mental health. Data were analyzed using hierarchical linear regression modeling. Results from the analyses revealed that childhood maltreatment was a significant predictor of poorer adult romantic relationship outcomes. Total social support and friend social support were moderators within the total sample. When these relationships were examined by sex, no moderation effect was observed. Resilience was a protective factor within the total sample. When this was examined by sex, resilience was a protective factor only for women. Implications for theory, clinical practice, and future research are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Childhood Maltreatment, Resilience, Romantic Relationship Outcomes, Social Support
Lyndsay Jenkins, Professor Directing Dissertation; Melissa Radey, University Representative; Debra Osborn, Committee Member; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Gustatory and Intraoral Thermosensory Signaling in the Insular Cortex of the Mouse

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The experience of eating food and beverages generates sensations within the mouth that are inherently multimodal. These sensations involve the integration of intraoral gustatory, olfactory (retronasal), and somatosensory cues, which all contribute to the percept of flavor. The following studies detailed in this dissertation aim to better understand how neurons in the rodent's brain integrate information from two of these oral signals: taste and oral temperature. Over the years, researchers have investigated both the behavioral and physiological components of taste, which originate when nonvolatile chemicals dissolved in saliva stimulate specialized chemoreceptors within the mouth. The sense of taste allows us to nourish our bodies by identifying nutrients and calorie-rich foods and discerning foods that may be potentially harmful or toxic. Information about nonvolatile chemicals dissolved in saliva is transduced into electrical signals by specialized receptors on the tongue. The gustatory information is then transmitted to multiple central and interconnected brain regions, including the gustatory portion of the insular cortex (gustatory cortex; GC), the primary cortical region responsible for processing taste information. GC neurons have been extensively studied and are known to represent the five basic taste qualities – sweet, salty, sour, bitter and umami - through changes in their spiking activity. These responses reflect the ongoing processing and integration of diverse gustatory information. For example, GC neurons respond to the chemosensory qualities of gustatory stimuli while also accounting for sensory signals that anticipate the availability of food and behavioral states. The vast majority of previous studies on cortical taste processing in behaving animals have been performed using rats as animal models, and intraoral cannulae (IOCs) as a method for fluid taste delivery. In contrast, relatively less work has been done in mice, an animal model that offers easier access to genetic tools for manipulating and visualizing neuronal activity. Additionally, although IOCs provide a reliable and rapid method of delivering taste solutions, they add a degree of passivity to taste delivery and could potentially alter the sequence of events associated with neural processing of gustatory information. In Chapter 2, I present data pertaining to cortical taste processing in behaving mice that sense liquid gustatory stimuli by licking, a stereotyped behavior by which fluids are actively introduced in the mouth. The result of this study, published in The Journal of Neurophysiology, provided the first description of how the GC of active licking mice encodes information about taste qualities and ongoing sampling (licking) behavior, expanding our knowledge of cortical taste processing. Most of what is known about the neural substrates of taste originates from studies - including my first one - in which stimuli are experienced at a single temperature. Although this approach has shaped our understanding of the role of gustation, it provides only a partial picture of the functional features of the gustatory system. In our natural environment, foods and beverages are rarely experienced at a single temperature. From our common daily experience, we know that temperature can serve as an important signal that can influence the sensory attributes of food and the perceived intensity of taste qualities relevant to food and beverage preferences, influencing eating habits. In the second part of my dissertation, I first focused on understanding how neurons in the GC of active licking mice represent oral thermosensory input in the absence of taste information. The results of this study, published in Chemical Senses, highlight that GC neurons are capable of representing different non-nociceptive fluid temperature in absence of a taste signal, further expanding on their multimodal nature. In Chapter 4, we begin to explore the interaction between taste and temperature within the mouse GC. Our aim is to elucidate how GC neurons process intraoral thermal cues and how this information might modulate taste quality or intensity coding. Preliminary findings indicate that GC neurons possess the capacity to integrate intraoral thermal and taste information, distinctly coding taste qualities at different temperatures and modulating taste intensity representation. Collectively, these observations highlight the potential role of the GC as a cortical nexus for integrating intraoral taste and thermal inputs.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Active licking, Cortex, Extracellular recording, Flavor, Gustation, Thermal
Roberto Vincis, Professor Directing Dissertation; Pamela Keel, University Representative; Alan Spector, Committee Member; Douglas Storace, Committee Member; Emily Lemmon, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Essays on the Relationship between Policy and Management of Public Financial Resources to Achieve Normative Goals

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Since the advent of New Public Management paradigms, scholars and practitioners have long been interested in how governance and political institutions efficiently and effectively manage public financial resources. However, recent movements have stressed the importance in understanding how public finance can aid in the execution and achievement in more "normative" policy priorities which go beyond standard economic theories of efficiency. This dissertation seeks to expand upon these nascent literatures by exploring the relationship between public policy and financial resource management in three different policy environments and normative outcomes. Through three studies which range in their theoretical application and methodological design, these essays contribute to numerous literatures on effective governance of public financial resources by (i) exploring different types of government levels' responses to financial resources within various political systems, (ii) analyzing various policy outcomes financial resources are tied to which vary in ambiguity and complexity, (iii) documenting the importance in viewing financial resource administration as both a management and policy purpose, (iv) identifying the importance in policy design of financial resource systems, and (v) exploring solutions to the oft-dilemma of constrained public institutions in working with constrained financial resources.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Public administration, Public budgeting and finance, Public management, Public policy
Daniel Fay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric Coleman, University Representative; Frances Berry, Committee Member; Danielle Atkins, Committee Member; Elizabeth Bell, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Traversing American Souths
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Movement of Marginalized Peoples across Geographies and Digital Spaces

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Literature, art, film, and media frequently depict the southern region of the United States as a singular cultural entity. Thus, those in the American and global populace neglect the diversity of cultural, historical, and enriching narratives stemming from the area's peoples. As such, approaching "the South" as a collection of smaller communities and cultures highlights the plurality of American souths. This dissertation accomplishes this by attending to the southern figures often omitted or misrepresented from mainstream representation of souths—Black and African American women able to pass as white, hillbillies and mountain southerners, and individuals deemed queer by themselves and/or society. Advancing New Southern Studies' endeavor to explore diversity and reflection of American souths and southern lives benefits from utilizing an interdisciplinary methodology. Furthermore, this project investigates the multiplicity of identities, experiences, and societies of southerners by analyzing mediums like fictional novels, video games, and social media videos from TikTok. Revolving around the theme of movement, I uncover the effects of moving bodies, perceptions and ideologies, and community formation across physical geographies, time, and digital space in Brit Bennett's The Vanishing Half, Bethesda's Fallout 3's Downloadable Content Point Lookout, and TikTok creators Andi Marie Tilman and Danae Hays. This project aims to restore agency and voices to those forgotten and silenced.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Frances Tran, Professor Directing Dissertation; Karen Bearor, University Representative; Leigh H. Edwards, Committee Member; John Rib, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Assessment of Embedded Perovskite/Mechanoluminescence-Based Sensors for Structural Health Monitoring of Composites

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Advanced composite materials, known for their exceptional tailorability for complex shapes, high strength-to-weight ratio, thermal stability, and corrosion resistance, have transformed engineering structures. However, their anisotropic nature complicates failure prediction and damage detection compared to traditional materials. Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) presents a viable solution, offering real-time structural integrity monitoring through integrated sensors and data processing devices. This dissertation focuses on developing and assessing mechanoluminescence (ML)-perovskite sensors for composite structures. It first delves into the feasibility and performance of planar ML-perovskite sensors, including MAPb(Br0.1I0.9)3 and CsPbBr3 perovskites, which demonstrated sensitivities of 0.47 J-1 and 0.74J-1 respectively, with the capacity to detect impact energies as low as 0.6J and 0.4J. These planar-based ML-perovskite sensors were then compared to the design and fabrication of an innovative fiber-shaped ML-perovskite sensor. This fiber-shaped sensor, showing a promising sensitivity of 1.31J-1 and able to detect energy as low as 1.5J, mitigates the intrusive effect on the composite system's properties by seamlessly integrating into the composite fabric. The ML-perovskite sensors operate on an exciting mechanism where mechanical deformation causes the sensors to emit light. This light emission, or ML, is absorbed by the perovskite layer, which functions as a photodetector. The photodetector converts the light into electrical signals that can be monitored and correlated to potential damage. Notably, these sensors activate only under mechanical stimulation, virtually eliminating false alarms. Rigorous experiments demonstrate their outstanding sensitivity and repeatability, critical attributes for detecting and locating low energy impacts, which can potentially cause barely visible impact damage (BVID), thus playing a crucial role in preventative maintenance and extending the structures' longevity. Detailed discussions on the methods, experiments, and interpretations connected to these sensor performance evaluations substantiate the transformative potential of ML-perovskite sensors in enhancing the safety, reliability, and efficiency of composite structures, thereby paving the way for the development of novel intelligent composite materials and SHM
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Composites, Mechanoluminescence, Perovskite, Sensors, Structural Health Monitoring
Okenwa Okoli, Professor Directing Dissertation; Biwu Ma, University Representative; Tarik Dickens, Committee Member; Zhiyong Liang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Spatial Navigation
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: How I Made It Here

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Spatial navigation cognition is a critical area of study, providing insights into how we perceive our environment and offering early indicators of Alzheimer's disease (AD), such as disorientation and getting lost. Alzheimer's disease is highly prevalent, and understanding its progression is crucial for early diagnosis and intervention. To address this, we have developed specialized hardware and software for spatial navigation tasks, which have revealed spatial reorientation deficits in 12-month-old 3xTg-AD mice, paralleling early stage human AD symptoms. Additionally, we introduced the Map to Action Transformation Task, a novel behavioral assay, to better comprehend the use of spatial navigation reference frames in rats and the cognitive transformation between these frames. Utilizing this method in TgF344-AD rats and control groups, we discovered starting at six month-old, reference frame transformation is significantly impaired. These deficits are age-specific, and our task demonstrates greater sensitivity in detecting early spatial navigation impairments compared to traditional methods. Furthermore, our research has employed this task to induce brain dynamics during sleep involving parietal cortex and hippocampus. This innovative approach enhances our understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying spatial navigation deficits in Alzheimer's disease and provides a robust framework for early detection and therapeutic strategies. Such a complete and novel approach is key to understanding aspects of the disease that have yet to be explored.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Aaron Wilber, Professor Directing Dissertation; Wei Wu, University Representative; Chris Martin, Committee Member; Roberto Vincis, Committee Member; Yi Zhou, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Variability of the Wet Season over Southeast Asia

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study uses an objective definition for the onset and demise date for the seasonal evolution of the rainy season over the Southeast Asia (SEA) region. The onset and demise dates are defined as the first and last date of the year when the daily rain rate exceeds the annual mean climatological rainfall rate. This gives rise to a varying length of the season that has a significant impact on the estimate of the seasonal rainfall and its anomaly over the rainy season. It is observed that the interannual variability of the seasonal rainfall of the rainy season is significantly affected by the variations of the onset and demise dates. However, the influence of the onset and demise date appears to be independent of each other. Using the Integrated Multi-Satellite Retrievals for Global Precipitation Mission version 6 (IMERG) rainfall analysis available on 0.1°grid we have analyzed the variations of the rainy season over SEA. We generate an ensemble of 1,001 members by slightly perturbing the original time series to account for uncertainties in the observed rainfall analyses. This also ensures that the diagnoses of the onset/demise dates are not sensitive to sporadic synoptic/mesoscale rain events that may be unconnected to the seasonal evolution of rainfall in SEA. Using this ensemble of 1,001 members per season, we find that we can provide a reliable probabilistic outlook of the forthcoming rainy season over the SEA region based on the variations of the onset date of the wet season. This is possible because of the strong intrinsic relationship of earlier or later onset seasons of the SEA rainy season associated with longer and wetter or shorter and drier season, respectively.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Vasubandhu Misra, Professor Directing Thesis; Mark Bourassa, Committee Member; Michael Diamond, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Long in the Tooth Paleoclimate Reconstruction Using Legacy Faunal Collections and Stable Isotopes at the Page-Ladson Site (8JE591), Jefferson County, Florida

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In the past half century, the remains of terrestrial megafaunal species have been recovered from archaeological sites across the Florida peninsula. Many of these remains have been the subject of archaeological investigations – both traditional zooarchaeological investigations and analyses of a variety of stable isotopes. In this study two specimens, a molar from a Camelops sp. individual recovered in-situ during the 2014 excavations of the Page-Ladson site (8JE591) and an Equus sp. incisor recovered from the same site during 1988 cleaning operations, are the subject of analyses of stable isotopes of carbon and oxygen. Paleoclimate reconstructions are conducted using these analyses, first utilizing the Camelops sp. individual and later the same practice is applied to the Equus sp. specimen. The resultant data highlight that, while isotopic analyses on remains recovered in-situ are preferred, these same analyses conducted on remains lacking accurate stratigraphy and provenience may still provide archaeologists with significant insight into archaeological sites – especially those submerged where stratigraphic control can prove to be difficult. The results of the present study highlight the potential of isotopic analyses when applied to legacy collections. These data highlight the drastic environmental changes experienced during the Pleistocene-Holocene transition in North America and how these changes affected behavioral and land-use pattern changes in both the animals and humans of this period. The Camelops sp. specimen yielded an average δ13C value of -11.6‰ and an average δ18O value of -1.4‰. The Equus sp. specimen yielded an average δ13C value of -6.8‰ and an average δ18O value of 1.3‰. These data further support the hypothesis that the Page-Ladson served as an oasis in an otherwise arid C3 grassland environment.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Anthropology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Jessi J. Halligan, Professor Directing Thesis; Yang Wang, Committee Member; Rochelle A. Marrinan, Committee Member; Tanya Michelle Peres Lemons, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Role of Pragmatics and Predictability in the Production of Non-Sentential Replies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: We report two experiments that examine the role of pragmatic factors (informality and formality) and predictability factors (how likely is a given response to a question?) that lead speakers to produce full sentences versus non-sentential responses to requests for information. In Experiment 1, we replicate the basic design of Brousse et al. (under review), asking participants to answer a series of questions about their lives. Speakers were instructed to be informal or formal when answering the questions. Speakers in the informal condition produced more non-sentential replies than speakers in the formal condition. In Experiment 2, we collected norming data to establish two metrics of predictability for responses to our questions (unique counts of responses and proportion of dominant responses). These predictability measures were then used to predict the rate of non-sentential replies for each item in Experiment 1. Items that elicited more unique responses in Experiment 2 were more likely to be answered with a full sentence in Experiment 1 than items that elicited fewer unique responses. The proportion of dominant responses did not predict rates of full sentence and non-sentential replies. The results provide partial support for the claim that the use of non-sentential forms is linked to the predictability of the linguistic material that is omitted in short responses to questions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Michael P. Kaschak, Professor Directing Thesis; Chris B. Martin, Committee Member; Chris Schatschneider, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Causal Investigation of Visual Cortical Disinhibition in Fear Memory

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Fear and anxiety disorders remain difficult to treat, but research into the mechanisms underlying fear memory would provide an important insight into their underlying pathology and identify effective targets for future therapeutics. The sensory cortex has traditionally been overshadowed by the well-documented roles of the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex in fear and anxiety. However, growing evidence in the past decade suggests that it would be a critical player in fear processing (particularly, long-term fear memory) and thus an accessible and effective target for mitigating pathological fear. The current study aims to causally elucidate the role of the human visual cortex in underlying fear memory. Specifically, we tested the hypothesis that conditioning-induced disinhibition in the human visual cortex is critical for the formation of fear memory. In a Pavlovian fear conditioning study, we combined experimental augmentation of alpha oscillations (8-12 Hz; critical for cortical inhibition) via high-definition alpha-frequency transcranial alternating current stimulation (HD α-tACS) with simultaneous EEG-fMRI before, during, and immediately after conditioning, as well as EEG recordings on Day 2 and Day 8. As the alpha oscillation acts as a key inhibitory modulator of visual cortical activity, alpha augmentation via α-tACS would experimentally enhance visual cortical inhibition, thereby resisting disinhibition evoked by fear conditioning and impeding fear memory formation. Indeed, we demonstrated that α-tACS (vs. sham control) prevented such suppression during fear memory consolidation (as indexed by EEG on Day 1). Importantly, we found that during fear memory recall (on Day 8), α-tACS (vs. sham control) diminished visual cortical response (as indexed by the visual evoked potential—P1) to the CS+ (vs. CS-). Moreover, relative to the Sham Group, α-tACS weakened activation of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and the right early visual cortex during immediate recall testing. These results causally evinced the critical role of sensory cortex in human fear memory, highlighting a novel mechanism—sensory cortical disinhibition—in this process. The findings thus expand canonical fear models centered on the amygdala and prefrontal cortex. Importantly, by demonstrating the efficacy of α-tACS in disrupting fear memory, the study further promotes novel therapeutics for fear and anxiety disorders via non-invasive brain stimulation.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Wen Li, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Lisa Eckel, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Wei Wu, University Representative; Chris Martin, Committee Member; Mohamed Kabbaj, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Modeling Synchronization in Pancreatic Islets and Biomarker Discovery in Sepsis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This work concerns two different topics. The first topic is mathematical modeling of insulin release. Insulin is secreted in pulses by β-cells located within pancreatic islets. This pulsatility is reflected in blood insulin measurements, indicating that the activity of hundreds of thousands of islets is synchronized. One possible mechanism for this synchronization is a negative feedback loop between the pancreas and liver hepatocytes, in which the action of hepatocytes to lower glucose levels in response to insulin serves as a global coordinating signal to pancreatic islets. With a time delay in the glucose response, small populations of in vitro and computer simulated model islets display bistability, capable of producing both fast and slow coordinated oscillations. We investigate the dynamic mechanism for this bistability through simulations with large islet populations, long time delays, and a reduced model that captures the dynamics of the full closed-loop system with only two variables. The second topic is sepsis. Sepsis is the body's severe and extreme reaction to an infection that can lead to multiple organ failure and death. Early detection and treatment of sepsis are essential for a positive outcome and can be guided by host-response biomarkers indicative of sepsis type and prognosis. Topological Data Analysis (TDA) was used to cluster patients according to similarities in their plasma metabolite profile. Then, metabolites that were differentially expressed between survivors and nonsurvivors were identified for both the overall cohort and individual phenotype groups identified through TDA. Finally, pathway analysis was used to identify the metabolic path- ways associated with the dysregulated metabolites and was integrated with transcriptomic data to view relationships in a biological network. We found that phenotype groups differed in what metabolites were differentially expressed between survivors and nonsurvivors, thus demonstrating the need to stratify and treat patients differently.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Richard Bertram, Professor Directing Dissertation; Wei Yang, University Representative; Monica Hurdal, Committee Member; Bhargav Karamched, Committee Member; Michael Roper, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interrelationships between Resilience, Early Life Contexts, and Health Inequalities in Adulthood

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Despite incremental improvements in racial health inequalities in previous decades, gaps in morbidity and mortality have expanded in the past 10 years (Curtin and Xu 2022; Xu et al. 2022). Growing racial inequalities are especially visible in patterns of chronic disease prevalence and mortality among adults approaching midlife (Curtin and Xu 2022). One resource that has garnered increasing attention in public discourse, clinical practice, programmatic interventions, and policy is "resilience." Resilience is generally understood as an adaptive capacity to handle stressors in ways that sustain or improve health and well-being (Manning 2013). Though originally grounded in individual, family, and community contexts (Luthar 2006; Rutter 1987), recent interventions grounded in resilience have increased their attention towards psychological resilience (hereafter "resilience") as a means to bolster health and well-being (Joyce et al. 2018). When measured as a psychological resource, resilience is generally shown to bolster physical and mental health. However, several knowledge gaps limit our understanding of the connections between resilience and racial health inequalities over the life course. Better understanding of how early life resources and contexts shape these trends is greatly needed to help reduce chronic disease prevalence and observed inequalities over the life course. This dissertation helps elucidate the linkages between resilience, physical health, and racialized health inequalities in adulthood. Few studies have been able to estimate relationships between resilience and physical health in early adulthood and midlife (Lehrer et al. 2020; Yi et al. 2008). This critical gap in resilience research limits understanding of how resilience shapes both physical health and racial health inequalities. Among scholars identifying racialized relationships between psychological resources and physical health, the consensus is that such patterns reflect racial stratification in stressors and resources over the life course (Erving, Satcher, and Chen 2020; James, Hartnett, and Kalsbeek 1983; Tobin et al. 2022). For this reason, some scholars point to discourse and interventions centered on individual-level sources of resilience as displacing the onus of social inequalities from institutions and policymakers to the communities and people experiencing them (Mahdiani and Ungar 2021; Suslovic and Lett 2023). But despite limited evidence of interrelationships between psychological resources, material resources, and health, few studies have been able to estimate how relationships between resilience and health are conditioned by the broad availability of material and social resources. Building on previous work, I examine how resilience shapes physical health and health inequalities across racialized groups as people approach midlife. I then incorporate novel measures of early life disadvantage to assess how such contexts and resilience in adulthood jointly shape health and health inequalities. This dissertation comprises 3 studies that assess the interrelationships between resilience, early life contexts, and health inequalities in adulthood. I leverage the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health to measure early life exposure to stressors, resilience in adulthood, and physical health among non-Hispanic White ("White"), non-Hispanic Black ("Black"), and Hispanic/Latinx people (N=7,085). These data allowed me to build on previous research by developing a novel measure of resilience within a nationally representative sample and creating extensive measures of early life contexts that capture different dimensions of disadvantage within family, school, and neighborhood environments. Collectively, these studies illustrate the dynamic effects of resilience and early life contexts on health and health inequalities over the life course. Study 1 shows that associations between resilience and physical health vary among non-Hispanic White, non-Hispanic Black, and Hispanic/Latinx people. Measuring self-rated health and chronic conditions, analyses suggest that because the health benefits of resilience vary across racialized groups, health inequalities between Black respondents and their peers expand at higher levels of resilience. Studies 2 and 3 focus on chronic conditions and highlight 1) how different dimensions of early life disadvantage shape health and health inequalities; and 2) how early life exposures and resilience jointly inform chronic condition prevalence across racialized groups. Due to their unique effects on chronic conditions across racialized groups, resilience and early life disadvantage jointly foster dynamic patterns in chronic disease prevalence among Black, Hispanic/Latinx, and White respondents. This dissertation provides valuable contributions to how scholars conceptualize resilience and provides insights for future resilience-based interventions that are focused on bolstering physical health. I propose that future work examine resilience as a structural process, that as others have argued (Szanton, Gill, and Thorpe Jr. 2010), draws on resilience from individual, community, and society-level contexts. I find that associations between psychological resilience and physical health are contingent on broader contexts, suggesting that other mechanisms of resilience can modify the effectiveness of this individual-level resource for bolstering health and well-being. To my knowledge, this dissertation is the first to examine the conditional health impacts of psychological resilience and different dimensions of early life disadvantage across racialized groups. Implementing this framework can help future studies bridge together silos of resilience research, and thereby illuminate the joint impacts of resources across different domains of resilience. Organizations and policymakers can also leverage this framework to bolster health and reduce racial inequalities, by designing interventions that modify resilience mechanisms across domains beyond the individual level.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Chronic Disease, Early Life Disadvantage, Life Course, Racial Stratification, Resilience
Dawn C. Carr, Professor Directing Dissertation; Penny Ralston, University Representative; John R. Reynolds, Committee Member; Miles Taylor, Committee Member; Patricia Homan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Personalizing the Education Experience in Rural Schools
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Exploratory Case Study in Rural Supports and Values

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation explored the rural identity of a small county in North Florida and the educational experiences of their students, through the perspectives of the educators who live and work there. I began by examining the complex definition of rurality through the descriptions educators share about the community and the school. Then I examined the systems of support that this organization had in place to personalize the education experiences of their students. Lastly, I examined the logics observed to better understand the motivations of this work, within the rural context, identifying several dominant logics. The findings from this dissertation highlight the complexity of the meaning of rurality and demonstrate the importance of considering local context in the field of education research, reform, and policy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Stacey Rutledge, Professor Directing Dissertation; Vanessa Dennen, University Representative; Carolyn Herrington, Committee Member; Toby Park-Gaghan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Mysteries of the Gothic Heroine
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Case for a Feminist Tradition of American Detective Fiction

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation makes a case for an intersectional feminist tradition and critique of American detective fiction. Moving from the detective novel's beginnings in the mid-19th century and into major late 19th and early 20th century participants in the genre, my archive highlights the underexplored connections between domestic fiction and detective fiction, African American writers' hybridization of the trans-racial Gothic and detective fiction, and the significance of queer readership communities and fandoms to the genre of detective fiction. This project grew out of my sense that, for all the revision the canon has undergone to make it more inclusive and reflective of numerous viewpoints and identities, academic discussion and pop culture representation of detective fiction retains a distinctly masculinist bias rooted in a male-centric critical tradition and in the preoccupations of popular fan studies. Women authors and detectives, particularly those offering a further marginalized perspective through race and queerness, have a position akin to outsiders in the genre, which has left us with a skewed understanding of both detective fiction as a mode and nineteenth and twentieth-century American literature more broadly. My dissertation seeks to uncover this neglected history of female investigators and their authors, as well as their shifting motivations, identities, and strategies. In the process, I explore the hidden histories of women's detective fiction and their female detectives, the female detective as an intrinsically intersectional figure, the American Gothic as a mode of exploration of the detective genre, and the underexplored possibilities of critical race, queer, and feminist approaches to detective fiction. I posit that reorienting the familiar macro-narrative of detective fiction can bring to light alternative strategies for unpacking the relationship between the figure of the detective and issues of race, gender, and sexuality. Ultimately, my dissertation positions women's detective fiction as a battle ground concerning women's rights, and ideas on femininity and feminism. The Gothic girl detective's transgressive performances of (white) womanhood and heterosexuality dramatize the bifurcations of the first-wave feminist movement on the basis of marriage and family, establish gender, race, and sexuality, as social and political constructs, and reappropriate the domestic sphere as a space of autonomy for women.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Aaron Jaffe, Professor Directing Dissertation; Katherine Mooney, University Representative; Trinyan Mariano, Committee Member; John McCoy Kilgore, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Translational Analysis of the Association between Binge Eating and Inflammation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: There is evidence to suggest that individuals with bulimic syndromes (i.e., eating disorders characterized by binge eating, including binge-purge anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder) experience peripheral inflammation before and after the onset of eating pathology. However, the role that inflammation plays in the development and/or maintenance of these dysregulated eating behaviors is poorly understood. The goal of this dissertation was to examine immune alterations in response to binge-like eating in female rats, and bulimic syndromes in humans. Here, we investigated whether intermittent overconsumption of a high fat diet (HFD), in the form of a binge, could promote microglial reactivity in brain regions implicated in the neural control of food intake, including the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus (ARC) and the nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS). Our findings demonstrated that binge-like eating behavior occurs in female rats that are intermittently presented with a HFD, compared to female rats given either daily chow access only, or daily chow and HFD access. We found for the first time that both continuous and intermittent consumption of a HFD led to increased Iba1 expression (a cytoskeletal protein marker of microglia/macrophages) and decreased microglial branch length and number in the ARC and NTS compared to chow-fed controls. Additionally, we tested whether attenuating HFD-induced microglial reactivity using pharmacological manipulation would lead to a reduction in binge-like eating behavior in female rats. Minocycline is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that has been shown to cross the blood brain barrier readily and exhibits anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective effects that are ultimately mediated by its ability to inhibit microglial reactivity. Thus, using the same intermittent HFD access paradigm used in our first study, we gave female rats either minocycline (40 mg/kg) in their drinking water, or gave them tap water (control) for the duration of the 14-day paradigm. There was no effect of minocycline on total food intake, water intake, body weight, or body adiposity. While minocycline did not reduce binge-like eating behavior in female rats given intermittent HFD access, minocycline did attenuate HFD intake and increase chow intake in rats after 24 h of intermittent HFD access, relative to rats given intermittent HFD access and tap water. This suggests that minocycline may alter dietary preference in rats that display binge-like eating behavior. Minocycline did not reliably decrease microglial reactivity in the ARC or NTS across diet conditions. Separate from our studies in rodents, we examined peripheral immune alterations in women diagnosed with bulimic syndromes. The available literature suggests a relationship between bulimic syndromes and peripheral inflammation, but is limited by underpowered studies and a failure to control for confounding variables like body mass index (BMI), percentage of body fat, and comorbidities that could promote inflammation independent of engaging in binge eating. Thus, the goal of this project was to assess a marker of peripheral inflammation (plasma IL-6, a pro-inflammatory cytokine) in a large sample of women with bulimic syndromes and healthy controls across the entire BMI spectrum. We found that plasma concentrations of IL-6 were greater in women with bulimic syndromes, compared to women without eating disorder diagnoses, while controlling for both BMI and percentage of body fat. This demonstrates that there is something about eating pathology in the individuals with bulimic syndromes that is linked to peripheral inflammation. Secondary analyses unveiled that plasma IL-6 was positively correlated with scores on types of assessments that determine whether an individual meets diagnostic criterion for an eating disorder diagnosis, such as the Clinical Impairment Assessment (CIA) and the Global Eating Disorder Examination (EDE), confirming that our participants met eating disorder diagnostic criteria. Plasma IL-6 was also positively correlated with the largest eating episode and fasting leptin levels in all participants. We also found a trend level association between IL-6 and binge frequency in participants with bulimic syndromes. These data demonstrate that women with bulimic syndromes experience peripheral inflammation that occurs separate from elevated adiposity. Ultimately, these studies demonstrate that binge-like eating in female rats, and binge eating in women with bulimic syndromes, is associated with a degree of either central or peripheral inflammation.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
binge eating, eating disorders, female rats, inflammation, microglia, women
Lisa Eckel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hengli Tang, University Representative; Pamela Keel, Committee Member; Linda Rinaman, Committee Member; Cathy Levenson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigations into the Recruitment of Substrate Ambiguous Enzymes for Metabolic Innovation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Alterations in environmental conditions can selectively influence the evolutionary outcome of organisms. A striking example of this evolutionary response is metabolic innovation, where a change in an environment's chemical composition promotes the emergence of new metabolic pathways. Indeed, metabolic innovation encompasses many of today's most significant health-related issues, including antibiotic resistance or the bioremediation of anthropogenic toxins. The patchwork evolution model, by which genomic alterations recruit enzymes from existing metabolic pathways to perform new functions, is believed to be the predominant process facilitating metabolic innovation. Functional promiscuity is a distinguishing characteristic of the enzymes recruited for metabolic innovation, manifesting as either ambiguity in substrate recognition or promiscuity in chemical transformation. These promiscuous properties of modern enzymes fuel enzyme recruitment, composing a reservoir of hidden functions that can become beneficial during environmental change and subsequently be recruited for metabolic innovation. Despite recognizing that functional promiscuity is widespread in extant proteomes, what factors dictate the preferential recruitment of one functionally promiscuous enzyme over another candidate is unknown. Thus, it is currently impossible to accurately predict the trajectory of metabolic innovation. Model microorganism Escherichia coli contains four sugar kinases that are candidates for recruitment when the native glucokinase machinery is deleted — allokinase (AlsK), manno(fructo)kinase (Mak), N-acetylmannosamine kinase (NanK) and N-acetylglucosamine kinase (NagK). The catalytic efficiencies of these enzymes are 103 to 105-fold lower than native glucokinases, ranging from 2400 M-1 s-1 for the most active candidate, NagK, to 15 M-1 s-1 for the least active candidate, AlsK. Initially, to investigate the relationship between the catalytic activities of promiscuous enzymes and their recruitment, we performed adaptive evolution of a glucokinase-deficient E. coli strain to restore glycolytic metabolism. We observed preferential recruitment of NanK via a trajectory involving early mutations that facilitate glucose uptake and amplify nanK transcription, followed by nonsynonymous, active-site substitutions in NanK that enhance the enzyme's promiscuous glucokinase activity. These substitutions reduced the native activity of NanK. They also reduced organismal fitness during growth on an N-acetylated carbon source, indicating that enzyme recruitment comes at a cost for growth on other substrates. Notably, the two most active candidates, NagK and Mak, were not recruited, suggesting that catalytic activity alone does not dictate evolutionary outcomes. To determine if another candidate glucokinase besides NanK could restore glycolytic metabolism, we deleted nanK from the genome of the original glucokinase-deficient E. coli strain and repeated the same adaptive evolution experiments. Despite lacking the original preferred recruitment candidate of NanK, we observed a robust recovery of glycolytic metabolism that exceeded the fitness levels of the wild-type strain. Interestingly however, we did not observe the recruitment of any alternate glucokinase candidate besides NanK in these strains, suggesting that only NanK is the only latent glucokinase capable of being natively recruited in E. coli via an obvious mutational mechanism. Additionally, the addition of antibiotics as an additional environmental stressor only partially altered the recruitment trajectory of these strains, as while the identity of the observed mutations changes, their phenotypic impact remained the same. These results highlight our lack of knowledge regarding biological drivers of enzyme recruitment and emphasize the need for a systems-wide approach to identify factors facilitating or constraining this important adaptive process.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Molecular Biophysics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Brian G. Miller, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lei Zhu, University Representative; Wen Zhu, Committee Member; Margaret Elizabeth Stroupe, Committee Member; Michael Gabriel Roper, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Zooarchaeological Analysis of the Vertebrate Fauna from the Heber Springs Site (3CE68), Arkansas

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Heber Springs site (3CE68) is a Woodland period (700BC-AD 1000) site located in Cleburne County, Arkansas. In 1979, the Arkansas Archaeological Survey excavated four units into the mound at the Heber Springs site and recovered vertebrate faunal material. The goal of this research was to determine if the Heber Springs site was the location of a feasting event. I performed zooarchaeological analysis on the vertebrate fauna from the Heber Springs site to better understand the lifeways of Indigenous peoples. This research implemented Kassabaum's dual-dimension model in order to determine if the model can be applied to zooarchaeological data to detect feasting behavior. This thesis contributes to the body of research on feasting behaviors in zooarchaeology as well as the growing field of zooarchaeological analysis in Arkansas.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Anthropology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
archaeology, Arkansas, fauna, Southeast, vertebrate fauna, zooarchaeology
