To assess the efficacy of this software 60 older adult (65+) participants with (M = 73.13, SD = 4.69) and without probable mild cognitive impairment (M = 71.73, SD = 4.16) engaged in a gamified visual search task across two conditions (feature search, conjunction search), each lasting 15 minutes, across three difficulty levels (DL; number of search items), each lasting 5 minutes. Task performance and movement data were collected during gameplay. System usability, workload, cybersickness, and enjoyment were also assessed via self-report questionnaires at the end of the session. The probable Mild Cognitive Impairment (pMCI) group exhibited significantly lower performance compared to a non-impaired control group (NIC) and engaged in significantly less travel. Despite these differences, a binary logistic regression did not significantly predict group placement probability. Overall, the task and platform were found to be enjoyable and easy to use by both groups. However, the pMCI group reported the system to be significantly less usable and felt significantly more insecure about their task performance compared to the NIC group. Although the current study failed to discern group placement, results presented offer further evidence of visuospatial ability differences between pMCI and NIC individuals, as well as feasibility insights toward an IVR-based cognitive screening solution.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
immersive virtual reality, mild cognitive impairment, visual search

Chris Martin, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Walter Boot, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Michael Kaschak, Committee Member; Dawn Carr, Committee Member; Fengfeng Ke, Committee Member; Colleen Ganley, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Determinants of Presence in Virtual Reality Environments
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Examining the Role of Attention through a Novel Application of Feature Integration Theory

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Immersive virtual reality (IVR) has shown promise in being an effective and cost-efficient method to deploy a variety of programs for promoting health, wellbeing, and physical and everyday functioning. The psychological construct of presence, often described as the "sense of being there," is considered a core aspect of the technology, and consequently a major facilitator of successful IVR experiences and interventions. While prior research has explored how individual difference factors and technology characteristics impact presence, relatively little is known about how the cognitive demands of the virtual experience itself could impact an individual's sense of being there. To that end, the current study investigated how the attentional demands of IVR experiences might influence presence. Within a virtual nature environment, participants were asked to "catch" different animals. Inspired by feature integration theory (FIT), different IVR scenarios involved search targets that varied in the degree to which attention was necessary to locate them (low-attention – similar to feature search; high-attention – similar to conjunction search). Initially, a small pilot study (N = 6, 4 female, mean age = 19) demonstrated that search targets and distractors chosen, when placed in a typical search paradigm, produced search efficiencies that varied significantly (set size by scenario interaction, F(1,32) = 8.42, p < 0.01, η²p = 0.21; low-attention slope: 33 ms/item, high-attention slope: 173 ms/item). Next, fifty participants (35 female, 1 non-binary, mean age = 19) engaged in an IVR foraging task in which they navigated the environment to collect these animals. Despite pilot and concurrent evidence that the two scenarios varied substantially and significantly in attentional demand, no effect of presence was observed (F(1, 49) = 0.69, p = 0.41, η²p = 0.01). Results suggest that different levels of visual attention to the virtual environment does not modulate presence.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Attention, Presence, Virtual Reality, Visual Search
Walter Boot, Professor Directing Thesis; Neil Charness, Committee Member; Sara Hart, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Functional Regression Models for Multi-Site Imaging Data Integration

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In large-scale imaging studies, addressing heterogeneity presents a big challenge arising from diverse geographic locations, variations in instrumentation, differences in image acquisition protocols, and undisclosed latent variables. While numerous regression models have been devised to explore the relationship between imaging responses and relevant covariates, limited attention has been paid to scenarios involving shape-related responses. This introduces additional complexity due to the unique characteristics of shape representations, such as nonlinearity, high-dimensionality, and the intricate nature of quotient space geometry. The second chapter addresses these complexities, and propose an innovative approach: a novel shape-on-scalar regression model integrated with confounder adjustment. Specifically, we utilize the square-root velocity function to capture elastic shape representations, which are embedded within the linear Hilbert space of square-integrable functions. We subsequently introduce a shape regression framework to understand the intricate associations between elastic shapes and the covariates of interest, effectively managing the challenges posed by imaging heterogeneity. We develop robust methodologies for estimating and drawing inferences about the model parameters. Through empirical analyses using real-world data, our method demonstrates superior estimation accuracy compared to existing methodologies. The third chapter discusses a new statistical framework designed to analyze multi-site brain cancer imaging data. As large-scale biomedical studies, such as the Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA), increasingly collect brain tumor data, understanding the relationships between brain tumor responses and clinical features becomes crucial. Traditional methods like mass univariate analysis (MPA) and functional regression models have limitations, particularly when faced with imaging heterogeneity. To overcome these challenges, researchers use feature-based methods, which extract imaging features for association analysis, and distribution-based approaches, which utilize functional representations like density curves and quantile functions. These methods aim to provide deeper insights but also face issues like non-linear constraints and restrictive linear models. We propose a framework that aims to model distributional representations of tumor responses through a transformative function and also incorporate the effect of multi-site heterogeneity. The main purpose is to introduce two strategies for integrative analysis of tumor data: the "merged learner" and the "ensemble learner." The merged learner combines data from different studies into a unified dataset for model training, employing techniques like PCA, CATE, and dSVA to manage inter-study heterogeneity. The ensemble learner, which averages models from individual datasets, often performs better in heterogeneous scenarios. This framework aims to enhance prediction accuracy and identify reliable imaging biomarkers across diverse studies, addressing the complexities posed by inter-study variability. Keywords: shape analysis, inter-site heterogeneity, corpus callosum, alzheimer's disease, functional data analysis, tumor heterogeneity, ensemble modelling, data integration.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
corpus callosum, distribution-on-scalar regression, function-on-scalar regression, inter-site heterogeneity, shape data analysis, tumor heterogeneity
Chao Huang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hongyu Miao, University Representative; Debajyoti Sinha, Committee Member; Andrés Felipe Barrientos, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Deadbeat-Based Instantaneous Gfl/Gfm Control for Sic Inverters with 𝐿 Filter

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The global push towards achieving carbon neutrality has accelerated the adoption of renewable energy sources, resulting in an increased integration of inverter-based resources (IBRs) within power systems. Of paramount importance in this integration is the precise control of voltage, current, and power in grid-tied inverters, a subject that has garnered extensive research attention due to its potential to enhance system stability, robustness, and reliability. Concurrently, SiC grid-tied inverters have garnered significant traction across diverse applications, leveraging their advantages such as higher switching speeds, superior efficiency, increased power density, and reduced system costs in comparison to their Si-based counterparts. However, the transition from device-level advantages to system-level benefits while ensuring stability, particularly in scenarios involving high switching frequencies and rapid dynamics like low-voltage ride-through (LVRT), presents numerous challenges. Inverter control strategies are broadly categorized into Grid-Following (GFL) and Grid-Forming (GFM) methods. Established GFL control methods commonly rely on voltage sensors, phase-lock loops (PLLs), or frequency-lock loops (FLLs) to attain effective current and power control. Nevertheless, issues of stability and constrained dynamic performance arising from PLLs and voltage sensors persist. Despite advancements that have demonstrated PLL-less, voltage sensor-less approaches with enhanced reliability and stability, these methods still exhibit limited dynamic responses, and intricate and time-consuming design remains unavoidable. In the context of cutting-edge GFM approaches, the P-? Q-E droop algorithm is adopted, and various versions of Power-Synchronization-Loop (PSL) based methods are introduced. These methods facilitate automatic power sharing and eliminate the need for PLL units during islanding mode. However, their dynamic response tends to be relatively sluggish, necessitating additional hardware and/or software to handle fault scenarios. Furthermore, the droop characteristics need to be meticulous designed with unavoidable frequency and voltage deviations. Additionally, a distinct current limitation control is indispensable to guarantee the secure operation of GFM inverters. Efforts to leverage model predictive control (MPC) techniques in grid-tied inverters for fast control have been reported. Nonetheless, many of these approaches deal with challenges like high current harmonics, the impact of delay time, discrepancies in model parameters, and an ongoing reliance on PLLs (or FLLs). Furthermore, the fault ride-through capabilities, including scenarios like LVRT, have yet to be thoroughly explored within MPC-based methods. The focal point of this research is to introduce PLL-less deadbeat-based control methods for SiC GFL and GFM inverters. The aim is to simultaneously enhance system stability, reliability, dynamic response, and fault ride through capabilities. These methods are realized on 50kHz SiC inverters, implementing a unified control algorithm spanning steady-state, transient, and LVRT scenarios. Notably, the mitigation of inrush currents does not necessitate supplementary hardware circuits or transient controllers. Moreover, the need for intricate and time-consuming controller parameter design is circumvented, ensuring ease of implementation. Importantly, the global stability of the proposed methods is established and verified mathematically.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Deadbeat control, Grid-following, Grid-forming, Instantaneous control, LVRT/ZVRT, SiC inverter
Hui Li, Professor Directing Dissertation; Juan Ordóñez, University Representative; Fang Z. Peng, Committee Member; Olugbenga Moses Anubi, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Colloidal Perovskite Quantum Dots
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Surface Passivation and Photochemical Processes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The colloidal lead halide perovskite nanocrystals (PNCs) have sparked significant interest in recent years due to their unique optical properties and potential applications in light-emitting devices and solar cells. However, challenges with their colloidal and photophysical instability have hindered the exploration of their fundamental properties and integration into optoelectronic devices. The focus of this dissertation is to introduce a surface chemistry strategy based on ligand exchange method using high affinity coordinating polymers. This enhances the surface passivation of PNCs and enables their use in photochemical processes. In Chapter 1, we provided an overview of the fundamental physical and chemical characteristics of semiconducting quantum dots (QDs), as well as a detailed introduction to metal halide perovskites, emphasizing their growth methods, crystal structures, shape control, anion exchange, and characteristic phase transformations. Additionally, we summarized various strategies reported in literature to address the stability issues of PNCs, focusing on their colloidal, structural, and photophysical properties. In Chapter 2, we studied the photo-assisted halide exchange reaction of CsPbBr3 perovskite quantum dots (PQDs) dispersed in chlorinated solvents. We probed the kinetics of this process and the associated blue shift in the emission properties, by varying the irradiation source, its duration, and the structure of the solvent molecules. We carried out a thorough characterization of the nanocrystal intermediates during this irradiation period, using optical and fluorescence spectroscopy, supplemented with powder X-ray diffraction and X-ray fluorescence spectrometry measurements. Our findings indicate that the PQDs can act as photocatalysts, where they absorb high-energy photons, promoting rapid electron transfer to the alkyl chloride molecules and triggering their dissociative degradation to produce radical alkyl molecules and chloride ions. These findings show that PQDs exhibit promising photocatalytic properties that may find use in common organic reactions including dehalogenation. In Chapter 3, we presented energy transfer interactions between PQDs and cyanine-based dye molecules. We employed CsPbBr3 PQDs and various cyanine dye molecules with tailored structures to control spectral overlap and their affinity to PQD surfaces, enabling a precise manipulation of the donor-acceptor separation distance. This approach offers a unique system for xiii probing FRET interactions within PQD/dye assemblies. Our findings consistently indicate efficient energy transfer between donor and acceptor molecules, as evidenced by the reduced PQD emission, shortened PQD fluorescence lifetime, and concurrent enhancement of dye fluorescence. Additionally, we assessed the impact of spectral overlap on FRET efficiency, revealing that reduced spectral overlap leads to less efficient energy transfer, aligning with the Förster formalism. In Chapter 4, we introduced a novel polyzwitterionic polymer ligand based on the carboxybetaine motif with enhanced coordination interactions for the surface treatment of hybrid MAPbBr3 PNCs. These ligands incorporate several octylamine solubilizing moieties, in addition to multiple carboxybetaine groups. We showed that mixing as-grown dispersion of MAPbBr3 PNCs with polycarboxybetaine ligands triggers rapid homogenization of the nanocrystal dispersion, resulting in narrow emission profiles along with increased quantum yield. This was attributed to enhanced ligand binding to the PNC surfaces, promoted through templating effects, which produces size focusing combined with better passivation of surface defects. Furthermore, we found that this coating strategy is effective in promoting long term colloidal stability of these dispersions while preserving their colloidal and structural integrity. In Chapter 5, we summarized the work in this dissertation on the surface passivation of PNCs and their use in photochemical processes, along with a discussion on future directions, including the exploration of their potential applications in light emitting diodes.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Hedi Mattoussi, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Oliver Steinbock, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Debra Fadool, University Representative; Justin G. Kennemur, Committee Member; Geoffrey F. Strouse, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: At Home in Middle Republican Colonies
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Colonial Households and Water Management

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study focuses on the domestic activities of middle Republican colonies, that iscolonies of the 3rd to 1st centuries BCE, including those of non-elite households, to understand the regional adaptations to the environment and its effects on house design and household behavior, with a specific focus on water. The archaeological data collected reveal the variety of ways in which the construction and domestic practices of Roman colonies adapted water management practices to new environments. The results of this analysis elucidate elements of the daily life of middle Roman colonists across the Italian peninsula, an area and period with comparatively low resolution in scholarship outside of the Bay of Naples. This project fills the lacuna by presenting a series of case studies that preserve piecemeal evidence of the domestic sphere during the pivotal period of Roman development on the Italian peninsula in the 3rd to 1st centuries BCE. This study investigates responses to variations in regional and local ecologies to analyze how adaptations to local environment shaped divergent architecture of domestic spaces in different localized environments of Italy. I analyze practices of harvesting rainwater in the domestic sphere at the microscale—at the level of individual houses—as well as at the macroscale--the regional level of the Italian peninsula--drawing on recent approaches in the field of household archaeology and on behavior-focused theories, including Bourdieu's practice theory. This multiscalar analysis facilitates broader comparisons of individual and societal responses to resource management and house design in the context of the local environment with a focus on the households of central Italian Roman colonies in the middle Republican period.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Classics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Andrea U. De Giorgi, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jennifer L. Koslow, University Representative; Jessica H. Clark, Committee Member; Elizabeth A. Murphy, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Validation of a Teacher Knowledge Measure of Evidence-Based Practices of Early Foundational Skills of Reading

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Enhancing students' reading achievement hinges on educators' expert grasp of evidence-based practices (EBPs) proven effective in delivering reading instruction. Although several teacher knowledge measures are available to gauge teachers' knowledge of reading and reading-related skills (Binks-Cantrell et al., 2012; Elleman & Oslund, 2019; Folsom et al., 2017; Foorman et al., 2020; Hindman et al., 2020; Joshi et al., 2009b; Kretlow & Helf, 2013; Leader-Janssen & Rankin-Erickson, 2013; Moats, 2020; Tortorelli et al., 2021), few include items that reflect knowledge of both code- and meaning-based skills (Davis et al., 2022; Hall et al., 2023; Spear-Swerling & Cheesman, 201) and few have reported using a rigorous validation process to ensure adequate reliability and validity of the measure. The purpose of this study was to further develop and evaluate a measure of teacher knowledge aligned with recommendations from the What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) practice guide, Foundational Skills to Support Reading for Understanding in Kindergarten through 3rd Grade (Foorman et al., 2016) and its companion Professional Learning Community (PLC) (Kosanovich & Foorman, 2016). The 30-item measure was designed specifically to assess early elementary teachers' content knowledge and pedagogical content knowledge of code-based and meaning-based skills associated with the EBPs highlighted in the practice guide. The validation process for this study was guided by a primer created by Boateng and colleagues (2018). The steps in the three-phase process of the development and evaluation of a scale for validation aligns with the standards created jointly by the American Educational Research Association (AERA), the American Psychological Association (APA), and the National Council on Measurement in Education (NCME; 2014). In addition, both Classical Test Theory (CTT) and Item Response Theory (IRT) were used to determine the psychometric properties of items on the measure. The study sample included kindergarten, first, second, and third grade classroom teachers (n = 80) who were predominantly female (n = 76), White (n = 48), and spoke English as their native language (n = 77). All participants received their teacher certification in the United States, and all but one was currently teaching in classrooms in the United States. The majority of participants had been teaching for more than 10 years (n = 60) and most held a master's degree (n = 45). Results indicated that the mean and standard deviation (SD) of the correct responses on the survey was 19.08 (8.31), with individual scores ranging from 3 (n = 4) to 30 (n = 1). All items received responses, with none being rarely answered incorrectly (less than 5%), and one item (3.33%) was always answered correctly (greater than 95%). As hypothesized, the measure achieved reliability levels meeting the standards set forth by CTT for these specific indexes of the psychometric properties utilized. The measure also demonstrated acceptable reliability indices according to IRT. Finally, confirmatory factor analyses revealed a unidimensional model most appropriately described the fit indices on the measure (Byrne, 2005; Kline, 2016; Wagner, 2022). The results are discussed in relation to other teacher knowledge measures and implications for ongoing validation of the tool to support research and practice. Keywords: teacher knowledge, reading evidence-based practices, scale development and validation
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Nicole Patton Terry, Professor Directing Dissertation; Donald Compton, University Representative; Laura M. Steacy, Committee Member; Sonia Cabell, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Meaning in Life and Suicide
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Meta-Analysis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Meaning in life is often assumed to be related to suicidal outcomes such as suicide ideation, suicide risk, and suicide attempt, and past studies have indeed found associations between meaning in life and various suicide-relevant constructs. It is unclear, however, what the extent of relations between meaning in life and suicide-relevant constructs are when the overall literature is taken into account. It is also unclear whether publication bias may be affecting the estimates of the effect sizes of associations between meaning in life and suicide-relevant constructs. The present meta-analysis seeks to determine the effect size of the relation between meaning in life and various suicide-relevant constructs across the literature. Moreover, the present meta-analysis seeks to determine whether publication bias may be present in the extant literature on meaning in life and suicidal outcomes. Finally, the present meta-analysis seeks to determine whether associations between meaning in life and suicidal outcomes systematically differ across a variety of moderator variables, including depression, anxiety, narrowness of the definition of the meaning-in-life construct, and country of study. Studies that included a measure of meaning in life, included a measure of a suicidal outcome (viz., suicide ideation, suicide risk, and/or suicide attempt), and had obtainable sample sizes and correlations for these measures were included in the meta-analysis. Studies were excluded if they were solely qualitative studies, were duplicates, consisted of duplicate data, or were not available in English. Fisher's Zr was calculated as a measure of effect size for all studies. Effect sizes were evaluated using a random-effects model with an REML estimator. Overall, results indicate that meaning in life is negatively associated with suicide ideation, with a moderate estimated mean effect size; negatively associated with suicide risk, with a moderate estimated mean effect size; and negatively associated with suicide attempt, with a small–moderate estimated mean effect size—such that greater meaning in life is associated with decreased suicide ideation, decreased suicide risk, and fewer suicide attempts. Study effect sizes were consistently found to be heterogeneous, and heterogeneity was generally not accounted for by the moderator variables. Sensitivity analyses corroborated the robustness of these findings. Assessments of publication bias indicated a lack of substantial publication bias, further supporting the robustness of these findings. Given these findings, assessments of meaning in life may aid in detecting suicidality, and meaning in life may be a robust intervention target when trying to reduce suicidal thoughts and behaviors.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor in Philosophy.
meaning in life, meta-analysis, purpose in life, STBs, suicidality, suicide
Thomas Joiner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Mark Winegardner, University Representative; Richard Wagner, Committee Member; Jesse Cougle, Committee Member; Victor Buitron, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Mortality Salience and Motivation in Eating Disorders
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Application of the Terror Management Health Model

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In line with the Terror Management Health Model, death-related fear appeals are often utilized in public health campaigns. Research, however, suggests that these approaches may increase engagement in health risk behaviors when said behavior is esteem relevant. This study utilized a clinical eating disorder sample to investigate the effect of death-related eating disorder awareness posters on motivation to change and meal plan completion. Participants (N = 122) recruited from eating disorder treatment facilities completed an assessment of eating disorder-related self-esteem, were exposed to 1) death-related [mortality salience] and 2) eating disorder awareness [control] poster stimuli across two sessions. Outcomes were self-reported motivation to change and meal plan completion. A series of linear mixed models were employed to evaluate motivation to change and next-meal and 24-hour meal plan completion with condition, eating disorder related self-esteem, and their interaction as predictors. All results of primary models were non-significant. Exploratory analyses examined an anorexia nervosa only subsample, residential level-of-care only subsample, and the substitution of general self-esteem for eating disorder-related self-esteem. Overall results were in contrast with study hypotheses, suggesting that mortality salience has little effect on the motivation of those with eating disorders broadly, but may be helpful in motivating those with anorexia nervosa and severe symptoms. Eating disorder-related self-esteem may be of greater relevance to those with more severe eating disorders. General self-esteem may be important to consider regarding motivation. Future studies should consider utilizing non-treatment seeking samples and testing different delivery methods, like verbal communication from providers or family.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
eating disorder, motivation, self-esteem, terror management theory
Thomas E. Joiner, Professor Directing Dissertation; John Corrigan, University Representative; Greg Hajcak, Committee Member; N. Brad Schmidt, Committee Member; Ashby Plant, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Contextual and Experiential Effcts on Ambiguous Word Meaning Selection
Contextual and Experiential Effects on Ambiguous Word Meaning Selection

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The following studies examined the role of context on ambiguous word interpretation. We ran three experiments in which contextual information was presented to bias participants toward a less frequent (subordinate) meaning of a target ambiguous word. While the contextual information contained cues relevant to the subordinate meaning, it did not contain the target ambiguous word itself. Experiment 1 examined a single sentence context priming effect on participants use of a subordinate response on a subsequent word association task. Experiment 2 took context a step further by adding two additional sentences to produce a paragraph containing more contextual information biased toward the subordinate meaning. Finally, Experiment 3 contained the increased contextual information narratives from Experiment 2 but also added an immersion factor in which participants participated in the context by choosing a sentence to complete the 3-sentence narratives. For all three experiments, there was no significant effect of priming. We then conducted follow-up exploratory analyses that examined the relationship between context and the ambiguous word. We focused on the dominance frequency of the ambiguous words and the associations between the ambiguous word and words in context by examining the effect of dominance and Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA) values on subordinate meaning responses. Dominance and LSA values had a significant effect on subordinate meaning production. As dominance values increased, subordinate meaning responses decreased. As LSA values increased, subordinate meaning responses increased. The following results highlight that associations within the context and the type of experience may need to be examined further regarding word meaning interpretation.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Michael Kaschak, Professor Directing Dissertation; Laura Steacy, University Representative; Richard Wagner, Committee Member; Colleen Ganley, Committee Member; Walter Boot, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interior Design for Wellbeing
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Trauma-Informed Approach to Higher Education Social Spaces

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Interior Architecture and Design

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Trauma is a global concern and can have various negative effects on individuals. This is prevalent among Generation Z, leading to an increased demand for mental health services among college students. This may influence how these individuals perceive their environment, affecting their comfort and motivation to engage in social spaces. This research explores a trauma-informed design approach for creating environments that meet the needs of trauma-experienced students, potentially reducing stress and enhancing wellbeing. This Master of Fine Arts thesis uses a mixed methods approach utilizing surveys and interviews with college students who have experienced trauma to explore their spatial preferences and affected sense of wellbeing. Participants evaluated design qualities of university social spaces including scale and proportion, access to views, line and form, biophilic elements, lighting, prospect and refuge, color, and materiality, and discussed their impact on emotional wellbeing. Findings suggest that qualities such as openness, access to views and natural light, comfort and adaptability, connections to nature, layered lighting, privacy and security, lighter colors, natural materials, acoustical considerations, and a focus on inclusivity may enhance students' perceived sense of wellbeing. These design considerations were then applied in a hypothetical design proposal for a university student union. This study aims to provide a foundation in advancing research and practice in designing environments that support users who have experienced trauma, with the intention to create inclusive and supportive social spaces that may enhance wellbeing.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Interior Architecture and Design in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
Higher Education, Interior Design, Mental Health, Trauma, Trauma-Informed Design, Wellbeing
Jill Pable, Professor Directing Thesis; Yelena McLane, Committee Member; Meghan Mick, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Tracing the Historical Increase of Sediment Organic Carbon in a Coastal Lagoon
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Insights from Dual Analytical Approaches

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study investigated the spatiotemporal changes in sediment organic carbon (OC) content in Apalachicola Bay, Florida, USA employing two complementary analytical approaches. The first approach compared region-wide surface sediment samples collected from three time points in the past 60 years and the second approach analyzed dated sediment cores from the past century in key locations identified by the surface sample comparisons. Both approaches revealed a consistent increase in OC content since the 1950s.The most significant change was a regionwide significant increase in OC concentration from a median of 6.6 mg g-1 to 23.8 mg g-1 occurring between 1959 and 1994. Lignin degradation indices showed (Ad:Al)v oxidation levels from 0.21 to 0.36 and 3,5Bd/V indicating low to moderate degradation of soil OC. S/V of 0.82 to 0.98 indicated angiosperm dominance, while C/V ratios of 0.12 to 0.39 reflected varying woody and non-woody tissue proportions. Distance from the mainland and the river mouth trended with higher degradation and oxidation, lower lignin, and more non-woody OC sources when comparing seaward cores from those closer to the mainland. Core depth profiles revealed significant changes in oxidation, degradation, and lignin content by factors up to 2.4 in the past 5 decades. Comparison between the two approaches in this study revealed A) both approaches indicated a significant increase in OC content through time and B) that there was less agreement on the exact OC concentrations for older samples than the newer. Despite potential differences arising from dating, elemental analyses, or spatial sampling, both approaches underscore the onset of OC accumulation coinciding with historical anthropogenic activities, particularly the construction of dams and extensive dredging in the region. These findings shed light on the complex interactions between human activities, environmental stressors, and sediment OC dynamics in coastal ecosystems, emphasizing the importance of multi-approach analyses for comprehensive understanding and management of such systems.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Joshua L. Breithaupt, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Jeffrey P. Chanton, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Robert G. M. Spencer, Committee Member; Markus H. Huettel, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Death of Graeme MacGowan

mods:mods.mods:abstract: My master's thesis contains two sections of my novel The Death of Graeme MacGowan. The book itself is historical fantasy set in London, England in the 1620s. The book draws from the social and political structures of the time—focusing on the Protestant Reformation, the guild system, and the witch trials—while amending history to incorporate more of a fantastical element. In this version of our world, magic is real, if hard to access, the king of England has ruled for six hundred years, and magical knowledge is kept contained to the magician's guild, called The Worshipful Order of Magicians. Those suspected of illegal witchcraft are burned at the stake.The two parts of the thesis cover the dual narratives of Graeme MacGowan and Aelish Broward. Graeme's section is the first section and follows him both in the past as he first arrives in London and becomes embroiled in the criminal underworld there and in the present day as he attempts to con a rich boy by taking on the identity of an upper class boy. Graeme's focus is on joining the Worshipful Order of Magicians, which is primarily made up of people from the upper classes. Aelish's section is the second section and it is a spiral narrative that showcases the world of the village that she and Graeme both come from, the unfolding and destruction of their relationship, the story of her family, and the matrilineal line of magical education amongst wise woman or witches.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
Ravi Howard, Professor Directing Thesis; Elizabeth Stuckey-French, Committee Member; Molly Hand, Committee Member; Judith Pascoe, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Political Playgrounds
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Effekt Group's Activist Art in Postwar West Germany and Yugoslavia

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Dominant scholarship on postwar German art has tended to focus on individual West German artists, at times broadly situated within movements like Capitalist Realism and Zero, and their engagement with themes of postwar recovery, cultural memory, and legacies of the Holocaust. In more recent years, alongside new scholarship on socio-communist art and politics in Eastern Europe, revisionist art historical scholarship on art collectives, in and across Europe, has drawn attention to art groups in West Germany, bringing a finer understanding of art, politics, and collectives to studies on this region. However, despite these changes, remarkably no study has yet addressed the Munich-based art collective, the Effekt group (composed of Dieter Hacker, Karl Reinhartz, Helge Sommerrock, and Walter Zehringer) who, from 1961 to 1968, were not only part of New Tendencies, a major international avant-garde movement based in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, but who exhibited pervasively, in major locations around the world. In response to this problem, this dissertation is the first sustained study on Effekt. Supported by extensive archival and field research conducted in Germany, Croatia, and the United States, including the gathering of new oral histories and unpublished or little-known photos, videos, and artworks, I examine Effekt's vanguard, collectivist practice within the politicized cultural contexts of West Germany and trans-European, Yugoslav-centered New Tendencies movement. Using formal and social art historical analysis, this dissertation especially attends to Effekt's kinetic and ephemeral artworks, namely their interactive environments and participatory objects. Alongside these innovative works made of Styrofoam spheres, bubbles, candy, and other materials, in 1965 Effekt published their manifesto, On a New Exhibition Type, proposing a new model for the display of art with a supporting anti-capitalist economic structure. I argue that Effekt's turn to innovative materials, kinetic objects, and participatory art radically altered what it meant to be an active participant in an increasingly mediated and networked world. I find that Effekt, driven by socialist and anti-authoritarian ideals of the 1960s, positioned tactile, kinetic, and playful art as a means of social and political transformation. Their artworks challenged traditional power structures by advocating for democratic art spaces that actively engaged a spectator. Using spectator agency as a metaphor for democratic participation, Effekt asserted that art could be used to empower spectators to make decisions in matters of cultural, economic, and social governance. A comprehensive analysis of Effekt's multi-faceted oeuvre expands existing discourses on postwar German socially engaged art, as well as artistic and political exchanges between West Germany and Yugoslavia. Bridging scholarship on art activism and the growing discourse on "nonaligned modernism," an aesthetic-political practice coming from Yugoslavia in this period, this dissertation elucidates the understudied impact of the political, critical, and even visionary role of art and artists like Effekt in offering alternatives to hegemonic systems in revolutionary sociopolitical and artistic contexts of the 1960s. Chapter One, "Seeds of Dissent: Experimental Art in Postwar Munich, 1961," examines Effekt's foundational years. Working within postwar Concrete and Neo-Constructivist avant-garde paradigms, as seen in Hacker's Bodies series, and coinciding with involvement in student activism in Munich, Effekt artists experimented with reduced geometric forms and spectator participation as egalitarian gestures between artist and spectator. Chapter Two, "Art for Modern Times: Democratic Spectatorship and the Grid, 1962–1964," traces Effekt's engagement with New Tendencies. It examines how this movement simultaneously resonated with Effekt's experiments in participatory and Op art while also inspiring these Munich artists to investigate new strategies, like systems aesthetics, as seen in Sommerrock's 1964 work III/4. Chapter Three, "Socialist Utopias: Formation of Effekt, 1965," analyzes the formal creation of Effekt catalyzed by their desire to combat elitism in art spaces and corruption in governmental bodies. To model spectator's agency in social and political systems, Effekt transformed their kinetic objects to kinetic spaces, as exemplified by Effekt's Soap Bubble Room, modeled after Hacker's Play Object. Chapter Four, "Global Cultural Revolution(s): Rupture and Disintegration, 1968," accounts for the fragmentation of Effekt within the context of the West-German student revolutions. It also traces the trajectories of Effekt's changed aesthetic-political strategies to align with their evolving agendas, as in Sommerrock's turn to street theater and Zehringer's creation of an anti-authoritarian kindergarten. The concluding chapter, "Legacies of Art and Politics in the Aftermath of '68," examines how the artistic and cultural developments of the 1960s continue to shape contemporary life. This chapter also proposes a larger project on the critical relationship between the avant-garde and countercultural movements in 1960s Munich, a topic that is currently absent in scholarship. This dissertation addresses Effekt's revolutionary strategies and constitutes the initial effort to address this gap.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Tenley Bick, Professor Directing Dissertation; Nathan Stoltzfus, University Representative; Bojana Videkanić, Committee Member; Adam Jolles, Committee Member; Karen Bearor, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Do You Feel Confident Enough to Seek Help
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Relationship between Mental Health Confidence and Help Seeking in Military Members

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Literature review supports that when looking at help-seeking behaviors, specifically, in the military population, there is a significant amount of service members who endorse mental health concerns or distress, but do not seek help for their mental health (Hom, Stanley, Schneider, & Joiner, 2017) The range of mental health concerns include depression, anxiety, adjustment disorder, posttraumatic stress, and suicidal ideations and substance abuse behaviors to name a few (Waitzkin, et al., 2018). Physiological concerns may also arise when mental health concerns are not attended to within the military which primarily have been supported to be exhibited as unsolicited weight gain, insomnia, and maladaptive coping strategies (Maclean, 2012; Heyat, Akhtar, Ansari, Khan, Alkahtani, Khan, & Lai, 2021). A sample of 102 adult participants (ages 18-59) were recruited from a Southern state Army National Guard unit. For the first research question, a linear regression model was utilized to investigate the relationship between General Self-Efficacy and Mental Health Confidence. The first research question asked: 1) Does general self-efficacy have a positive correlation with mental health confidence? The second research question utilized a path analysis primarily focused on a mediation model. The second research question investigated: 2) Does mental health confidence have a strong correlation with help-seeking intentions and help-seeking attitudes mediated by military stigma or self-reliance? Measures included were the General Self-Efficacy Scale, Mental Health Confidence Scale, Help-Seeking Intention Scale, Help-Seeking Attitude Scale, Military Stigma Scale, Self-Reliance Scale, and a series of military service-related questions and demographic items. The gathered data was analyzed utilizing linear regression and mediation path analysis. Results from the Analyses chapter support that General Self-Efficacy does have a significant and positive correlation to Mental Health Confidence; as well, Military Stigma did significantly partially mediate and Self-Reliance-Counterdependence fully mediate the relationship between Mental Health Confidence and Help-Seeking Intentions. Implications and considerations for theory, clinical practice, and future research are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Help-Seeking, Mental Health Confidence, Military, Military Stigma, Self-Efficacy, Self-Reliance
Martin Swanbrow Becker, Professor Directing Dissertation; Thomas Joiner, University Representative; Deborah Ebener, Committee Member; Lyndsay Jenkins, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Gender and Racial Differences among College Athletes in Re-Injury Anxiety, Coping Strategies, and Psychological Distress Due to Injury

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Re-injury anxiety is common among college student-athletes at the varsity (Podlog et al., 2011; Putukian, 2016) and club (Watanabe et al., 2023) level. Coping with sport injury has been studied in previous reviews (Putukian, 2016; Sims & Mulcahey, 2018) and literature (Kontos et al., 2013; Schlierf & Vosloo, 2017), but the relationship between re-injury anxiety, coping, and psychological distress due to injury has rarely been studied. The purpose of this study was to observe relationships among the variables of re-injury anxiety, coping strategy, and psychological distress due to injury given an athlete's gender and race. Student-athletes (n=80) were recruited from universities in the United States. A MANCOVA and PROCESS Model mediation analysis were used to analyze the data. Results indicated that female athletes reported significantly more psychological distress due to injury compared to male athletes (t(78) = -2.444, p = .008). Avoidance coping strategies (e.g., denial, venting, substance use, behavioral disengagement, and self-blame) partially mediated the relationship between re-injury anxiety and psychological distress due to injury (B = .199, C.I. [.0096, .3779]). Implications for research, theory, and practice are discussed given the results of the study.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational and Psychological Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Deborah Ebener, Professor Directing Dissertation; Amy Kim, University Representative; Debra Osborn, Committee Member; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Food Intake in Response to Positive and Negative Mood in Eating Disorders
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Is There Too Much of a Good Thing?

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Binge eating, defined as consuming an objectively large amount of food and experiencing a sense of loss of control, is a hallmark of bulimia nervosa (BN) and binge eating disorder (BED). Affect regulation theory posits that negative emotion commonly triggers binge eating episodes, consistent with considerable empirical evidence. More recent theory and research suggests that high arousal positive affect may also constitute an important catalyst for eating pathology. However, limited empirical work has examined this premise. In the present study, data came from a longitudinal study examining biobehavioral differences between women with diagnosed eating disorders (n=226) and controls (n=64). Participants made ratings of current affect and arousal as well as physiological states just prior to and following consuming an ad lib test meal. As expected, the eating disorder group consumed more food and endorsed higher pre- and post-meal negative affect, as well as lower positive affect, compared to controls. However, the eating disorder and control groups did not differ on arousal, and neither affect nor arousal predicted amount of food consumed. Study confounds, notably the lack of experimental mood manipulation, may partly explain null findings. Given notable confounds, and given that individuals with eating disorders began with lower positive affect than controls and further decreased in positive affect following eating, future research should continue to explore the influence of negative and positive affect and arousal on eating pathology.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Pamela Keel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Debra Fadool, University Representative; Thomas Joiner, Committee Member; Jesse Cougle, Committee Member; Ashby Plant, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Pepper Games and the Gospel of Pleasure
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Baseball and Religion in the Israelite House of David

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study focuses on the Israelite House of David, an early twentieth century American communal society in Benton Harbor, Michigan. It argues that they invested in pleasure as a form of embodied religious expression through practices such as baseball. Playing baseball generated excitement and aroused intense feelings, which could be understood as either favorable or problematic. Baseball, played with properly managed pleasure, provided a means through which to assert themselves against other groups and to generate publicity. In the Israelite House of David, a Progressive Era emphasis on masculine virility merged with a renewed commitment to a Victorian era emphasis on internal piety. As American society moved from a culture of character to a culture of personality, and from an economy centered on production to one focused on consumption, the Israelite House of David fully embraced the moment. By including the Israelite House of David and their baseball teams in the story of American religion, sports, and citizenship, a new picture emerges that brings into focus the deliberative fundamentalist opposition to popular modes of "muscular Christianity" and the conscious revolt against assimilation goals. It also reveals the exhaustive efforts that such groups undertook to construct their ideal society and implement their own social reforms.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Religion in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
American Religious History, Communal Societies, Israelite House of David, Muscular Christianity, New Religious Movements, Sports History
John Corrigan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Mark Winegardner, University Representative; Michael J. McVicar, Committee Member; Matthew Goff, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigating Biological Carbon Pump Variability and Functionality
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Application of Old and New Conceptual Frameworks across Spatial and Temporal Scales

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The ocean is a central cog in the global carbon cycle, playing a major role in regulating the Earth's climate. A prominent mechanism driving uptake and sequestration of carbon is the "biological carbon pump" (BCP). Driven by newly sinking particulate organic matter (POM), the BCP sequesters atmospheric CO2 to the deep ocean via the transport of photosynthetically-fixed organic carbon from the euphotic zone (EZ) to depth. While there are multiple recognized controls on the BCP including the EZ biogeochemical environment (e.g., nutrient source and availability, temperature etc.), and food-web structure (e.g., zooplankton abundance), large uncertainties of the BCP magnitude remain due to sparse sampling and poor constraints on the mesopelagic remineralization rate. We apply two approaches to constrain BCP variability and functionality across spatial and temporal scales, including the implementation of the nitrogen (N) isotope (δ15N) mass balance approach to estimate the contribution of N2 fixation to export production in the understudied western tropical South Pacific (WTSP), and the introduction of a new conceptual framework, the molecular-level 'diagenetic clock', that relates molecular stability patterns of sinking POM to bulk flux metrics. Using geochemically-derived δ15N budgets, we quantified rates of N2 fixation, a new N source, and its importance for supporting export production in the WTSP, where shallow hydrothermal iron sources support EZ primary productivity. Results from the δ15N budgets yield high N2 fixation rates (up to 638 µmol N m-2 d-1) at stations impacted by hydrothermal activity, supporting the majority (64 to 92%) of export production in late spring. These results are consistent with contemporaneous 15N2 fixation rate estimates and molecular work describing high Trichodesmium spp. abundances associated with elevated N2 fixation rates. Further, the δ15N of sinking particulates collected over an annual cycle revealed temporally distinct N sources supporting export. This large N2 fixation-supported export flux describes the WTSP as a region of elevated carbon export, at least in the late spring, describing a more efficient BCP. Further, this sinking flux of reduced isotopic composition (~ -1‰) can have large implications for South Pacific basin-scale N mass balances. Further, we introduce a new conceptual framework, the molecular-level 'diagenetic clock', from a novel dataset of the molecular composition of sinking POM across dominant marine biogeochemical environments (i.e., nutrient-poor oligotrophic and nutrient-rich upwelling sites). We find distinct and inverse associations in molecular-level N-content and organic matter stability (the 'Island of Stability' formulae, IOS) across a productivity gradient from coastal upwelling to oligotrophic conditions. This is evident in the elevated N-content and low IOS relative abundance (%RA) observed at the coastal upwelling site that persisted to depths >400 m, describing a fast flux of very 'fresh' organic matter in this region. Further, the strong particulate flux-IOS correlation (R2 = 0.91 and p <0.001), describes an emergent, ubiquitous pattern of epi- and mesopelagic diagenesis across productivity regimes and depths. These findings highlight that although sinking speeds and EZ microbial diagenetic length scales vary across biogeochemical regions, the general trajectory of organic matter towards increased stability underpins a global ocean molecular signature of sinking POM and describes an emergent framework to assess BCP functionality through particle stability gradients across trophic regimes. We then applied the diagenetic clock to a Southern Ocean dataset, spatially across the Subtropical Convergence Zone and temporally in the Antarctic Zone (AZ) summer, where unique food-web structures and nutrient cycling regimes were observed. The Southern Ocean samples conformed with the molecular-level diagenetic clock, and we observed a strong flux-IOS correlation (R2 = 0.68 and p <0.001). However, the range of IOS %RA largely aligned with temporal and spatial changes in primary productivity and associated primary processing (i.e., krill versus salp grazing and fecal pellet production). Notably, at the Subtropical Convergence Zone where a salp-dominant food web structure was observed, unique bioavailable molecular signatures (N- and sulphur (S)-enrichment) worked to reduce the IOS-flux gradient. While in the krill-dominant food web structure of the AZ, a strong bioavailable to stable gradient with regards to IOS and heteroatom %RA, was observed over the temporal summer. Although the degree to which fecal pellets drive IOS signatures remains unclear, we postulate that the different grazing and digestive mechanisms employed by krill and salps may cause distinct fecal pellet IOS signatures, potentially explaining the observed variability between the two regions. These findings in this dissertation have clear implications for our understanding of marine carbon sequestration, specifically constraining export production in an understudied region and offering new insights into microbes' roles in altering mesopelagic flux attenuation, largely determining relative remineralization length scales and thus carbon sequestration duration.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
biological carbon pump, carbon export, molecular-level composition, nitrogen budget

Michael R. Stukel, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Robert G. M. Spencer, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Sherry A. Southerland, University Representative; Jeffrey P. Chanton, Committee Member; Sarah E. Fawcett, Committee Member; Sven A. Kranz, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Burnout in Learning Design and Performance Improvement Professionals

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This mixed methods study explores burnout in individuals who work in learning design and performance improvement. Fifty-three learning professionals completed a survey that gauged the degree of burnout, burnout causes and supports, and job satisfaction. Ten of those participants took part in interviews to collect further qualitative data. The data showed that the top factors for workplace burnout were poor leadership, back-to-back meetings, working too many hours, and the inability to disconnect from work. The top-rated supports counter the top-rated causes, each serving as a remedy to the causes, such as taking time off to counterbalance working too many hours. While no relationship was found between the degree of burnout based on the subscales of exhaustion, cynicism, professional efficacy, and time in role; there was a strong positive relationship between exhaustion and cynicism when correlated to job satisfaction, and a moderate positive correlation with professional efficacy and job satisfaction. By knowing the causes that affect workplace burnout, individuals and employers can better address burnout in the workplace through prevention or mitigation. In addition, knowing the support these individuals want can aid in addressing burnout when it is already present in the workplace or put it in place during periods when it may be anticipated and help employees find ways to address it themselves. Addressing burnout has the potential to increase their employees' job satisfaction, and, considering the impact of the work learning professionals do, it can have significant trickle-down effects on all those they service.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Burnout, burnout causes, burnout supports, job satisfaction, Learning Professionals, Workplace burnout
Secil Caskurlu, Professor Directing Dissertation; George Williamson, University Representative; Vanessa Dennen, Committee Member; Allan Jeong, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Molecular Characterization of Polyfunctinal Heteroatom Compounds in Ultracomplex Mixtures by 21 Tesla Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry (21 T FT-ICR MS)

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The work described herein summarizes the molecular characterization across two categories of complex mixtures, petroleum photoproducts and non-terrestrial soluble organic material (SOM). Ultrahigh resolution Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry (FT-ICR MS) uniquely provides the resolving power and mass accuracy necessary for molecular formula assignments in a variety of complex mixtures. Over the years, FT-ICR MS has proven useful to petroleum characterization, but increased compositional complexity introduced through weathering processes after spills makes it essential. The weathering process of photooxidation has been identified as a primary factor in phototransformation reactions, resulting in increased complexity of the transformed products. Photooxidation generates new oil-soluble, interfacial, and water-soluble materials through increased oxygenation. Creation of these materials is detrimental to the environment and has been classified as an emerging contaminate. Increased understanding of how these materials interact with each other is necessary to combat the effects on the environment after oil spills. The complexity of organic material generated in space has proven just as complex as terrestrial dissolved organic material (DOM) or petroleum with tens of thousands of molecular formulas assigned for each spectrum. Therefore, FT-ICR MS is a necessity for characterization to increase the comprehensive knowledge of these types of samples, especially as the second space race begins. Most lunar research was conducted shortly after the first space race but used low resolution mass spectrometry instrumentation relative to techniques available today. Unlike lunar regolith research, meteorite characterization has continued throughout the years as new and more exciting samples landed. This provides a great starting point to begin lunar analysis and excellent test samples for the development of new techniques before astronauts return to the lunar surface within the decade. Chapter 1 introduces terrestrial and non-terrestrial complex mixtures along with how FT-ICR MS is utilized in molecular characterization. Separations often used in terrestrial complex mixtures such as petroleum and dissolved organic matter are also introduced. Chapter 2 explores the separations used on the photooxidized products generated through the irradiation of a heavy vacuum gas oil (HVGO). The oil-soluble and interfacial material is characterized to understand how the acidic species contribute to interfacial material formation. Chapter 3 continues analysis of the HVGO photoproducts with the investigation of the water-soluble material. Utilization of a new DOM separation provides the first separation of water-soluble material based off aromaticity and increased oxygenation. The results are then compared to the results obtained from Chapter 2. These two chapters provide a comprehensive analysis of photoproducts generated in the oil-soluble, interfacial, and water-soluble materials across a range of irradiation periods. Chapter 4 describes the development of a new sequential solvent extraction and analysis method for SOM from meteorites. This work focuses on the comprehensive molecular characterization to expand the knowledge of meteorite SOM. Chapter 5 utilizes the separation method created in Chapter 4 to extract and characterize SOM from lunar regolith returned by the Apollo 12 and 16 lander missions. This work is the first time ultra-high resolution mass spectrometry has been used for analysis of these materials. Collectively, Chapter 4 and 5 demonstrate the necessity of FT-ICR MS in organic characterization of these samples and specifically the 21 T FT-ICR MS at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
FT-ICR MS, Lunar regolith, Meteorites, Petroleum, Photooxidation, Soluble organic material
Alan G. Marshall, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jeffery Chanton, University Representative; Christian Bleiholder, Committee Member; Michael G. Roper, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Stories to Read Aloud to Strangers on the Bus

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Stories to Read Aloud to Strangers on the Bus is a collection of published and unpublished short stories ranging from 100-word "flash fiction" to 10,000 words. The emphasis in this manuscript is on variety and eclecticism---of genre, of style, of voice, and even of form. I wanted to avoid a technically-proficient but dull Default Collection composed of a dozen ten-page stories that all read similarly. In keeping with the diversity of style and voice, these stories also range across multiple genres and hybrid genres. The majority are straightforward "literary fiction," whatever that means. Others are speculative fiction—itself a many-headed beast, this includes magical realism, Borges-inspired philosophical fiction, historical fiction, and even one whiz-bang sci-fi story in the vein of Isaac Asimov. As with the diversity of styles, it is my aim that these disparate genres complement each other rather than detract, and make for a reading experience that is more interesting and exciting for its variety, akin to eating a heart-shaped box of chocolates after you've lost the little leaflet they slip under the lid telling you which bonbons are coconut and which bonbons have explosives hidden underneath them. (The manuscript does not reveal in the table of contents which short stories have explosives hidden underneath them.) Despite this project of emphasizing disparity (disparate times call for disparate measures), the stories are still tied together in other ways, by recurring themes and threads. One unifying element across the stories is humor. Every story in the collection contains some comic element, even if not all are strictly comedies. Though I have published a handful of more serious solemn short stories, these have not been included. Likewise, though a small number of the stories are direct parodies or style imitations of some of my favorite authors, I have also not included anything that comes across more as a "humor piece" than a "story" in which the narrative is first and foremost. The stories are also united by recurring elements not of style but substance, the ideas I continually come back to as a writer and which are necessarily dealt with differently in different genres. For example, both "The False Law" and "Birth of Venus" are narratives concerned on some level with truth and falsehood and the relationship of representational art to the real world, but because one is gothic literary fiction and the other a campy sci-fi parable, they are able to do different things with the same subject matter—for example, the literary story is better equipped to follow the interior thoughts of an artist experiencing a crisis of faith, while the speculative story can better explore dramatic counterfactual premises which would be out of place or unbelievable in realist fiction ("What if a dictator obsessed with the truth prosecuted poets for perjury?"). Juxtaposing these different genres next to each other might, if successful, produce an effect like a cubist painting, whereby the same object is viewed from multiple angles at once. Likewise, both "Lie Lightly" and "Tall Tale" are stories in which the narrator is an inveterate liar, but one is told by a folksy 1800s raconteur and the other by a cynical Westchester stage magician. The dreamlike, impressionistic style of the first story creates a feeling of postmodern uncertainty and unreliability which mirrors the character's confusion, whereas the more comic, folkloric genre of the second more subtly deconstructs this deconstruction to demonstrate that this unreliability is not some modern innovation but rather the fundamental characteristic of fiction: All fiction is, by definition, lies.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
Mark Winegardner, Professor Directing Thesis; Skip Horack, Committee Member; Barbara Hamby, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: How to Go around Single Particle Cryo-EM Challenges

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Structural biology is a fundamental tool for addressing critical biological and medical questions. Cryogenic electron microscopy (Cryo-EM) is a powerful technique within this field, and although still in its early stages, it has become increasingly versatile over recent years. This thesis presents two case studies of challenging protein structures analyzed using Cryo-EM, employing alternative methods to extract valuable structural data. The study focuses on a minimal heterodimer from the sulfite reductase enzyme and the methionine tRNA synthetase (MetRS) enzyme from Mycoplasma penetrans. Additionally, the thesis introduces a novel technique to overcome significant challenges associated with Cryo-EM single-particle sample preparation. The first case study examines a minimal heterodimer from the sulfite reductase enzyme, which plays a critical role in reducing sulfite to sulfide in sulfur metabolism. Traditional Cryo-EM techniques encountered significant obstacles due to the enzyme's inherent instability and tendency to aggregate. To address these issues, various alternative approaches were employed, including optimizing buffer conditions and incorporating mild detergents. These modifications significantly reduced aggregation, and advanced classification algorithms were used to segregate different conformational states, allowing for the reconstruction of a high-resolution map of the minimal heterodimer. This successful resolution provided detailed insights into the enzyme's active site and laid the groundwork for further functional studies. The second case study involves the MetRS enzyme from Mycoplasma penetrans, which is essential for the aminoacylation of tRNA with methionine, a critical step in protein synthesis. Analyzing MetRS using conventional Cryo-EM techniques proved particularly challenging due to its high nucleic acid content and structural heterogeneity. Initial attempts with standard preparation methods resulted in significant aggregation and poor particle distribution. To overcome these challenges, various alternative preservation methods were tested, including homemade graphene grids and the Chameleon plunger. These methods significantly improved sample quality and data acquisition, enabling the resolution of a high-quality map of the core dimer, although the catalytic domain remained elusive in the high-resolution maps. Further analysis using CryoSPARC and CryoDRGN revealed significant motion and heterogeneity in the catalytic domain. Attempts to stabilize this domain with tRNA, methionine, ATP, and cross-linking agents were partially successful, with some treatments producing more defined 2D class averages but also adding noise to the data. Despite these challenges, the final model provided detailed insights into the enzyme's structure, including the helical bundle of one catalytic domain, offering potential targets for further stabilization and structural studies. Additionally, this thesis introduces a novel technique for Cryo-EM single-particle sample preparation, addressing major challenges such as protein aggregation and poor particle distribution. This technique involves the use of homemade graphene grids, which provide good particle dispersion and contrast, and the Chameleon plunger, which allows for plunging at high protein concentrations, producing grids with thin ice and high particle density. These innovations significantly improve sample quality and data acquisition, proving that having alternative methods for sample preparation can change the direction of structural studies and produce intact samples from previously intractable ones. In summary, this thesis demonstrates the versatility and potential of Cryo-EM in overcoming significant structural biology challenges. The examination of two difficult protein structures and the introduction of a novel sample preparation technique, it highlight the importance of innovative approaches in advancing our understanding of complex biological macromolecules.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Institute of Molecular Biophysics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
