mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Read with Care
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Aided AAC Modeling Intervention for Young Children with ASD and CCN

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Young children with ASD who produce fewer than 50 words require additional supports and explicit interventions to acquire language using an augmented language communication (AAC) system and increase their participation and communication during shared book reading activities. This nonconcurrent multiple baseline study across participants investigated the relationship between the Read with CARE + Aided AAC Modeling intervention (Intervention A) on the total number of communicative acts three young children (ages 4:11 to 5:9) with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) with complex communication needs (CCN) produce during shared book reading. This multicomponent intervention combines responsive language interventions and evidence-based practices effective for children with ASD and CCN. The Read with CARE instructional sequence is adapted from Nelson's (2010) shared book reading procedure (i.e., CAR; Comment, Ask Questions, Respond) and is paired with expectant delay, aided AAC modeling, and an error correction procedure (i.e., mand-modeling). Children whose data showed little increasing trend or high levels of variability during Intervention A, were introduced to a second, intensified intervention (Intervention B) in which AAC symbol vocabulary was pre-taught during book reading session. All participants increased their AAC use over time and were able to maintain this skill three weeks post intervention. Two participants also increased their use of verbal speech across phases. Percent of Goal (PoGo; Ferron et al., 2020) calculations indicate large effects for two out of three participants with the Read with CARE + Aided AAC Modeling intervention (Intervention A) and moderately large to large effects from Intervention B. In addition, pre-teaching AAC symbol vocabulary prior to book reading sessions provided some added benefit for all three participants. These findings suggest that the Read with CARE + aided AAC Modeling intervention is effective for children with ASD and CCN, especially when implemented consistently.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Special Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Augmentative and Alternative Communication, Autism, Complex Communication Needs, Early Childhood Education, Emergent Literacy, Shared Book Reading
Veronica P. Fleury, Professor Directing Dissertation; Carla Wood, University Representative; Jenny Root, Committee Member; Lindsay Dennis, Committee Member; Kelly Farquharson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring Social and Emotional Learning Policies and Instructional Materials in Florida Public School Districts
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Qualitative Content Analysis

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Social emotional learning (SEL) is a term that encompasses a set of essential life skills including self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, relationship skills, and responsible decision-making (Collaborative for Academic Social and Emotional Learning [CASEL], 2024, para. 1). Despite growing interest, many school districts struggle with integrating sustainable and meaningful SEL instruction (Albright et al., 2019; Jones & Bouffard, 2012; Muñiz, 2020). In 2019, the Florida Senate passed the Comprehensive Health Education (CHE) instructional policy to enhance K-12 education, responding to the MSD tragedy and the 2017 Florida Youth Rish Behavior Survey's alarming mental health statistics (U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2017). The 2021 policy revision emphasized concepts of mental and emotional health, highlighting character traits and resiliency in student development. In 2022, Florida's House Bill 7 introduced new language within the CHE policy, emphasizing the need for instruction to aligned with SEL core competencies, yet without using the term SEL (Individual Freedom Act, 2022, p. 18). The bill offered minimal program and resource selection guidance, leaving districts to navigate independently. Despite this legislation on competencies, Florida politicians were in the national spotlight for distancing themselves from the term SEL due to political and social implications (Fittes, 2023). In this larger political context, my dissertation analyzed how Florida's 67 school districts have interpreted and adapted to policy shifts in CHE instruction over four academic years (2019–2023) focusing on the documented instructional materials for Resiliency Education and Character Education. A qualitative content analysis identified 161 uploaded instructional materials; 87% of programs were evidence-based for Resiliency Education, and 89% of programs were evidence-based for Character Development. Regarding alignment to CASEL's SEL core competencies, 38% of programs for Resiliency Education and 51% of programs for Character Development aligned to CASEL's SEL core competencies. Moreover, 45% of instructional materials aligned to Florida's new Resiliency Education standards. The study also found that more instructional materials were documented for Resiliency Education (required to document) than for Character Development (not required to document). Yet, more CASEL-endorsed programs were documented for Character Development. Subtle changes in districts documentation were observed over 4 years of CHE policy implementation. Compliance rates for required documentation of instructional materials for Resiliency Education were 88% in 2020–2021, 97% in 2021–2022, and 98% in 2022–2023. Although there were few subtle changes in the compliance rate, there were no major changes in how districts documented their instructional materials across the various demographic make-up for Resiliency Education instruction as the CHE policy shifted over the 4 years of the policy. Large districts, those with above-median socioeconomic status, and districts appointed superintendents all achieved 100% compliance with CHE policy requirements over the 4 years. Orange School District was the only district out of the five largest districts to document a high level of complexity among their programs for Character Education. I propose recommendations for policymakers, the Florida Department of Education, district leaders, and school-based educators to support districts in choosing instructional materials that are both evidence-based and aligned to CASEL's SEL core competencies. Additionally, I recommend conducting implementation studies to evaluate the effectiveness of these materials, thereby providing Florida school districts with deeper insights into evidence-based, high-quality programming that aligns with the CHE policy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Stacey Rutledge, Professor Directing Dissertation; Robert Eklund, University Representative; Akiba Motoko, Committee Member; Jeffrey Milligan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Core-Collapse Supernova Theory
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Explosion Mechanism and Explodability Conditions

mods:mods.mods:abstract: One of the major challenges in stellar evolution theory is to understand how massive stars die. Most massive stars ($M > 8M_\odot$) undergo core collapse at the end of their lives. Some explode as a Core-collapse Supernova explosion, leaving behind a neutron star (NS), while others fail to explode and collapse to a black hole (BH). Understanding what is the explosion mechanism and predicting which massive stars explode have been two main questions in CCSN theory for decades. Answering these questions is key in understanding nucleosynthesis, NS and BH formation and distributions. To develop a better understanding of the explosion mechanism we develop: 1. an analytic theory of which stars explode and which collapse to BH and 2. develop a next-generation CCSN-simulation code~-~ Phoebus. We first derive an analytic theory for the explosion condition in spherical symmetry. This explosion condition is called the force explosion condition (FEC) and considers the imbalance of forces needed to for a successful explosion; dominant effects are neutrino heating and gravitational forces. We tested the FEC in three different ways. In the first, we compared the FEC with the semi-analytic, steady-state solutions of \cite{BURROWS1993}. In the second, we tested it with one-dimensional (1D) CCSN simulations with light-bulb neutrino approximation. In the third, we tested it with 1D radiation-hydrodynamic simulations. The FEC has passed all of these tests which indicates that it is an accurate measure of the explodability of spherical CCSN explosions. State-of-the-art simulations show that successful CCSN explosions require additional multi-dimensional effects, in particular neutrino-driven convection and turbulent dissipation. Motivated by the success of the spherical FEC, we generalized the simple model by including these important multi-dimensional effects. This generalized condition is called the FEC+ and promises to predict explodability of multi-dimensional simulations. Adding multi-dimensional effects in the model generates two additional terms that make the critical threshold for multi-dimensional simulations $\sim 25 \%$ smaller compared to 1D simulations. This matches the results of previous multi-dimensional simulations. Another important key is to develop fast multi-dimensional CCSN simulations that enable parametric studies using three-dimensional (3D) simulations. This is now possible with next-generation GPU capable codes. We develop Phoebus~-~ a GPU-capable code that solves the GR MHD equations and includes a wide array of neutrino transport capabilities, including moments and Monte Carlo transport. Phoebus is an improvement both in terms of physics and performance. It enables CCSN simulations that complete $10-100$ times faster than current multi-dimensional simulations. This will enable us to perform long-overdue systematic studies of the explosion mechanism as well as to test the analytic predictions with series of 3D explosions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Jeremiah W. Murphy, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric P. Chassignet, University Representative; Kevin Huffenberger, Committee Member; Peter Hoeflich, Committee Member; Harrison B. Prosper, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Constraining New Physics via Improved Global Fits of the Standard Model Effective Field Theory

mods:mods.mods:abstract: We present a comprehensive study of the dimension-6 Standard Model Effective Field Theory (SMEFT) aimed at constraining new physics through a global fit of a broad selection of collider observables. In particular we focus on electroweak and Higgs-boson production cross sections and decay rates, evaluate them in the SMEFT including state-of-the-art Standard Model predictions and up to quadratic terms in the dimension-6 operators, and use our results to test the consistency of the SMEFT approach and to constrain its free parameters (Wilson coefficients) via a global fit of collider data that also include top-quark observables. Through an incremental approach, we test the constraining power of the global fits due to different sets of observables, as well as the impact of theoretical refinements that include in our case the evolution of the Wilson coefficients from the scale of new physics to the electroweak scale and the consideration of dimension-6 quadratic corrections in the perturbative expansion of the SMEFT. Overall, the global analysis presented in this work already provides meaningful constraints on the SMEFT and supports the validity of the SMEFT approach for a broad spectrum of extensions of the Standard Model. It hence sets the framework for future studies that will further benefit from constantly evolving theoretical predictions and the outstanding precision made available by the high-luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC).
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Laura Reina, Professor Directing Dissertation; Philip L. Bowers, University Representative; Rachel Yohay, Committee Member; Fernando Febres Cordero, Committee Member; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Vanity Limbo
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Poems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Vanity Limbo is a full-length poetry collection about growing up as a non-heteronormative individual, contending with that realization into adulthood, and ultimately embracing oneself. Distinct voice, vivid imagery, playfulness, self-deprecation, and humor dominate the narrative arc of the manuscript, which moves largely from adulthood, young adulthood, and back to childhood, tracing the overarching speaker's life in reverse. Despite its dark themes, such as how not accepting oneself can lead to suicidal ideation, the manuscript contains moments of levity throughout and begins and ends on hopeful notes. Ultimately, the manuscript strives toward self-recovery, inspired by Ralph Waldo Emerson's belief that "[v]alor consists in the power of self-recovery, so that a man cannot have his flank turned, cannot be out-generalled, but put him where you will, he stands." The manuscript's overarching speaker stands, and he has this manuscript to prove it.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Barbara Hamby, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; James Kimbrell, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Martin Kavka, University Representative; Andrew Epstein, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Evaluating Early Intervention Strategies for High-Risk Newborns
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Content Analysis of Florida's Early Steps and Sing with Me Programs

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine a generalized and a music therapy-based early intervention program for high-risk newborns and compare program structures and objectives. More specifically, Florida's Early Steps and Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare's Sing With Me programs were analyzed. A content analysis of 23 online resources was conducted to evaluate similarities and differences between both programs, identifying 14 research categories: location of services, governing body, funding sources, eligibility criteria, referral method, enrollment process, plan of care, developmental domains addressed, disciplines involved, session frequency, parent involvement, assessment procedures, termination process, and continued care. Of the resources analyzed, only 19 were utilized for the completion of this study as the remaining four contained repetitive information or did not address research topics. The results indicate unique characteristics and similarities between both programs, underscoring their effectiveness and value as early intervention strategies. This study highlights the need for further research in music therapy within early intervention and follow-up care for high-risk newborns. The findings suggest the potential for music therapy services to emerge as a universal early intervention program or an addition to state-based programs such as Early Steps.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
Early Interventioon, Early Steps, High-Risk Newborns, Music Therapy, Sing With Me
Lori Gooding, Professor Directing Thesis; Dawn Iwamasa, Committee Member; Kimberly VanWeelden, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Does Central Executive Training (CET) and/or Inhibitory Control Training (ICT) Improve Emotion Regulation for Children with ADHD?
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Randomized Controlled Trial

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Approximately 48-54% of children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) have impairing difficulties with emotion regulation, and these difficulties are not ameliorated by first-line ADHD treatments. Working memory and inhibitory control represent promising intervention targets given their functional, if not causal, links with ADHD-related emotion dysregulation. This preregistered randomized controlled trial tested whether two digital therapeutic training protocols that have been previously shown to improve working memory (Central Executive Training/CET) and inhibitory control (Inhibitory Control Training/ICT) can improve emotion regulation in a sample of 94 children with ADHD aged 8-13 years (M = 10.22, SD = 1.43; 76% White/non-Hispanic; 29 girls). Results of Bayesian mixed model ANOVAs indicated both treatment groups demonstrated significant decreases in emotion dysregulation relative to pre-treatment at immediate post-treatment (parent report; d=1.25, BF10=8.04x1013, p<.001), at 1-2 months after completing treatment (teacher report; d=0.99, BF10 = 1.22x106, p < .001), and at 2-4-month follow-up (parent report; d=1.22, BF10=1.15x1014, p<.001). Contrary to our hypotheses, the CET and ICT groups demonstrated equivalent reductions in emotion dysregulation and maintenance of effects. Exploratory analyses revealed that results were robust to control for informant expectancies, ADHD medication status/changes, in-person vs. at-home treatment, child age, and time from treatment completion to post-treatment ratings. Thus, it appears possible that both working memory and inhibitory control are causally linked with ADHD-related emotion dysregulation. However, these hypotheses should be investigated with active control conditions that do not train executive functions prior to making decisions about the clinical utility of CET/ICT for the treatment of emotion dysregulation in ADHD.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
ADHD, cognitive training, emotion regulation, executive function, inhibitory control, working memory

Michael J. Kofler, Professor Directing Dissertation; S. Kathleen Krach, University Representative; Walter Boot, Committee Member; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Christopher Patrick, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sexual Selection, Population Structure, and Gene Flow in the Trinidadian Guppy (Poecilia Reticulata)
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Insights for the Conservation of Genetic Variation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The diversity of life has fascinated evolutionary biologists since the conception of the field. Particularly captivating is the paradox of phenotypic variation found within a species: trait variation is required for adaptation, yet adaptation can erode this variation over time. While processes such as gene flow, mutation, and balancing selection can maintain genetic variation, quantifying how each of these processes proceed in natural populations remains poorly understood. Negative frequency-dependent selection in which rare phenotypes benefit from fitness advantages compared to common phenotypes has been implicated in the maintenance of several discrete polymorphisms in the wild. However, many ecologically significant traits are quantitative and the ecological mechanisms maintaining these polymorphisms are challenging to identify. One well-known example of a highly polymorphic trait is the color pattern of male Trinidadian guppies (Poecilia reticualta). Substantial evidence implicates female preference for rare or unfamiliar color patterns in the maintenance of color pattern variation. Yet, complex, highly polygenic traits, such as color pattern, can be subject to different selective pressures and warrants further exploration. One process that may promote or inhibit the maintenance of color pattern variation in guppies is male-male competition. When males compete more strongly toward phenotypically similar males, this should lead to a mating advantage for rare male types. This form of male-biased aggression can have profound effects on the maintenance of variation in sexually selected traits. In Chapter 2 of my dissertation, I explicitly tested whether male competitive behavior operates in negative frequency-dependent manner. Using three phenotypically distinct genetic lines, I asked whether males compete more strongly with similar competitor males compared to dissimilar. I found males were almost twice as likely to compete with dissimilar rivals and females prefer less competitive males. These findings suggest male competitive behaviors should promote positive frequency-dependent selection, and potentially oppose negative frequency-dependent selection imposed by female mate choice. In addition to various selective forces simultaneously operating in nature, different evolutionary forces affect trait variation. For example, varying rates of gene flow among patchy environments can affect the fate of alleles and their maintenance in the population. How gene flow is affected in systems that exhibit negative frequency-dependent selection is not clear. In Chapter 3 of my dissertation, I assessed whether male color pattern rarity contributed to the genetic rescue of small, inbred guppy populations. Using data from a long-term mark-recapture experiment in which genetically divergent individuals migrated into small recipient populations, I found color pattern rarity enhanced the reproductive and mating success of males with intermediate hybrid indices. Results from this project provide important insight into the potential selective process that contributed to hybrid vigor. In Chapter 4, I identified a potential behavioral mechanism responsible for gene flow within natural guppy populations. I explicitly tested whether immigrant males with unfamiliar color patterns benefited from increased female preference and evasion of male-male competition. I found immigrant males with unfamiliar color patterns were indeed more preferred by females and were subject to less competition than resident males. I also found color patterns tend to diverge among pools along increased geographic distances. Thus, dispersal and negative frequency-dependent selection likely promote gene flow and aid in the maintenance of genetic variation within populations. Whether male-male competition and female mate choice act in concordance with one another to select for the same trait, work in opposition by selecting for different extremes of the same trait, or act on different traits entirely can be informative for sexual selection results in complex and exaggerated male secondary sexual traits. In Chapter 5, I asked whether male-male competition and female mate choice act on the same male traits in guppies. I found evidence that males rely on different elements of guppy color pattern (increased black coloration and decreased orange) for initiating and winning competitive outcomes than what is preferred by females. These results substantiate my finding in Chapter 2 that males are more likely to compete with dissimilar rivals and provide a potential reason for why: males seem to be more successful when they exhibit greater phenotypic differences with their competitor. The proximate mechanism for such a competitive decision remains unknown. In conclusion, my dissertation characterizes the role male-male competition plays in maintenance of color pattern variation in guppies and suggest the two modes of sexual selection may be at odds. I also provide evidence that negative frequency-dependent selection likely contributed to the genetic rescue of small, inbred guppy populations and identified behavioral mechanisms that should promote gene flow in natural populations. More causal analyses are needed to determine the long-term fitness effects of male-male competition in this system and future investigations of the ecological scenarios in which negative frequency-dependent selection may be more likely to enhance beneficial gene flow into highly inbred populations should be performed. Overall, my work highlights the importance of considering the complex ecological and evolutionary interactions occurring in natural populations, particularly for those systems in which we hope to conserve.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Color pattern, Genetic variation, Guppies, Male-male competition, Poecilia reticulata, Sexual selection
Kimberly A. Hughes, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michelle Arbeitman, University Representative; Joseph Travis, Committee Member; Emily DuVal, Committee Member; Scott Burgess, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revisionist History
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Machine Learning Approach to Reexamine the Psychological Continuum Model and Its Derivative Staging Algorithm

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Sport is a transformative force, uniting people globally from various socio-economic backgrounds. Individuals develop psychological connections with sport objects (e.g., teams, leagues, athletes) to fulfill various needs and desires, enriching their lives. Funk and James (2001) developed the Psychological Continuum Model (PCM) to understand how individuals connect with a sport object. The PCM is a stage-based framework outlining four hierarchical stages of psychological connection: Awareness, Attraction, Attachment, and Allegiance. The PCM has been refined over the past two decades to better understand psychological connections in different sport and recreation contexts. Funk and James (2006) expanded the PCM to include developmental progression with inputs, processes, and outputs functioning between stages. Beaton et al. (2009) further operationalized the PCM by using the construct of sport involvement, categorizing sport consumers into the PCM stages based on dimensions of pleasure, centrality, and sign. While these dimensions offer a concise way to stage individuals within the PCM, literature suggests that involvement should also consider perceived risk dimensions (Funk et al., 2004) and differentiate the symbolic involvement into internal sign (identity affirmation) and external sign (identity expression) components (Kyle et al., 2007). Laurent and Kapferer (1985) emphasized that all facets of involvement should be considered simultaneously as they influence consumer behavior differently. A comprehensive conceptualization and operationalization of sport involvement is necessary to thoroughly understand the underpinnings of the PCM framework and the nuances of psychological connections. Funk and James (2016) mention examining transition stages within the PCM framework to understand the psychological processes leading to higher levels of connection and to elucidate the developmental nature of the PCM framework. These transitions could provide insights into the mechanisms driving progression through the PCM, thereby refining the PCM framework. Understanding the transition between different PCM stages also helps comprehend the attitudes and behaviors shaping movement along the PCM framework, enhancing the understanding of consumer behavior in sport contexts (Baker et al., 2020). To answer the call, the present dissertation aimed to enhance the PCM framework and its derivative staging algorithm by re-examining the ontological, epistemological, and methodological foundations of the PCM framework. The dissertation incorporated a pilot study and a main study. The pilot study employed Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) to examine the psychometric properties of the survey instrument, measuring sport involvement dimensions (pleasure, centrality, internal sign, external sign, risk importance, and risk probability). The main study employed machine learning-based unsupervised clustering algorithms (Hierarchical and K-means clustering) to delineate clusters based on the sport involvement scores and employed Multivariate Analysis of Variance (MANOVA) to examine the predictive capacity of retained cluster solutions on individuals' attitudinal and behavioral characteristics. The results of the CFA procedure, especially McDonald's Omega and AVE values, provide evidence for reliability and validity. However, factor correlations between certain constructs were fairly high. In the main study, the results of the clustering analysis revealed a six-cluster solution, which led to the examination of two transition stages: Transition 1 between Awareness and Attraction, and Transition 2 between Attraction and Attachment. The MANOVA results showed significant differences in attitudinal and behavioral characteristics based on the six-cluster solution. However, the present dissertation has several limitations, including the presence of high factor correlations between certain sport involvement factors and the inability of risk involvement dimensions to effectively explain the variances in the strength of psychological connections among different clusters of sport spectators. The present dissertation represents the first effort to provide empirical evidence to examine the idea of transition stages within the existing PCM framework, particularly in the domain of sport spectatorship, offering avenues for future explorations in sport marketing scholarship. The present dissertation contributes to sport management research and practice by re-examining the PCM framework. Using machine learning-based unsupervised clustering algorithms offers a scalable, bespoke new avenue for sport management scholars and professionals to expand their understanding of the subtleties of dynamic transitional phases along the PCM framework. While the present study examined the psychological connection of individuals with the act of watching sport in general, future studies examining the transition stage-based PCM framework should emphasize specific sport objects (such as sport team or athletes) in their measurement of sport involvement to better elucidate and differentiate the different aspects of psychological connection developed with sport objects. By emphasizing the specific sport object, future research can more accurately capture the nuanced and multifaceted nature of sport involvement to study the impact of different dimensions along different stages of the PCM framework.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sport Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
artificial intelligence, clustering analysis, PCM, psychological connection
Wenjie James Du, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Jeffrey D. James, Committee Member; Amy C. H. Kim, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Comparison of Two Measurement Frameworks in the Context of Differential Item Functioning

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Many empirical and simulation-based studies have been conducted to compare cognitive diagnostic models (CDMs) with multidimensional item response theory (MIRT) models. Most of these studies have focused on the evaluation of either model-data fit or classification accuracy. A few studies have examined the equivalency of model parameters in the two measurement frameworks. All these studies have investigated deterministic inputs, noisy-and-gate and unidimensional IRT models. The two-parameter logistic compensatory MIRT (2PL-CMIRT) model and compensatory reparametrized unified model (CRUM) have a lot in common. None of the studies has compared the 2PL-CMIRT model and the CRUM in the context of differential item functioning (DIF). Moreover, there is a lack of studies that investigate the model-data fit of the 2PL-CMIRT model and the CRUM when they are retrofitted. The main purpose of this simulation study was to compare the performance of the Wald and likelihood ratio (LR) tests in both the 2PL-CMIRT model and the CRUM in detecting DIF when data were retrofitted. The Wald and LR tests using multiple group analysis approach are applicable to MIRT models and CDMs. A simulation study was conducted by manipulating factors as follows: number of items in a test (2 levels), correlation between the latent variables (2 levels), distribution of person parameters (3 levels), item parameters complexity (2 levels), DIF type (2 levels), and DIF magnitude (2 levels). The Wald test and LR test in the 2PL-CMIRT model performed well across all conditions in the no-DIF scenario. The Wald test and LR test in the CRUM controlled the Type I error rates across all the CRUM data generation conditions in no-DIF scenario. However, in the scenario where data were fitted to the CRUM, the Wald test and LR test had high Type I error rates in the presence of the group differences in the mean of ability. The powers of the Wald and LR tests in both models were acceptable under the conditions where no group differences in the mean of ability were present. This study also evaluated the model-data fit of both models under the simulation conditions when data were retrofitted. The limited information, M2, statistic, root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), and standardized root mean square residuals (SRMR) were used to evaluate model-data fit in the CDMs and MIRT models. More specifically, the performance of these fit indices across all simulation conditions were examined in the retrofitting scenarios. When data were generated from the 2PL-CMIRT model, the M2 statistic in the 2PL-CMIRT model controlled the Type I error rates across the no-DIF conditions while the M2 statistic in the CRUM had high rejection rates. RMSEA and SRMR values suggested adequate model-data fit in both models even though their values tended to be slightly higher in the CRUM. When data were generated from the CRUM, the Type I error rates of the M2 statistic in the CRUM were acceptable under the no-DIF scenario while the rejection rates of the M2 statistic in the 2PL-CMIRT model were high under the conditions where the size of the main effect parameter was medium. RMSEA and SRMR values suggested adequate model-data fit in both models.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cognitive Diagnostic Model, Differential Item Functioning, Item Response Theory, Likelihood Ratio Test, Wald Test
Yanyun Yang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Fred Huffer, University Representative; Russell Almond, Committee Member; Jeannine Turner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Neurobiology of Ketamine Seeking Behavior in Rats

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Ketamine (KET), a non-competitive N-Methyl-D-Aspartate receptor antagonist, is currently being used for numerous neuropsychiatric disorders. However, KET is addictive at higher doses and shown to have reinforcing properties. To date, no research has studied the addictive potential of repeated low-dose KET in both sexes. First, we characterized a dose-response of varied low doses of KET under an increasing work requirement self-administration (SA) model, followed by Reinstatement Test. Novel, and previously not reported, sex- and dose-dependent differences were present, including increased sensitivity of male Long Evan rats to the reinforcing properties of 0.25 mg/kg/infusion KET compared to female rats, which we chose to pursue. All male and female rats self-administering KET reinstated to cues, suggesting that KET is reinforcing even at lower doses. Subsequent quantification of cFos implicated the nucleus accumbens (NAc) core in mediating responsivity to KET cues. Our follow-up experiment took advantage of the distinct subpopulations of dopamine 1 or dopamine 2 receptor (D1R/D2R) containing GABAergic medium spiny neurons (MSNs) in the nucleus accumbens (NAc). Neuronal silencing of D1R- and D2R-containing MSNs was achieved with the Cre-dependent designer receptor exclusively activated by designer drugs (DREADDs) inhibitory hM4i virus and the designer drug Clozapine N-oxide (CNO) in transgenic rats. We used selective inhibition to examine the role of D1R- and D2R-MSNs in mediating cue-induced reinstatement to KET. We found that only D1R rats pre-treated with CNO failed to reinstate responding, while all other the CNO and vehicle pre-treated Wild-type and Drd2 rats did reinstate to cues previously paired with KET SA. Subsequent quantification and reduction of expression of cFos in viral transfected D1R cells confirmed our behavioral findings. Taken together, the selective inhibition of D1-receptor containing MSNs suggests that reinstatement to cues is mediated by this subpopulation of cells in the NAc Core.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy, Neuroscience.
Mohamed Kabbaj, Professor Directing Dissertation; Chris Schatschneider, University Representative; Michelle Arbeitman, Committee Member; Yi Zhou, Committee Member; Cathy Levenson, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: T1R-Independent Oronasal Detection of Carbohydrates in the Mouse Model
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Psychophysical Analysis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: It is uncontested that one key role of taste is to allow animals to detect food-derived chemicals and distinguish between beneficial nutrients and harmful toxins. In humans and many mammals, there are thought to be 5 basic taste qualities: sour, salty, umami, bitter, and sweet. "Sweet" is the adjective used by humans to describe the perceptual quality of sugars and non-caloric sweeteners. Sugars are one form of carbohydrates that make up an important portion of any diet. Other dietary carbohydrates include oligosaccharides and polysaccharides. Orosensory detection of carbohydrates is beneficial, as glucose is a crucial source of energy and required for normal brain function. Sugars interact with the T1R2 + T1R3 heterodimeric receptor found in taste receptor cells. There is evidence that strongly suggests the presence of T1R-independent mechanisms that contribute to carbohydrate detection for glucose and glucose polymers, but such processes remain to be fully understood. It has been shown that rodents avidly consume maltodextrins, or oligosaccharide mixtures, in short-term, long-term, and brief-access tests. Oligosaccharides appear to generate a qualitative perception distinct from the basic tastes, like sweet. Mice lacking one or both subunits of the T1R2 + T1R3 still display relatively normal preference for maltodextrins, yet have blunted responsiveness to sugars. In Chapter 2, we tested whether taste contributes to maltodextrin responsiveness. Mice with (WT) and without a functional T1R3 subunit (KO), underwent sham (SHAM) or lingual gustatory nerve transection (NX). Following surgery, mice were tested, after a ~23-h fast, on their concentration-dependent licking responses to Maltrin, a maltodextrin, and sucrose in a brief-access paradigm (10-s access trials, 30-min sessions), which minimizes postingestive influence on responsiveness. NX mice displayed significantly blunted lick responses and initiated fewer trials to Maltrin. The SHAM mice displayed similar responses to Maltrin across sessions, albeit KO-SHAM displayed lower lick responses at higher concentrations in the first session. The KO mice exhibited some concentration-dependent licking to sucrose, though attenuated. This could be due to prior exposure to Maltrin, and learning associated with postingestive cues. However, NX blunted this responsiveness in both WT and KO mice; in the KO-NX group severely so. The results suggest an intact chorda tympani and/or glossopharyngeal nerve are required for normal concentration-dependent licking to maltodextrin and sucrose solutions confirming a contribution of gustatory signals to the behavior. In Chapter 3, we explored the potential for a T1R-independent pathway to contribute to the taste detection of glucose. One proposed mechanism, the sodium glucose cotransporter-1 (SGLT1), has been found to be expressed in T1R3-positive taste receptor cells. This transporter is thought to primarily play a role in glucose absorption from the intestine and glucose-sensing in metabolic signaling pathways but may also contribute to T1R-independent signaling of the oral presence of glucose. Prior studies of peripheral gustatory nerve responsiveness in mice, or psychophysical assessment of detection thresholds in humans, suggest the addition of small amounts of NaCl to the solution enhance the glucose signal; an effect reversed by oral treatment with the SGLT inhibitor, phlorizin. To further investigate this phenomenon, WT and T1R3KO were trained on a two-response operant task to differentially respond to 2 M glucose + 0.01 M NaCl vs. 0.01 M NaCl in a gustometer. Despite extensive training T1R3KO mice could not perform the task reliably. WT mice were then tested on a descending array of concentrations of glucose + 0.01 M NaCl, followed by glucose without NaCl. Interestingly, the WT mice exhibited a slightly lower, though significant, detection threshold to glucose alone, which could be attributed to experience. These results provided no psychophysical evidence of a non-T1R taste pathway involved in the detection of glucose in mice, though it is possible SGLT1 contributes to taste functions other than sensory discriminative detection. The final experiment (Chapter 4) explored the potential for sensory signals outside of the gustatory system to contribute to carbohydrate detection. The literature has examples of rodents using odor cues of tastants to guide responsiveness. Here, we assessed the olfactory sensitivity of head-fixed WT and T1R3KO mice in a Go/No-Go conditioning procedure to different carbohydrate stimuli. WT mice could detect the volatiles associated with Maltrin and glucose stimuli in a concentration-dependent manner. Because of their limited volatility at room temperature, it is unlikely the carbohydrates are being detected by mice, rather it is probably contaminants within the solution guiding responsiveness. T1R3KO mice could similarly detect these glucose-associated odors but were apparently unable to use such cues to guide their performance in the gustometer (Chapter 3). Olfactory detection thresholds to these stimuli are lower than those of taste.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Carbohydrates, Gustation, Olfaction, Psychophysics, T1R3 Knock-out
Alan C. Spector, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Roper, University Representative; Adam Dewan, Committee Member; Colleen Ganley, Committee Member; Roberto Vincis, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Consequences of Myelin Debris Clearance by Microvascular Cells and Macrophages in the Progression of Secondary Spinal Cord Injury

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating and potentially life-threatening condition that can not only cause life-long chronic symptoms but also places an immense socioeconomic burden on the patients. SCI can be divided into two defined phases: primary injury and secondary injury. Primary injury is characterized by the initial mechanical damage caused by the injury, which is closely followed by the multifaceted and chronic secondary injury. This secondary stage of SCI can be marked by the propagation of an immense inflammatory cascade, widespread cell death, immune cell infiltration, scar formation, and disruption of the blood-spinal cord-barrier (BSCB). The work described in this dissertation aims to uncover the various consequences of cells phagocytosing myelin debris, a form of debris generated at an SCI lesion site, and the mechanistic role it plays in dramatically altering different cellular functions and promoting secondary injury progression after SCI. The changes in BSCB permeability after SCI have been well-established as a secondary injury hallmark, characterized as long-term disruption of the spinal cord vasculature radiating outward rostral and caudal of the lesion core. This disruption allows the influx of immune cells and other neurotoxic blood-associated substances into the spinal cord tissue, leading to chronic inflammation and an environment that hinders neuronal outgrowth and repair. Endothelial cells (ECs) form the innermost lining of the BSCB, which is composed of a collaborative cluster of several different cell types including pericytes and astrocytes surrounding a continuous EC membrane. The BSCB's function as a tightly regulated barrier is maintained by junctional proteins between ECs which restrict blood related substances from entering the spinal cord tissue. Alterations to these junctions can drastically impair BSCB function. A comprehensive understanding of the lesion related factors that may alter these junctional proteins and induce the increased BSCB permeability are as of yet unknown. One major goal of this work is to illustrate myelin debris' impact on endothelial junctions, demonstrate how it mechanistically promotes increased permeability and contributes to the breakdown of the BSCB, and investigate potential therapeutic techniques to block myelin debris' interaction with endothelial cells. The secondary stage of SCI involves the propagation of an extensive inflammatory cascade and immune cell infiltration, including bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMΦ). Another well documented event after SCI is the increased expression of members of the chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan (CSPG) family, such as neuron-glial antigen 2 (NG2), within the glial scar where it inhibits axonal growth. However, a complete picture of the cellular origins and function of this NG2 expression has yet to be made. In this study, we illustrate that certain BMDMΦ cells are among the first cells to express and secrete NG2/CSPG4 following SCI. We demonstrate, for the first time, that phagocytosis of myelin debris by BMDMΦ can induce NG2/CSPG4 expression within these cells, subsequently leading to increased proliferation and reduced phagocytic ability. These findings imply that BMDMΦ may have a more intricate role in secondary SCI progression than previously recognized, including their involvement as early contributors to the glial scar.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Blood-spinal cord-barrier, Neuroinflammation, Spinal cord injury
Yi Ren, Professor Directing Dissertation; Fanxiu Zhu, University Representative; Jose Pinto, Committee Member; Branko Stefanovic, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Longitudinal Bidirectional Associations between Parent Child Positive Relationships and Internalizing Problems in Middle Childhood

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Middle childhood internalizing problems are prevalent and persistent, and parental factors play a significant role as both risk and protective factors for the issues. Guided by attachment theory and family systems framework, this longitudinal study examined the bidirectional associations among parental anxiety, parent-child positive relationships, and child internalizing problems across Grades 1, 3, and 5 (referred to as G1, G3, and G5 thereafter) among 683 resident biological dual parents and their child in NICHD Study of Early Child Care and Youth Development (SECCYD). Both mothers and fathers reported their own anxiety and depression symptoms at G1, and their perceived relationships with the child and the child's behavioral problems related to internalizing symptoms at G1, G3, and G5. Autoregressive cross-lagged panel models estimated the bidirectional relations between parent-child positive relationships and child internalizing problems, the mediation effects of parent-child positive relationships and child internalizing problems, and the different effects of mothers and fathers in these associations. A higher level of child internalizing problems at G1 predicted a lower level of mother-child positive relationships at G3. Maternal anxiety had a higher number of significant associations than paternal anxiety with parent-child positive relationships and child internalizing problems. Conversely, paternal depression, compared to maternal depression, had a higher number of significant effects on parent-child positive relationships and child internalizing problems. In addition, a multigroup path model by child sex was utilized to investigate the differences between boys and girls. For both boys and girls, a higher level of maternal anxiety at G1 predicted a lower level of mother-child positive relationships at G1 and G5, and a higher level of child internalizing problems at G5. Higher levels of paternal anxiety and depression at G1 were associated with a lower level of father-child positive relationships at G1. Higher levels of maternal and paternal depression at G1 were linked to a higher level of child internalizing problems at G1. A higher level of paternal depression at G1 was related to lower levels of father-child positive relationships at G3 and G5, and a higher level of child internalizing problems at G5. Furthermore, girls showed a more significant association between maternal depression at G1 and mother-child positive relationships at G1 than boys. For girls, but not boys, a higher level of child internalizing problems at G1 predicted a lower level of mother-daughter positive relationships at G3. Also, a higher level of maternal depression at G1 predicted a higher level of child internalizing problems at G3 only among girls but not boys. In contrast, for boys, but not girls, a higher level of mother-son positive relationships at G3 predicted a lower level of child internalizing problems at G5. This study integrated both attachment theory and family systems theory to investigate family processes. The findings underscore the importance of incorporating parental and child sex into the understanding of child outcomes during middle childhood. Implications for clinical interventions and future research are included. Keywords: child internalizing problems, parent-child relationships, intergenerational transmission, middle childhood, gender differences
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
child internalizing problems, gender differences, intergenerational transmission, middle childhood, parent-child relationships
Qiong Wu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sonja E. Siennick, University Representative; Lenore M. McWey, Committee Member; Jonathan G. Kimmes, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Advancing Methods for Improving the Robustness of Evidence Syntheses

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Evidence synthesis has been widely used in contemporary evidence-based medicine. In evidence synthesis, systematic reviews and meta-analyses are transparent and reproducible methods for synthesizing data from multiple sources, thereby informing healthcare and clinical decision-making with high-quality synthesized evidence. However, the heterogeneity between studies and the potential for publication bias can compromise the validity of synthesized results, leading to unreliable or biased conclusions. This dissertation introduces novel statistical methods to assess these two critical issues in pairwise meta-analyses. It proposes tipping point analyses to evaluate the impact of heterogeneity parameters on the robustness of meta-analytical findings. Furthermore, the dissertation refines the current popular trim-and-fill method to improve its performance in adjusting for publication bias. First, we introduce an arm-based meta-analysis model, bivariate generalized linear mixed effects model, which models the distribution of absolute treatment effects. The arm-based model has several advantages, including providing flexible outcome measures and the ability to incorporate single-arm studies and double-zero event studies without further adjustments, which improves estimation efficiency. However, its inference heavily depends on the heterogeneity parameters (i.e., between-arm correlation and heterogeneity standard deviations) related to design and model assumptions. To address this, we develop tipping point analyses within a Bayesian framework to assess the robustness of meta-analysis results. We initially evaluate the tipping point analysis for the between-arm correlation, and subsequently assess the tipping point analysis for the heterogeneity standard deviations. Finally, we discuss the trim-and-fill method, a popular approach for detecting and adjusting for publication bias by imputing missing studies. However, the original trim-and-fill method has limitations because it relies on a single point estimate for the number of missing studies and overlooks the corresponding estimation errors. We refine this method by incorporating the distribution of the number of missing studies into the analysis. The original and refined trim-and-fill methods are compared in various scenarios, including with and without heterogeneity among studies. By integrating the uncertainty of missing studies estimates and data resamplings, researchers can produce more reliable and robust interval estimates of the adjusted overall effect size, thereby enhancing the validity of meta-analysis findings.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Arm-based model, Meta-analysis, Publication bias, Tipping point analysis

Lifeng Lin, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Xufeng Niu, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Zhe He, University Representative; Andrés Felipe Barrientos, Committee Member; Rongjie Liu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Education-Technology Public Private Partnerships

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This critical case study investigates the role of Education-Technology public-private partnerships (Ed-Tech PPPs) in the privatization of public education in Illinois, using the Critical Political Economy of Communication (CPEC) and Power Elite frameworks. The study specifically examines how these PPPs, particularly those focused on Career and Technical Education (CTE) and cybersecurity apprenticeships, are promoted by power elites as solutions to economic disparities and workforce development needs. Through qualitative document analysis, the research reveals that Ed-Tech PPPs serve neoliberal school reform agendas, granting tech companies undue influence over educational priorities and curricula. This influence could transform schools into corporate training centers, aligning education with industry demands. The study argues that the modernized apprenticeship model may perpetuate cycles of low-wage work without addressing the root causes of economic disparities. To counter these trends, the study calls for increased transparency, oversight, and democratic governance of PPPs, along with policies that empower workers and reaffirm education as a public good essential for fostering critical, engaged citizens.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the school of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Jennifer M. Proffitt, Professor Directing Thesis; Stephen McDowell, Committee Member; John Reynolds, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Dimensions of Inhibitory Processes and Their Associations with Preschool Children's Early Academic Skills and Externalizing Behaviors

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Inhibitory processes have been consistently linked to children's academic and behavioral outcomes. Researchers have argued that response inhibition (i.e., the ability to suppress a prepotent response) and interference suppression (i.e., the ability to ignore task-irrelevant information) represent two distinct constructs in preschool-age children and may be differentially related to children's academic and behavioral outcomes. However, due to issues with study design, the structure of inhibitory processes and their specific relations to academic and behavioral outcomes remains unclear. The goals of this study were to determine the structure of inhibitory processes with preschool-age children using tasks counterbalanced by measurement method (i.e., computerized vs. non-computerized) and to examine their relations to children's early academic and behavioral outcomes. In this study, 167 preschool-age children were assessed on measures of response inhibition, interference suppression, and early academic skills (i.e., phonological awareness and early math). Teachers of participating children completed a measure of externalizing behaviors (i.e., the CTRS-15). Contrary to the reported results of other studies of preschool-age children, a two-factor model consisting of separate response inhibition and interference suppression factors did not provide a better fit than a one-factor model of inhibition. The unitary Inhibition factor did have some differential relations to children's early academic skills and externalizing behavior dimensions. Implications of findings and future directions are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
early math skills, externalizing behaviors, inhition, phonological awareness, problem behaviors, response inhibition

Christopher J. Lonigan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hugh Catts, University Representative; Michael Kofler, Committee Member; Christopher Schatschneider, Committee Member; Christopher Patrick, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Small Cosmos
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Poems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Small Cosmos is a full-length poetry collection about grieving the loss of the queer beloved and how the self is transformed through loss. Distinct voice, piquant imagery, and dialectical tone propel each poem and the narrative arc of the manuscript to its culmination in hard-earned acceptance of self and expanded worldview. Entrenched in grief, the manuscript's speaker grapples with disconnection, substance misuse, family trauma, fears of mortality, and the inherent hostility of the Anthropocene towards the environment and the individual. Realism does not suffice to convey the complexity of emotion in Small Cosmos, and magical realism is employed to engage in a queer poetics that disrupts and deconstructs the realm of the conventional and expression within that realm. Similarly, without viable models from the dominant culture to solve problems of self, the manuscript's speaker forges her/their own path in hopes of finding eventual redemption and more meaningful connection.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Barbara Hamby, Professor Directing Dissertation; James Kimbrell, Professor Directing Dissertation; Silvia Valisa, University Representative; David Kirby, Committee Member; John Mac Kilgore, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Black Adolescent Reader Study
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Latent Profile Analysis

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This exploratory, descriptive study explores the impact of the subcomponents of reading according to the Simple View of Reading such as word recognition, language comprehension, and reading comprehension on the reading performance of Black middle school students. School climate data is also examined on the reading components to ascertain if correlational relationships exist between student perceptions of positive school climate for Black adolescent readers. Given the increased demand for higher-order reading skills among older students and the limited research on effective reading instruction for this demographic, the study employs a person-centered approach using Latent Profile Analysis (LPA) to identify distinct reading profiles within a sample (n=54) of eighth-grade Black students. The findings reveal two unique reading profiles, highlighting variability in reading skills among students. Additionally, the study examines the correlation between school climate and reading skills, although no significant relationships are found. The results contribute to the literature on adolescent reading, particularly for older Black students, by emphasizing the need for targeted, evidence-based interventions that account for individual differences and ecological factors affecting learning. Keywords: reading, adolescent reading, Black adolescent reading, latent profile analysis, mixture modeling, word recognition, language comprehension, reading comprehension, individual differences
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Describing the Morphological Complexity of Teachers' Spoken Language
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Comparisons across Four Instructional Subjects

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Morphology has a unique role in reading due to the morphophonemic structure of English (Venezky, 1967). Morphemes exist as the smallest meaningful unit of language (Carlisle, 2003) and connect orthographical patterns to phonological representations and semantic meanings (Kirby & Bowers, 2017; Perfetti, 2007). Accordingly, morphological awareness (MA), or the ability to understand and use morphemes (Carlisle, 2003), has an important role in both decoding and reading comprehension according to multiple theories and frameworks (e.g., Kirby & Bowers, 2017; Levesque et al., 2021; Perfetti & Stafura, 2014). In academic reading, MA is particularly crucial due to the large amount of complex polymorphemic words in academic vocabulary (Nagy & Anderson, 1984). MA and morphological instruction have been empirically tied to reading skills for K-12 students, including vulnerable populations such as English language learners (ELLs) or students with learning disabilities (LD) (Goodwin & Ahn, 2013; Lee et al., 2023). During elementary school, when students' derivational MA is still developing (Carlisle & Stone, 2005; Kuo & Andrson, 2006), sources of language input include both print and spoken language. While some studies have investigated the vocabulary content of teachers' spoken language input (Hollo & Wehby, 2017; Wanzek et al., 2022, 2023), there is a dearth of literature examining the morphological complexity (MC) of teachers' instructional dialogues. To address this gap in the literature, the current study asked two questions: (1) What types and frequencies of affixes occur in teachers' instructional dialogues as described by Bauer and Nation's (1993) Levels of morphological complexity? (2) How do types, frequencies, and proportions of affixes occurring in teachers' instructional dialogues as described by Bauer and Nation's (1993) Levels differ by instructional subject? This study examined fifteen-minute transcriptions (n = 1494) of teachers' (n = 40) dialogues occurring during four instructional subjects—English Language Arts (ELA), math, science, and social science—using Morpholex, an online affix profiler (Cobb, 2023). Morpholex generated descriptive statistics on the frequency of base words, inflections, and derivations. The profiler provided further information on affix characteristics by categorizing morphemes into Bauer and Nations' (1993) Levels. Results found that frequencies of inflectional and derivational morphemes differed between subjects but were low across the sample. Implications for instruction and future research are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
language, morphology, reading, subject, teacher, vocabulary
Sana T. Tibi, Professor Directing Thesis; Carla L. Wood, Committee Member; Shannon S. J. Hall-Mills, Committee Member; Christopher W. Schatschneider, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Elusive Self
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Transversal Subjectivities in 21st Iberian Cultures

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The economic crisis of 2008 has forced the Peninsular social body to reevaluate the dominant narratives of the last two decades. Feelings of distrust in the population were caused by the (mis)management of the government and its State institutions in the economic crisis and the uncovering of many cases of corruption, resulting in the collapse of the 'big narratives'. This research project analyzes the shifts in Spanish subjectivity that have taken place since 2008 as a consequence of the economic crisis. I follow the critical theory of Homi Bhabha, who proposes the study of 'in-between' spaces as new sites of contestation and collaboration against the hegemony. According to him, it is in these liminal spaces where new strategies, singular and communal, are created in the act of redefining society. At the same time, Edward Soja's critical theory about the Thirdspace studies liminal spaces as a third space that draws selectively and strategically from a binary to open new alternatives. Following Bhabha's and Soja's third space theory, this dissertation proposes the emergence of transversal subjectivities as an alternative to the established narratives and as a space of collaboration and intervention for minority groups against the hegemony in contemporary cultural production in Spain since 2008. I define transversal subjectivities as those that reach out across two sides of the normative discourse in a binary to create new forms of interaction, representation, and intervention. I analyze three kinds of transversal subjectivities in relationship with three concepts that interact with the subject: nationality, gender, and morality. First, I examine the emergency of transversal subjectivities of nationality in the novel Desencajada (2020) by Ukrainian-Spanish author Margaryta Yakovenko and in the poetry book Invocación a las mayorías silenciosas (2022) by Chinese-Spanish poet Paloma Chen. Both authors are second generation immigrants, whose literature has not yet received much attention by academic scholars, but who represent a transversal subjectivity of nationality due to the fact that they are 'in-between' two nations, two cultures, and two sets of expectations. Second, I analyzed the emergence of transversal subjectivities of gender in the poetry book Poesía para niñas bien. Tits in my bowl (2011) by trans poet Txus García and the graphic novel El bebé verde (2016) by trans artist Roberta Marrero. In their works, there is a destabilization of the culturally constructed concept of gender through the representation of a transversal subjectivity of gender, which reaches out across the gender binary to propose a new concept of gender that is not attached to the biological genitalia. Lastly, I identify the emergence of transversal subjectivities of socio-morality in the films El Olivo (2016) directed by Icíar Bollaín and Magical Girl (2014) directed by Carlos Vermut. These transversal subjectivities establish a direct relationship between the social descent of the middle class in Spain, due to the precarious job market, and the resignification of moral judgment, due to the mistrust in the "grand narratives", both caused by the economic crisis of 2008. As a consequence, the morally ambiguous actions of the characters represented in both movies can be justified due to their precarious lives. In my research project, the analysis of transversal subjectivities in three different aspects, that interact with the self, indicate the beginning of a shift in contemporary Spanish subjectivity. The conditions of possibility necessary for their emergence within the Spanish social body imply a resignification of the concept of nationality, gender, and morality that points towards a change in the understanding of contemporary Peninsular subjectivity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Enrique Alvarez, Professor Directing Dissertation; Benjamin Dodds, University Representative; Keith Howard, Committee Member; Matthew Goldmark, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Age Is Just a Number
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Gender, Genre, and the Marketing of the Mature Woman in 1950S Hollywood

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation argues that Western genre films were not always concerned with issues of masculinity; and in some ways, the western and other traditionally masculine genres, were co-opted by aging actresses as a vehicle for representation. This film cycle of women-centered westerns reimagines and hybridizes the genre while questioning post-war stereotypes. From 1950 to 1959 Hollywood released 746 westerns and women received first billing in 46 of them. During a period in which aging actresses were dismissed as "has-beens," the western became a haven for the mature woman over 40. The new more mature women of the west were single, childless, owned business and property. They took risks leaving big cities for frontier towns and unlike their counterparts in male-dominated westerns, they are not supporting characters, nor working traditional feminine occupations. The women-driven western represents the dual nature of the 1950s woman, images of the happy homemaker and the working professional reflected the characters in the films. Women-driven westerns were advertised as genre hybrids, changing the way audiences viewed the western genre and its familiar conventions. Combining romantic comedy and the western, or melodrama and the western allows the exploration of gender's transformative effect on genre, gender as performance, and cultural influences on film.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Aging, Film Studies, Genre, Hollywood, Western
Leigh Edwards, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jennifer Proffitt, University Representative; Alisha Gaines, Committee Member; John Rib, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Quantifying Listening Effort during Dysarthric Speech Perception Using Pupil Dilation and Perceived Listening Effort Ratings

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Dysarthria is a motor speech disorder that results in changes to the quality of speech, often resulting in reduced speech intelligibility. Thus, interventions for dysarthria often target reduced intelligibility. However, there are limitations to relying on it as a sole perceptual outcome in dysarthria. Therefore, additional perceptual outcomes that can complement intelligibility measures need to be investigated within the context of dysarthric speech perception. Listening effort is a measure that has the potential to complement speech intelligibility measures to advance our understanding of communication challenges associated with dysarthria. Therefore, this current study's primary aim is to investigate listening effort, measured by pupil dilation and perceived listening effort ratings, during the perception of dysarthric speech. A total of 34 listeners completed a speech perception task, in which they listened to phrases from a speaker with dysarthria secondary to ALS and a speaker with neurotypical speech. The listeners' pupil dilation was tracked using an eye-tracking system while listening to a phrase spoken from one of the speakers. After listening to the phrase, listeners repeated back what they heard aloud and then gave a 7-point Likert rating of their perceived listening effort for that trial. The listeners completed a total of 5 practice trials, 40 trials from the speaker with ALS and 40 trials from the neurotypical speaker. Generalized additive mixed models (GAMMs) were used to evaluate the influence of the speaker (neurotypical vs ALS), the phrase repetition accuracy (accurate vs inaccurate), and their interaction on pupil dilation. Perceived listening effort ratings were similarly evaluated using linear mixed-effects (LME) models. The results indicated that both pupil dilation and perceived listening effort ratings were greater for the speaker with ALS compared to the neurotypical speaker and greater for inaccurately recognized phrases compared to accurately recognized phrases. However, for the pupil dilation measure of effort, the difference between inaccurately and accurately recognized phrases was greater when listening to the ALS speaker compared to the neurotypical speaker. There was no interaction between speaker and phrase repetition accuracy for perceived listening effort ratings. The pupil dilation results also indicated that the shape of pupil dilation was different when listening to the ALS speaker compared to the neurotypical speaker, indicating that the allocation of effort was different for the ALS speaker. Overall, the results suggest that listening effort is greater when listening to dysarthric speech compared to neurotypical speech, even if intelligibility is preserved. Additionally, phrases, where the intelligibility was reduced, were more effortful compared to phrases that were completely intelligible to the listener. Therefore, while some relationship between listening effort and intelligibility is present, listening effort is more sensitive to differences in speech perception between dysarthric and neurotypical speech. While there was some overlap in the results for listening effort as measured by pupil dilation and perceived listening effort ratings, there were some notable differences. Implications of these findings and future areas of research, as indicated by the study's findings, are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
dysarthria, intelligibility, listening effort, pupillometry, speech perception

Kaitlin L. Lansford, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Kaschak, University Representative; Yunjung Kim, Committee Member; Richard Morris, Committee Member; Stephanie A. Borrie, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cultural Negotiation of Practice Boundaries through New Rituals
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Case of Self-Care Consumption

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Although consumption practices are often assumed to have clearly defined cultural scripts that lay out their associated objects, doings, and meanings, what happens when consumers have multiple, competing cultural scripts available to choose from when enacting consumption practices? Through an analysis of consumers' self-care consumption, we find that consumers engage in introspection to create new personal rituals from available cultural scripts and then protect them from external infringement. Once consumers create new personal rituals, they justify their choice of personal ritual in ways that narrow, expand, or maintain practice boundaries. To narrow practice boundaries and reinforce some self-care consumption rituals as legitimate and others as illegitimate, consumers engage in denouncing strategies. To expand practice boundaries and allow for variations within self-care consumption rituals, consumers engage in positioning strategies. To maintain practice boundaries, consumers engage in blurring strategies that resolve tensions between competing cultural scripts and lead to a new, cohesive cultural script for a practice. Our findings advance work on consumption practices and rituals by laying out how personal rituals resolve tensions between competing cultural scripts, create boundaries around consumption practices, and lead to the emergence of new consumption practices.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Rockwood School of Marketing in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Practice Theory, Self-Care, Self-Discipline, Self-Indulgence, Work/Life

Colleen Harmeling, Professor Directing Dissertation; Samantha Paustian-Underdahl, University Representative; Ela Veresiu, Committee Member; Michael K. Brady, Committee Member; Meredith Rhoads Thomas, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Daddies Cry Too
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Cumulative Collage Process to Explore Fathers Lived Experiences of Paternal Postpartum Depression: Phenomenological Arts-Informed Study

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this qualitative arts-informed phenomenological study was to understand the lived experiences of fathers with postpartum depression. The focus of this study was to use an arts-informed interview process based upon theoretical principles of art therapy to enable fathers to reflect and convey their frequently unspoken postpartum depression experiences. To understand these lived experiences the researcher used an arts-informed visual and oral interview called the Cumulative Collage Open-Ended Responsive Interview. One participant was recruited, then signed informed consent and completed the Cumulative Collage Open-Ended Responsive Interview. Five essential structures came out of the data analysis that highlighted the participant's experience of fatherhood which was expressed verbally and visually through the collage images. The participant reflected his experience of fatherhood feeling a machine not expected to stop, the battle of being present and absent, fatherhood becoming a calm acceptance, not being able to fit into the images of others and developing a symbolic meaning of fatherhood through the Cumulative Collage. From the essential structures, clinical applications were developed for the inclusion of fathers in art therapy. The study's major findings provided suggestions for possible future research opportunities to expand upon fathers expressing their experiences visually and verbally.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Art Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Nancy Gerber, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Barbara Parker-Bell, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Sara Scott Shields, Committee Member; David Gussak, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: (Un)Womanly
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Collection of Short Stories
