mods:mods.mods:abstract: As a writer, I am always writing about women: women I have heard of, women I have known, women I have been. For my creative dissertation titled (Un)womanly, I wrote a collection of nine short stories based on the women of my home country, Bangladesh. The creative leap for my dissertation was to craft each story by using a woman's body part as its central theme, ultimately creating a 'body' of stories on women. The entire collection represents fictional women characters bearing original individual or community identities in Bangladesh with each story including one or more pivotal women characters that drive the plot forward. While the purpose of the collection is to shed light on the societal taboos and celebrate traditional practices that take place around the country, the tales also touch on universal themes of unrequited love, teenage bullying, sexual abuse, gender identity and superstitious beliefs, among others. Through (Un)womanly, I aim to further contribute to women of colour writing, especially writing that originate from political pigeonholes of the 'third world' and showcase Bangladesh and its rich culture of stories as an emerging nation deserving of more positive global attention. My scholarly objective as a Bangladeshi writer is to continue to participate in discourses, creative projects and literary studies based on women's writing, postcolonial literature, South Asian studies and Bangladeshi writing in English.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Ravi Howard, Professor Directing Dissertation; Maxine Jones, University Representative; Robert Stilling, Committee Member; Diane Roberts, Committee Member; Elizabeth Stuckey-French, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Geospatial Insights into Access Disparities
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Analyzing Opioid Use Disorder Treatment Facilities in Florida

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study investigates the accessibility of Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) treatment facilities in Florida, focusing on geographical disparities and examining how accessibility varies across different income groups, racial demographics, and age groups. Utilizing Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and travel time analysis, the research provides a comprehensive view of accessibility variations at the county and block group levels, applying both nearest opportunity and cumulative opportunity models. The analysis highlights significant disparities among the counties, with Monroe and Franklin exhibiting the highest travel costs, reflecting substantial accessibility challenges. This study also identifies disparities in accessibility among different income groups, indicating that individuals with higher incomes face greater travel costs, potentially due to residing in areas with fewer treatment facilities. Conversely, those earning $14K or less experience slightly lower travel costs. This pattern underscores the need for targeted strategies to improve accessibility for all income groups, particularly in high-cost counties like Taylor and Highlands, where travel costs are exceptionally high for all income groups. The study further reveals notable disparities in accessibility across different racial and ethnic. White residents have an average travel cost closely aligned with the overall average, while Black and Asian residents face slightly higher costs, and Hispanic residents experience somewhat lower travel costs. In high-burden counties such as Taylor, Black residents face significantly higher travel costs than the county average, indicating that racial minorities in certain areas encounter extreme accessibility challenges. These findings highlight the need for targeted policy interventions to address these disparities. In terms of age group accessibility, the study finds that age alone does not significantly impact travel costs to OUD treatment facilities. The average travel cost for the total population and various age groups (18-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-64, and 65+) falls within a narrow range, suggesting consistent accessibility challenges across age demographics. However, specific metro counties such as Broward, Palm Beach, and Miami-Dade demonstrate lower travel costs across all age groups, indicating better accessibility in these regions due to higher facility density and developed infrastructure. The findings underscore the urgent need for strategic planning and policy interventions to improve accessibility to OUD treatment facilities in Florida. Addressing these challenges requires a multifaceted approach, including the expansion of treatment facilities in underserved areas, improved transportation infrastructure, and enhanced public awareness and education about available treatment options. Future research should consider dynamic models and real-time data to provide more accurate assessments of accessibility and explore the impact of other socio-economic factors on treatment accessibility.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Geography in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Mark W. Horner, Professor Directing Thesis; Christopher Uejio, Committee Member; Tingting Zhao, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Buying and Selling Foreign Aid
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Donor Motivations and Public Perceptions of Foreign Aid

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Chapter 1: How do states attain monetary status? States can attain monetary status by taking actions that promote the use of their currency. By linking diversification into its currency with policies that benefit the investing state, a reserve currency issuer can promote its currency even if the economic factors of the currency alone are insufficient to attract other nations to invest. Scholars have long studied the influence geopolitical and security considerations have on the rise and persistence of reserve currencies. However, security guarantees are not the only commodity reserve currency issuers can leverage to enhance their monetary status. I propose that foreign aid is an alternative tool that a reserve currency issuer can use to encourage states to invest in its currency. Using an instrumental variable, I demonstrate how China has used foreign aid to induce other nations to invest in the renminbi and thereby enhance its monetary status. My findings show that the probability that a country will adopt the renminbi as a reserve currency increases as the number of Chinese-financed aid projects the state receives increases. When a state's currency lacks the economic factors to achieve international reserve currency status, states can turn to foreign aid to buy monetary status. Chapter 2: What drives public support for foreign aid? Foreign aid is a crucial tool donor nations use to advance their interests at home and abroad. Therefore, to sell foreign assistance to the public, elites portray foreign aid programs as 1) a means to alleviate suffering in the recipient country (altruistic frame), 2) a tool to gain access to natural resources and help domestic industries at home (transactional frame), or 3) a way to enhance international status and prestige (status frame). Prior research has tested these frames in isolation and typically does not vary the type of aid being allocated or the regime type of the recipient country. Using an original pairwise conjoint experiment, this paper demonstrates how different frames impact attitudes toward different types of foreign assistance (humanitarian aid, military aid, and aid for economic development) going to democracies and non-democracies. My analysis shows that respondents are generally the most supportive of humanitarian aid, going to a democracy, that is framed as providing altruistic benefits to the recipient. However, conservatives and isolationists are more supportive of aid framed as providing the donor nation transactional benefits compared to aid framed as providing altruistic or status benefits. Chapter 3: How can elites frame foreign aid to increase public support for foreign aid spending? Using an original pre-post survey experiment, I test how different elite issue frames (transactional, altruistic, status) about the benefits of providing foreign aid impact public support for foreign aid spending. My analysis shows that framing foreign aid as providing transactional benefits to the U.S. and altruistic benefits to those in need increases support for foreign aid spending. In fact, on average, respondents go from wanting the U.S. to decrease foreign aid spending to increasing foreign aid spending after learning the transactional and altruistic benefits of providing foreign aid. Additionally, contrary to past findings, I find that framing foreign aid as providing transactional benefits to the U.S. increases support for foreign aid for both conservative (Republican) and liberal (Democrat) respondents.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Matthew Pietryka, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Sean Ehrlich, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Manoj Atolia, University Representative; Dotan Haim, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Take the Tomatoes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Take the Tomatoes is a poetry collection about the difficulties of growing up and making it through trauma. Voice and tone are at the heart of each sequence; they bring the poetry through distinct phases of life and through to a moment not of clarity but of affirmation. The speaker finds herself in turbulent situations stemming from trauma, class issues, self-loathing, anxiety, and fruitless romantic entanglements. In many instances, magical realism is used to work through more difficult subjects. In the end the speaker has a greater understanding of herself and the things she's able to control or walk away from in her life.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bruce Springsteen, Creative Writing, Ekphrasis, Poetry, Poetry Manuscript, Southern Literature
David Kirby, Professor Directing Dissertation; Barbara Hamby, Committee Member; Holly Hanessian, University Representative; John Mac Kilgore, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Relationship between Helicopter Parenting and Disordered Eating among Emerging Adults
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Role of Emotional Dysregulation

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The aim of this thesis is to examine the associations among perceived helicopter parenting, emotional dysregulation, and disordered eating in emerging adults. Guided by the socialization and cognitive behavior theories, I proposed that the association between helicopter parenting and disordered eating is linked by emotional dysregulation. Specially, I hypothesized that higher levels of perceived helicopter parenting would be related to higher levels of emotional dysregulation, which in turn is associated with higher levels of disordered eating. Participants were 432 college students ranging in age from 18 to 29 years old from two universities in Florida. Participants completed an online survey, including measures of perceived helicopter parenting, emotional dysregulation, and disordered eating. Using SPSS PROCESS, the results suggested that the indirect effect of emotional dysregulation was significant for paternal (but not for maternal) helicopter parenting. The implications of the findings were also discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
college students, disordered eating, emerging adults, emotional dysregulation, helicopter parenting
Ming Cui, Professor Directing Thesis; Lyndsay Jenkins, Committee Member; Lenore McWey, Committee Member; Qiong (Joanna) Wu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Latine College Student Mental Health
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Role of Ethnic Racial Identity, Social Support, Financial Strain and Vicarious Discrimination Online

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study examined the associations between financial strain, vicarious discrimination online and mental health (i.e., depression, anxiety) in a sample of 200 Latine university students. Moreover, the moderating roles of ethnic-racial identity (ERI) (i.e., resolution, exploration, affirmation) and perceived social support in these associations were explored. Path analysis results suggested there were significant associations between financial strain and both depression and anxiety. Similarly, vicarious discrimination online significantly predicted mental health. Greater levels of ERI affirmation significantly predicted lower levels of depressive symptoms. Moreover, ERI resolution significantly moderated the association between financial strain and anxiety, as well as the association between financial strain and depression. Graphed simple slopes suggested that the associations between financial strain and mental health (i.e., depression and anxiety) were stronger for those who reported higher levels of ERI resolution. Social support, ERI affirmation and ERI exploration did not significantly moderate the associations between stressors and mental health. These findings highlight the continued need to examine the influence of different types of ethnic-racial discrimination and racism across multiple contexts given that vicarious discrimination online has emerged as a risk factor for adverse mental health among Latine College students. The significant associations between financial strain and mental health also highlight the need to address financial stressors among the college student population. Lastly, this study adds to current evidence which supports a lifespan model of ERI. Findings have implications for clinical practice, research development and support initiatives for historically underrepresented college students.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Melinda Gonzales-Backen, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lara Perez-Felkner, University Representative; Lenore McWey, Committee Member; Thomas Ledermann, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Fault Simulation, Detection and Analysis for Monte Carlo Computational Resilience

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Computational Resilience is the process of maintaining the correctness and efficiency of computing systems in the presence of faults. Resilience is increasingly becoming a major issue for systems running Large Scale High-Performance applications. These systems consist of millions of processors and run billions of threads, and this makes them susceptible to various types of faults. The time taken to perform Application Level Checkpoint and Restart, which is the current approach to resilience, is approaching the mean time to failure of these systems. There is a critical need for new approaches to fault tolerance for the current Exascale systems and systems of the future.\\~\\Monte Carlo Methods are intrinsically suited to High-Performance Computing and can be applied to a variety of problems. They are stochastic methods that involve numerous independent computations that scale quite linearly. These programs are affected by several types of faults including Single Event Upsets, hardware failures, and software faults. In this work, we simulate exascale machines running Monte Carlo applications and observe their performance and behavior in the presence of faults. Faults are injected into the system in a controlled fashion and the propagation of the errors introduced by the faults are recorded. This information can be used to analyze the consequences of faults and to mitigate and constrain the effects of unpredictable faults. Observing the propagation of faulty calculations, it was determined that it is possible to complete calculations that would have otherwise stopped and restarted several times, within an acceptable error bound.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Computational Resilience, Exascale Computing, Fault Tolerance, Monte Carlo Methods
Michael Mascagni, Professor Directing Thesis; Arash Fahim, University Representative; Sonia Haiduc, Committee Member; Piyush Kumar, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On the Ethics of Broadway an Opera in Two Acts Thesis Submission
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: First Three Scenes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In a modern-day New York City, politician Eva Rice has passed a law requiring the heavy censorship of Broadway. As a result, the industry soon fails to adapt, and few theaters survive without facing bankruptcy. Leonard Wright finds himself distraught and depressed, cocooning himself within his theater and forgetting his past as a successful musical composer and director. Nadia, a young university student, writes her own show, breaking nearly every one of Rice's laws. Confident in her ability as a writer and composer, Nadia presents her show to Leonard, the only remaining Broadway writer who would be able to produce a show; in immediate refusal, Leonard dismisses Nadia, who in return plays a poorly written song. Catching her bait, Leonard rewrites the song with Nadia, convincing himself that they must produce the show and defy Rice's laws to bring Broadway back as it once was. In hearing rumors of the production of their show, Eva Rice appears at the theater mid-rehearsal to confront the two. Nadia and Leonard, however, give Eva a censored version of their libretto, which she finds suspicious yet cannot legally challenge. They invite her to the opening night, to which she refuses and leaves. On opening night, Leonard and Nadia plan to premiere their fully uncensored show, which is interrupted by Eva Rice once more. After a confrontational argument, the Senator learns her connections to Broadway exist far beyond her destructive laws, and she agrees to watch the show, leading her to make reconsiderations on her political stance against Broadway.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Composition in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music.
Clifton Callender, Professor Directing Thesis; Liliya Ugay, Committee Member; Osman Eren Gümrükçüoğlu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Codesign of a Research Support Platform for BIPOC Women Faculty

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The project described in this thesis will utilize a design-based research framework in order to design an online platform that will support the unique needs of Black, Indigenous, and Women of Color (BIPOC) Women in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields at historically Black colleges and universities (HBCU) and predominantly white institutions (PWI). Additionally, the project will also explore if the unique needs of BIPOC Women STEM faculty can be supported with an online tool. The project will be informed by a Black feminist framework, as the purpose of the platform is to support historically underrepresented communities in academia. Through the design process, I will shed light on the forms of oppression that constitute the creation of a platform in the first place. Utilizing a design-based research framework, a card sorting activity with community members will be used to inform features and goals of the platform. Proceeding findings from the card sorting activity, a prototype will be developed, then engaged with by community members. We will evaluate the overall success of the platform through surveys. What I am hoping to find with the implementation of this project is if an online space will support the unique funding needs of BIPOC Women faculty within the academic sphere.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Information in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Marcia A. Mardis, Professor Directing Thesis; Faye R. Jones, Committee Member; Christy L. Chatmon, Committee Member; Margaret Ann Sullivan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Scalable Hierarchical Metadata Classification in Heterogeneous Large-Scale Datasets

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Tabular metadata (i.e., attributes in a table) identification and classification is a fundamental prob-lem in large-scale data management of structured corpora, especially for complex, non-relational tables rich in hierarchical metadata. Medical research tables, such as CORD-19 [68] and Web tables [51], contain millions of tables with hierarchical metadata but often lack or have noisy labels for metadata rows (or columns) (e.g., Pfizer side-effects, Age group). Missing or incorrect meta- data labels or tags [35] hinder fundamental downstream tasks such as structural query processing, data fusion, indexing, analytics, visualization, and others. Different sources position and structure metadata uniquely and differently inside a table, making accurate identification challenging. In this work, we describe and evaluate two new scalable learning approaches for metadata classification. The first approach utilizes machine-learning techniques with our novel positional features. These features capture the contextual relationships and dependencies of the table, along with the position of the tuple and its neighbouring cells inside the deeper levels of the table. This enables our model to understand the local structure of the data and capture patterns and correlations that exist in the immediate vicinity of the tuple. Compared to the state-of-the-art [14, 20, 13, 50] (on large-scale datasets), our model achieved high F-measures, up to 97% accuracy, and an F-measure delta ranging from 6% to 18.7%. The inclusion of our novel positional features during training had a significant effect, increasing the F-measure by up to 55% compared to models trained without these features. In addition to our supervised machine-learning method with innovative positional features, this thesis explores an unsupervised approach involving contrastive learning to improve the metadata identification accuracy further. We employed this technique to discern relationships between data and metadata, leveraging a geometric interpretation of the tabular context. Specifically, we utilized the cosine angles and centroid between the embedding vectors of metadata and data terms to create a robust mathematical framework for this issue. Drawing from the inherent structure and relationships in the data, contrastive learning allowed us to encode more intricate aspects of tabular information into the learning model. This method provides a clear representation of how the different elements in a table relate to each other based on the spatial distance of their geometric representations. By implementing this novel application of contrastive learning, we observed a notable boost in metadata identification accuracy, including the deeper levels of the metadata in the table, achieving up to 90% accuracy on several large-scale datasets - justifying the scalability and eﬀiciency of the approach. Through the dual use of machine learning with new positional features and contrastive learning focusing on geometric relationships between data and metadata, our work offers an effective combination of methods that enable complex metadata identification at scale.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Computer Science.
Michael Gubanov, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sonia Haiduc, Committee Member; Grigory Fedyukovich, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: DNA Epigenetics of Alcohol Use Disorder Susceptibility in the Mouse Nucleus Accumbens

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a chronically-relapsing neuropsychiatric disease that occurs in some, but not all, recreational alcohol users. Growing evidence supports DNA epigenetic signatures in brain reward regions that may be associated with susceptibility to AUD, but the factors that lead to their establishment are presently unknown. Chapter 1 of this dissertation reviews the known and potential roles of DNA epigenetics in drug and alcohol addiction susceptibility. The chapter focuses on major phenotypes of addiction susceptibility and reviews evidence of cell type-specific, time-dependent, and sex-biased effects of drug and alcohol use. The roles of DNA epigenetics in these processes are also reviewed and proposed to contribute to addiction susceptibility. Chapter 2 describes a series of experiments used to establish a preclinical model of AUD susceptibility in inbred male C57BL/6J mice. The model took advantage of variability in the propensity of mice to develop behavioral sensitization to experimenter-administered alcohol. High-responding (HR) mice that developed robust behavioral sensitization also exhibited clinically-relevant AUD-like behaviors compared to their low-responding (LR) counterparts, despite all mice having the same genetic background and alcohol exposure history. The DNA epigenetic underpinnings of AUD susceptibility were explored in Chapter 3, which details the results of comprehensive DNA methylation profiling in the nucleus accumbens (NAc), with many divergent changes between HR and LR mice. Furthermore, integrated transcriptome and chromatin accessibility (ATACseq) assessments not only demonstrate contrasting genomic changes in HR and LR mice, but also indicate their association with DNA methylation alterations, which may represent DNA epigenetic signatures of AUD susceptibility. With the recognition of opposing Tet3 expression, which was up-regulated in HR mice and down-regulated in LR mice, Chapter 4 aims to elucidate the functional role of this methylcytosine dioxygenase in AUD. We found that knocking down Tet3 in the NAc decreased the magnitude of alcohol behavioral sensitization in HR mice and recapitulated gene expression changes seen in LR mice. Genome-wide methylation profiling revealed DNA methylation changes in the dopamine D2 receptor gene, Drd2, which have also been described in AUD susceptibility. Notably, our data provide the first evidence of Tet3's role in this process. The overall findings and future directions are discussed in Chapter 5. In summary, this dissertation elucidates novel facets of AUD susceptibility, advancing the understanding of AUD etiology and offering a potential foundation for therapeutic innovations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
alcohol use disorder, DNA methylation, epigenetics, nucleus accumbens

Jian Feng, Professor Directing Dissertation; Peixiang Zhao, University Representative; Emily H. DuVal, Committee Member; Mohamed Kabbaj, Committee Member; Paul Q. Trombley, Committee Member; Zuoxin Wang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Villains on Vellum Depictions of Hybrid "Others" in the Luttrell Psalter

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Some of the most well-known illuminated manuscript marginalia come from the 14th-century Luttrell Psalter. Along with imaginative grotesques and working peasants, the Psalter includes depictions of non-English foreigners who would have been perceived as enemies by the book's patron, Sir Geoffrey Luttrell. These foreign "others" have taken a back seat to the informative images of English medieval life in the scholarship surrounding the Psalter. This thesis explores the use of racially composite "others" who embodied the believed immorality of several different groups including the Scots, Jews, and Muslims. The ambiguity of these figures allows for interpretation by both medieval and modern readers, highlighting the enduring impact of visual imagery in shaping and reinforcing societal attitudes. The hybrid "others" served as an antithesis to the ideal English Christian, generalizing "them" to more clearly define "us." Selective scratching and rubbing of multiple "others" suggest that readers understood the artists' visual language and actively fought these invented enemies. Alternatively, medieval literature suggests racial "others" may have served as reminders of the unsaved to a liturgical audience. This thesis argues that the Luttrell Psalter's ambiguous constructions allowed readers to readily identify certain figures as geographic and religious outsiders, allowing them to decide whether to approach the figures with disdain or empathy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Art History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master's in Art History.
English Middle Ages, illuminated manuscript, Luttrell Psalter, marginalia, other, Race
Erika Loic, Professor Directing Thesis; Lynn Jones, Committee Member; Kyle Killian, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding Elementary Preservice Teachers Sensemaking about Scientific Explorations and Responsive Science Teaching
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Vexation Focus

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: It is widely recognized that teachers (both preservice and in-service) often struggle to understand and enact reform-oriented pedagogies, and in their efforts to consider such pedagogies, they express concern and discomfort. In the literature that focuses on teachers' sensemaking, such moments of concern or discomfort that emerge as teachers struggle to make sense of new ideas or approaches are known as vexations. A body of research focuses on ways to support elementary preservice teachers' learning about responsive teaching, however, there are few investigations that focus on surfacing the vexations they experience in a science methods class. In this qualitative, cross-case study, I explored the vexations that preservice elementary teachers experience during a methods course that engaged them in scientific explorations as a tool to consider the affordances of responsive science teaching. I describe the epistemic and pedagogical vexations experienced by three elementary preservice teachers, Harper, Yasmin, and Oakley, during their sensemaking efforts during the science methods class and I also describe how these participants worked through their vexations. Participants were strategically selected as each of them had a different racial background, and their past racialized educational experiences were varied. However, they were similar in that they were open to communicating their ideas and feelings during their engagement in the science method class. The research context, elementary science method class, was designed with uncertainty as central to scientific explorations, and preservice teachers were encouraged to figure things out by themselves through responsively facilitated inquiries. My analysis suggests that each of the participants had a different approach to resolving the epistemic vexations that surfaced during their scientific explorations. When Harper and Yasmin realized a gap in their knowledge or found something that did not make sense to them, they attempted to resolve their vexation by drawing on everyday examples to make connections with the explored phenomena; Oakley, in contrast, avoided her epistemic vexations when she realized a gap in her knowledge. Instead, she sought direct answers to her questions and asked for confirmation from the instructor rather than attempting to figure it out by herself. This key finding was later connected to elementary preservice teachers' pedagogical vexations about responsive teaching. As Harper and Yasmin experienced success in their efforts to use their own resources to figure things out, their pedagogical vexations faded away and they embraced responsive teaching. Oakley's avoidance of resolving her epistemic vexation impeded the development of her scientific knowledge. Without a positive experience of her own, she was not compelled to develop an understanding of responsive teaching. I also reported the instructor's efforts to support the preservice teachers' sensemaking during sensemaking by making these vexations the disciplinary substance of our instruction. My analysis showed that the instructor recognized, normalized, and commiserated with preservice teachers' epistemic and pedagogical vexations, which helped them to reframe uncertainty in scientific explorations and vexations during those explorations as integrated into science learning and teaching. In addition, the instructor sidestepped during vexations, invited other peers to conversation to foster inclusion, and offered different resources for them rather than direct answers. This study illustrates the significance of the preservice teachers' productive struggle around emerging epistemic vexations. Exploring one's own resources to resolve one's own vexations and the particular joy and excitement that comes from a successful resolution of productive struggle feelings affords elementary preservice teachers a recognition of the utility of responsive teaching for supporting their own students' learning. This research also speaks to the call for preservice teachers to be provided spaces to realize and articulate their epistemic and pedagogical vexations and be allowed to sit with and recognize these feelings and experiences. The study describes how the inclusion of both scientific explorations and an opportunity to work with elementary students' ideas were essential for the preservice teachers' learning. Together, they provided elementary preservice teachers with opportunities to wrestle with anchoring phenomena, surface their vexations, and leverage their content knowledge. This combination also assisted them in recognizing the effectiveness of responsive practices enacted by the instructor and practicing this approach themselves. It is important to note that the participants' sensemaking about science and responsive teaching was influenced by their own racialized educational experiences, as the construct of "privilege-preserving epistemic pushback" was used to characterize the resistance to responsiveness found in the participant who excelled in science taught in more traditional ways.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Elementary preservice teachers', Responsive science teaching, Sensemaking, Teacher education, Vexations
Sherry A. Southerland, Professor Directing Dissertation; Alysia Roehrig, University Representative; Lama Z. Jaber, Committee Member; Amal Ibourk, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding the Impact of Pay Transparency on Attracting Talent

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In an effort to close gender and race pay gaps, some organizations have started to provide salary ranges on job postings/job advertisements. Although recent research has examined the impact of providing pay information, we know little about how it influences job seeker attraction towards the organization. Using signaling theory and person-organization (P-O) fit theory, this dissertation examines how providing different levels of pay information in a job posting influences recruitment outcomes—such as organizational attraction and job pursuit intentions—through perceptions of organizational equity and P-O fit. The model explores how three levels of pay information: 1) no salary range is disclosed, 2) salary ranges are provided because of government requirements, or 3) salary ranges are voluntarily supplied by the organization, indirectly relate to job seekers' attraction to an organization, via perceptions of organizational equity and P-O fit. Using an experimental vignette methodology, results suggest higher perceptions of organizational equity lead to increased P-O fit. In turn, higher P-O fit leads to increased organizational attraction and higher intention to pursue employment with the organization.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
pay information disclosure, pay secrecy, pay transparecy, recruitment, salary ranges

Samantha Paustian-Underdahl, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard K. Wagner, University Representative; Jack Fiorito, Committee Member; Remy E. Jennings, Committee Member; Gang Wang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Phylogenetic Analysis
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Exploration of Treespace Using Pathtrees and Multilocus Evolutionary Analysis with Probabilistic Topic Modeling

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Evolutionary trees, or phylogenetic trees, or phylogenies, have been used extensively throughout biology and other fields to graphically represent the evolutionary history of species. Phylogenetics has advanced considerably since the mid 1960's. Computer-intensive numerical methods, such as parsimony, distance-based, and likelihood methods, were used to evaluate trees that describe the relationship among species. Over the years, the amount of data and the number of species used in such analyses grew. The field was mostly concerned how to recover the best tree and how to characterize the uncertainty estimates of the branch lengths and the topology. With large numbers of species the potential number of phylogenies is extremely large and analyses of the neighborhood of a particular phylogeny becomes important when we apply heuristic methods, such as Markov chain Monte Carlo to search for the best phylogeny. This dissertation explores new methods to create accurate phylogenies with fewer assumptions as are currently used, and describes potential advancements in the understanding of the treespace and the relationship among these phylogenies. The general research agenda of my PhD dissertation focuses on developing methods to construct phylogenetic trees, subsets of phylogenetic networks, and understanding the evolutionary aspects of genomic data. Two primary contributions of my research works are: (1) Geodesics to Characterize the Phylogenetic Landscape. Phylogenetic trees of a set of sequences are fundamental for understanding the evolutionary history of a set of species. Understanding the relationship between the highest likelihood trees and the local neighborhood of a phylogenetic tree is essential, but since trees are high-dimensional objects, discussing these neighborhoods is difficult. Collaborators and I work on a computational method to explore trees in a more deterministic manner using insights from the Billera-Holmes-Vogtmann tree space and the maximum likelihood optimality criterion. We developed an open-source Python package Pathtrees, which enables construction, visualization and exploration of a continuous tree landscape. This research work has been published on June 23, 2023. (2) Multilocus Evolutionary Analysis Using Probabilistic Topic Modeling. In this research work we use machine learning to get better estimates of phylogenetic trees from non-aligned sequence data using the topic modeling, a statistical approach based on document analysis techniques. The alignment-free approaches are gaining more attention from the scientific community because of their ability to overcome the drawbacks of sequence alignment techniques. We developed an alignment-free method to infer the multilocus species tree which is implemented in the Python package TopicContml. In this method, we first design the k-mer extraction from sequences; then we adopt an alignment-free technique of probabilistic topic modeling, Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) model, to extract topic frequencies from multilocus DNA sequences as documents; we next use these frequencies as an input to the program Contml in the PHYLIP-package to generate a species tree. I have also collaborated with another project entitled Coalescence-based Inference of Adaptation. In this research, I investigated the correlation structure of genetic markers using measures of distance among genealogies derived from these markers. Genealogies from different markers are different due to some biological reasons. I applied a distance measure among the genealogies to investigate the correlation structure of the genetic markers, and to corroborate that the nearby markers have the same genealogy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Scientific Computing in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Geodesic distance, Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), PATHTREES, Phylogenetic treespace, Topic modeling, TopicContml
Peter Beerli, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Bertram, University Representative; Gordon Erlebacher, Committee Member; Sachin Shanbhag, Committee Member; Alan Lemmon, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Trolling for Likes
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Does Approval-Seeking Motivation Fuel Political Aggression?

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Rising partisan prejudice in the U.S. has rendered relations between the two political sides increasingly volatile. Meanwhile, an uncivil and hyper-partisan political climate has likely fomented social tolerance for, and even approval of, hostile expressions toward members of the political outgroup. The present work first reports preliminary evidence that the desire to politically aggress is strongly related to approval-seeking motivation to express political hostility (Study 1). Initial findings suggest that approval-seeking motivation predicts the desire to politically aggress above and beyond mere perceptions of ingroup support for political hostility, personal approval of political hostility, and other key variables (e.g., trait aggression). An experiment then measured political aggression behaviorally (i.e., with a noise blast task; Study 2). Participants played a reaction time game, during which they were given the opportunity to aggress against a political outgroup opponent in the presence of an ostensible spectator who was presented as either a political ingroup member (experimental) or neutral (control) spectator. Participants high (compared to low) in approval-seeking motivation were predicted to display greater levels of aggression toward the outgroup opponent when they thought a fellow ingroup member was watching. Results indicated, however, that Republican/Right-leaning participants showed more aggression in the ingroup spectator (compared to the control) condition. The same pattern did not emerge for Democratic/Left-leaning participants, who displayed lower levels of aggression overall. Findings suggest political aggression is a complex phenomenon and its findings may vary across time and behavior.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
intergroup relations, motivation, political aggression, social approval

Elizabeth Ashby Plant, Professor Directing Dissertation; Brad T. Gomez, University Representative; James K. McNulty, Committee Member; Jon K. Maner, Committee Member; Jesse R. Cougle, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Employee Behaviors, Attitudes, and Strategic Human Resource Management in Public and Non-Profit Organizations

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Public and non-profit organizations are often faced with challenges in recruiting and retaining competent and motivated employees. For more effective management of public human resources and enrichment of the workforce, understanding what employees seek from their workplaces and what influences their work behaviors are crucial. The three studies presented here aim to answer the question of what makes public organizations attractive as employers. To address this question, the studies investigate different organizational and individual factors related to employees' choices of careers, work behaviors and attitudes in government and non-profit workplaces. The first study examines employees' teleworking behaviors especially after majority of employees had to work remotely during the peak of Covid-19 pandemic. The study finds that there are some endowment effects involved in employees wanting to continue working remotely after the pandemic. Also, the study finds that telework can be a way for less satisfied employees to stay away from their office while still maintaining their employment. The second study explores the career choices and job satisfaction of highly educated employees with doctoral degrees and their job satisfaction in government and non-profit sectors. The study examines the effects of material, social, and idealistic work values on their career choices in public and non-profit organizations. Overall, the findings suggest employees with doctoral degrees were more likely to pursue careers in sectors and be satisfied with their jobs when they perceive better fit between themselves and the organizations and their jobs. Lastly, the third study focuses on the employees' behaviors in reaction to their performance appraisals. A survey experiment was developed and implemented to see if employees will engage in impression management tactics more if they perceive their performance appraisals to be unfair. Using a list experiment method, the study finds that the perceived fairness and unfairness differently motivates employees to engage in different impression management behaviors.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Daniel L. Fay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Christine Mokher, University Representative; Frances Berry, Committee Member; Keon-Hyung Lee, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Integrating People in Place-Based Accessibility Measures
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Design and Application of a Novel Mode Choice Accessibility Model

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation introduces a novel place-based accessibility measure called 'mode choice accessibility.' This measure addresses the limitations of conventional place-based accessibility measures, which fail to reflect individual socioeconomic characteristics and assume equal accessibility levels for individuals living in the same location. Mode choice accessibility, built by integrating a travel mode choice model determined by socioeconomic characteristics and built environment attributes, facilitates the evaluation of accessibility gaps among individuals based on locations. Conventional place-based accessibility serves as a useful indicator for understanding the relationship between land use and transportation system. However, its assumption that all individuals living in the same location experience the same level of accessibility makes it incapable of measuring accessibility gaps arising from individuals' circumstances and socioeconomic characteristics. In addition, the abstraction of polygons is critical in place-based accessibility due to its reliance on polygon-based travel costs between origins and destinations. Despite its significance, the impact of centroids on accessibility measurements has been somewhat overlooked. This dissertation aims to enrich the literature on place-based accessibility by investigating the impact of centroid methods on accessibility and by designing a mode choice accessibility model. To achieve these goals, the dissertation compares differences between geometric-based and population-based centroid methods by analyzing their relationship with residential area ratios and their spatial disparities in accessibility. In addition, to ensure the reliability of the mode choice accessibility model, two statistical models (multinomial logit model (MNL) and mixed-logit model (MXL)) and five machine learning classifiers (naive Bayes (NB), support vector machine (SVM), artificial neural network (NN), random forest (RF), and extreme gradient boosting (XGB)) are compared and validated, taking into account the issue of imbalanced classes. The effects of socioeconomic and built environment characteristics on travel mode choices are then examined using relative variable importance and accumulated local effects (ALE) plots. Having identified the NB classifier as the superior predictive model, the mode choice accessibility is applied to spatial access to grocery stores in Minnesota. The effects of income, age, ethnicity, and vehicle ownership on accessibility are examined across Hennepin County and Ramsey County by comparing the accessibility of the reference population group. Moreover, the accessibility gaps generated by different socioeconomic characteristics of hypothetical individuals are investigated while holding other built environment attributes constant. This dissertation reveals that the geometric-based centroid method tends to underestimate accessibility more than population-based centroid methods. Moreover, these differences are more pronounced in rural areas compared to urban areas. In terms of mode choice accessibility, mobility options, such as the lack of access to a car, significantly impact the accessibility gaps among individuals, thereby overcoming the limitations of conventional place-based accessibility measures. Importantly, even when mobility options remain the same, other socioeconomic characteristics such as income and age also partially affect accessibility by influencing travel mode choices. These findings demonstrate that mode choice accessibility enables the hypothetical evaluation of how infrastructure changes impact the accessibility of a specific population group and the potential effects of urban and transport plans in advance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Geography in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Accessibility, Geographic information science, Grocery store, Machine learning, Planning, Travel mode choice
Mark W. Horner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eren Erman Ozguven, University Representative; Christopher K. Uejio, Committee Member; Sandy Wong, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Teacher Decision-Making and Classroom Autonomy under Test-Based Accountability
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Comparative Analysis

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The current study explored the relationship between test-based accountability and teachers' involvement in school-level decision-making and classroom autonomy, examining how this varied by country, specifically in the United States, Australia, South Korea, and Japan. Additionally, the study investigated whether this relationship differs based on principals' level of involvement in school-level decision-making. To this end, the current study used the 2018 Teaching and Learning International Survey (TALIS 2018) data administered by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). Over the past two to three decades, there has been a surge of interest in test-based accountability policies across various countries as a way to improve the quality of education and raise student achievement. This interest, in particular, has intensified since the implementation of the No Child Left Behind and international student testing programs, such as the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) (Hooge et al., 2012; H.-D. Meyer, 2014; Ozga, 2013). Concurrently, there has been a call for advocating granting teachers greater decision-making authority at the school and classroom levels as a strategy to enhance student achievement, teacher satisfaction, and motivation to improve teaching quality. Although it has been found that test-based accountability policy reduced teachers' school-level decision-making authority and classroom autonomy while increasing those of government and school principals (Hilferty, 2008; Jeong & Luschei, 2018; Kim, 2018; Mehta, 2013b; Smith & Benavot, 2019), few studies have explored this empirically using international data. To understand this relationship, this study employed data from TALIS 2018 to examine how test-based accountability policy was associated with teachers' decision-making authorities and how test-based accountability policy shaped the dynamics of decision-making within school organizations.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Stacey Rutledge, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Patrice Iatarola, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; John Reynolds, University Representative; Toby Park-Gaghan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Social Networks of an Inquiry-Oriented Linear Algebra Class and the Experiences of Women of Color within the Networks

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In postsecondary Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education, equity issues regarding race and gender receive attention. On this attention, it is suggested to view from the sociopolitical perspective—mathematics is political, mathematics education is political, and equity is defined with the critical dimension of identity and power. Using the central tenets of the sociopolitical perspective and intersectionality, Black and Latina Women's counter-stories provide insights into systemic issues, but quantitative approaches remain challenges. On the other hand, it is discussed that active learning in STEM education is potentially equitable but not inherently. Thus, what mechanisms of active learning determine equity or inequity is essential. So, this study argues that social network analysis (SNA)—a quantitative approach to mapping social structures- is promising. Thus, this study utilized SNA to examine equity and zoom in on women of color's experiences considering social networks in an active learning classroom in undergraduate mathematics education. By adopting the two perspectives "social capital" and "identity" to interpret social networks, which are consistent with the sociopolitical perspective, this study investigates (1) the structures of social networks of students and how race and gender relate to the social networks, (2) the experiences of women of color, and (3) the relationships between social networks and the experiences of women of color experiences, in an inquiry-oriented linear algebra (IOLA) class. This study is a single case study of one IOLA classroom in a public Southeastern university. The primary data sources are (1) student nominations in required discussion board assignments to map classroom-wide social networks and (2) journals and individual interviews of women of color. SNA was used to visualize directed networks and to calculate measurements to find the relationships between student nominations and race and gender. Journals and interviews were analyzed through initial and axial coding. Then, the networks of women of color were tracked back and related to themes of journals and interviews. The results show that the social network has a statistically identical number of nominations between non-White and White students and men and women and a strong tendency of the same racial and gender groups to nominate each other. Also, the group of most influential students determined by centrality includes women of color disproportionally compared to the entire classroom representation. Additionally, the findings of journals and interviews by women of color describe socially affirmed experiences with female classmates in the IOLA setting class and uncomfortable experiences with men in STEM classes. The experiences related to race/ethnicity and general IOLA settings vary depending on the participants. This study implies the potential equitability of the IOLA class with intentional intervention to provide supportive and inclusive active learning experiences. Furthermore, potential additional labor for women of color and the interpretation of simultaneous solidarity and segregation that the IOLA setting classroom possesses are discussed. Lastly, this study suggests future research and practices of more active adoption of intersectionality and further investigation of equitable active STEM learning mechanisms.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Christine Andrews-Larson, Professor Directing Dissertation; Amy Chan Hyung Kim, University Representative; Amal Ibourk, Committee Member; Lara Perez-Felkner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigations of Magnetoelastic Coupling in Spinel Cobalt Vanadate Thin Films

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Spinel CoV2O4 is a frustrated magnetic material that displays remarkable coupling between magnetic and structural degrees of freedom. When deposited as a thin film on a lattice mismatched substrate, the epitaxial strain breaks cubic symmetry into a tetragonally distorted unit cell. As a consequence, various elastic and magnetic properties show anisotropy in the out-of-plane versus in-plane directions. In this dissertation, various experimental works in structural and magnetic characterization are used to shed light on how strain induced anisotropy forms in the elastic and magnetic response. From structural measurements in X-ray diffraction, the in-plane lattice parameters are on average compressed shorter than the out-of-plane, but display a large variation from the mean due to misfit dislocations. From the rotational torque magnetometry results, the magnetic easy axis is shown to continuously transition from the in-plane to out-of-plane directions between 30 K to 125 K, with high magnetic field variations supporting the presence of anisotropic magnetostriction in both high and low temperature phases. Infrared spectroscopy confirms the presence of the low temperature magneto-elastic coupling with field variations, and hint at electric dipoles in the spin-canted regime through anisotropic splitting of the longitudinal and transverse modes. X-ray absorption spectroscopy shows a normal spinel type growth absent of spinel inversion, and combined with X-ray magnetic circular dichroism supports a small trigonal distortion be concurrent with the easy axis change. At the end, the dissertation sets out a roadmap for future analysis for thin films of spinel cobalt vanadates, with an eye for multiferroic applications due the presence of the electric dipole.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Christianne Beekman, Professor Directing Dissertation; Theo Siegrist, University Representative; Rachel Yohay, Committee Member; Kaya Wei, Committee Member; Hitesh Changlani, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Lot of People like Me Don't Go to College
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: " Understanding the College Experience of Students Previously in Foster Care

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: College students previously in the foster care system are facing a lifelong achievement gap when looking at college retention and completion rates (Salazar, 2013). These college students uniquely face a myriad of challenges including an absence of social capital to help guide them through the bureaucracy of college, low socioeconomic status that can lead to food insecurity, unstable housing, and lack of reliable transportation, little academic readiness for the rigor of college coursework, and ongoing emotional trauma from their youth. These challenges affect their ability to persist from one semester to another and contribute to low completion rates of former foster youth nationwide. A lack of a college degrees impacts college students previously in the foster care system's academic future and their ability to have financial independence moving forward into adulthood. Salazar's (2013) comparison study on college graduates previously in the foster care system compared to their general counterparts, they found that college degrees bring a higher level of satisfaction and quality of life, including higher income potential, higher job satisfaction and quality of life, and "substantially lower rates of reliance on public welfare programs" (p. 139). Life attributes like income, housing, the need for public assistance, and mental health are generally found to be positively related to educational attainment (Okpych, 2012; Salazar, 2013). The Community Cultural Wealth theory advances an idea of cultural capital that acknowledges that a lack of said capital leaves members of society, often people of color or those from lower socio-economic backgrounds, at a disadvantage that extends to both education and their future lives (Yosso, 2005). Yosso challenges the deficit-based view of cultural and social capital and instead looks at the intrinsic strengths marginalized communities bring. In its place, Yosso identifies six forms of capital that underserved populations possess that "most often go unacknowledged or unrecognized" (Yosso, 2005, p. 70) by society and the educational system. This study sought to understand the perceptions and experiences of college students previously in the foster care system at a local state college while acknowledging the strengths and resilience these students bring with them to college. With the knowledge and understanding of the college experience and fostering a sense of belonging, institutions can make changes that increase persistence and completion rates improving the college experience of these students.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Tamara Bertrand Jones, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sana Tibi, University Representative; Ayesha Khurshid, Committee Member; Annie Wofford, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Stereoelectronic Effects of Oxygen

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The focus of this dissertation is exploring the role of stereoelectronic effects in organic chemistry. After a general introduction, seven research projects will be discussed in detail to illustrate how stereoelectronic effects can be used to control reactivity. Chapter One starts by introducing stereoelectronic effects. In this chapter the concept of 'classical' chemical bonding is expanded to include second-order (delocalizing) interactions. The different types of stereoelectronic interactions are classified by the types and locations of interacting orbitals. Finally, the factors controlling stereoelectronic effects are discussed. Chapter Two discusses the modeling and theoretical study of stereoelectronic effects. Studying stereoelectronic effects experimentally can be difficult due to the many layers of complexity in an organic reaction. Computational tools can be utilized to explore and isolate stereoelectronic effects. In this chapter the main quantitative tools for studying stereoelectronic effects are introduced, in addition to examples of their applications. The main tools discussed in this chapter include: conformational changes, bond breaking/bond forming equations, thermochemical equations, and wavefunction analysis methods. Chapter Three discloses two research projects which illustrate how stereoelectronic effects can be used to control reactivity. Stereoelectronic effects that are present in a reactant and become stronger in the transition state lead to an increase in reactivity. Therefore, deactivating the stereoelectronic effects in the reactant can help decrease the reactivity, making it possible to capture a previously elusive intermediate. Furthermore, activating stereoelectronic effects in the reactant that need to be forfeited in the transition state will further decrease reactivity. Both of these concepts are utilized to capture the Criegee Intermediate and to explore the layers of stereoelectronic protection which made this intermediate elusive for over seventy years. The second project in this chapter discusses the systematic modification of phenols in order to control their antioxidant activity. A primary role of antioxidants is to quench free radicals through mechanisms such as H-atom transfer. Therefore, the antioxidant ability can potentially be increased by introducing stereoelectronic effects which stabilize the phenol radical product. This hypothesis is explored in a series of pyrrolidone- and caprolactam-substituted phenols. Chapter Four discusses how to control the reactivity of carboxylate radicals using transition metals. Harnessing carboxylate radicals is difficult because of their propensity to undergo rapid decarboxylation. However, with certain transition metals the carboxylate radicals can coordinate to the metal center as a non-innocent L-ligand. When behaving as an L-ligand the radical character at the carboxylate is preserved while decarboxylation is avoided. Once these reactive radicals are trapped, they can be used for C-H activation on both activated and non-activated C-H bonds. In Chapter Five, the mechanisms of two reactions controlled by stereoelectronic effects are explored. First, the mechanism of metal-free C-H functionalization using a domino reaction of aerobic amine oxidation and a vinylogous Mannich reaction is discussed. Computations reveal the crucial role of the thiourea additive as an electron-transfer mediator and a scavenger of reactive oxygen species. Finally, in this chapter, three radical cascades are explored for the controlled termination of radical alkyne peri-annulations. The termination of the radical cascades is controlled by the pre-installation of a 'weak link' which undergoes C-O fragmentation in the final cascade step. Computations determined that the C-O fragmentation step can be assisted by entropy, a gain of conjugation in the product, and stabilization of the released radical fragment. The three unique radical cascades discussed include a reductive termination with re-entry pathway, an oxidative termination with re-entry pathway, and a dyotropic-like intermolecular disproportionation pathway. All three pathways are possible in the reaction conditions and contribute to both the necessity of excess radical precursors and a longer reaction time. In the final chapter, Chapter Six, the origin of the anomeric effect is explored using statistical analysis. The hyperconjugative model is generally the most popular explanation for the origin of the anomeric effect, however, several literature reports offer dissenting opinions and argue for the primary importance of other factors, such as, electrostatics and sterics. Due to the inherent complexity of molecules, in addition to the use of specific computational methods, confirmation bias can be introduced. In order to remove any potential bias a computer could be allowed to interpret the data. Therefore, statistical analysis was performed on a data set of fifty substituted 2-X tetrahydropyran molecules. Parameters measuring sterics, electrostatics, and stereoelectronic effects were included in order to allow the computer to decide the origin of the anomeric effect.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Igor V. Alabugin, Professor Directing Dissertation; Bruce Locke, University Representative; Wei Yang, Committee Member; Justin Kennemur, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Effects of Message Framing in Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Advertising on Consumers' Responses
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Integration of Environmental and Social CSR Dimensions

mods:mods.mods:abstract: As consumer demand for companies to address social and environmental issues increases, companies have integrated corporate social responsibility (CSR) into their business models. Further, they often use advertising to effectively promote their ethical practices, known as CSR advertising. Message framing in CSR advertising, which highlights the positive or negative outcomes of adopting or not adopting certain behaviors, has attracted significant attention. Researchers have sought to identify the most effective ways to frame these CSR messages. However, given the varied contexts of CSR, the results concerning message framing effects have been mixed. Moreover, while CSR encompasses both environmental and social dimensions, much of the research has predominantly focused on the environmental aspect as a representation of CSR advertising. Additionally, despite the growing importance of social media as a tool for promoting CSR practices, there has been limited research on how CSR advertising is implemented across these platforms. The present study addresses these gaps in the literature by conducting a series of online experimental studies. It aims to explore how consumers perceive environmental and social CSR advertising differently and their reactions to gain versus loss message framing. Furthermore, the study examines how message framing effects can be enhanced by aligning them with the appropriate CSR dimensions and how varying levels of issue involvement can moderate the interaction between message framing and CSR dimensions. This research contributes valuable insights to the field of CSR advertising, benefiting both academic researchers and practitioners.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Corporate social responsibility (CSR) advertising, Issue involvement, Message framing, Social media
Jaejin Lee, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Juliann Cortese, Committee Member; Rachel Bailey, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Response of Rectangular Jet Shear Layers to Plasma Actuator Based Forcing

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Intense noise levels produced by high-speed military aircraft have adverse impact on the personnel and surrounding structures. Noise levels are often above 120dB (the human hearing pain threshold), which leads to physical and mental health problems, including hearing loss. These acoustic waves can also cause structural damage to surrounding buildings and aircraft control surfaces. Thus, a study of jet noise and control strategies for noise reduction is vital. There has been a renewed interest in the study of non-axisymmetric jets, in particular, those generated from rectangular nozzles, due to their superior air-frame integration properties and lower drag penalty in comparison to an axisymmetric nozzle. Many active and passive noise control techniques have been explored in the context of circular nozzles but very few on rectangular nozzles. One such active noise control technique involves leveraging the instabilities in the shear layer by imposing perturbations via the use of Localized Arc Filament Plasma Actuator (LAFPA). These plasma actuators have been shown to be effective in noise reduction for circular jets. However, its impact on rectangular jets has not been explored, posing numerous questions about the optimal forcing parameters (forcing frequency, duty cycle and phase difference between actuations), shear layer and acoustic response of the jet to forcing, flow field modifications and noise reduction efficacy unanswered. Also undetermined is its applicability to imperfectly expanded conditions. A computational study to determine the effects of LAFPA based control on the flow-field and acoustics of supersonic a Mach 1.5, 2:1 aspect ratio perfectly expanded rectangular jet is performed to address these queries. A preliminary linear analysis identifies that the frequency, St ∼ 1, has a relatively high overall amplification within the baseline shear layer while St ∼ 2 has the highest amplification rate, and is hence tested for control in the subsequent nonlinear simulations. Post validation of the baseline jet, effects of control in the context of noise reduction are studied at experimentally-guided forcing parameters, including frequencies, St = 0.3, 1.0 and St = 2.0, with duty cycles (DC), 20% and 50%. In general, high-frequency forcing reduces noise in the downstream direction, with the actuator signature appearing mostly in the sideline direction. St = 1 DC=50% yields an optimum balance between peak-noise reduction (of ∼ 1.5dB) and actuator tones, with control being most effective on the major axis plane that bisects the shorter edges of the nozzle. Shear layer response to the most effective forcing includes generation of successive arrays of mutually interacting staggered lambda vortices, which eventually energize streamwise vortical elements. Causal mechanisms of noise mitigation are further elucidated as follows; first, the control reduces the energy within the supersonic phase-speed regime of peak radiating frequencies, by redistributing a part of it into a high-frequency band. Second, it enhances azimuthal percolation of energy into the first and second helical modes at frequencies where noise reduction is seen, thus weakening the radiatively efficient axisymmetric mode. Finally, sound-producing intermittent events in the jet are significantly reduced, thereby minimizing the high-intensity acoustic emissions. This small perturbation-based control strategy results in only minor variations in the mean flow properties. However, reduced production and enhanced convection attenuate turbulent kinetic energy within the spreading shear layer in the controlled jet. These control parameters also produced less than 1% change in performance characteristics such as thrust. Post identification of optimal forcing frequency and duty cycle, a computational analysis is also performed to study the three-dimensional response of rectangular shear layers to plasma actuator-based control, in the context of sound mitigation of supersonic non-axisymmetric jets. The rectangular jet is now controlled using experimentally informed actuation patterns, referred to as M0, M1, M2, M3, Mπ and M+/-1. While the first five progressively increase the phase difference between successive actuators thus enhancing three-dimensionality of the shear layer structures, the latter corresponds to the flapping mode of the jet. Each actuation reveals unique near-field vortical and acoustic responses that have a profound impact on far-field noise levels. M0 actuation induces circumferentially interconnected strong streamwise vortices, while M1 actuation enhances the circumferential variability in the coherent structures. M2 actuation encompasses both these effects, and along with the least tonal impact of forcing, produces the most desirable far-field noise mitigation (∼ 2.6dB), contributed by a broadband reduction around the column mode peak of the baseline jet. Through a near-field analysis of the acoustic component, the efficacy of M2 actuation is attributed to the attenuation of the radiative efficiency of the jet, including reduced energy in the supersonic phase speeds, and redistribution of energy into the higher helical modes. Further, it curtails the nonlinear difference interactions in the plume that energize column mode frequencies, which often appear as strong intermittent sound-producing events. While the shear layer turbulent kinetic energy decreases with actuation, the controlled jets show minimal variations in mean flow properties, particularly under M2 actuation, suggesting this to be a promising small perturbation-based noise control strategy. Control authority was observed to saturate with higher phase differences (M3 and Mπ). Based on the knowledge of flow field impact of control on perfectly expanded jets, control is then applied to an over-expanded jet containing additional noise components such as BBSAN and screech. Forcing patterns M0, M1, M2, M3 and M+/-1 are studied in this context at a forcing frequency of St = 1 and duty cycle of 50%. Significant changes to mean flow properties such as core collapse location and spreading rate were observed with M0 and M+/-1 forcing while they remained relatively similar across other forcing cases. In general TKE levels were seen to decrease with increased phase difference between actuations. Far-field acoustic spectra of the baseline jet identified three distinct noise components corresponding to turbulent mixing, BBSAN and screech. Control is able to significantly affect all three components with the largest reduction observed with M3 forcing. However, the penalty arising from the actuation tone at the forcing frequency is significant. Directivity and amplitude of the forcing frequency tone is observed to vary across forcing sequences. An overall noise reduction of ∼ 2.5dB is observed with M3 forcing at downstream polar angles and upstream polar angles on both planes. Detoned noise levels which excludes the contribution from the actuation tone showed that all control cases were successful in reducing noise levels by ≥ 3dB. In particular, M3 forcing showed 6dB reduction in peak noise levels and 7dB reduction in the upstream directed noise levels. Further, M3 forcing was observed to weaken the coherent-structure/shock interactions resulting in a subdued tonal response. It was also observed to curtail upstream propagating guided jet modes which form an important part of the screech feedback loop and was also successful in reducing jet flapping. These modifications ensured reduction in BBSAN and screech in addition to reduction in mixing noise while having minimal impact on thrust.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Acoustics, Active control, Computational Fluid Dynamics, Jets, Noise reduction, Shear layer
Unnikrishnan Sasidharan Nair, Professor Directing Dissertation; Kevin Speer, University Representative; Farrukh S. Alvi, Committee Member; Christian Hubicki, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: American Amida
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Buddhist Churches of America, Religious Incorporation, and Translation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Buddhist Churches of America (BCA) is the largest and oldest Japanese American Buddhist organization.
