While scholars have recognized the several ways the BCA has assimilated to American cultural and Protestant religious norms and standards, less addressed are the direct causal influences for such assimilation beyond broad appeals to American culture or anti-Asian sentiment. This project explores the material mechanisms through which cultural and political discourse is mediated to religio-racial minority communities, especially through law and bureaucratic administration. I argue that Japanese American Buddhist encounters with American law, bureaucracy, and language were foundational to the transformations of Pure Land Buddhism in America. In order to abide in the American context, both culturally and legally, Buddhist churches engaged necessary legal statutes and bureaucratic paperwork, which impressed upon them state definitions of race, religion, and citizenship. Due to the nature of American legal structures, Japanese American Buddhists encountered a wide range of paperwork to signify their religiosity, rights, and legal statuses, especially regarding land ownership, the tax system, citizenship or residential status, and immigration legislation, among others. However, the variable nature of American law and bureaucracy creates unique opportunities for religious, legal, and political negotiation. Religious incorporation is a potent site of research and analysis for this dynamic as it exemplifies the legal logics and bureaucratic mechanisms operating at the interface of government and governed populations. The multifaceted and flexible nature of state bureaucracy and law, as well the problems and politics of linguistic translation, allowed Japanese American Buddhists to assert their right to belong in the American religious and legal landscape. Shaped by the experience of encountering rapid social change impositions of imperial power in Meiji-era Japan, Japanese American Buddhists adapted to the imperial ideologies and administrative structures of their new context, thereby producing a unique American expression of Pure Land Buddhism.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Religion in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Buddhism, Bureaucracy, Japanese American, Law, Secularism
John Corrigan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Suzanne M. Sinke, University Representative; Jimmy Yu, Committee Member; Michael J. McVicar, Committee Member; Sonia Hazard, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Design, Architecture, and Function of Advanced Polypentenamers

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation details the structure-property relationships of several advanced polypentenamers, a five-carbon backbone topology of the polyolefin family. Synthesizing precise, high molar mass, low dispersity polypentenamers was a challenging target until recently due to the low ring strain of cyclopentene (CP) and cross metathesis side reactions that occur during ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP). The ROMP of pre-functionalized CP monomers presents a variety of precise, rubbery-like materials in the unsaturated form and linear polyethylene materials after hydrogenation. These functionalized polypentenamers can then undergo further post-polymerization reactions to produce advanced polymer architectures, such as bottlebrushes, or to modify existing functionalities. The variety of precise materials possible from ROMP of CP enrich our understanding of polymer structure-property relationships at the five-carbon topology, which is nearly impossible to replicate with other methods. Several advanced polypentenamer systems with well-defined structures were synthesized utilizing previously developed synthetic methods and the resulting materials properties of these polypentenamers were investigated. ROMP of bromoisobutyryl bromide (BIB) functionalized CP produced linear backbones, known as macroinitiators, from which, grafts were grown via atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) to afford bottlebrush (BB) polymers. A systematic library of these PCP-based BBs was prepared in order to study the onset on BB behavior as a function of increasing graft length in dilute solution. Another library of polynorbornene (PNB) BBs, with similar backbone length and sidechain length, was also prepared for direct property comparison to PCP BBs as a function of backbone flexibility. This study suggests that BB behavior begins with grafts as small as 4 repeat units long and provided a unique perspective compared to the typical PNB BB systems, which are the most prominently used type of backbone in literature. The sulfonation of hydrogenated poly(4-phenylcyclopentene) (p5Ph) was also investigated to further expand the diverse functionalization possible from polypentenamers. This was accomplished using acetyl sulfate, an underexplored method in literature, to generate sulfonated aromatic hydrocarbon polymers towards proton exchange membranes for clean energy devices. A library of sulfonated polymers with modulated levels of sulfonation was produced by using a consistent stoichiometric equivalents of reagents at varying reaction time. The resulting level of sulfonation was verified by several analytical and qualitative techniques that are commonly used in literature. This study provided a comprehensive investigation of the acetyl sulfate through a synthetic lens, which has been underexplored relative to other methods of sulfonation. Future material investigations will provide important structure-property relationships capable of improving the synthesis and design of fluorine-free polymer membranes. Finally, the synthesis of catechol-containing polypentenamers was investigated towards their potential use as underwater pressure sensitive adhesives (PSAs). Many ocean shellfish, such as sandcastle worms and mussels, use biological adhesives with high content of L-3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) to bind themselves to rocks and other surfaces underwater. The ultimate goal of this project is to identify the influence of Tg on the adhesive strength of co- or terpolymers synthesized from CP derivatives. A small synthetic library was prepared and characterized in an effort to identify synthetic outcomes, copolymerization reproducibility, and resulting thermal properties of the copolymers towards better design of catechol-containing polypentenamers.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Justin G. Kennemur, Professor Directing Dissertation; Daniel Hallinan, University Representative; Joseph Schlenoff, Committee Member; Lei Zhu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Structural Insights into Asynchronous Flight Muscle Thick Filament in Insects

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In structural biology, the ultimate goal is to understand the fundamental function of various biological components through their structure, ranging from a single protein to the complex cellular structures. The key to this mission lies in the visualization of their structures in vitro through various established techniques. Methods like X-ray crystallography, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, Single Particle Cryo-Electron Microscopy (Cryo-EM), and Cryo-Electron Tomography (Cryo-ET) have been developed for this purpose, while each of them comes with its own set of strengths and limitations. When it comes to investigating large biomolecules or complexes in their natural states, Cryo-EM stands out for its ability to probe structural details at high resolution, although it could pose a challenge in the process of sample preparation, data collection and image processing across different type of proteins. The core of this work is devoted to the structure of different insect flight muscle thick filaments resolved by Single Particle Cryo-EM. As one of the major components of muscle structure, the thick filament in insect asynchronous flight muscle is a complex containing the major protein myosin and many associated non-myosin proteins. As one of the largest subcellular macromolecular structures, obtaining a high-resolution structure and investigating its molecular interactions has been historically challenging. Our work started with constructing high-resolution structures. Alongside complementary result from Mass spectrometry, multiple sequence alignment and model prediction, an exhaustive analysis was conducted to correlate structural insights to functional significance. Chapter 1 serves as an introduction to muscle proteins, mostly found in striated muscle, and single particle cryo-EM. The introduction is deliberately concise, outlining only the essential concepts necessary to understand the subsequent chapters. Chapter 2 focuses on the single-particle structure of the Bombus ignitus flight muscle thick filament, the structure of which has been published on the International Journal of Molecular Science (1). Using conventional single particle Cryo-EM techniques but with data collected on a more advanced camera and data analysis conducted with more powerful programs, an exceptional high-resolution structure (6Å) was achieved – a notable feat at the time. This study provides many insights into flight muscle thick filament structure and function by comparing Bombus to the structures of Lethocerus and Drosophila, which highlights the fundamental structure and assembly of the myosin but variations in non-myosin proteins, and more significant, the different myosin heads structure of relaxed muscle. Chapter 3 narrows the scope to data analysis of Drosophila thick filament structure with 4.7 Å resolution. Disordered densities in the Cryo-EM structure have been a big hurdle to attaining high resolution due to the heterogeneity. However, with an expanded dataset and particle number, we improved the resolution of the thick filament structure, even when the myosin heads were disordered. This breakthrough led us, for the first time, to build and study the atomic structure of myosin and non-myosin proteins, it enabled us to investigate the atomic interactions between myosin and flightin, one of the non-myosin proteins associated with myosin, the significance has been demonstrated by sequence conservation and disease-related mutation sites. This segment of work also has been published on the International Journal of Molecular Science (2). Chapter 4 focuses on the work on a Bess beetle, Odontotaenius disjunctus, which is an insect of the Coleoptera order. Coleopterans are the fourth and last insect order that has asynchronous flight muscle. Beetles have a similar lifestyle as Lethocerus as they barely fly, indicating the similar thick filament structure and function. We observed a consistent myosin structure and arrangement in the thick filament backbone, but unexpectedly disordered myosin heads. For the non-myosin proteins, we also observed a novel surface protein appeared in Bess beetle thick filament with unknown identity, also flightin is missing. We also resolved alpha helical structure of putative paramyosin in this thick filament map. Our investigation into the flight muscle thick filaments across four distinct insects - Lethocerus, Drosophila, Bombus and Odontotaenius – belonging to four different orders with a shared ancestor. Our comparative and comprehensive analyses of the thick filaments across the species demonstrated the preservation of fundamental structure of thick filament backbone, and diversity of non-myosin proteins. These findings enhanced our understanding of the structure of thick filaments, which is applicable to all striated muscle, including cardiac muscle. Non-myosin proteins contribute to many key features of thick filament, and they have adapted different conformations in four insects to support distinct muscle functions and physiological demands by cooperating with myosin. We believe all proteins work collectively to establish and preserve the structural integrity of the thick filament.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Molecular Biophysics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Kenneth A. Taylor, Professor Directing Dissertation; Alan Lemmon, University Representative; M. Elizabeth Stroupe, Committee Member; P. Bryant Chase, Committee Member; Qian Yin, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Is the Ally Helping or Hurting You?
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: an Empirical Research Study on Allyship Experiences of Marginalized Employees

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Allyship is the act of supporting and advocating for members of marginalized groups with the goal of promoting equality, inclusion, and social justice. While the concept of allyship has recently gained traction in the media and academic literature, the effects of allyship lack empirical support. This dissertation aims to explain how trust in the ally can influence marginalized employees' perceptions of allyship experiences and impact the effectiveness of allyship. I utilized Conservation of Resources (COR) theory to hypothesize that allyship indirectly affects employee work outcomes via resources generated by the allyship experience. In addition, I proposed that the marginalized employee's trust in the ally would moderate this indirect relationship, such that higher trust in the ally would lead to more resource gains, but when trust is low, this moderated indirect effect would be weakened. I conducted two studies to test my hypotheses - a two-wave longitudinal survey study and an experimental vignette study. The two-wave longitudinal survey study used a sample of marginalized employees recruited on Prolific, and captured the extent to which the allyship experiences translated into resources (e.g., emotional support, instrumental support, psychological empowerment, and participation in decision making) for the marginalized employee and influenced marginalized employees' work outcomes. Furthermore, the moderated indirect effect of trust in the ally was also examined. In this study (study 1), allyship was positively related to marginalized employees' perceptions of emotional support, instrumental support, psychological empowerment, and PDM, but the indirect effect of allyship on employee work outcomes and the moderated indirect effect of trust were not supported. To examine the moderating effect of trust on marginalized employees' perceptions of resources, trust in the ally was manipulated through vignettes that varied on the description of trust in the ally in allyship interactions at work. Results of Study 2 indicated that the presence of an ally was an important factor which enhanced marginalized employees' perceptions of emotional support, instrumental support, and participation in decision making (PDM). This dissertation offers both theoretical and practical contributions to allyship research.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Shanna R. Daniels, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Samantha Paustian-Underdahl, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Lyndsay Jenkins, University Representative; Remy Jennings, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Metrics of Surface Ocean Dissolved Organic Nutrient Cycling
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Global Patterns of Production and Consumption

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The marine biological pump sequesters atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) in the ocean when phytoplankton convert CO2 to organic carbon in the surface ocean. Subsequent sinking of dead planktonic biomass to the deep ocean moves carbon from the atmosphere to the deep ocean on century to millennial timescales. Nutrients (e.g., nitrogen, phosphorus, and iron) are essential for phytoplankton growth and exert bottom-up control on the strength of the marine biological pump. In vast areas of the surface ocean, particularly in the subtropical gyres, inorganic nutrients like nitrate and phosphate are often near or below detection limits, limiting phytoplankton growth. However, rates of export production in these inorganic nutrient-depleted regions are comparable to more nutrient-replete regions. Identifying the nutrient sources and their supply mechanisms in the subtropical gyres has thus been a long-term goal of the oceanographic community. Potential nutrient sources fueling export in the subtropical gyres include the physical transport of subsurface nutrients to surface waters, vertical migration of phytoplankton to deeper, nutrient replete waters, atmospheric deposition, nitrogen fixation, and the consumption of dissolved organic nutrients. Recently, attention has focused on dissolved organic nutrients including dissolved organic nitrogen (DON) and phosphorus (DOP) because they are the quantitatively dominant forms of bioavailable nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) in subtropical surface waters, and because they can be utilized as a N and P source by diverse phytoplankton groups. However, our understanding of DON and DOP production and consumption patterns in the global ocean is still limited. In this dissertation, I take advantage of recently updated global marine dissolved organic carbon (DOC), DON, and DOP concentration datasets and use DOC:DON:DOP concentration stoichiometry as a geochemical tracer to illustrate the production and consumption patterns of surface ocean DON and DOP from basin to global scale. I find that ~15-20% of new production is released as DOC, DON, and DOP, and is produced in the surface ocean in concentration ratios near "Redfield" stoichiometry (C:N:P = 106:16:1), similar to their phytoplankton source. However, most surface ocean DOC:DON:DOP concentration ratios are elevated compared to Redfield stoichiometry, implying that loss of DOC, DON, and DOP occurs in non-Redfield proportions in the surface ocean. Additionally, I find that surface ocean DOC:DON, DON:DOP, and DOC:DOP concentration ratios vary across different geographic and biogeochemical regions. Surface ocean DOP concentrations exhibit a broader dynamic range in concentration than DOC or DON, which I attribute to preferential consumption of DOP by autotrophs compared to DOC and DON. I further link variations in surface DOC:DON:DOP concentration stoichiometry with basin-scale biogeochemical processes including elevated rates of water column denitrification in the Eastern Pacific Ocean and atmospheric dust depositions to the North Atlantic Ocean. The narrow range of DON concentration and DOC:DON concentration ratios in the surface ocean limit their use alone in identifying regions of DON production and consumption in the surface ocean. To address this, I further use the nitrogen isotopic composition of DON (DON δ15N) as a more sensitive geochemical tracer to study production and consumption patterns of marine DON. I report DON concentration and DON δ15N measurements from the upper 300 m along a >10,000 km zonal transect (P06-2017) across the South Pacific from the Chilean coast to the Australian coast. Combining DON concentration and DON δ15N data, I find higher upper 50 m DON concentrations in the eastern portion of the P06-2017 transect associated with DON production in the region with elevated primary productivity, and inverse relationship between DON concentrations and DON δ15N associated with DON consumption in the western portion of the P06-2017 transect. Furthermore, I develop global ocean DOC and DON inverse models that simulate global ocean DOC and DON concentration fields conditional on their observations. Combining these fields with the output from our previous work on a global ocean inverse DOP model, I obtain a modeled, three-dimensional, DOC:DON:DOP concentration ratio field and calculate associated biogeochemical fluxes, including the rates of autotrophic DON uptake. I further quantify the lateral transport of DON and DOP to the subtropical gyres and find that their fluxes exceed the atmospheric deposition flux and can reach 17-90% of the nitrogen fixation flux in the subtropical gyres. I also investigate the preferential remineralization of DON and DOP relative to DOC in the shallow mesopelagic as another mechanism by which DON and DOP serve as organic nutrient sources to sustain productivity in the subtropical gyres. Together, this work provides new, quantitative metrics of the significance of DON and DOP production and consumption as autotrophic nutrients in oligotrophic gyres.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Angela Knapp, Professor Directing Dissertation; Kevin Speer, University Representative; Olivia Mason, Committee Member; Jeremy Owens, Committee Member; Sven Kranz, Committee Member; Robert Letscher, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Public Service Ecosystems Framework for Value Creation in the Context of Public Participation
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Case of Taiwan

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Democratic governments rely on the consent of the people and the respect for citizens' right to participate in public affairs decision-making, which significantly impacts government investments in citizen-oriented services and internal administrative processes. In response, the government must apply governance models with values and characteristics of public participation, which helps to balance the government's ability to use and safeguard the interests of the people. This study proposes an integrated conceptual framework that illustrates the multi-actor configuration, the institutional arrangement, and the end-user citizens' lifeworld. Using data from two cases in Taiwan – Taipei Citizen Participation Committee (TCPC) and the Street Doctor Plan – the research contributes to the understanding of public participation, particularly in terms of how the integration of institutional arrangement leads to both new ways of public participation design and value creation in public service systems by linking service ecosystem concept with our different proposed case cases. In addition, this study provides practitioners with theoretical and applied insights about the connections between participatory designs and outcomes that can shape local government committees to be more effectively leveraged and bridged public organizations and the public and can help them consider more carefully how the impact of digital technology interacts with public participation.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Reubin O'D Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Frances S. Berry, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Daniel L. Fay, Committee Member; Tian Tang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Affordable Housing Communities' Attendance to Resident Well-Being through Holistic Design

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Interior Architecture and Design

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The global housing crisis, an increasingly complex and challenging issue, is a pressing concern as individuals and families struggle to find stable and affordable housing to meet their basic needs (Habitat for Humanity, 2023). The conventional practice of establishing single-family zoned communities, which unjustly discriminate against higher-density and lower-income multi-family communities, has created a hierarchy that exacerbates the crisis and perpetuates social inequality. Marginalized populations, already at risk, are further vulnerable to gentrification in their living, working, and educational environments. These exclusionary zoning policies not only contribute to the decline in people's mental and physical well-being but also displace them from places they value. The direct link between housing conditions and health outcomes is a stark reality that demands our immediate attention (Donkin, 2014; Osmick & Wilson, 2020; Rolfe et al., 2020). Health equity is not only a concept but a fundamental principle that asserts that everyone should have a fair opportunity for optimal health, thereby requiring an equitable distribution of resources, opportunities, and conditions conducive to good health. Yet, the reality is stark. Millions of households in the United States face inadequate rental conditions or struggle with unaffordable rent burdens, a clear violation of this principle. This is a call to action for all of us to work towards a more equitable future (The White House, 2023). This study explores how the holistic design of affordable housing communities impacts the residents who live there. Using evidence-based design theories in new urbanism, community index theory, and the theory of supportive design, a framework of design implications was developed to foster identity restoration in marginalized populations living in affordable housing communities. Housing conditions and instability as social determinants of health, environmental conditions, socioeconomic status, food insecurity, and neighborhood characteristics significantly influence overall health outcomes (Handy, 2014.) The methodology includes an analysis of available amenities and the lived experiences of tiny home residents in low-income tiny home communities, low-income tiny home agrihood communities, and luxury tiny home agrihood communities. Each community, amenity, and home feature is analyzed for benefits using a lens of safety, privacy, identity, purpose, and connection. The results form a basis for comparison in determining which amenities best support human well-being. Key findings include determining the proximity of affordable housing's urban location to ensure access to grocery stores, healthcare, education, work opportunities, and entertainment, supporting residents who may not own a car (Gao et al., 2021). Secondly, promoting social interaction by engaging residents in daily activities such as maintenance and programmed amenities that bring people together can help create a sense of purpose and belonging, allowing individuals to connect and thrive. Lastly, the socioeconomic benefits of a sharing economy are explored where the local community is invited to engage with a membership to amenities and access to fresh food from an urban farm, breaking the perception that living near affordable housing communities lowers single-family house values. Involving the local community impacts the economic vitality of affordable housing. At an unprecedented pace, people are investing in smart, affordable, and factory-built homes within sustainable Farm-to-Table communities to forge a deeper connection with the land, build strong communal ties, benefit from green infrastructure, and have full confidence in the origin of their food (agrihoodliving.com, n.d.). Further research is needed on place attachment and the health impacts of supportive amenities and home features that foster a sense of belonging and satisfaction, fulfilling human needs for control, creativity, mastery, privacy, personal expression, security, and tranquility (Altman & Low, 1992).
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Interior Architecture and Design in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
Affordable Housing Design, Agrihood, Community Design, Sustainability, Tiny Homes, Well-being
Jill Pable, Professor Directing Thesis; Yelena McLane, Committee Member; Kelley Robinson, Committee Member; Kelly Kinahan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Analysis of HIV Gp41 Interaction with Raft-Forming Membranes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy combined with site-directed spin labeling (SDSL) has emerged as a versatile and powerful approach in structural and dynamical biology for investigating membrane/protein complexes using spin-labels. In this work, our focus was to characterize protein-lipid interactions in the membrane of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The process of HIV infection relies on membrane fusion, which is mediated by the fusion protein gp41. However, the molecular details of gp41-viral membrane interactions during this process are still a subject of debate. Several EPR methods were employed to investigate the disruptive behavior of the membrane-associated regions of gp41, known as MPER-TMD, and to elucidate the collaborative roles of lipid raft domains in HIV cell entry. Achieving high-quality EPR data for doubly spin-labeled proteins, which can provide meaningful information on structural dynamics by measuring distances between spin centers in the 1.5–8 nm range, requires dedicated optimization of pulsed EPR experiments. In this work, we also demonstrated the advantages of utilizing frequency-swept shaped pulses in DEER distance measurements of the Cu(Ⅱ)-labeled protein, with a W-band home-built EPR spectrometer.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cu(Ⅱ)-Cu(Ⅱ) distance, DEER, HIV gp41, lipid raft, membrane fusion, MPER-TMD
Likai Song, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Stephen Hill, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Yan-Yan Hu, University Representative; Ted Kolberg, Committee Member; Kun Yang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Towards Optimal Mesenchymal Stem Cell Derived Extracellular Vesicle Therapies
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Impacts of Tissue Source, in Vitro Aging and Adhesive Substrates

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Recently, therapies utilizing extracellular vesicles (EVs) derived from mesenchymal stromal/stem cells (MSCs) have begun to show promise in clinical trials, such as for the treatment of osteoarthritis, Crohn's disease, graft-vs-host disease, and other conditions. However, EV therapeutic potential varies with MSC tissue source, culture conditions, and in vitro expansion through passaging. To find the optimal MSC source for clinically translatable EV-derived therapies, this study compared the in vitro angiogenic and immunomodulatory potentials and the protein and miRNA cargo compositions of EVs isolated from the two most common clinical sources of adult MSCs, bone marrow and adipose tissue, across different passage numbers. The impact of cell adhesion coatings on EV secretion and therapeutic potential was also analyzed in the two types of primary MSCs and several common cell lines. Primary bone marrow-derived MSCs (BMSCs) and adipose-derived MSCs (ASCs) were isolated from adult female Lewis rats and expanded in vitro to the indicated passage numbers (P2, P4, and P8). MSC surface markers were confirmed by flow cytometry. EV size, number, surface markers, protein content, and morphology were characterized via nanoparticle tracking analysis, western blotting, BCA kit, and transmission electron microscopy, separately. EV immunomodulatory and angiogenic capacity were assessed via qRT-PCR, ELISA, cell proliferation assays, and tube formation assays employing RAW264.7 cells, human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs), and primary BMSCs. Proteomics and small RNA sequencing were performed for EV cargo profiling. Primary BMSCs, ASCs, NIH3T3 cells and RAW264.7 cells were cultured on type I collagen, poly-l-lysine (PLL), and fibronectin (FN) substrate coatings and compared to uncoated controls. EV production was characterized via nanoparticle tracking analysis, while parental cell viability, cytoskeletal arrangement and expression of adhesion and EV biogenesis genes were assessed on the coatings via live/dead staining, phalloidin staining, and qRT-PCR. EV immunomodulatory capacity was assessed via primary bone marrow- derived macrophage proliferation assay. Our findings suggest that both tissue source and passage number affected EV yield, cargo composition, and therapeutic potentials. For example, ASC-EVs generally showed stronger angiogenic capacity while early passage BMSC-EVs generally displayed stronger immunomodulatory effects in activated macrophages. The effects of cell adhesion coatings on EV production were found to be coating and cell specific, with PLL increasing EV secretion in ASCs while FN increased EV secretion in NIH3T3 cells. Together, our results provide valuable insights towards improved production of clinical MSC-EV therapies.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Christina Andrea Holmes, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Yan Li, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Zucai Suo, University Representative; Samuel C. Grant, Committee Member; Tristan Patrick Driscoll, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: LFuzz
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Locality Sensitive File-System Image Fuzzing

mods:mods.mods:abstract: File systems store critical data, and file-system bugs can lead to data loss and security vulnerabilities. An effective technique for identifying bugs is fuzzing, which can find bugs that may be difficult to detect through traditional regression suites and human testing. For file systems, fuzzing involves two parts: (1) altering bits of a file system at random file-system image locations and (2) applying random sequences of file operations to a file-system image. Since leading file-system fuzzers tend to access a small set of files to encourage the exploration of deep code branches, the accessed file-system image locations tend to be clustered and localized. Thus, altering bits at random file-system locations is ineffective in triggering bugs, as these locations are often not referenced by file operations. Furthermore, the minimum file-system image is insufficiently small for frequent image saves and restores due to performance and storage overhead. In this dissertation, we introduce LFuzz, which exploits the locality shown in typical file-system fuzzing workloads. LFuzz tracks recently accessed image locations and nearby locations to predict which locations will soon be referenced. The scheme is adaptive to migrating file-access patterns. Moreover, since modified image locations are localized, LFuzz can compactly and incrementally accumulate file-system image changes so that file-system states can be fuzzed from intermediary images instead of top-level seed images. LFuzz further explores the use of partially updated images to simulate corrupted file systems with mixed versions of metadata. We applied LFuzz to ext4, BTRFS, and F2FS and found 21 new bugs. Compared to JANUS, LFuzz reduced the fuzzing area by up to a factor of eight with unique edges deviated by up to 15%.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
An-I Andy Wang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Shuyuan Mary Ho, University Representative; Xiuwen Liu, Committee Member; Sonia Haiduc, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Low Dimensional Metal Halide Perovskites and Hybrids for Light Emitting Diodes

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Metal halide perovskites have emerged as highly promising materials for light emission, boasting several advantages over traditional light emitters. These include easy preparation, highly adjustable and pure emissions, as well as strong charge transport properties. One of the most rapidly developing areas of research in the use of metal halide structures is lead halide perovskites, the technology of lead halide perovskites as solution processable optical materials have improved significantly in the past five years for light emitting diode (LED) applications with the external quantum efficiency (EQE) of going from 0.1% to over 20%. While this is very impressive, one of the major issues that prevents the commercialization is that most perovskite and perovskite-like structures are only metastable under normal atmospheric conditions due to reactivity with water and oxygen. Achieving high stability for perovskites is notably effective through the creation of surface-passivated single crystalline nanocrystals with minimal defects. However, most perovskite nanocrystals developed to date have surface passivation by insulating organic ligands, resulting in inferior change transfer and energy level alignment in perovskites LEDs with low performance. Besides the instability, lead perovskite come with significant environmental and health issues impede future commercial applications. Hence, there is considerable interest in improving the stability and efficiency of perovskite LEDs and developing new class lead free materials and fabrication techniques to enhance their performance. In this thesis, chapters 2 and 3 are about to develop the high stability and efficiency of blue perovskite LEDs, and chapter 4 explores constructing efficient lead-free red perovskite-related LEDs. Stable blue LEDs based on CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets (NPLs) with surface passivation by a multifunctional organic sulfate was presented in chapter 2. We report a facile synthetic approach for the preparation of surface passivated CsPbBr3 nanoplatelets, by introducing an organic sulfate, 2,2-(ethylenedioxy) bis(ethylammonium) sulfate (EDBESO4), into CsPbBr3 NPL precursors. EDBESO4 can interact with CsPbBr3 through both EDBE2+ and SO42- to occupy Cs vacancies and bind uncoordinated lead atoms on the surface. The EDBESO4 treated CsPbBr3 NPLs are found to exhibit significantly improved stability as compared to pristine CsPbBr3 NPLs with capping ligands of oleylamine and oleic acid. With EDBESO4 treated CsPbBr3 NPLs as emitter, spectrally stable blue PeLEDs with an emission peak at 462 nm have been fabricated to exhibit EQEs of up to 1.77% and luminance of 691 cd m-2. This research project clearly shows the potential of using properly surface passivated perovskite NPLs as emitters for highly efficient and stable PeLEDs. Organic semiconducting ligands passivated CsPbBr3 NPLs for blue LEDs were presented in chapter 3. To fill the gap between CsPbBr3 NPLs blue emitter and high conductivity for enhanced blue LED performance, dual conducting organic ligands triphenyl(9-phenyl-9H-carbazol-3-yl) phosphonium sulfate and triphenyl(9-phenyl-9H-carbazol-3-yl) phosphonium bromide (TPPcarz2SO4 and TPPcarzBr) are meticulously designed for the passivation of CsPbBr3 NPLs. The processed CsPbBr3 NPLs films exhibit high luminescence efficiency and good stability with the passivation of TPPcarz2SO4 and TPPcarzBr. More importantly, TPPcarz2SO4 and TPPcarzBr, as energetically aligned conductive ligands, enables the improvement of charge mobility by orders of magnitude and avoids charge accumulation by balanced charge injection at the perovskite interface, therefore, breaking the key bottleneck of low efficiency and inferior stability of LED device based on 2D layered CsPbBr3. When employing the dual conductive organic ligands treated CsPbBr3 NPLs into LEDs, a maximum luminance and an EQE of 1511 cd m−2 and 4.15 % were achieved, respectively, which are the best values reported to date for pure blue LEDs based on CsPbBr3 NPLs. The meticulous design of conductive ligands in this work further pushes this bright class materials of blue CsPbBr3 NPLs toward practical device driven applications. Efficient red LEDs based on a zero-dimensional organic antimony halide hybrid was presented in chapter 4. We report a simple molecular engineering approach to addressing the issues of low conductivity and poor energy alignment in electrically driven LEDs based on zero-dimensional (0D) organic metal halide hybrids (OMHHs). A 0D OMHH TPPcarzSbBr4 was then synthesized for the first time, in which light emitting antimony bromide dimer anions (Sb2Br82-) are surrounded and isolated by TPPcarz+. Electrically driven LEDs with solution processed TPPcarzSbBr4 emitting layer exhibit a EQE of 5.12%, a peak luminance of 5957 cd m -2, and a current efficiency of 14.2 cd A-1, the best values reported to date for 0D OMHHs based electroluminescence devices. This work paves a new pathway to achieve desired functionalities in organic metal halide hybrids, which would guide the development of new generation hybrid materials for applications in optoelectronic devices.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Biwu Ma, Professor Directing Dissertation; Subramanian Ramakrishnan, University Representative; Mykhailo Shatruk, Committee Member; Lea Nienhaus, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigating Strategy Flexibility in Algebra
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Role of Conceptual Knowledge, Procedural Fluency, and Executive Function

mods:mods.mods:abstract: An important outcome in the domain of math problem solving is strategy flexibility, which refers to one's ability to adaptively select and execute the more efficient strategy during problem solving (Verschaffel et al., 2009). The current study aimed to investigate the relationship between conceptual knowledge, procedural knowledge, and executive function and strategy flexibility. To better understand strategy flexibility, I distinguished strategy flexibility into two aspects: potential flexibility, which includes students' knowledge of strategy validity, their ability to recall multiple strategies to solve the same problem (strategy production), and their knowledge of strategy efficiency; and practical flexibility, which includes student's ability to select the more efficient strategy (strategy selection) and their ability to execute the more efficient strategy accurately(strategy execution). In two experiments, middle school and high school students completed measures of their conceptual knowledge, procedural fluency, executive function, and the two aspects of strategy flexibility were assessed. Structural Equation Modeling was used to test the hypothesis. It was found that conceptual knowledge was a unique predictor of all aspects of strategy flexibility, and potential flexibility mediated the link between conceptual knowledge and strategy selection. Procedural fluency was found to be a unique predictor of all aspects of potential flexibility and strategy execution while executive function did not emerge as a unique predictor of any aspects of strategy flexibility. Exploratory analysis revealed that the link between executive function and potential flexibility was mediated by conceptual knowledge and procedural fluency. As the study revealed patterns between the three factors with individual aspects of strategy flexibility, it has both theoretical and educational implications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
executive function, individual differences, math problem solving, strategy selection

David W. Braithwaite, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Colleen Ganley, Committee Member; Derek E. Nee, Committee Member; Chris Schatschneider, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Hippocampus in Animal Models of Neuropsychiatric Diseases

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The hippocampus is a critical structure in the brain with several key roles in regulating behaviors. The hippocampal formation is essential to encoding memory, processing sensory input, maintaining spatial orientation, and emotional regulation. Because of the crucial mechanisms the hippocampus performs within the brain, any dysfunction or damage to the structure typically results in severe behavioral abnormalities. Neurocircuitry malfunctions can lead to a series of severe mental health outcomes. These malfunctions can manifest in the form of emotional disruptions like anxiety and depression, memory loss as in Alzheimer's dementia, psychosis, and seizures. While these conditions have been extensively studied for generations, medical care with regard to these conditions still faces huge challenges, particularly in regard to effective, targeted treatments. In order to better address the deficits present in the treatments for neuropsychiatric illnesses, more must be understood about the hippocampal neural circuitry and how it can be modulated at the cellular and synaptic level. Here, we addressed knowledge gaps in multiple animal models to ascertain how hippocampal circuitry can become deregulated and ways that these irregularities might potentially be addressed to resolve the modeled illness. Here, we demonstrate that a social isolation model of anxiety and depression causes impairments to hippocampal synaptic plasticity in both pre- and post-synaptic ways and that some of these impairments can be rescued by administration of ketamine. Additionally, we show that a 14-3-3 FKO mouse model exhibits hyperactive action potential firing from hippocampal CA1 pyramidal neurons and provide evidence that these neurons exhibit altered functionality from voltage gated calcium channels. Together, these suggest that hippocampal microcircuitry is a prime target for pharmaceutical modulation in mental health treatments.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Yi Zhou, Professor Directing Dissertation; Wei Wu, University Representative; Stephen Chelko, Committee Member; Cathy Levenson, Committee Member; Zuoxin Wang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Language and Motor Production
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Relationship between Spatial Demonstrative Choice and Reach Planning

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Language production and the execution of motor acts have long been thought to have similarities in the rules of their execution. Recent studies have begun to directly compare these two processes by measuring certain phenomena found in both. Until now, comparisons have only been done in parallel, with different groups of participants and/or tasks. A novel paradigm was developed to compare phenomena classically found in motor planning or language production both within and across the two domains. The first phenomenon of interest in this study was the hysteresis effect, or the persistence of choice when repeating that choice. Evidence for the hysteresis effect is robust in motor production studies, though it has only recently been of focus in language research. The next phenomenon is the inverse frequency effect, one of language production priming which finds that subordinate choices prime more effectively than dominant ones. A third effect of interest is the plan reuse benefit, or the savings of repeating an action over developing a new plan. Finally, the contrast effect was a focus because it is often found with hysteresis but study of the effect has not been previously afforded in language production. It is expected to be shown that motor and language production share commonalities in their decision-making processes.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Michael Kaschak, Professor Directing Dissertation; Gretchen Sunderman, University Representative; Walter Boot, Committee Member; Colleen Ganley, Committee Member; Derek Nee, Committee Member; Gretchen Sunderman, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Historical Context and Content of Central Conservatory of Music in China's Standard Grade Examination for Violin

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Exploring the Central Conservatory of Music (CCOM)'s Standard Grade Examination System for Violin, this thesis delves into its establishment, structure, and impact on music education in China. Initiated in 1992 by CCOM's Academic Committee, the system involves a Grade Examination Committee comprising professors from diverse music disciplines, aimed at evaluating students' musical proficiency through standardized graded examinations. Authored by Weijian Zhao, a former CCOM violin professor, the first edition of the violin examination book was published in 1993, gaining widespread adoption as the primary resource for violin grade examinations in China. Through a comprehensive examination framework, encompassing foundational skills, repertoire comprehension, and musicianship, the system provides students with valuable performance opportunities and constructive feedback from judges. Despite criticisms and challenges, including parental pressure and stress on students, based on the analysis of the materials, the system has significantly contributed to the development of young violin learners' musical abilities and continues to shape music education practices in China.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Music Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Music Education.
Central Conservatory of Music, Music Education in China, Standard Grade Examination for Music, String Pedagogy, Violin Pedagogy
Katarzyna Bugaj, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; David Knapp, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Gregory Springer, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Role of Teachers' Unions for School-Based Speech-Language Pathologists
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Preliminary Findings from Florida

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Over the past decade, there has been a growing public discourse on the costs and benefits of teachers' unions in public education. Within the body of empirical literature, little is known about the role that teachers' unions play in the professional lives of school-based speech-language pathologists (SLPs). Although most SLPs work in states with teachers' unions and collective bargaining, many have not participated in union activities or structures. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to investigate the role of teachers' unions for school-based SLPs and their perceptions of the benefits and barriers to union membership. A 44-item survey was used to solicit information about the perceptions of and participation in teachers' unions of 320 school-based SLPs. The survey included subsections on teachers' union engagement, perceptions of teachers' unions, benefits and barriers to teachers' union membership, and roles and responsibilities of teachers' unions. Directed content analysis of 70 district collective bargaining agreements was also conducted to explore SLP provisions. Results confirm that teachers' unions collectively bargain on behalf of SLPs as they are often recognized as bargaining unit members. SLP provisions pertaining to salary supplements, caseload and workload caps, opportunities for professional development and mentorship, and alternative evaluations were uncovered. However, SLPs' perceptions of teachers' unions and collective bargaining were mixed. Frequently cited benefits of union membership included improved working conditions, legal and professional protections, and collective bargaining. Common barriers were misunderstandings about the role and responsibilities of unions and monetary costs. The findings of this study suggest that teachers' unions are not a widely used support structure for school-based SLPs. Despite the barriers highlighted by participants, unions can collectively bargain for provisions that could improve the living and working conditions of practitioners, such as salary supplements, caseload caps, and professional development. Though unions could improve outreach to SLPs in the schools, SLPs may benefit from additional training and professional development opportunities to support the degree to which they advocate and engage with their bargaining units.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
public schools, speech-language pathology, survey, teachers' unions
Mollie Romano, Professor Directing Dissertation; Patrice Iatarola, University Representative; Shannon Hall-Mills, Committee Member; Christopher Constantino, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Principal Decision-Making and Title I Funding
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Exploratory Case Study

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study investigated the allocation of Title I funds by elementary school principals in the Alabama Russell County School District. The following research questions were explored: How do Russell County elementary school principals design an effective Title I allocation system? What type(s) of decision-making guide Russell County elementary school principals in designing an effective Title I allocation system? Purposive and convenience sampling was used for the selection of study participants. Participants consisted of four elementary school principals from Russell County School District. Semi-structured interviews were conducted to gather data addressing the research questions. Through descriptive coding, categorical data analysis, and subcoding, the study examined how four elementary school principals designed an effective allocation system. The Region 9 Comprehensive Center (2024) presents equity, transparency, engagement of stakeholders, and alignment with district goals and priorities as the four properties of their framework for an effective resource allocation system. The findings highlight Russell County's resource allocation system is procedural, providing sequential steps to resource allocation: 1. Identify needs. 2. Determine how to address the needs. 3. Align resources and initiatives with funding. 4. Engage stakeholders. Although the two systems differ in structure, elements of the Region 9 framework are found within the steps of Russell County's allocation system. Another consideration of this study was, what type(s) of decision-making process are involved in allocating resources. This study found that principals made rational choices due to limitations in resources and their perceptions of what would yield the best educational outcomes. In addition to making rational decisions, principals used data-based decision-making to guide their decisions around the needs of their schools and how to address them.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.

Carolyn Herrington, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Eric Ludwig, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Patrice Iatarola, Committee Member; Jeffrey Milligan, Committee Member; George Williamson, University Representative.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Roman Philosopher Kings?
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: the Ideal Political Ruler in Cassius Dio's Roman History

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation seeks to contextualize Cassius Dio as a Second Sophistic author and historian, and to demonstrate his use of Plato's political philosophy as a rubric by which to evaluate the government of the contemporary Roman Empire that he helped to administer. To do this, in Chapter 1 I first review the current state of Dio scholarship. Next, I propose an intertextual methodology to establish Dio's reference to Plato, noting that reference to Plato is a common historiographical technique. Chapter 2 reconstructs elite education in the late 2nd century CE. This reconstruction, along with a few definitions of terms indicate a heavy use of Plato's Republic as an essential educational text. Chapter 3 reviews the state of political philosophy as conceived by the four major philosophical schools of Roman antiquity, concentrating on the "Middle Platonic" philosophy of Dio's own time. This chapter demonstrates a heavy debt by the other schools to Plato's, including notions of the ideal constitution. Chapter 4 focuses on the figure of Plato's philosopher-king from the Republic. The last chapter deals with Platonic references in the speeches of the Augustan books. I conclude with a discussion of further lines of inquiry into the relationship between Plato and Dio, including his use of the tyrant from book 9 of the Republic as a paradigm for those negative imperial portraits found in the History.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Classics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cassius DIo, Philosopher-king, Plato, Political Philosophy, Republic, Roman History
Svetoslava Slaveva-Griffin, Professor Directing Dissertation; David Levenson, University Representative; James Sickinger, Committee Member; Trevor Luke, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Filtering Problems and Convergence Analysis of Kernel Learning Fbsde Filter

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This article gives a summary of state-of-art filtering methods in the literature. Among all methods, KDE kernel learning FBSDE filter is demonstrated to be superior in accuracy and efficiency of numerical solution. However, it has not been proved to converge yet. In this article, We present a convergence analysis for this method.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Convergence Analysis, FBSDE Filter, KDE kernel learning, Nonlinear Filtering
Feng Bao, Professor Directing Dissertation; Xiuwen Liu, University Representative; Giray Okten, Committee Member; Lingjiong Zhu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: High Dimensional Replicable Inference of Multiple Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Replicability is the cornerstone of scientific research. In this dissertation, we study replicability analysis of multiple studies from high throughput experiments, where tens of thousands of features are examined simultaneously. In the first chapter, we propose a statistical method, JUMP, for the high dimensional replicable analysis of two studies. The input is a high dimensional paired sequence of $p$-values from two studies and the test statistic is the maximum of $p$-values of the pair. JUMP uses four states of the $p$-value pairs to indicate whether they are null or non-null. Conditional on the hidden states, JUMP computes the cumulative distribution function of the maximum of $p$-values for each state to conservatively approximate the probability of rejection under the composite null of replicability. JUMP estimates unknown parameters and uses a step-up procedure to control the false discovery rate. By incorporating different states of composite null, JUMP achieves a substantial power gain over existing methods while controlling the false discovery rate. Analyzing two pairs of spatially resolved transcriptomic datasets, JUMP makes biological discoveries that otherwise cannot be obtained by using existing methods. In the second chapter, we study the replicability analysis of multiple studies accounting for dependence. Existing replicability analysis methods either ignore the dependence among features or impose strong modeling assumptions, producing overly conservative or overly liberal results. Based on $p$-values from two studies, we use a four-state hidden Markov model to capture the structure of local dependence. Our method effectively borrows information from different features and studies while accounting for dependence among features and heterogeneity across studies. We show that the proposed method has better power than competing methods while controlling the false discovery rate, both empirically and theoretically. Analyzing datasets from genome-wide association studies reveals new biological insights that otherwise cannot be obtained by using existing methods. In the third chapter, we focus on replicable analysis of more than two studies. Since the dimension of cross-study signal indicators grows exponentially with the number of studies, existing methods for replicability analysis of two studies are not scalable. we propose a hierarchical model to group cross-study signal indicators into a small number of clusters. Our procedure borrows information from different studies by jointly analyzing different clusters. Simulation studies show that our procedure controls the false discovery rate and has higher power than competing methods.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
dimensional reduction, false discovery rate, hidden Markov model, high dimensional inference, replicable analysis
Hongyuan Cao, Professor Directing Dissertation; Steven Lenhert, University Representative; Fred Huffer, Committee Member; Chao Huang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Time Warping Model for Bayesian Function Registration

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this dissertation, I will present three research projects that I have been working on during my doctoral study at Florida State University. The first project focus on providing linear framework for time warping functions. The second one is providing a new prior in Bayesian function registration based on the linear framework proposed in first project. The third one is on temporal point process. I will provide a brief summary for each of these projects as follows. The detailed studies will be given in the two chapters of this dissertation. Project 1: A Stochastic Process Framework for Time Warping Functions. Time warping function provides a mathematical representation to measure phase variability in functional data. Recent studies have developed various approaches to estimate optimal warping between functions and provide non-Euclidean models. However, a principled, linear, generative framework on time warping functions is still under-explored. This is a highly challenging because the warping functions are non-linear in the conventional $\mathbb L^2$ space. To address this problem, we define two new linear warping spaces and propose a stochastic process framework to characterize time warping functions. The key is to define a linear, inner-product structure on the time warping space and then transform the warping functions into a sub-space of the $\mathbb L^2$ space. With certain constraints on the warping functions, this transformation is an isometric isomorphism. In the transformed space, we adopt the $\mathbb L^2$ basis in the Hilbert space for representation. This new framework can be easily utilized to generate time warping functions by using different types of stochastic process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this new framework by using it as a new penalty in the penalized function registration, and propose an efficient gradient method to minimize the cost function. We illustrate the new penalized method using simulations that properly characterize nonuniform and correlated constraints in the time domain. Furthermore, we utilize the new framework to develop boxplot for warping functions. This boxplot can be used to estimate templates and identify warping outliers. Finally, we apply the new framework to a Covid-19 dataset to construct boxplot and identify the states with different growth patterns. Project 2: A New Framework for Bayesian Function Registration. Function registration, also referred to as alignment, has been one of the fundamental problems in the field of functional data analysis. Classical registration methods such as Fisher-Rao alignment focus on estimating optimal time warping function between functions. In recent studies, the model on time warping has attracted more attention, and it can be used as a prior term to combine with the classical method (as a likelihood term) in a Bayesian framework. The Bayesian frameworks have been shown improvement over the classical approaches. However, its prior model on time warping is often based a nonlinear approximation, which may introduce inaccuracy, instability, and inefficiency. To overcome these problems, we propose a new Bayesian approach by adopting a prior which provides a linear representation and various stochastic processes (Gaussian or non-Gaussian) can be effectively utilized on time warping. No approximation is needed in the time warping computation, and posterior distribution can be obtained via a conventional Markov chain Monte Carlo approach. We thoroughly investigate the impact of prior on the performance of functional registration with multiple simulation examples, which demonstrate the superiority of the Bayesian framework over the classical methods. We finally utilize the new method in a real dataset and obtain desirable alignment result. Project 3: Rank-based likelihood of point process spike trains. Point process provides a mathematical framework for characterizing neuronal spiking activities. Classical point process methods often focus on the conditional intensity function, which describes the likelihood at any time point given its spiking history. However, these models do not describe the central tendency or importance of the spike train observations. Based on the recent development on the notion of center-outward rank for point process, we propose a new modeling framework on spike train data. The new likelihood of a spike train is a product of the marginal probability on the number of spikes and the probability of spike timings conditioned on the same number. In particular, the conditioned distribution is calculated by adopting the well-known Isometric Log-Ratio transformation. We systematically compare the new likelihood with the state-of-the-art point process likelihoods in terms of ranking, outlier detection, and classification using simulations and real spike train data. This new framework can effectively identify templates as well as outliers in spike train data. It also provides a reasonable model, and the parameters can be efficiently estimated with conventional maximum likelihood methods. It is found that the proposed likelihood provides an appropriate ranking on the spike train observations, effectively detects outliers, and accurately conducts classification tasks in the given data.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Wei Wu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yi Ren, University Representative; Anuj Srivastava, Committee Member; Jonathan Stewart, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Evaluating and Improving Source Code Extraction from Programming Screencasts

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The ability to extract and accurately transcribe source code from tutorial videos and online courses is crucial for software developers seeking to reuse and adapt code. However, current methods that rely on optical character recognition (OCR) often produce inaccurate results due to the complexity of the code and variations in screencast formats. In this dissertation, we present three studies that aim to evaluate and improve code extraction accuracy from screencasts and code images. In the first study, we empirically evaluate six OCR engines for extracting source code from screencasts and code images. Our results show that the transcription accuracy varies greatly from one OCR engine to another and that the most widely chosen OCR engine in previous studies is not the best choice. We also identify font type and size as factors that impact the results of some OCR engines, and provide guidelines for programming screencast creators and researchers aiming to analyze source code in screencasts. In the second study, we propose a novel method that utilizes a pre-trained encoder-decoder model for code understanding and generation to enhance code extraction accuracy. By leveraging a large and diverse dataset of source code images and a state-of-the-art encoder-decoder model, we demonstrate significant improvements in the accuracy of the extracted code, outperforming the baseline OCR engine. Additionally, our proposed approach is significantly more time-efficient compared to the baseline. In the third study, we explore the effectiveness of image pre-processing techniques for improving code extraction accuracy from programming screenshots and screencasts. We comprehensively evaluate various image pre-processing methods, including resampling and denoising, to enhance the quality of the input images and improve code extraction accuracy. Additionally, we explore the application of post-processing techniques, such as OCR post-processing with CodeT5-base-OCRfix and PLBART-base-OCRfix, to further refine the extracted code and improve overall accuracy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Sonia Haiduc, Professor Directing Dissertation; Alina Dana Weber, University Representative; Zhenhai Duan, Committee Member; Shayok Chakraborty, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Effects of Signal Head Placement on the Severity of Crashes

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study investigates five signalized intersections in Jacksonville, Florida on StateRoad (SR) 10, also known as Atlantic Boulevard. Over one thousand crash reports were analyzed to create a greater understanding of the way signal head configuration and other variables can affect crash severity. The crash reports for the old data were taken from 2014 to 2016 at the intersections of Hickory Creek Boulevard/Kensington Gardens Boulevard, Girvin Road, Hodges Boulevard/Joeandy Road, Queens Harbor Boulevard, and San Pablo Road. The crash reports for the new data were taken from 2020 to 2023 from the same intersections. This study found that each intersection had its own configuration at both times. All intersections except for San Pablo Road had the signal heads located on mast arms at both times. Some intersections have been upgraded since the data was taken. This corridor will also be going through major rehabilitation in the coming years, thus improving safety and changing the configuration of at least one signalized intersection. The main objective of this study was to determine whether or not the placement of the signal heads could substantially affect the severity of crashes. The standards listed in the Florida Department of Transportation's Design Manual (FDM) 2024, Standard Plans/Index 2024, and the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) 2009 Edition were directly considered as well. It was found that the signal head configuration influenced the severity of crashes at the considered intersections but not to the same extent as other factors (e.g., total number of persons in the vehicle, road surface condition, day or night, influence by alcohol or drugs, intersection-related, and driver age). More data must be collected in the following years to conduct additional experiments and obtain more thorough insights into the effects of signal head configuration on the occurrence of crashes and their severity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Maxim A. Dulebenets, Professor Directing Thesis; Ren Moses, Committee Member; Eren E. Ozguven, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Evaluation of Alternative Lapped Tape Electrical Insulation for Gaseous Helium Cooled Superconducting Power Cables

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: As global concerns over environmental impacts grow, there is an increasing demand for energy-efficient technologies across various sectors, including transportation. In response, the development of energy-efficient electric transport has garnered significant interest. This initiative aims to mitigate the environmental footprint of the transportation industry through the adoption of electric ships and aircraft. These innovations can achieve superior energy efficiency compared to conventional modes of transportation, reducing greenhouse gas emissions associated with the transportation industry. Electric ships and aircraft will require advanced technologies such as high-temperature superconductors (HTS) to meet their demanding power and energy density requirements. One key application of HTS technology is the transmission system for high-power loads necessary for propulsion and onboard electrical systems. HTS power cables offer a compact solution capable of transmitting substantial power while adhering to the size and weight constraints. HTS technologies require cryogenic operating temperatures, and gaseous helium (GHe) is the preferred coolant, for electric transport applications. Effective electrical insulation is crucial for HTS cables operating in cryogenic environments. Conventional insulation materials often fail under such conditions due to becoming brittle and cracking. Lapped tape insulation has emerged as a promising solution, offering robust insulation that maintains structural integrity and high dielectric performance at cryogenic temperatures. Materials like polypropylene laminated paper (PPLP) and polyimide film (Kapton) have been identified previously for their suitability in GHe cooled lapped tape cable designs. To further enhance performance, new materials such as polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), polyethylene (PE), and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) have been identified due to their low dielectric constants and availability in thin tape form. Additionally, varying the conductor diameter has been explored to understand its impact on cable performance. Finite Element Method (FEM) analyses have been employed to evaluate lapped tape cable designs under both AC and DC electric fields. AC electric field simulations highlighted the potential of low dielectric constant materials in reducing electrical field enhancement, with larger conductor diameters also contributing to improved performance. Notably, AC simulations identified the grounding layer as a critical area of field enhancement. DC electric field simulations, on the other hand, indicated a transition in field behavior from being influenced by permittivity to conductivity factors as steady-state conditions were reached. The time required for DC steady state conditions to be established is a function of temperature, and cryogenic temperatures have a longer transition period compared to room temperature. Experimental validation involved the fabrication and testing of six lapped tape cable samples using PTFE, PE, and PET as insulation materials, paired with varying conductor diameters. Tests conducted at Florida State University's Center for Advanced Power Systems (FSU-CAPS) under GHe cooled AC conditions measured partial discharge inception voltage (PDIV) and partial discharge extinction voltage (PDEV) of all cables. Meanwhile, DC partial discharge measurements were performed on PE cables subjected to prolonged DC stress conditions. The results from these experiments were compared against FEM simulations to validate the theoretical models. Analysis of the AC test results indicated that factors beyond insulation material and conductor diameter significantly influenced cable performance. Issues such as inconsistent application of the grounding layer and introduction of dust particles during manufacturing emerged as critical sources of human error that obscured the effects of insulating material and conductor diameter. Addressing these challenges through improved manufacturing processes and enhanced grounding layer applications was identified as crucial for optimizing HTS cable performance. DC test outcomes aligned closely with FEM simulations, suggesting that the models may accurately describe the behavior of lapped tape cables under DC stresses. Apparent charge measurements during DC tests demonstrated consistency with simulation results. However, there is a need for further DC measurements with extended run times and detailed data analysis to deepen the understanding of DC stress effects on lapped tape cables.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Peter Cheetham, Professor Directing Thesis; Sastry Pamidi, Committee Member; Simon Foo, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Examining the Effects of Children's Word Specific Phonological Awareness on Word Reading Accuracy within a Lexical Quality Theoretical Framework

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Although decades of empirical research have documented the significant relation between phonemic awareness and word reading, questions remain about the nature of this relationship over time. These questions are of particular interest when considering that learning (which is item-based and depends on the unique interaction between the skills a child brings to the task and item/word characteristics) results in continued changes to a child's word specific lexical representations (McClelland & Rumelhart, 1986; Nation & Castles, 2017; Rumelhart & Norman, 1978; Seidenberg & McClelland, 1989; Perfetti, 1991). While prior work exploring child and word effects on children's word recognition abilities have incorporated an extensive set of child-level and word-level predictors of word reading and decoding accuracy (e.g., Gilbert et al., 2011; Goodwin et al., 2014; Kearns et al., 2016; Steacy et al., 2022), to date there have been no investigations of phonological awareness at the child, word, and child-by-word level when predicting word reading accuracy. Using a sample of second-grade students (who demonstrated a distribution of word reading and decoding skills and whose phonological systems were at least partially established), this study aimed to further clarify the relationship between word reading accuracy and the quality of children's phonological representations utilizing Rasch-based Explanatory Item Response Models. This approach allowed for the exploration of the simultaneous contribution of child-level (e.g., phonological awareness, vocabulary, rapid naming, pseudoword decoding efficiency), word-level (e.g., length, phonological Levenshtein distance, concreteness, spelling-to-pronunciation transparency) and child-by-word level (e.g., word specific phonological awareness, word specific grapheme phoneme correspondence knowledge, word specific familiarity) predictors of word reading accuracy. A sample of 80 second-grade students (mean age = 8.21 years, 48.8% female, 70% White, 17.5% Hispanic, 7.5% African American) read 52 words from the Phonological Awareness Screening Test (PAST; Kilpatrick, 2021). At the child-level, pseudoword decoding efficiency and definitional vocabulary knowledge were significant predictors of word reading accuracy.
