At the word-level, spelling-to-pronunciation transparency rating, frequency of occurrence, and number of phonemes were significant predictors of a word being accurately read by an average child in our study. At the child-by-word level, neither a child's word specific phonological awareness, grapheme phoneme correspondence knowledge, nor familiarity were significant predictors of word reading accuracy. Because the probability of an average child reading an average word in the study was 0.96, results from this study suggest that these second-graders may have fully specified, stable (precise), and sufficiently redundant orthographic – O, phonological – P, and semantic – S, representations of the words in our study (Perfetti, 1991, 1992). As proposed by the Lexical Quality Hypothesis (Perfetti & Hart, 2002), this redundancy can facilitate word recognition in the absence of complete and precise word knowledge (Adlof et al., 2016). For the children and the words in our study, the lack of significant child-by-word effects in our models may be representative of the important role precision and redundancy played in their word reading accuracy and the potential consequences of lexical quality (Perfetti, 2007).
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
cross-classified generalized random-effects models, lexical quality, phonological awareness, second grade, word reading

Laura M. Steacy, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Nicole Patton Terry, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Richard Wagner, University Representative; Donald Compton, Committee Member; Matthew Cooper Borkenhagen, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Addressing Barriers to Affirmative Consent Adherence
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Brief, Online Mindfulness Training

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The affirmative consent movement attempts to shift the societal mindset toward the idea that only an enthusiastic "yes" means consent, however, there are identified barriers that make it difficult for individual and couples to maintain the standards outlined by affirmative consent. This novel study attempted to examine mindfulness as a means to address the barriers of emotional discomfort and social scripts/cognitive heuristics. Participants include 21 individuals in the control group and 16 individuals in the treatment group. All participants completed pretest, posttest, and follow-up surveys that included self-report measures of sexual mindfulness, emotional comfort during sexual interaction, cognitive flexibility, and consent attitudes, as well as, vignettes measuring adherence to affirmative consent standards. Treatment group participants attended a 3-week, online, Mindfulness, Intimacy, and Communication training. When considering the total sample, results of this study indicated that participants in the treatment group showed improved sexual mindfulness awareness over time compared to participants in the control group. There were no changes in sexual mindfulness nonjudgement, emotional comfort during sexual interactions, cognitive flexibility, or vignettes 5 and 6 for either group. While consent attitudes improved across time regardless of group condition, for vignettes 1-4, regardless of group condition, adherence to affirmative consent standards tended to decrease across time (though the main effect of time was only significant for vignette 1). Potential implications and future directions are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Affirmative Consent, Consent, Intimacy, Mindfulness, Sexual Communication
Thomas Ledermann, Professor Directing Dissertation; Andrea Meltzer, University Representative; Jonathan Kimmes, Committee Member; Ming Cui, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Measurement of near-Threshold Resonances in Boron-9 for Big Bang Nucleosynthesis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This work details a package of experiments aimed at understanding low-energy resonances in $\bedfull$ for Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (BBN). Two indirect experiments involving the Super-Enge Split-Pole Spectrograph (SE-SPS) and the Silicon Array for Branching Ratio Experiments (SABRE) were run to measure branching ratios of states populated in 9B through 10B(3He, a)9B. One experiment involving the Array for Nuclear Astrophysics and Structure with Exotic Nuclei (ANASEN) was run at TRIUMF national laboratory to perform a direct measurement of 7Be+d->a+a+p at energies relevant for BBN. The resonance identified in Ref. [33] has now been completely calibrated, and it's impact on BBN determined. Additionally, a new region of interest was identified through the SE-SPS \& SABRE measurements. In this region, a new resonance-like structure was discovered, however, it could not be confirmed to be a resonance in the system of interest. Experiments are proposed to further explore this new region of interest.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Big Bang Nucleosynthesis, Branching Ratio, Nuclear Astrophysics, Nuclear Physics, Radiation Detection

Ingo Wiedenhöver, Professor Directing Dissertation; Henry Fuelberg, University Representative; Sergio Almaraz-Calderon, Committee Member; Alexander Volya, Committee Member; Peter Hoeflich, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Nonequilibrium Dynamics of Strongly Correlated Magnetic Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this thesis is to investigate the physics of magnetic systems away from equilibrium. Nonequilibrium phenomena are intriguing for their fundamental and technological relevance in emerging quantum technologies. A fundamental question in this field is how isolated and driven systems reach equilibrium or fail to thermalize especially when they are composed of constituents which strongly interact with one another. In particular, we explore the breakdown of thermalization in strongly correlated quantum many-body systems, with a particular focus on magnetic models harboring quantum many-body scars (QMBS). These analyses were conducted by simulating models in 1D and 2D using exact diagonalization and matrix product state time evolution algorithms. Although the models studied here are non-integrable, a subset of eigenstates can be ascertained using analytical methods. The first chapter introduces paradigms of thermalization in quantum many-body systems. It also develops a formalism to characterize thermalization, including the time profile of observables, entanglement entropy, and the Loschmidt echo which provides a measure for ergodicity. After presenting generic thermalizing models and their expected features, chapter one examines situations which violate thermalization. Some of the models that capture these phenomena have also been realized in recent experiments, and fall under the umbrella of systems with quantum many-body scars (QMBS). QMBS are athermal wave functions embedded in models which are expected to be thermal. Using the formalism introduced, it is shown how to diagnose when QMBS are present in a model. The second chapter discusses how QMBS arise in non-integrable quantum many-body systems from two particular mathematical techniques: projector constructions and spectrum generating algebras. Inspired by these developments we explore $s=1/2$ alternating Heisenberg chain (AHC) and the $s=1/2$ alternating XXZ model on the kagome lattice. These models illuminate the workings of the coherent precession of a super-spin which are the heart of QMBS. An understanding of the spectra of quantum many-body systems is closely related to their dynamical behaviors. In this spirit, in chapter 3 we take a close look at the existence of large exact degeneracies at zero energy in the alternating models. These suggest integrable analytical structures hidden in otherwise chaotic non-integrable models. We explicitly show that many of the numerically observed eigenstates can be exactly parameterized analytically in these alternating motif models. In particular, we employed a generalized version of the coordinate Bethe ansatz, typically used for integrable models, and found that it remarkably explains many exact eigenstates at zero energy. Building on the previous analytical insights on the structure of the eigenstates, chapter 4 investigates the stability of QMBS to time varying perturbations. We investigate the time dynamics of QMBS in periodically driven Floquet systems. This permits us to explore a rich dynamical phase space. By varying the parameters in locally driven systems we characterize parametric regimes in these models. We identify certain parameters for which the system globally thermalizes yet locally the system develops an athermal "cold" region. Given the context presented in the preceding chapters, in chapter 5 we discuss several open directions including: exploring the QMBS phase diagram in a family of $s=1/2$ and $s=1$ spin systems, understanding the role of zero modes discovered in time dynamics, parametrizing multi-magnon excitations in higher dimensions, extending to charge models especially those that have athermal states which contribute to superconducting order, and extending the investigations to open quantum system. This thesis provides a foundation for future investigations in the area of nonequilibrium quantum dynamics.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Non-equilibrium dynamics, Quantum magnetism, Quantum many body physics, Strongly correlated electronic systems

Hitesh Changlani, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eugene DePrince, University Representative; Luis Balicas, Committee Member; Nicholas Bonesteel, Committee Member; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Role of Interferon Signaling in Zika Virus Mediated Cell Cycle Perturbation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito born flavivirus that has recently reemerged and new strains have been associated with the development of microcephaly in babies born to infected mothers as well as Guillain-Barré syndrome in adults. This rise of ZIKV and the novel neurological symptoms associated ZIKV prompted the World Health Organization to declare ZIKV a public health emergency in 2015. Since then, significant research has been performed to understand cell type specific infection characteristics in neuronal and nonneuronal cells. Here we summarize the knowledge acquired since then on the ZIKV life cycle and its cellular targets; discuss the current knowledge of how infections cause neuropathologies as well as what approaches researchers are currently taking to further advance such knowledge. A key aspect of ZIKV neuropathogenesis is virus-induced neuronal apoptosis via numerous mechanisms including cell cycle dysregulation, mitochondrial fragmentation, ER stress, and the unfolded protein response. These in turn result in the activation of p53-mediated intrinsic cell death pathways. A full spectrum of infection models including stem cells and co-cultures, transwells to simulate blood-tissue barriers, brain-region specific organoids, and animal models have been developed for ZIKV research. While it has been established that ZIKV infection induces cell cycle dysregulation and DNA damage such as double stranded breaks, the exact mechanism is still of concern. Here we focus on investigating the interferon response to ZIKV infection as a potential signaling pathway involved in the phenotypic cell cycle dysregulation. Type I interferons (IFNs) are essential in activating intra- and intercellular anti-viral responses. During ZIKV infection, the recognition of viral nucleic acid triggers the production and secretion of interferon beta (IFN-β). Subsequently, IFN-β signaling through the Interferon alpha/ beta receptor (IFNAR1/2) complex activating the JAK/STAT pathway leads to the expression of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs). To investigate the involvement of interferon signaling in ZIKV induced cell cycle dysregulation, we created IFNAR1 KO cell lines using CRISPR/Cas9. Genetic analysis through sequencing of the region surrounding the sgRNA target region revealed frame shift mutations inducing early stop codons, which indicated a successful KO of the IFNAR1 gene. Phenotypic analysis of the KO cells indicated functional elimination of the receptor as well as the absence of ISGS upon IFN-β stimulation. Further were KO cells not susceptible to IFN-β induced slowing of cell growth. Analysis of cells cycle profiles revealed that ZIKV infection induces a diminished cell cycle arrest phenotype in early S-phase in IFNAR1 KO cells compared to WT cells. Investigation of the early S-phase arrest phenotype had previously revealed that simultaneous induction DNA double stranded breaks indicated by γH2Ax phosphorylation. Studies in our lab further showed that pathogenic R-loop accumulation occurs during ZIKV infection, specifically in interferon stimulated gene regions. Here we showed that interferon signaling plays a crucial role in the induction of these R-loops. Performing sequencing of immunoprecipitation of DNA:RNA hybrids in both WT and IFNAR1 KO cells revealed the induction of interferon signaling dependent R-loops upon ZIKV infection. Further research revealed that accumulation of DSB observed in infected WT cells was significantly reduced in IFNAR1 KO cells. The results overall indicate a mechanism by which ZIKV infection induces R-loop accumulation in an interferon signaling dependent manner that results in extensive DNA damage ultimately leading to cell cycle arrest.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Hengli Tang, Professor Directing Thesis; Fanxiu Zhu, Committee Member; Jonathan Dennis, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Causal Manipulation of Neural Mechanisms Supporting Cognitive Control

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Cognitive control is essential for adapting behavior to meet various challenges and is often impaired in psychiatric disorders. Research has highlighted frontoparietal regions as crucial for cognitive control, but how these regions interact to generate behavior are still debated. Effective connectivity modeling suggests future-oriented frontoparietal regions can be characterized by within-subsystem excitation and between-subsystem inhibition (Nee, 2021). Additionally, the lateral frontal pole and mid-lateral prefrontal cortex have been proposed as particularly influential regions within this system. In this study, we used continuous theta burst stimulation to causally test proposed models of regional communication among control regions and to examine its effects on the brain and behavior. We used a combination of fMRI and stimulation in a within-subjects cross-over design and leveraged univariate BOLD analysis, effective connectivity measures, and behavioral measures pre – and post – cTBS. Results showed cTBS to the prefrontal cortex targets altered BOLD activation and behavioral outcomes consistent with the proposed effective connectivity model. Notably, cTBS to the mid-lateral prefrontal cortex produced differential changes not observed with lateral frontal pole stimulation, suggesting the mid-lateral prefrontal cortex may play a unique role in control. Effective connectivity analyses further supported the model of frontoparietal regions influence seen in Nee 2021. Collectively, these data indicate cTBS-induced changes may be best characterized by the target's effective influence. They also suggest that frontoparietal regions may be organized hierarchically, with the mid-lateral prefrontal cortex playing a central role, potentially offering future clinical utility.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cognitive Control, Effective Connectivity, Functional MRI, Hierarchical Control, Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation
Derek Evan Nee, Professor Directing Dissertation; F. Andrew Kozel, University Representative; Caterina Gratton, Committee Member; Justin Riddle, Committee Member; Tehila Nugiel, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Interfacial Interactions between Polymers and Particles
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Applications in Sensors and All-Solid-State Batteries

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Polymer-particle composites are ubiquitous in everyday life. Engineered interactions between these two components facilitate a massive breadth of applications. Herein, we explore in-depth some of the key properties of each constituent and how they affect the structure and properties of bulk composites in two very different systems: (i) magnetic-core/gold-shell nanoparticles (MAuNPs) for surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS)-based sensing platforms and (ii) novel argyrodite Li6PS5Cl (LPSCl) sulfide solid electrolyte thin films utilizing poly(isobutylene) (PIB) binder. For the first system, MAuNPs were grafted with methoxy poly(ethylene glycol) thiol (PEG) and/or 4-mercaptobenzoic acid (4-MBA) and examined using a variety of microscopy, spectroscopy, magnetometry, and scattering techniques. The second system focused on sulfide solid-state electrolytes, which possess high room-temperature ionic conductivity. However, slurry casting of the free-standing, sheet-type thin sulfide solid electrolyte (SE) films to enable all-solid-state batteries to deliver high energy and power density remains challenging. For MAuNPs grafted with both PEG and 4-MBA, the order in which they were grafted impacted not only the graft density of the individual ligands, but also the overall graft density. It was found that the presence of 4-MBA slowed the magnetic mass deposition rate, and it was postulated that the rate disparity originated from differing NP-substrate surface interactions. A paradigm of solvent and binder selection for solution processing LPSCl solid-state electrolyte particles based on Hansen solubility parameters (HSPs) is introduced. Treatment of the LPSCl in selected solvents results in particle morphological change, but crystallographic structure remains intact. Although solution processing reduced the LPSCl's ionic conductivity, it promoted interfacial stability by alleviating its reductive decomposition against Li metal. The HSP theoretical framework was also applied to an anti-perovskite-structured oxide SE, Li2OHBr, and surface energy parameters determined, but on account of Li2OHBr strong dipole moments or hydrogen bonding tendencies, the results require additional stringent validation. Applying these findings, LPSCl was slurry cast to form free-standing films with low (≤ 5 wt.%) loadings of PIB binder. Nevertheless, increasing polymer binder loading inevitably introduced voids in the thin film SEs, compromising anode/electrolyte interfacial ion transport. It was demonstrated PIB molecular weight plays a crucial part in determining the properties of the SE thin film separators. Three important trends were observed: (i) increased PIB molecular weight lowered the limit on binder mass loading required to fabricate free-standing films, (ii) increased binder molecular weight resulted in greater grain boundary resistance and decreased critical current density, and (iii) lower molecular weight PIB film surfaces exhibited more even binder distribution than higher molecular weight PIB film surfaces, but the resulting confined PIB chains were less able to provide the elastic recovery required to maintain contact with the active material. Finally, it was shown that the choice of slurry constituents and relative quantities have a profound effect on SE film quality using LPSCl, Li2OHBr, Li3PS4, and Li3InCl6 SEs.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
energy storage, interface, nanomaterials, polymer physics, Raman, solid-state batteries
Daniel T. Hallinan, Jr., Professor Directing Dissertation; Hedi Mattoussi, University Representative; Rufina G. Alamo, Committee Member; Jingjiao Guan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Perceived Acceptability, Appropriateness, and Participation Fidelity in a Web-Based Intervention for Error Sensitivity in 5-7-Year-Olds
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Mixed-Methods Evaluation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Error sensitivity, or high reactivity to making mistakes, is an aspect of perfectionism, which confers risk for future anxiety disorders and a range of other poor mental health outcomes in youth. Preliminary research has shown that perfectionism and error sensitivity can be reduced in youth via psychosocial interventions. Pilot data from our own research group have also shown that a brief digital health intervention can reduce error sensitivity in young children who have an elevated response to errors. Despite initial evidence for efficacy of psychosocial and digital health interventions in decreasing error sensitivity and perfectionism, these programs are unlikely to effect change on a large scale without proper consideration of the implementation context, and incorporation of consumer perspectives. The present study evaluated the implementation and engagement outcomes associated with a novel, digital-health preventive intervention program targeting error sensitivity in children aged 5 to 7 years that is currently being tested in a randomized controlled trial. Intervention topics include providing psychoeducation on error sensitivity, responding positively to mistakes, modeling positive reactions to mistakes, challenging yourself, listening to your "mistake buddy" and not your "mistake bully", and making mistakes on purpose. The present study used quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the implementation characteristics of this novel intervention program, including perceived acceptability, appropriateness, and participation fidelity. Quantitatively, both parents and children self-reported high perceived acceptability and appropriateness at two time points. Participants adhered to just over one third of the weekly modules on average. Coded transcripts from semi-structured interviews conducted with parents and children (18 parents, 14 children) were thematically analyzed, yielding four themes: Content Embraced and Implemented, Acceptable Delivery with Room for Improvement, Diverse Family Characteristics and Needs, and Positive Changes. Qualitative data revealed the program to be acceptable and appropriate to parents and children, with somewhat more variability in perceived appropriateness. Participation fidelity was variable with respect to the proportion of weekly activities completed, timing of completing the weekly activities, and enactment of strategies learned. Participants provided useful feedback regarding the program content, delivery, engagement strategies, and desired dose of intervention. Barriers and facilitators of engagement were also identified, which pertained to program and family characteristics. The intervention components of psychoeducation, responding positively to errors, modeling positive reactions to mistakes, and parent-child interactive activities emerged as essential components of the program. Results suggest that the novel, preventive digital-health intervention targeting error sensitivity is largely acceptable and appropriate to families, and that further refinement of the program may enhance the program's implementation potential (e.g., further gamify the program, create a mobile app, increase customizability, include additional content modules and examples). Results also have implications for other digital-health interventions, preventive programs, programs targeting error sensitivity or perfectionism, psychosocial interventions for parent-child dyads, programs for preschool-aged children, and qualitative methodologies with young children.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
children, digital mental health intervention, engagement, parenting, perfectionism, qualitative

Alexandria Meyer, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lyndsay N. Jenkins, University Representative; Michael J. Kofler, Committee Member; Walter R. Boot, Committee Member; Anne E. Barrett, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Essays in Applied Microeconomics

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation is composed of three papers, each examining how households value an exogenous change in neighborhood amenities. The first chapter combines data from police incident reports to examine property values pre and post homicide. The second chapter examines move rates of owner-occupied single-family households whose next-door neighbor transitions from an owner-occupied single-family home to a renter-occupied single-family home. The third chapter examines how COVID-19 affected property values near Metrorail transit stations. The first chapter of my dissertation is called "Impact of a Homicide on Nearby Property Values: New Evidence from Miami-Dade County" In this paper, I look at the impact of a homicide on nearby property values. Employing a difference-in- difference methodology, I exploit a unique dataset containing dates and locations of homicides in Miami-Dade County over the period 2010-2018. I examine variation in property values pre and post-homicide within 0.1 miles, 0.1-0.2 miles, and 0.2-0.3 miles of a homicide. I find that homes within 0.1 miles post homicide sell for 4.8% less compared to homes slightly further away, significant at the 1% level. I then leverage data from police incident reports and the Florida Supplemental Homicide Report to obtain demographic characteristics for victims(s) and offender(s) in each homicide case. I find no statistically significant relationship between a particular offender group on housing prices post homicide. I do find a statistically significant negative relationship between all victim groups under 18, regardless of race or gender. This effect is most pronounced for white female victims under 18, as homes within 0.1 miles post homicide sell for 16.3% less. The second chapter is called "Do Renters Actually Cause Homeowners to Move: New Evidence from a Nearest Neighbors Design". This chapter uses a nearest neighbors design similar to Bayer et al (2024) to examine move rates of owner-occupied single family households whose next-door neighbor transitioned from an owner-occupied single-family home to a renter-occupied single-family home against owner- occupied households between two and five doors down who did not receive such a neighbor in the same quarter-year. I find those in the treatment group have a 7.24% higher move rate compared to households in the control group statistically significant at the 10% level. This effect is more pronounced for census blocks in the bottom and top quintile of the single-family rental rate distribution and census blocks in the top quintile of the churn rate distribution. Finally, I look at rental type and I find no statistically significant effect for non-corporate rentals as opposed to corporate rentals where the treatment group has a 11.12% higher move rate compared to the control group statistically significant at the 10% level. The third chapter is called "The Impact of Close Proximity to Metrorail Stations on Property Values during COVID-19 in Miami-Dade County". This chapter examines the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on property values near Metrorail transit stations in Miami-Dade County, Florida, using a difference-in-differences methodology. Results show that housing prices within 1/3 miles of a Metrorail station decreased by 12.2% post-COVID-19, with a persistent effect up to 1 mile. The heterogeneous impact analysis reveals that the negative effect was more pronounced in neighborhoods with high population density, older populations, higher income levels, and a higher share of Democrat voters. These findings suggest that the pandemic has altered households' valuation of urban amenities, particularly in neighborhoods with specific socioeconomic and political characteristics. The study highlights the need for targeted policy interventions to mitigate the negative effects on specific communities and adapt urban development strategies to changing preferences in the wake of the pandemic.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Economics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Access to Transit, COVID-19, Crime Economics, Economics, Neighborhood Change, Valuation of Amenities
Keith Ihlanfeldt, Professor Directing Dissertation; Daniel Broxterman, University Representative; Fan Yang, Committee Member; Luke Rodgers, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Magneto-Transport Properties of a Two-Dimensional Centrosymmetric Ferromagnet and Its Heterostructure

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The study of magnetism and superconductivity in the highly crystalline two-dimensional(2D) materials became possible after the discovery of graphene in 2004, which led to the exploration of many other compounds. In this dissertation, I will focus on two main projects: the investigating of topological spin textures or charges in exfoliated Fe5−xGeTe2 where we found evidence that we write them with a magnetic field and detect them via a simple Hall response even without any external magnetic field; and a study on the possibility of stabilizing unconventional superconductivity in in NbSe2/Fe5GeTe2 heterostructures. Evidence for "written" topological charges is provided by micromagnetic simulations, Lorentz Transmission Electron Microscopy (LTEM) measurement, and analysis. We also found a "magic" thickness of ∼ 30 nm in Fe5−xGeTe2 where the areal density of topological spin textures becomes maximum, inducing large magnitudes for the topological charge density, and large anomalous and topological Hall effects. The exfoliation tunes the relative strengths between dipolar and exchange interactions. This modification affects the density of chiral spin textures, affecting the Berry phase of the flowing charge carriers in real and reciprocal spaces. When this material is stacked with a 2D superconductor such as NbSe2, the superconductivity is affected by the proximity effect through the interface and its transport properties deviate from those of NbSe2. The proximity effect was investigated via the magnetic field dependence of the resistivity of three samples having different thicknesses of the NbSe2 crystal and through I -V characteristics.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Device fabrication, Ferromagnet, Heterostructure, Magneto-transport property, Topological charge, Two-dimensional material

Luis Balicas, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hitesh Changlani, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Michael Shatruk, University Representative; Peng Xiong, Committee Member; Vandana Tripathi, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Characterizing the Tropical Hydroclimate Response to the 8.2Ka Event

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The 8.2ka Event, a prominent climate anomaly that occurred approximately 8,200 years before present (yr BP), has been the subject of extensive research due to its potential implications for understanding past and future climate variability. This thesis focuses on characterizing the tropical hydroclimate response to the 8.2ka Event using a multiproxy data compilation and an isotope-enabled model simulation to constrain the timing, duration, and magnitude of hydroclimate anomalies associated with the 8.2ka Event, comparing the reconstructed hydroclimate response to water isotope-enabled model simulations, and quantifying the agreement between the two approaches to reduce uncertainties. Here, an updated compilation of 70 high-resolution tropical hydroclimate-sensitive proxies is presented, and the timing and duration of hydroclimate anomalies through the pantropics is calculated using Bayesian age ensembles and a robust, objective changepoint detection algorithm which propagates age uncertainties through event detection analyses. When age uncertainties are explicitly accounted for, hydroclimate anomalies associated with the 8.2ka Event are detected in approximately 29\% of the records in the compilation, with a median start age of 8246 yr BP (8.25ka), a median termination at 8101 yr BP (8.10ka), and a median duration of 160 years. Anomalous conditions are characterized by regional drying in southern Central America; northern, northwestern, and southeastern South America; the Arabian Peninsula; and regions of South and East Asia. Conversely, regionally wetter conditions prevailed over the Caribbean; northeastern South America; southeastern Africa; the southern Tibetan Plateau; and the South China Sea. Notably, there is no clear pantropical north-south hydroclimate dipole, but significant regional variability. In an isotope-enabled model simulation, freshwater forcing across the North Atlantic leads to a broad southward shift in tropical rainfall, resulting in a generally drier Northern Hemisphere and wetter Southern Hemisphere, but with large regional variations. Large changes in the isotopic composition of tropical rainfall also occur. Over the oceans, the isotopic anomalies are generally consistent with the "amount effect," wherein areas characterized by drying have more isotopically enriched precipitation and areas of wetting have more isotopically depleted precipitation. However, changes in precipitation isotopes are more decoupled from changes in precipitation amount over land. The proxy data compare somewhat well with the model simulation. When comparing simulated speleothem $\delta$$^{18}$O from NE South American sites to real speleothem $\delta$$^{18}$O, a fair level of agreement is seen ($\kappa_w$ = 0.38). However, no agreement is found between simulated East Asian speleothem $\delta$$^{18}$O and real speleothem $\delta$$^{18}$O in the region ($\kappa_w$ = 0), indicating the complexity of simulating the regional hydroclimatology in the model. These results highlight both the advantages and challenges of quantitative data-model comparison, and serve as a lower-bound estimate of data-model uncertainty. Overall, this thesis provides new insights into the tropical hydroclimate response to the 8.2ka Event, emphasizing the importance of accounting for age uncertainty in hydroclimate reconstructions, comparing with isotope-enabled model data, and incorporating proxy system models into data-model comparisons. The findings highlight regional hydroclimate variability and the challenges in comparing model simulations and proxy data.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Alyssa Atwood, Professor Directing Thesis; Angela Knapp, Committee Member; Hussein Sayani, Committee Member; Zhaohua Wu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Structure and Measurement of the Working Memory System in Elementary-School Children

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Working memory (WM) is an area of increased interest in fields studying children and their development because of the associations between WM and other developmental outcomes of interest. Consensus among theoretical perspectives of WM describe it as a broad system or set of processes responsible for the active storage and processing of information. However, clarification of the structure of the WM system and the tasks used to measure the constructs is imperative as work moves forward to investigate the associations between the components of the WM system and outcomes of interest. This study used a CFA approach to determine the structure of the WM system as measured by a variety of WM tasks. Results of confirmatory factor analyses of data from 177 elementary-school-aged children (51% female; mean age 113.86 months, SD = 14.82) indicated that the best fitting model to the data suggested a two-factor structure of the WM system that distinguished between tasks primarily by the sensory qualities of their input (i.e., verbal or visuospatial), rather than by their processing demands (i.e., storage or storage-plus-processing). Additionally, results of the S-1 Bifactor models in this study indicated that what is common among all measures of the WM system may be heavily influenced by verbal processing skills, even when the main stimulus of the task itself is visual. Overall, results of this study suggest that previous research pointing toward distinct relations between the influence of verbal and visuospatial WM on developmental outcomes of interest may be misguided.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
