mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Have We Left Educators Behind?
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Narrative Inquiry on Educators with Unresolved Trauma

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The unique study "Have We Left Educators Behind: A Narrative Inquiry on Educators with Unresolved Trauma" delved into the distinctive impact of unresolved trauma on teachers' professional identity, classroom environments, and interactions with students. This research, which stood out for its use of narrative inquiry, involved seven teachers from the Broward County Public Schools, a specific and significant location, and collected data through in-depth interviews and journaling. The findings revealed that unresolved trauma adversely affected teachers' self-efficacy, leading to conflicts with professional identity, difficulties in classroom management, and challenging interactions with students. The teachers in this study often experienced emotional volatility—rapid or unpredictable mood or emotional state changes characterized by frequent and intense emotional reactions (e.g., anger, sadness, dissociation)—and anxiety, which could disrupt classroom dynamics (environment and interactions). However, some teachers reported increased resilience and empathy, enhancing their teaching practices. The study underscored the importance of trauma-informed practices and comprehensive mental health support within educational institutions designed specifically for educators. Recommendations also included implementing trauma-informed training, revising educational policies to address teachers' unique challenges and mental needs, and fostering a supportive school culture. Addressing these issues is essential for improving teacher retention, job satisfaction, and educational outcomes. The study shows the need for systemic change to support educators' mental health and well-being, ultimately benefitting both teachers and students.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Patrice Iatarola, Professor Directing Dissertation; Maxine Jones, University Representative; Carolyn Herrington, Committee Member; Jeffrey Milligan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Evaluation of a Self-Monitoring Intervention to Reduce Safety Behaviors in Social Anxiety
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Randomized Controlled Trial

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Introduction: Previous research supports the use of safety behavior (SB) fading paradigms as a potential intervention for social anxiety symptoms. Technology-based interventions have been demonstrated to be acceptable and efficacious in the treatment of social anxiety disorder, and SB fading experimental paradigms utilizing daily monitoring of SBs have demonstrated efficacy in reducing social anxiety symptoms compared to no instruction controls. However, to date, these protocols have not been tested against an active control condition. The current study evaluated the efficacy of a brief text message-based SB fading intervention against a credible control intervention. Method: Participants with elevated social anxiety symptoms (N = 74) were recruited from across the United States and randomized to receive one of two 14-day behavior fading interventions. Participants were sent daily behavior monitoring checklists and reminders to fade either SBs or unhealthy behaviors (UB). All participants were given measures of social anxiety, SB use, loneliness, depression, and general anxiety symptoms at baseline, post-treatment and at one-month follow-up. Results: The SB fading intervention led to marginally significant lower SB use at one month follow-up compared to the UB intervention, with a small to medium effect size, though these effects were not present at post-treatment. The SB intervention did not lead to significantly lower social anxiety symptoms at post-treatment or one month follow-up. However, a small to medium effect was detected at follow-up such that SB fading led to lower social anxiety (sr2 = 061). In individuals who completed two or more checklists, SB fading led to significantly lower SB use and social anxiety symptoms at follow-up compared to the control intervention. No treatment differences were found on other outcomes, though this may have been due to low power. Greater number of checklists completed was associated with lower social anxiety at post-treatment in the SB group but not the UB group. Discussion: This study provides initial effect sizes to support further examining a brief SB fading intervention in a larger randomized controlled trial. Limitations and directions for future research are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Jesse R. Cougle, Professor Directing Dissertation; Stephen Tripodi, University Representative; N. Brad Schmidt, Committee Member; Alexandria Meyer, Committee Member; Jon K. Maner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Training at Lockheed Martin Space
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Kirkpatrick Evaluation of Current Practices and Impact on Employee Retention

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The study conducted a survey to assess employee perceptions of online training practices at the Space Business Area at Lockheed Martin Corp (LMC), specifically within the Space Business Area (BA), to evaluate current training and its correlation with employee retention. Utilizing the New World Kirkpatrick Model (NWKM), the survey measured four levels: Level 1 (Engagement, Relevance, and Customer Satisfaction), Level 2 (Attitude, Confidence, and Commitment), Level 3 (On-The-Job Behaviors and Drivers), Level 4 (Leading Indicators & Organizational Results) and Level 4 (Individual Results & Retention). Descriptive statistics were used to evaluate training at each level, and multiple regression analysis was conducted to determine the impact of current online training practices on employee retention. The sample included 72 employees, but results were limited to Space BA, and constraints were placed on recruitment and data collection. The survey responses revealed moderate levels of engagement and satisfaction with training, with 66% indicating lower engagement due to job priorities, irrelevance, and lack of incentives. Engagement increased with job tenure, especially among those in their 2nd to 5th year. While 28% found the training relevant, newer and older employees perceived it as more useful despite minimal incentives. High commitment to training was reported by 71%, with lower commitment linked to unclear expectations, lack of support, and confidence issues. Training positively impacted job behavior, with 57% applying what they learned, influenced by resources, accountability, and peer support. However, 43% struggled with application due to other priorities and lack of support. The overall organizational impact was moderately positive, with 65% rating the online training at a 6 or higher (on a scale of 10). Positive impacts were noted in quality of work, customer satisfaction, peer relationships, and productivity, but not on the participant perceptions of organizational mission. In light of the issues with normality and homogeneity in the data that require caution in the interpretation of the findings, the regression model showed a weak but significant effect of training on retention, with no statistical significance found in the individual impact of Level 1, Level 2, and Level 3 on retention. Exploratory analysis of the impact of a select set of factors from each level revealed that commitment to applying training to work and seeing positive results from the training are factors and intermediary outcomes that can influence employee retention. More exploratory analysis indicated that training impact perceptions varied with job tenure, with newer employees reporting the highest ratings, followed by longer-tenured employees, while those with 1-5 years reported the lowest ratings, largely because this group often reported having higher and competing priorities at work. Finally, the findings in this study reveal that factors from Levels 1, 2, and 3 were weakly associated with retention and that higher commitment to training and more personal results observed after training are specific factors that were found to be correlated with higher intention to stay on the job. Overall, these findings imply that effective training programs should be relevant, engaging, and aligned with job responsibilities and organizational goals. Providing incentives, clear expectations, resources, and accountability is crucial. Training should be adaptable to different job tenures, with continuous evaluation and feedback to identify areas for improvement. Ensuring training is useful and worthwhile can enhance its impact on job behavior and organizational effectiveness, ultimately improving job performance, satisfaction, and retention based on the results of the exploratory regression analysis.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Great Resignation, Lockheed Martin, New World Kirkpatrick Model, Online Training, Retention
Allan Jeong, Professor Directing Dissertation; Paul Cottle, University Representative; Fengfeng Ke, Committee Member; Sherry Southerland, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Atlas of Disquiet

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Atlas of Disquiet follows its speaker as she reckons with exile as a physical and psychic state. Engaging with international travel, home, girlhood, femininity, gender and religious violence, militarization, familial and domestic intimacy, food, and other quotidian malaises and wonders, Atlas interrogates the symptoms of the speaker's exclusion—as migrant, Muslim, daughter, woman, and citizen—as if to ask what anxieties and intimacies can be scavenged in the face of displacement, loss, and estrangement? Inspired by the progressive vision and cross-cultural poetics of contemporary thinkers and writers of exile, Atlas seeks to craft its own poetics of defamiliarization and belonging using free verse, a confessional style, and lyric and narrative gestures. Against conflicting attachments and a refusal to adjust, it displays a renewed cartography of dissonance and difference that seeks to assimilate the speaker's divergent roots. This dissertation opens with a critical introduction that situates the poems within a definition and an exploration of exile by prominent thinkers and contemporary poets.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
James Kimbrell, Professor Directing Dissertation; Silvia Valisa, University Representative; Barbara Hamby, Committee Member; David Kirby, Committee Member; Robert Stilling, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Context Matters
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Advancing Equity in Public Management, Policy Design, and Policy Implementation

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation focuses on state-level interventions that deliver Federal policies to local recipients and investigates how policy design and implementation influence social equity outcomes, one of the core values of public administration. Notably, three essays in this dissertation provide original theoretical and practical contributions by focusing on the contexts that shape the direction and effectiveness of policy design and implementation. The first essay explores the impact of affirmative action bans at the state level on female representation in law enforcement. This study finds that affirmative action bans disproportionately reduce female representation, even though the legislation asserts neutrality. The original theoretical framework developed in this study expands the scope of representative bureaucracy by highlighting that policy interventions and historical passive representation can shape current and future passive representation. The second essay examines contracting out and the social equity outcomes at the program partner and service recipient levels. Utilizing the publicness framework, the findings suggest that public agencies and quasi-public authorities yield better social equity outcomes than private entities when delivering federal grant programs to small businesses. This study bridges the scholarship on contracting out with the publicness framework, emphasizing the importance of publicness in achieving equitable resource distribution. The third essay focuses on the role of external assistance organizations in mitigating administrative burdens in the Federal economic development and technology transfer program. The study shows that the presence of external assistance organizations at the state level enhances client success, particularly in states with less favorable policy environments characterized by lower job creation rates. This study fills gaps in the scholarship on administrative burdens by highlighting the role of external assistance organizations in economic development. Overall, this dissertation demonstrates that variations in policy design and implementation significantly shape social equity outcomes across different contexts. Each of the three essays offers theoretical contributions by expanding the scope of existing theories, connecting different literatures, and filling gaps in scholarship. Furthermore, the findings suggest practical implications for policymakers, emphasizing the need for nuanced policy design and implementation to promote social equity in public administration.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Daniel L. Fay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael McFarland, University Representative; Frances Stokes Berry, Committee Member; Danielle Atkins, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring Grief and Aggression through an Adolescent Art Therapy Bereavement Program

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Using a case study of clients in an art therapy bereavement program, this dissertation examined the relationship between grief and aggression in adolescents, particularly in response to violent, violent, and traumatic deaths. Through an existential perspective, the relationship between aggression and grief is examined, particularly the triangulation between deceased, bereaved, and group members process that can occur in a group therapy setting. Art therapy is used to provide an outlet for the repressed grief, as bereaved youth explore and process loss through symbolic expression and reconstruction of relationship to the deceased. The bereavement program introduced, BraveHeart in Schools, is illustrated to emphasize the need for rituals and cessation. As demonstrated through participants, this collaborative program assisted young people to develop interpersonal skills, empathic social connections, and potential reduction of aggressive symptoms. This study utilized a qualitative approach and incorporated observations, semi-structured interviews, and views of the client's artwork to better understand how art therapy can aid in processing.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Art Therapy, Being-in-the-world, Being-towards-death, Complicated grief, Disenfranchised grief, Meaningful being
David E. Gussak, Professor Directing Dissertation; Stephen J. Tripodi, University Representative; Jeff Broome, Committee Member; Barbara F. Parker-Bell, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: B-Me Experience
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Recruitment, Resilience and Self-Care for Black Men Artist Educators

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study was an exploration into the lived histories of four study subjects—all Black men working as art teachers—to delve deeper into the intricacies of their educational journeys of becoming and being Black Men Art Educators in K-12 learning spaces. The marginalization and lack of representation of Black men in art education called for an examination of the quality of experiences for these helping professionals. Exposure to burnout, gendered microaggression and racial battle fatigue when working in the education field contributes to the low population of Black men seeking and retaining positions as K-12 educators in the U.S. The aim of this study was to engage BMAE participants in a process of multimodal art reflection and to make meaning of their lived experiences as Black male K-12 educators. The research questions were developed to elevate the voices of participants by highlighting perceived barriers, comprehend the process of choosing education as a career, and discover anecdotes of resilience through career stages in art education. A critical review of salient literature and existing programs focused on pathways that lead to recruiting and training more Black male teachers and preservice teachers. With an emphasis on Black males who teach art in elementary, middle, and high schools, this study identified strategies for buttressing representation in these educational spaces. More broadly, this study used tenets of pragmatism and critical race theory to make meaning of the lived experiences of Black male artist educators through a three-part qualitative interview series. My methodological approach, then, involved three qualitative interviews conducted with each participant and also multimodal art making experiences that revealed new understandings related to personal, behavioral, and environmental factors that impact the pursuit of recruitment, resilience, and self-care for BMAE. Using a preliminary questionnaire to solicit the participation of qualifying volunteers, I collected data from four Black male artist educators in the Washington DC metropolitan area. From there, I engaged in qualitative methods that employed a three-part interview and multimodal art making protocol with each participant. Through this approach I revealed rich insights from the study subjects' life histories related to being and becoming BMAE in K-12 educational spaces. The pertinent findings of this study were reported as participant profiles and highlighted each subject's teacher origin stories. Pseudonym assignments were given to each participant to conceal their identities and ensure anonymity. The codes and categories produced in the data analysis process revealed identity construction (personal and professional) as a thematic connector. This dissertation research is important work, and it contributes to the field of art education and the salient literature on the actions and experiences of Black men teaching art in K-12 classrooms. The findings support recruitment and retention efforts of the less than 2% of the K-12 educator population in the United States—specifically focusing on the professional and creative development of BMAE at the preservice and in-service levels. Practical implications for the field of art education include issues associated with preservice preparedness and alternative pathways that may lead to an increased pool of qualified Black men applicants for the educator pipeline, Additional findings address the need for establishing affirming communities to enhance a sense of belonging for BMAE. This research underscores the importance of recognizing and addressing the B-ME teaching experiences, and its contribution to the field of art education on the actions and experiences of Black men teaching art in K-12 classrooms.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
art teacher, Black male educator, Black men art educator, recruitment, resilience, self-care
Jeffrey L. Broome, Professor Directing Dissertation; Cameron Beatty, University Representative; Karina Donald, Committee Member; Amber Ward, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Health Behaviors in the LGB+ Population
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Variation across Adulthood and by Southern Residency Status

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Variation in health behaviors by sexual orientation is important to study because research shows that LGB people generally report worse mental and physical health than their heterosexual counterparts. These inequalities in physical and mental health might be partially explained by disparities in health behaviors. Research shows that sexual minorities often engage in more health-deleterious behaviors than heterosexuals – likely as a result of the stress they face as members of minoritized groups. However, research on these differences focuses almost exclusively on early stages of the life course, revealing patterns that may not be applicable to middle and later life when stress related to sexual minority status may be lower. In addition, almost no research considers that sexual minority status patterns in health behaviors may be different in the South – a relatively religious, conservative political context – compared with other regions of the United States. I use data from the National Health Interview Survey (2016-2018; n=5,279) to examine the relationship between sexual minority status and engagement with health behaviors, with an emphasis on variation by age and Southern residency status. I find that sexual minorities tend to engage in more health deleterious behaviors than heterosexuals and this difference tends to be largest at younger compared with older ages. In addition, I find regional differences in this age variation, but the direction of these differences in mixed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Age Variation, Health Behaviors, LGBTQ Populations, South
Anne E. Barrett, Professor Directing Dissertation; Frank Wong, University Representative; Koji Ueno, Committee Member; Amy Burdette, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring the Driving Forces Behind Gen-Z's Usage Motives on Video-Based Social Media Platforms through the Lens of Purchase Intentions and Engagement Behaviors

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Understanding consumer usage motivations on social media video-based platforms is a critical area of study for scholars and practitioners. It encompasses interaction, participation, and emotional connection between consumers and brands on social media platforms. The study's results provide valuable insights for researchers and marketers, helping them understand the motivations and gratifications that drive Gen-Z's (18 -25 years old) social media engagement behavior and purchase intentions regarding branded video content with relation to social interaction, archiving, self-expression, escapism, peeking, trendiness uses and gratifications motives. The study highlights that peeking emerged as the strongest predictor of Gen-Z's intentions to purchase products or services from a brand and the primary motivation to engage with social media branded content. Insights into consumer behaviors help tailor strategies, leading to improved brand perception, customer satisfaction, and potential business growth. In summary, this research contributes to the existing knowledge by examining the motivations and gratifications of Gen-Z consumers in the context of social media engagement and purchase intentions with branded video content. Studying consumer motivations and engagement in social media marketing bridges academic research and practical application, fostering a mutually beneficial relationship between scholars and practitioners in developing effective digital marketing strategies. This research provides insights into users' motivation to use video-based social media content and how these motivations affect purchasing intentions and social media engagement behavior further to understand the brand-consumer relationships and overall advertising efforts performance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Digital Marketing & Branded Content, Gen-Z Consumers, Purchase Intentions, Social Media, Social Media Engagement Behavior (SMEB), Uses and Gratifications Theory
Jaejin Lee, Professor Directing Thesis; Sindy Chapa, Committee Member; Katherine Dale, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Analysis of Small Molecules Released from Islets of Langerhans with Liquid Chromatography-Tandem Mass Spectrometry

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this dissertation, liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) was applied for the quantitation of small molecules released from murine and human islets of Langerhans. Islets are known to release hormones for the proper maintenance of blood glucose homeostasis. A variety of small molecules, including classical neurotransmitters, are also released from islets. While the roles of most of these small molecules are unknown, some are thought to be involved in intra- and inter-islet communication, and eventually in hormone regulation. While several methods have been developed to monitor small molecules released from islets of Langerhans, these methods are mostly CE based or measure a few analytes at a time. In addition, the lack of detection selectivity of CE-based methods necessitates the development of alternative approaches. LC-MS/MS offers the advantages of improved quantitation, excellent detection selectivity and sensitivity when operated in multiple reaction monitoring mode. To better understand the role of small molecules in islet function, a liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) method was developed to separate and quantify 39 small molecules released from islets. Benzoyl chloride derivatization of analyte molecules was used to impart retention and facilitate electrospray ionization efficiency. Separation was achieved on a 2.1 x 150 mm column packed with 2.7 μm superficially porous C18 particles. Calibration curves showed excellent linearity between the concentration and analyte response, with relative standard deviations of the analyte responses below 15% and limits of detection from 0.01 – 40 nM. The method was applied to examine small molecules released from murine and human islets of Langerhans after static incubation and perfusion with glucose. Results showed a decrease in secretion rates with increasing glucose concentration for most of the analytes. Secretion rates were found to be higher in human islets compared to their murine counterpart. This method will be useful in understanding the roles of small molecules in biological systems. D-amino acids (D-AAs) are important signaling molecules due to their ability to bind ionotropic N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors. D-serine (D-Ser), D-alanine (D-Ala), and D-aspartate (D-Asp) have been found individually in the endocrine portion of the pancreas, the islets of Langerhans, and/or their secretions. However, there have been no reports of a comprehensive assessment of D-AAs in islet lysates or secretions. To evaluate the release of these compounds, the effectiveness of both 1-(9-fluorenyl)-ethyl chloroformate (FLEC reagent) and 1-fluoro-2,4-dinitrophenyl-5-L-alanine amide (Marfey's reagent, MR) in separation of D/L-AA enantiomeric pairs in islet-specific buffers were evaluated. MR-derivatized D/L AAs showed greater than baseline resolution (Rs ≥ 1.5) of 13 enantiomeric pairs when using a non-linear gradient and an acidic mobile phase system, while FLEC-derivatized AAs exhibited limited resolution on both biphenyl and C18 columns. The optimized MR method yielded highly reproducible separations with retention times less than 1% RSD. Excellent linearity between the analyte concentrations and response (R2 > 0.98) were obtained, with less than 15% RSD for all analyte responses. Most analytes had an LOD at or below 100 nM, except for L-Ala (200 nM). The optimized MR method was used to quantify D-AAs in secretions and lysates of murine islets after incubation in 3- and 20-mM glucose. In response to both solutions, D-Ser and D-glutamine were detected in both the secretions and lysates, while D-Ala and D-Asp were detected only in lysates. Although the absolute secreted amounts of both L- and D-AAs decreased in response to elevated glucose, the amount of D-AAs as compared to its corresponding L-enantiomer increased. We hypothesize that this is due to the metabolism of L-AAs being used metabolically during these states, resulting in an increase in the relative amount of D-AA secreted. The developed method is robust and can be applied to further examine the release of D-AAs and their potential roles in islet physiology.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
amino acids, benzoyl chloride, chiral separation, islets of Langerhans, liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry, marfey's reagent
Michael G. Roper, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sanjay Kumar, University Representative; Christian Bleiholder, Committee Member; Hong Li, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Different Dreams in Public Service Encounters
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Citizen Behavior, Technology, Policy Tools, and a Quest for Access to Public Services

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation broadens the perspectives of policy tools and citizen behavior in policy implementation research. Considering the impact of government actions on communities' quality of life, identifying potential barriers and enablers to citizen engagement and participation is crucial for effective governance and developing targeted interventions that are more likely to be successful. This dissertation provides a holistic framework to understand complex citizen behavior. Three essays in this dissertation employ interdisciplinary approaches from various fields of study, such as policy, information, and design sciences, behavioral economics, marketing, and public management by utilizing multiple analytic techniques. In order to identify and effectively address the needs and concerns of its citizens, the government must not only understand perspectives and interests of its citizens, but also is required to listen to feedback of how citizens would respond to its actions. This can help foster a more accountable, transparent and effective government for enhancing human dignity. This dissertation employs inter-disciplinary approaches from various fields of studies – policy, information, and design sciences, behavioral economics, marketing, and public management – and utilizing multiple analytic techniques to a holistic framework of citizen motivation and behavior.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Reubin O'D Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Frances S. Berry, Professor Directing Dissertation; Charles Barrilleaux, University Representative; Keon-Hyung Lee, Committee Member; Daniel L. Fay, Committee Member; Tian Tang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Psychological and Social Outcomes of Physical Activity among Children, Adolescents, and Adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Systematic Review and Metaanalysis

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is defined as "a complex developmental condition involving persistent challenges with social communication, restricted interests, and repetitive behavior" (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). The prevalence of ASD has been identified regardless of ethnic, racial, and socioeconomic status, and the prevalence rates of ASD population have increased continuously (Dietz et al., 2020; Maenner et al., 2023). Although there is no specific curative treatment for people with ASD (Shenoy et al., 2017), physical activity is known to be beneficial in alleviating the symptoms of extensive comorbidities, chronic diseases, depression, and anxiety among people with ASD (Sefen et al., 2020). Also, physical activity is treated as a cost-effective treatment compared to other treatments or therapies, being more affordable and versatile for people with ASD, reducing the burden of expenditures on healthcare utilization (Chan et al., 2020; Vohra et al., 2017). However, people with ASD had lower participation rates in physical activity compared to the general population due to the high existence of social and environmental barriers (Arkesteyn et al., 2023). For this study, a systematic review and meta-analysis were used to visit the current body of literature and address the research questions. Systematic review is the process of identification and evaluation of data from primary databases to the pre-defined research question based on the eligibility criteria (Pollock & Berge, 2018). Meta-analysis is a statistical method to synthesize the data from a systematic review to calculate the effect size based on the mean and variance of population effects from various studies identified with the same research question (Field and Gillett, 2010). Ten major databases, including APA PsycINFO, SPORTDiscus with Full Text, EMBASE, Medline (PubMed), Cochrane Library, PubMed (NLM), APA PsycArticles, CINAHL, ERIC (ProQuest), and Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA) were used to search and extract the previous studies. For the methodological results, a total of 81 articles were included in the systematic review after the screening process. The Mixed Methods Appraisal Tool (MMAT) was used to assess the quality of the research. 81 studies were included as the final results, with none excluded based on the quality assessment results (Hong et al., 2018). The quantitative design studies used for the meta-analysis data evaluated the risk of bias with the Effective Public Health Practice Project (EPHPP) Quality Assessment Tool (Effective Public Health Practice Project, 2009) under the weak, moderate, and strong rating. A total of 46 studies with 46 independent samples, including 865 participants, qualified for the overall inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis. Comprehensive Meta-Analysis (CMA) version 4 and Jamovi version 2.5 software were used to calculate the effect size in Hedge's g (Borenstein et al., 2021). The meta-analysis results were reported with statistical results, funnel plots, and forest plots. The psychological and social outcomes of different physical activity modes (i.e., unorganized physical activity, exercise, and sport) and different age brackets (i.e., children, adolescents, and adults) were found in the systematic review. The psychological and social outcomes of unorganized physical activity were the development of social communication, relationship, responsiveness, attachment behavior, cooperation, trust, social effectiveness, quality of life, receptive language skills, communicative language skills, socialization skills, individual self-esteem, confidence, positive self-perception, emotional response, great fun along with diminished stress and antisocial stereotypic behavior. Improved social interaction, adaptive behavior, social motivation, coordination, affective engagement, interaction quality, social communication, peer relations, verbal communication abilities, positive emotional expression, emotional inference, self-calmness and reduced level of stereotyped behaviors, sadness, anger, anxiety, fear, social withdrawal, and maladaptive behavior were reported as the psychological and social outcomes of exercise. Sport participation positively impacted relationship skills, social interactions, communication, emotional responses, self-esteem, self-competence, self-awareness, perceived competence, enjoyment, emotional exertion, and alleviation of anxiety, depressive symptoms, and negative emotional responses. The psychological and social outcomes of physical activity among children were reported in enhanced communication, socialization skills, verbal language skills, verbal and non-verbal communication skills, turn-taking skills, interpersonal skills, social reciprocity, and social effectiveness. Also, children experienced reduced socially maladaptive behavior, stereotyped behavior, antisocial behavior, sadness, anger, anxiety, fear, aggression, affect states, and depressive symptoms. Adolescents aged between 14 and 17 years old had positive outcomes in developing psychosocial well-being, self-calming, and socially targeted skills, including eye contact, contributing relevant information, and turn-taking skills. Adults were found to have a higher quality of life, psychological well-being, enhanced intrapersonal factors (i.e., self-concept, belief, and development history), interpersonal relationships (i.e., family systems, friends, acquaintances, and social groups), enjoyment, perceived exertion, affective engagement, competence, self-esteem, confidence, self-perception, mood, and emotional inference. The direction of the overall effect size of physical activity was positive (65%) with a small effect size (g=0.157). The direction of effect size in all different modes of physical activity, including unorganized physical activity (80%), exercise (65%), and sport (71%), were positive. In the comparison of different modes of physical activity, the unorganized physical activity had the largest effect size (g=0.379), and the smallest effect size was found in the exercise (g=0.086). Due to the limited calculable data among the final results, no study was included as the meta-analysis data for the adolescents. The effect size direction of children was majorly positive (62%), while the adult direction had a negative direction (67%). In the comparison of different age brackets (children and adults), the adults (g=0.464) were reported to have a larger effect size than the children (g=0.0016). The current study examined physical activity's psychological and social outcomes among children, adolescents, and adults with ASD using systematic review and meta-analysis. From the comparison of different modes of physical activity, unorganized physical activity can be an effective method resulting in positive psychological and social outcomes due to the less competition and regulations characteristics of participation (Arkesteyn et al., 2023). Even though the effectiveness of physical activity among the adult population was reported, the study still targeted super-aged adults who are over 70 (Suzuki, 2018), as well as adolescents, and it needs to be developed in the future. Considering the effectiveness of integration in various measurements and study designs, future studies need to conduct meta-analysis in specific pre-post design studies in which both comparative and treatment groups exist.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Sport Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Amy Chan Hyung Kim, Professor Directing Thesis; Wenjie James Du, Committee Member; Hanhan Xue, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Magnetism and Electronic Complexity in Topological Intermetallic Materials

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Topological materials have gained substantial attention due to their nontrivial band structures and their potential technological application. In parallel, there continues to be strong interest in complex magnetism and the question of how it might be combined with protected topologies to produce new phenomena. Thus motivated, this dissertation focuses on materials that harbor both topological phases and magnetic degrees of freedom. In particular, we present results on Mnintercalated Zr2Te2P, where structural characterization such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) reveals that Mn ions can be intercalated between the Zr layers, leading to the chemical formulas Mn0.06Zr0.03Zr2Te2P. We unexpectedly also find that even the parent compound is also self-intercalated with Zr, leading to the chemical formula Zr0.07Zr2Te2P. The impact of Mn intercalation is evident in the appearance of an anisotropic magnetic susceptibility, where Curie-Weiss fitting indicates that the Mn ions are in a divalent state. Magnetic ordering appears at TM ≈ 4 K and is characterized by a broad transition that is likely due to disordered Mn distribution. Heat capacity and electrical transport measurements show metallic behavior, with an enhanced electronic coefficient γMn ≈ 36.6 mJ/mol-K2 compared to the parent compound. These findings demonstrate that Mn substitution introduces magnetic interactions and tunes the electronic state, suggesting a potential route to producing novel behavior in Zr2Te2P and related ternary tetradymites. Next, we report results for TbSbxTe2−x−δ (x = 0 and 0.50), revealing a complex evolution of the structure going from TbTe1.8 to TbSbTe. To understand this behavior, we propose that there is an intrinsic charge imbalance for TbTe1.8, which causes disorder and structural variation away from the ZrSSi aristotype that is adopted by the charge balanced TbSbTe. This structural variation impacts the magnetic behavior, which exhibits evidence for frustration in TbTe1.8, while TbTe1.34Sb0.50 and TbSbTe simpler antiferromagnetic behavior. Taken together, this shows that this series is a reservoir for rich magnetic phenomena, but further work is needed to assess the evolution of the electronic state. It is also clear that challenges relating to antimony variation and disorder remain to be addressed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Ryan E. Baumbach, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Laura H. Greene, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Susan Latturner, University Representative; Simon Capstick, Committee Member; Hitesh Jaiprakash Changlani, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Black Joy in Green Spaces a Nature-Inspired, Endarkened, Visual Narrative Inquiry about Black Women and Joy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: What you are about to read is an a-typical dissertation developed to amplify the Black Joy message while disrupting the deficit narratives that have traditionally been the undercurrent of research regarding Black women. In response to Dr. Angela Dunbar's (2022) suggestion to "conduct research that moves beyond Black pain. Not just simply a matter of studying positive adjustment as an outcome or moderator of adversity but rather to have complete studies on non-oppressive everyday aspects…" (p. 4), Black Joy in Green Spaces served as a nature-inspired, Black Joy adventure that centered the voice and agency of Black women. Before you embark on this adventure, it is important to center my "current" Black experience that embodies both joy AND pain. I wrote this dissertation while grieving the impending death of my 16-year-old miniature pinscher, Rico, from a battle with cancer complicated by an auto-immune disease diagnosis, blindness, and hearing loss. Presently, I am grieving knowing that by the time you read these words, Rico will no longer be on this earthly plane. The grief is complex because I am being transported to the 10-days in 2016 when I watched the transition of my Mama from her 26-year battle with cancer. The overwhelming sadness experienced over the last several weeks have wreaked havoc on my emotional and mental well-being. Although heartbroken, I remain grateful and hold joy in my spirit. Rico could no longer walk for extended periods of time without falling and falling asleep, but he still enjoyed going for walks. I cradled him in my arms as we felt the gentle caress of the breeze, were kissed by the warmth of the sun, and delighted in the various aromas in the air. Rico transitioned to a spiritual plane, and it was Mother Earth who provided additional comfort during his final days. Through Rico's end-of-life journey, I am living my work in unimaginable ways. In this space, I am learning to deeply reassess the multi-generational narrative of being the "Strong" Black Woman so that I may openly pivot into a place of needing and accepting help. In this space, I am learning to challenge the White, patriarchal, capitalistic system of hyper productivity to let my BE-ing be enough. I have also learned that nature's ability to heal and restore are applicative to life AND death. As my mentor said, "You are in a sacred space and time, right now. Lean into the grief" (Haynes, personal communication, 2023). What you are about to read is that "lean in" process. Black Joy in Green Spaces leaned into the onto-epistemological strengths of Black and Brown women that ranged from both ancestral wisdom and embodied knowing, to Womanist thought, to Endarkened Narrative Inquiry, and to the personal stories from four generations of Black women to explore three primary research questions 1) What is the relationship between joy, green spaces, and Black women's experiences, 2) How does Black Joy show up for Black women who routinely commune with nature, and 3) How are the stories of Black women in green spaces used to conceptualize nature as a place of learning about and through Black Joy? This epic, intergenerational Black Joy adventure will invite you, Beloved SoulFlowers, into a space that creatively offers a novel, nature-inspired approach to address the problems of a flawed higher educational system that devalued pause along with the accompanying problems that comes with adopting an incomplete narrative that leaves Black women feeling a sense of obligation to tend to the needs of others over the needs of self. Black Joy in Green Spaces braided the fields of art education and public health to do more than contribute to a body of knowledge – it contributed to the bodies, minds, and spirits of Black women. This study utilized the primary research methods of walking, photography, and journal writing to enhance the emotional, physical, and social well-being of Black women and presented the findings as a digital storytelling project, Black Joy in Green Spaces: The Web Series, to make the research "realistic" and more relatable. My Beloved SoulFlowers, I choose not to reveal the findings in this abstract. Rather, I invite you to take a collective breath with me as you prepare to step into the world of Black Joy in Green Spaces. Are you ready? If so, join me in three…two…one: BBBRRREEEAAATTTHHHEEE!!! Let's begin…
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Black Joy, Black Women, Kujima Theory of Collective-Self Motivation, Narrative Inquiry, Visual narratives, Womanism
Sara Scott Shields, Professor Directing Dissertation; Donna Nudd, University Representative; Barbara Parker-Bell, Committee Member; Jeff Broome, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Composing Commitment
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Diversity Statements on the Writing Studies Job Market

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Over the years, writing studies scholarship on academic labor has focused primarily on the effects of neoliberalism's effects on the academy (Carter; Hendricks; Kahn and Pason; Scott; Winslow), especially for non-tenured employees (Connors; Doe; Hansel and Baird Giordano; Hansen; Horner; Klausman; Mechenbier; Penrose; Sledd; Taylor et al.). However, there has been a shift to study how other academics navigate their careers by studying emotion/emotional labor (Caswell et al.; Geller and Denny; Micciche) and the experiences of graduate students (Edgington and Taylor; Miller; Mountford). That said, with the exception of Carmen Kynard's, Craig Lamont's, and Staci M. Perryman-Clark's work, academic labor scholarship doesn't extensively connect the concept of "advocacy" while also considering facets of workers' identity (e.g., ability, race, gender, and sexuality). Studying professional documents can provide valuable insights into how individuals in the field of program administration identify themselves as teachers, scholars, and administrators. These documents, which include curriculum vitae, teaching philosophies, administrative vision statements, and research statements, are frequently requested when applying for jobs and are used to create a job applicant's dossier. In other words, more work should be done to answer this question: "How do professionals advocate for their stakeholders (i.e. students, colleagues, community members) from within their own positionalities in terms of academic job status (i.e. tenured or non-tenured) and (un)marked identities (i.e. race, ethnicity sexuality, gender status)? I argue that one way to fill this gap is by studying professional documents like diversity statements. The purpose of this study is to provide insight into writing studies professionals' experiences encountering job market diversity statements. This was a necessary measure if I wanted to assemble best practices on this specific writing task once the data collection and analysis was completed. On a broader scale, I hope to expand the current knowledge of how the field of writing studies—as a scholarly and praxis-driven discipline— conceptualizes commitments to diversity, equity, and inclusion across various job types. These include teaching, but also administration, scholarship, and service to the profession. As such, my research questions aim at identifying the ways my interview and survey participants (writers and readers of diversity statements): a)define each of the following terms: diversity, equity, and inclusion; b) articulate their understanding of a diversity statement's task and purpose; c) identify and reflect on the choices writers and readers make, including what writers include in their statements and the rationales they provide for these choices. To answer these questions, I employed thematic analysis to identify commonalities and differences between my participants' varied interactions with diversity statements. From these methods, I was able to make several tentative findings and point towards implications and further areas of study. Drawing from this data, this study assembles participants' recommended best practices for writing and reviewing diversity statements. It offers two contributions to the discipline. First, it provides a current portrait of what kinds of theories, actions, and values get highlighted in diversity statements. Second, I invite conversations about how employees throughout varied scholarly disciplines and job titles in higher education should use the diversity statement to take action against power structures that cause injustice to our students, colleagues, and communities.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
academic job market, academic labor, diversity statement, genre, writing studies
Michael Neal, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jennifer Proffitt, University Representative; Rhea Estelle Lathan, Committee Member; Elias Domínguez Barajas, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Queering Power of Latina Performance
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Exploration of Latina/X Femininity as Disidentyifying Force in American Culture

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation contributes to discourse examining the performing Latina. Particularly This work looks closely at the Latina/x's whose embodiment and public presentation require the queering act of disidentification. My dissertation zeroes in on interdisciplinary representations of Latinas, who, in literary, visual, and personal forms, offer performances that make these women real. Utilizing a queering definition of Latina performance, my research intersects with literary ideas concerning the performance of national histories, latinidad, gender, sexuality, and media studies. My goal is to examine different modalities of Latina performance that contribute to queer theory's ideas about subverting popular culture. I connect these performative and disidentifying acts of survival as the dissemination of dominant culture continues to erase marginalized subjects. My objects of study consider the historical influences of ethnic, gender, and racial stereotypes in literary and popular texts. Ultimately, Latinas survive within the narrow line of vision offered by dominant Western culture through performances that reinscribe difference as empowering. Considering this legacy, Latinx identities also reflect on how contemporary latinidad, queer culture, and queer theory challenge generalizing narratives of Latin figures.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding the Evolution of Carriers in Tin Cadmium Oxide Ternary Plasmonic Nanocrystals

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation focuses on understanding the plasmonic properties of novel transparent conductive oxides (TCOs), more specifically the family of binary and ternary Sn-Cd-O containing materials. The first chapter introduces the background, fundamental knowledge, concepts, and techniques necessary for the understanding and study of the localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) in nanocrystals (NCs). The second chapter introduces the novel synthesis of a well-faceted cadmium stannate (CTO) inverse spinel plasmonic semiconductor nanocrystals (PSNCs). The use of Sn(II) in the colloidal reaction for CTO results in reproducible octahedral PSNCs. Correlating extinction spectra with magnetic circular dichroism allows the calculation of carrier density and carrier effective mass. 113Cd and 119Sn solid-state NMR (SSNMR) experiments show clear evidence of metallic-like carriers in CTO NCs based upon the observation of Knight shifts (KS). These data suggest that carrier formation in CTO arises from Sn antisite occupation of octahedral Cd sites (SnCd). From a broader perspective, the results point to wide band gap spinels as being an important but understudied class of plasmonic PSNCs. The third chapter studies the evolution of the carrier properties in the Sn-Cd-O system. The defect evolution from an oxygen vacancy (VO) to an antisite (M'M) is underexplored and the nature of the optical properties from different types of defects is not fully understood. This Sn-Cd-O family provides the perfect system to study these changes. The evolution of the structure and optoelectronic properties is investigated through powder x-ray diffraction (pXRD), NMR, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), and femtosecond (fs) transient absorption (TA). The fourth chapter tries to understand the annealing effects on the plasmonic properties of CTO. Annealing is a physical process in which a material is heat up at a specific temperature for a certain amount of time to "anneal" crystallographic defects such as VO, metal vancancies (VM), and metal interstitials (Mi). This happens because atoms diffuse through the crystal during the annealing process, which allows for recrystallization of the crystal lattice into a more "perfect" configuration. Annealing as a technique has a rich history in metallurgy, solid state materials, and thin-film fields. The fifth chapter explores the optical properties of CTO made from SnF2 instead of SnOAc2. By employing a tin(II) fluoride source instead of the acetate, there are significant improvements to frequency of the LSPR, the Q-factor, NMR Knight-shift, and hot carrier dynamics of the final FCTO product. These observations demonstrate significant improvements to the optoelectronic properties by virtue of having an effective mass one order of magnitude lower than the one measured in CTO. Finally, chapter 6 explores some of the future work and some of the relevant questions that are still of much interest to the plasmonic field. These topics present exciting opportunities for future students and researchers to explore.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
antisite, high mobility, nano, nanomaterial, plasmon, transparent conductive oxide
Geoffrey F. Strouse, Professor Directing Dissertation; William Oates, University Representative; Kenneth Hanson, Committee Member; Robert W. Schurko, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Ambiguity, Fines, and Social Distance
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Experiments inside and Outside the Lab

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation is composed of three studies that take place both inside and outside the lab. Chapter 1 is a laboratory experiment based off of Gneezy and Rustichini's Isreali day care center field experiment and Kornhauser, Lu, and Tontrop's lab experiment. Using Kornhauser et al.'s set up we study whether or not ambiguity of punishment could be a mechanism driving results seen in the original day care center study. We find that subjects are indeed ambiguity averse, but also, more notably that the set up for Kornhauser et al, may not fully capture Gneezy and Rustichini's environment in a lab setting. We find evidence that the real effort task has a trade off between effort and performance. The more effort subjects put into the task, the worse they perform, something not seen in the original day care center study. We also notice that subjects may try harder when there are fewer subjects in the room, something explored further in Chapter 3. Besides the unintended trade off between effort and performance, we do see evidence that as ambiguity of punishment increases, so does performance. These results do not rule out ambiguity of punishment as a possible mechanism for Gneezy and Rustichini's day care center experiment where they proposed ambiguous punishments, or a possible incidence of moral crowding out driving behavior. Chapter 2 is a natural experiment using real world data collected from the University libraries of Florida Atlantic University, Florida International University, Florida State University, the University of Florida, and the University of South Florida to test if moral crowding out might impact book borrowing behavior. On July 1st, 2015 FSU became the first school within the sample to stop the collection of daily late fees. Using this as a natural experiment we are able to estimate the effect that daily late fees have on book returns using a difference-in-differences model. We find that books were returned roughly 2-3 days earlier without late fees, contrary to the deterrence hypothesis. This shows that moral obligation may be a mechanism behind returning books on time, and daily late fees may crowd out moral motivation and increase late returns. We are also able to estimate the effect that increasing the base borrowing period length has on late returns. we find that patrons hold books for about 50\% of the loan period, thus, increasing loan lengths does increase the amount of time a book is held, but crucially, it also decreases late returns. Chapter 3 is a laboratory experiment motivated by a result seen in the first chapter where sessions with fewer subjects seemed to outperform sessions with more subjects. In this study we test whether physical distance in the lab impacts social distance in three canonical economic games. Round 1 is a four person one-shot linear MPCR public goods game, round 2 is a dictator game, and round 3 is a trust game. The treatments vary the number of subjects in each session (4 vs 16) and the physical distance between subjects in small sessions (far apart vs close together). We find no statistical difference of average contributions in the Far treatment comparing high and low MPCR sub-treatments. We also find significant differences in behaviors in dictator games and trust games. Dictators tend to give more in smaller sessions closer together, supporting the hypothesis that physical distance can impact social distance. In the trust game subjects in smaller closer sessions tended to ensure equity of earnings between partners more often than in larger sessions. These results show that subtle changes in laboratory settings may play a more important role in lab experiments than previously thought.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Economics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
ambiguity, economics, experimental, fine, library, price
Robert Mark Isaac, Professor Directing Dissertation; Allen Blay, University Representative; Luke Boosey, Committee Member; Luke Rodgers, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Echoes of Fulfillment
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Investigating Unmet Emotional Needs in Childhood and Adult Romantic Relationships through Multimethod Analyses

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation explores the profound impact of unmet emotional needs during childhood on adult romantic relationships. Drawing on affirmation theory, it investigates how dysfunctional parent-child relationships, characterized by a lack of parental responsiveness and emotional support, contribute to unmet emotional needs and maladaptive developmental trajectories. The research underscores the importance of understanding childhood experiences in shaping adult psychosocial functioning and relationship dynamics. The first study employs mixed methods to examine the connections between childhood unmet emotional needs, adult psychosocial functioning, and romantic relationship quality. While quantitative analyses reveal direct effects of parental nurturance on adult psychosocial functioning and subsequent implications for adult romantic relationship quality, covariate analyses signified contextual factors such as income and number of children in romantic relationship quality. The qualitative findings provided empirical support for several tenets of affirmation theory while also revealing novel insights. These insights included the identification of parental constraints and the observation of individual resilience following experiences of unmet emotional needs. The second study delves into the relational dynamics of couples affected by one partner's unmet emotional needs during childhood. It uncovers a model of progression in couples' interactions, highlighting the role of corrective experiences and resilience in fostering relational growth and stability. Surprising findings challenge prevailing theoretical models, suggesting implications of multifinality and posttraumatic growth in understanding the diverse pathways stemming from childhood adversity. Integrating findings of the first and second studies offers a nuanced understanding of the complexities of intimate relationships and underscores the importance of addressing childhood influences in promoting healthy adult functioning and relationship satisfaction.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Childhood trauma, Developmental psychopathology, Emotional needs, Mixed methods research, Qualitative research, Romantic relationships
Lenore M. McWey, Professor Directing Dissertation; Melissa Radey, University Representative; Qiong Wu, Committee Member; Ming Cui, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Enigmatic, Abundant and Active Anaerolineae Mediate Carbon Transformations in a Salt Marsh Ecosystem

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Coastal salt marshes are some of the most productive ecosystems on Earth, with over half of plant biomass production occurring in the belowground. In this belowground environment, particularly the rhizosphere, Anaerolineae (Phylum Chloroflexota) has been reported as one of the most abundant microbial groups. To date, analyses of Anaerolineae have provided evidence for an anaerobic fermentative metabolism and an ability to utilize diverse carbon sources including cellulose. However, this class remains poorly understood, particularly in a salt marsh context, despite their high abundances in this environment. Here, 55 medium- and high-quality Anaerolineae metagenome assembled genomes (MAGs) were generated from salt marsh rhizosphere samples. These Anaerolineae were primarily classified as members of the Anaerolineales and Promineofilales orders. Metabolic functional traits and gene expression were determined by mapping metagenome and metatranscriptome reads to MAGs. Nearly all Anaerolineae encoded and transcribed genes required for oxidation of both simple sugars and more complex carbon compounds including cellulose, fermentation, and for carbon fixation. A large portion of MAGs also encoded genes for both aerobic and anaerobic metabolism suggesting metabolic flexibility regarding respiration. Further, the majority of Anaerolineae transcribed genes necessary to produce potentially biomedically important secondary metabolites such as non-ribosomal peptide synthases (NRPS) and polyketide synthases (PKS). The data revealed that the belowground salt marsh Anaerolineae in the rhizosphere are important players in carbon cycling, including degradation of simple carbon compounds to more recalcitrant plant material, such as cellulose, using a diversity of electron acceptors and represent an unexplored reservoir of novel secondary metabolites. These new insights reveal a central role of Anaerolineae in salt marsh biogeochemistry.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Olivia Mason, Professor Directing Thesis; Michael Stukel, Committee Member; Robert Spencer, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Relationships among Neuroticism Facets, Negative Career Thoughts, and Congruence in College Students

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The present study examined the relationships among neuroticism facets, three types of negative career thoughts, and congruence in a sample of 180 college students enrolled in a career development course. Bivariate correlations and multiple regression analyses revealed that the neuroticism facets most strongly associated with dysfunctional career thinking were facets 3 (depression) and 6 (vulnerability), both of which predicted higher scores on the decision-making confusion (DMC) and external conflict (EC) subscales of the Career Thoughts Inventory (CTI). Neuroticism facet 1 (anxiety) emerged as an inverse predictor of DMC, suggesting that anxiety may protect against this type of dysfunctional career thinking. This finding contributes to a limited but growing body of research on beneficial aspects of neuroticism. The neuroticism facet of vulnerability displayed a significant, negative correlation with one congruence index. However, neuroticism facets and negative career thoughts did not significantly predict congruence in multiple regression analyses, suggesting that negative emotionality and dysfunctional career thinking do not necessarily impair students' ability to identify career paths that align with their vocational interests. Multiple regression analyses also showed that holding a minoritized racial identity predicted lower scores on the commitment anxiety (CA) and EC subscales of the CTI, meaning that students from marginalized racial groups experienced fewer of these negative career thoughts. However, holding a minoritized racial identity also predicted less alignment between students' activities of interest and their skills, as did identifying as cisgender male. Finally, the limited overlap observed among the five congruence indices calculated in this study demonstrates the importance of considering multiple data generated by the Self-Directed Search (SDS) when assessing a college student's level of congruence and points to the continued need for research regarding the best ways to operationalize this construct. Implications for theory, practice, research, test development, and education/training are discussed. This exploratory study provides a foundation for future investigations into how personality facets impact college students' metacognitive skills, occupational choice, and career outcomes.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Debra Osborn, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; V. Casey Dozier, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Lenore McWey, University Representative; Deborah Ebener, Committee Member; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Solid-State NMR of Quadrupolar Nuclei in Organic Solids
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: New Directions in Mechanochemical Synthesis and Crystal Structure Prediction

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The work presented in this dissertation focuses on (i) the use of mechanochemistry for the preparation of cocrystals of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) and 17O-enrichment of carboxylic acids; (ii) the utility of multinuclear solid-state NMR (SSNMR) for the investigation of molecular-level structure and dynamics in crystalline organic solids; and (iii) the development of a new NMR crystallographic protocol for the prediction of crystal structures of hydrochloride (HCl) APIs. Herein, two solid forms of API are of interest HCl salts and cocrystals prepared with carboxylic acids. A major emphasis is placed upon the use of multinuclear SSNMR, with a special focus on quadrupolar nuclei, 35Cl and 17O, which provide invaluable information about intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions in organic crystals. Information on 35Cl and 17O NMR interaction tensors extracted from NMR spectra are used alongside state-of-the-art plane-wave dispersion corrected density functional theory (DFT-D2*), which is employed for refinement of structural models and structural prediction using the 35Cl electric field gradient (EFG) tensors. Three of the projects in this dissertation describe the detailed characterization of the solid forms of fluoxetine HCl, which is marketed under the brand name Prozac®, and several of its cocrystals involving simple carboxylic acids (i.e., benzoic acid, fumaric acid, and succinic acid). First, the use of mechanochemical methods is demonstrated for the quantitative synthesis of fluoxetine HCl cocrystals with the three carboxylic acids. Ball milling reactions are shown to outperform analogous preparations from solution in terms of speed, efficiency, and purity. Cocrystals are thoroughly characterized with powder X-ray diffraction (pXRD), multinuclear SSNMR (with an emphasis on 35Cl SSNMR), and DFT-D2* calculations. Second, competitive milling (CM) and stability milling (SM) reactions are shown to be useful methods for assessing the affinities of the three carboxylic acids for forming cocrystals with fluoxetine HCl and the stabilities of these cocrystals under mechanochemical conditions. Products resulting from CM and SM reactions are often complex mixtures, and are therefore characterized using pXRD and SSNMR, which provide quantification of the products of these reactions, and even demonstrate the occurrence of solid-state extraction, whereby ball milling of a cocrystal (e.g., XA) comprised of fluoxetine HCl (X) and one coformer (A), with a new coformer, B, can lead to the extraction of A, and forming a new cocrystal with B (e.g., XB). Third, an original protocol featuring mechanochemical saponification for the isotopic 17O-enrichment of carboxylic acids is demonstrated to successfully provide high enrichment yields. This opens the door for characterization of the coformers and their associated cocrystals with 17O SSNMR, revealing fascinating molecular-level dynamics and furthering our knowledge of hydrogen-bonding in cocrystals. The final chapter in this dissertation covers the design, benchmarking, and application of a new quadrupolar NMR crystallography guided crystal structure prediction (QNMRX-CSP) protocol, which draws upon many of the experimental and computational aspects of the first three projects. The QNMRX-CSP protocol is demonstrated to have great potential for the prediction of crystal structures of HCl APIs. The protocol draws upon structural information derived from XRD and 35Cl EFG tensors obtained from 35Cl SSNMR spectra, and features the use of a Monte-Carlo simulated annealing algorithm to search the crystal packing spaces. DFT-D2* calculations are used for refining structures, computing 35Cl EFG tensors, and selecting the best candidate structural models. Thoroughly benchmarked metrics determined from experiments and computations are used to select the structural models that best match known crystal structure candidates, and are even used to successfully predict the crystal structures of two simple organic HCl salts in blind tests. It is hoped that the multifaceted solid-state characterization techniques outlined herein, along with the nascent QNMRX-CSP protocol, will provide new pathways for structural refinement and prediction, and ultimately, the prospect of rationally designing a wide range of hitherto unknown solid forms of APIs.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Robert W. Schurko, Professor Directing Dissertation; Samuel C. Grant, University Representative; Geoffrey F. Strouse, Committee Member; Mykhailo Shatruk, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Tools for Cryogenic Electron Microscopy Enable Determination of Challenging Structures

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Cryogenic electron microscopy (Cryo-EM) techniques have been rapidly developing over the past decade, enabling faster, better structure determinations of many samples. However, there are still some samples presenting challenges for cryo-EM, such as dynamin-related protein Drp1. Mitochondrial health relies on the membrane fission mediated by Drp1. Previous structure studies on Drp1 remodeled membrane were hampered by heterogeneity, leaving a critical gap in our understanding of the mitochondrial fission mechanism. Here in Chapter 2, we present a cryo-electron microscopy structure of full-length human Drp1 decorated on membrane tubules. Using the reconstruction of average subtracted tubular regions (RASTR) technique, we report that Drp1 forms a lattice with no global helical symmetry, but only local order along the tubule. This lattice is similar to dynamin with rungs, which is formed by the stalk domains, connected by the GTPase domains. However, the G domains form a novel stacked conformation that is unique among dynamin family members. We also observed contact between Drp1 and membrane that can be assigned to variable domain. We revealed two states of Drp1 lattice representing a G domain conformational change related with curvature difference. Together these structures revealed a putative mechanism by which Drp1 constrict mitochondria membranes in a stepwise manner. The proof of concept for RASTR technique was reported previously (Randolph & Stagg, 2020). However, RASTR has its imperfections in terms of workflow and speed. In Chapter 3, we will present a new strategy of using 2D classification to fast determine the size of locally ordered region, and new algorithms to standardize the workflow and speed up data processing. Advances in detector technology enabled high-resolution cryo-EM structure determination. Direct Electron (DE) has introduced a new generation direct electron detector, the DE Apollo, featuring an innovative event-based MAPS detector specially engineered for ultra-fast electron counting. In Chapter 4, we present the performance characterization of the Apollo detector. Our findings indicate that Apollo exhibits exceptional detective quantum efficiency and low coincidence loss. When tested with mouse apoferritin, Apollo consistently achieved sub-2 Å resolution reconstruction at three tested dose rates from a half-day data collection session. With longer collection time and better grid, mouse apoferritin was reconstructed to a remarkable 1.66 Å resolution. When tested on a more challenging small protein aldolase, we obtained a 2.24 Å resolution reconstruction. These results demonstrate the ability of Apollo in acquiring high-quality cryo-EM data, enabling high-resolution reconstructions for both large and small single particle samples. We also utilized this new camera to determine the structure of Kvβ2.1 octamers, which is of low-resolution using earlier generation detector (DE-20). Almost immediately, we observed the resolution improvement from 4.9 Å to 2.3 Å. This result will be presented in Chapter 5.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Institute of Molecular Biophysics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Scott M. Stagg, Professor Directing Dissertation; Karen M. McGinnis, University Representative; Kenneth A. Taylor, Committee Member; Debra A. Fadool, Committee Member; Steven Lenhert, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Determinants of Health Disparities in the Covid-19 Pandemic from the Perspectives of Social and Governmental Responsiveness

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation examines the political and social determinants affecting health disparities during the COVID-19 pandemic, a focus that has been inadequately addressed in existing literature. The first empirical study reveals that minority representation within local commissions is a key factor in determining government responsiveness to health disparities in crises. Additionally, the political ideologies of local commissions influence how the form of local government and citizens affect health outcomes. The second empirical research explores how political ideology and income inequality moderate the contentious impact of social capital on health disparities. This nuanced approach provides a clearer understanding of the complex interplay between local government, civic society, and health equity in the context of public health emergencies.
