mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Frances Berry, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Tang Tian, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Tingting Zhao, University Representative; James E. Wright, II, Committee Member; Kaifeng Yang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Numerical Investigation of Turbulence and Vorticity in Canopy Flow for Wildfire Applications

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this dissertation is to explore the dynamics of turbulence that affect wildland fire. This dissertation is heavily motivated by the knowledge gap in canopy flow to quantify vorticity using a vorticity budget. Vorticity budgets have been successfully applied to other atmospheric phenomena, like arctic cyclones, hurricanes, and typhoons. This dissertation serves as the first comprehensive investigation of vorticity budgets around a forest canopy and its application and implications in wildfire behavior.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Institute in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Kevin Speer, Professor Directing Dissertation; Vasubandhu Misra, University Representative; Neda Yaghoobian, Committee Member; Bryan Quaife, Committee Member; Jesse Canfield, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Essays on Information and Probabilistic Reasoning

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In the first chapter, I consider a sender who chooses between disclosing the state or spending time and cost to utilize an imperfect reporting device. The sender's payoff is maximized if the receiver guesses the state is good, while the receiver's payoff is maximized by correctly identifying the state. The sender utilizes the device in the bad state to persuade and extract surplus from the receiver. Extraction is contingent on the sender's ability to hide the origin of reports, sender disclosures versus device reports, from the receiver. Due to the time requirement and state-dependent utilization of the test, a sophisticated receiver can infer the state if sender disclosure times vary across states. I model interaction, solve for all Bayesian Nash equilibria, and conduct an experiment varying the visibility of disclosure time. Consistent with theoretical benchmarks, treatment senders' difference in disclosure times between states are 28.04% smaller than control senders with similar test utilization. The second chapter explores probabilistic reasoning. The Monty Hall Paradox is the persistent observation of a systematic failure of human subjects to use new information to make decisions. James et al. 2018 explore potential candidates for explaining behavior. They identify failure to Bayesian update as an explanation, observing that implementing a more intuitive "merge' framework increases rational behavior by 40 percentage points. In the second chapter we extend their framework, introducing a two decision framework. The first decision quasi-replicates James et al. 2018 and we obtain a similar result. However, we find that in aggregate these gains are not robust to the presentation of irrelevant information in the second decision. Despite this, we do find evidence of learning transfer to the original MH problem following exposure to our extension and learning within our extension. In the third chapter, I study a principal-agent environment where the agent is incentivized based on the number of tasks she completes. Given the incentive structure, she will prefer to complete the tasks which require the least effort. The principal, however, prefers that the agent completes the most difficult tasks. The agent only knows the distribution of task difficulty and does not observe the difficulty of any specific task. Thus, without any information the agent simply randomizes over tasks. The principal cannot change the agent's incentive structure, but instead can utilize his private information about the difficulty of each task to offer an optimal randomization contract, which is a mean preserving spread of the agent's expected utility, but increases the principal's expected utility.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Economics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Contract, Game Theory, Information, Monty Hall, Principal-Agent Problem, Signaling
Luke Anthony Boosey, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jens W. Grosser, University Representative; Robert Mark Isaac, Committee Member; Vijay Ramdas Krishna, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Non-Linear Structures in L2-Italian and Spanish
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Case of Clitics and Passives

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The present dissertation intends to investigate the syntactic nature and L2-acquisition of passive sentence structure in two Romance varieties, Italian and Spanish. First, I will present an analytic proposal couched within the Generative Approach (Chomsky, 1957, and subsequent work); from there, and following Perlmutter and Postal's (1977) consideration on the universality of the main features of passivization, the analysis will be extended to English, in an attempt to test its cross-linguistic validity. To complete the theoretical framework that lays down the groundwork for this research, the acquisition of non-linear structures will be presented throughout Chapters Two and Four, in an effort to gather a well-rounded picture of processing difficulties that are typically encountered by intermediate L2-learners (L1-English) of Romance languages when they first approach either word-order or thematic inversion. The experimental portion of the present work is presented in Chapters Five, Six, and Seven: 58 intermediate-level learners of Italian and Spanish have completed two tasks in their respective L2, with the goal of gathering information on non-linear sentence comprehension. In the first task, students were presented with aural stimuli containing pre-verbal accusative (non-subject) clitics, and passive sentences, and they had to select the picture that best represented what they heard. For the second task, students read 100 sentences divided into segments that would appear in window-format and non-cumulatively. Results indicate that non-linear structures are a challenge for intermediate L2-learners, especially when syntactic-semantic manipulations on the input yield ambiguity; nonetheless, the presentation of written stimuli fosters better performance, highlighting the importance of multi-modal approaches to language testing (Torres, 2022).
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Modern Languages and Linguistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Italian, passive, passive sentence structure, SLA, Spanish, syntax
Michael J. Leeser, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Lara Reglero, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Michael Carrasco, University Representative; Gretchen Sunderman, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Gradients of Time, Action, and Memory within the Frontal, Parietal, and Temporal Cortices

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Cognitive control describes a composite set of multifaceted processes that adaptively align intentional behaviors with internal goals and dynamic contexts. Cognitive control is supported by frontal, parietal, and temporal areas, but how these areas contribute to cognitive control is poorly understood. Previously, we demonstrated that frontal and parietal areas are organized along a gradient wherein somatomotor proximal areas are sensitive to the present, while somatomotor distal areas are sensitive to the future (Nee, 2021, eLife). However, in that work, timescale (present/future) was confounded with focus (external/internal) as present-oriented control processes were also action-oriented, and future-oriented control processes were also memory-oriented. Here, we directly contrasted future/external-oriented processes (episodic control) with future/internal-oriented processes (temporal control), along with present/external-oriented processes (sensorimotor control). Gradients of control were observed in frontal, parietal, and previously undescribed lateral temporal cortices. Multidimensional scaling revealed that these areas could be explained by an abstraction gradient wherein areas at one end of the gradient were sensitive to action, regardless of timescale, while areas on the other end of the gradient were sensitive to the future regardless of focus. Interestingly, areas in the middle of the gradient conjunctively coded future external representations demonstrating non-linear, over-additive sensitivity to episodic control. We hypothesize that such conjunctive coding supports adaptive cognitive control that synthesizes processing at each end of the gradient to proactively prepare control for the future.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cognitive Control, Cortical Organization, Cortical Taxonomy, Frontal Parietal Network
Derek Evan Nee, Professor Directing Dissertation; Gregg Stanwood, University Representative; Caterina Gratton, Committee Member; Christopher Martin, Committee Member; Tehila Nugiel, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Feasibility of the Adapted Body Project Training and Its Impact on Treatment Outcomes

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Eating disorders (EDs) are often an under-detected problem with a substantial risk of development during emerging adulthood. These disorders are often lethal if left untreated and affect approximately 8.4% of women and 2.2% of men during their lifetime. Guided by cognitive dissonance theory and family systems theory, this study built upon the research of the Body Project. This intervention study was adapted from the original Body Project treatment in two distinct ways. First, it included a subclinical eating disorder sample rather than a clinically significant sample. Second, it included a support person who was chosen by the participant and asked to attend all four groups in a supportive role for the participant. This study aimed to deepen the understanding of the improvement of eating disorders, body image, and relationship quality and assessed the feasibility of the overall study design through a mixed methods framework. With these adaptations, this study presented a first-of-its-kind outlook on the integration of cognitive dissonance treatment groups and social support. A sample of 10 individuals with subclinical levels of eating disorders were recruited for this study. Treatment included four virtual treatment groups. Data collection included quantitative assessments on eating disorders, body image, and social support over four time points and semi-structured qualitative exit interviews. Quantitative results indicated that eating disorder behaviors and body image satisfaction decreased, while social support did not improve. Qualitative results showed that participants did have difficulty finding a support person. Still, once a support person was found, they felt supported by the group, their support person, and the group leader. Other qualitative themes supported feasibility, including codes showing motivations to join the groups to learn about body image, needing help, and struggling with body/body image. Participants noted themes related to improvements in health attitudes towards eating behaviors, improvements in body image dissatisfaction such as increased self-confidence/self-esteem, being able to compliment/appreciate self, showing empathy to others, and enhanced social support such as group support, group sameness, and social commitment from a support person. Participants identified ways in which they considered the group could be improved upon if it were to be done again, such as having a larger group, meeting more or less often, and adding additional resources to the group. Understanding the feasibility of the adapted Body Project intervention, as well as the improvement of ED behaviors, body image dissatisfaction, and relationship quality during the intervention, is important for both improvements and adaptations for the Body Project intervention and the future treatment of eating disorders.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Body Project, Eating Disorder, Family Systems Theory, Feasibility Study, Intervention Research
Qiong Wu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Pamela Keel, University Representative; Lenore M. McWey, Committee Member; Thomas Ledermann, Committee Member; Jessica Bahorski, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Essays on Collaborative Governance Mechanisms to Address Gender-Based Violence and Inequalities

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Gender-based violence (GBV) is deeply rooted in gender inequalities (re) produced by patriarchal formal and informal institutions, including the government. Gender inequalities intersect with other structural inequalities based on race, ethnicity, class, and disability, among others, placing differential burdens on marginalized social groups regarding their experiences with government policies aimed at addressing GBV. Historically, feminist and grass-roots organizations have advocated and worked for the implementation of public policies that recognize, address, and prevent GBV and inequalities. However, governments have faced different challenges to provide policy responses that go beyond punitivist and essentialist (i.e., single-axis views) approaches to GBV, to formalize adequate governance structures to reduce implementation and coordination failures, and to institutionalize a gendered perspective into government structures and policies to comprehensively tackle this multifaceted, multidimensional, and intersectional social problem. This dissertation relies on longitudinal analysis and feminist and collaborative governance literature to explore how collective government structures may contribute to broadening policy approaches in the United States, and how collective government structures, gender-sensitive budgeting, and gender action plans are formalized in Argentina. Thereby, it contributes to the literature on purpose-oriented networks by i) analyzing different types of networks with similar purposes but different positions and tasks within the policy subsystem, ii) exploring membership makeup related to more comprehensive policy adoption for more equitable solutions as network outcomes, iii) exploring the influence of national government metagovernance on subnational purpose-oriented networks formalization and makeup, and iv) employing longitudinal analyses, focusing on subnational governments as units of observation, and expanding the geographical scope of the literature to the Global South. These contributions also advance the literature on gender policies by placing the focus on less explored approaches to gender governance, i.e., both the formalization and the influence of collaborative institutional arrangements that include advocates and community-based organizations on gender policies to address GBV and other policy mechanisms to mainstream a gender perspective within public administration and policy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Collaborative governance, Gender mainstreaming, Gender-based violence, Metagoverance, Policy networks, Public governance
Daniel Fay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Petra Doan, University Representative; Frances Berry, Committee Member; James E. Wright, II, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Control Techniques to Increase Power Density for MMC Medium Voltage Grid-Tie Converter

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In today's world, power electronic converters are used in numerous applications. The size and weight of these converters are important factors that affect their power density. The converters that convert direct current (DC) to alternative current (AC) have advanced from two level voltage source converters to multilevel converters to achieve a higher power density. The multilevel converters have a higher power density and are suitable for various applications. A modular multilevel converter (MMC) is one of the most popular multilevel converters due to its modular nature and scalability. The focus of this research is on the control methods to increase power density in Modular Multilevel Converters. The advanced state of the art control methods used to reduce size of components like inductors and capacitors are presented. Then, Y-Matrix modulation is discussed as a modulation that enables MMC's self-voltage balancing. As a result of this modulation, the power density can be improved for MMC by eliminating the arms' inductors and converting it into Switched capacitor MMC(SC-MMC). This SC-MMC can balance capacitors voltage in each switch cycle. A mathematical discussion of Y-Matrix generation is presented in this research, both for SC-MMC without a middle submodule and for SC-MMC equipped with a middle submodule. A practical implementation of Y-Matrix modulation is then presented, followed by an experimental validation. The size of the capacitors in MMC is another barrier to power density. This research analyzes low-order harmonic power oscillation of MMC submodules. Low-order harmonic power oscillations cause MMC submodule capacitors to encounter large voltage ripples. Consequently, large capacitors are required, resulting in low- power density for MMCs. A theoretical analysis of fundamental frequency voltage ripple elimination in MMC's capacitors is presented in this paper. A controller is designed based on this analysis and capacitors are sized for this condition. This method shows significant capacitor reduction in MMC.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
GRID-TIE CONVERTER, Modular Multilevel Converter, Power Electronics
Fang Z. Peng, Professor Directing Dissertation; Juan C. Ordonez, University Representative; Hui "Helen" Li, Committee Member; Jinyeong Moon, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Trait Sensitivity and Evolution in Sessile Marine Invertebrates

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The sensitivity and evolution of phenotypes are key focuses in the fields of ecology and evolution. However, most research into these topics is performed in terrestrial and unitary animals, potentially introducing biases in any conclusions about the expected responses of organisms to environmental variation. Marine invertebrates often feed, grow, and disperse in different ways to terrestrial systems due to evolving under the physical properties of water instead of air. Thus, I explored the effects of temperature on the feeding rate and fitness-related traits in the marine bryozoan Bugula neritina. To accomplish this, I 1) constructed a thermal performance curve for feeding rate over a short period of time and 2) constructed multiple performance curves for development to reproductive maturity, growth rate, and reproductive capacity over the lifetime for B. neritina. I estimated that feeding rates in B. neritina would increase with temperature due to the rate of metabolic processes increasing at higher temperatures before rapidly declining after a critical point is reached. However, I found that feeding rate increased with temperature linearly even as the proportion of zooids within the colonies decreased. However, the traits tied more directly to fitness showed the expected trends of steady increases with temperatures before declining rapidly at temperatures greater than 29 °C. Taken together, these results show that increases in feeding rates do not result in increases to or maintenance of fitness. However, the proportion of zooids that regressed to a non-feeding state seemed to increase with temperature in both projects, revealing that the colonies have other strategies to balance their metabolic budget thanks to their modular body plan. Dispersal is a fundamental determinant of genetic and demographic structure within and between species. As a consequence of combinations of physiological, morphological, and behavioral traits, dispersal in marine taxa is accomplished during the larval stages, where the body plan and behavior often differ greatly from those of the adult. Using a breeding design, I partitioned the phenotypic variance for hatching success, trunk length, tail length, and settling success of ascidian (Molgula occidentalis), larvae into additive genetic, maternal, and dominance variance. I then used the additive genetic variance to look for evidence of genetic correlations for the traits that could produce genetic constraints on evolution. Additionally, I used the additive genetic variances to estimate evolvability to determine which traits would have the greatest response to selection. I found little evidence for genetic correlations between trunk length and tail length despite their positive phenotypic correlation. Similarly, I found little evidence for genetic correlations between hatching and settling success. Maternal variances for the morphological traits were greater than additive genetic variance, suggesting that maternal effects may affect the trait values more than the inherited alleles. The evolvabilities for hatching and settling success were an order of magnitude greater than the evolvabilities trunk length and tail length. I conclude that trunk and tail lengths can evolve independently, but that influence from mothers contributes to the phenotypic values to a greater degree than heritable genetics alone. Larval size may be a trait that can evolve through selection on mothers more than selection on the offspring larvae.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Climate change, Evolvability, Invertebrates, Larval biology, Marine, Modular organisms
Scott C. Burgess, Professor Directing Dissertation; Markus Huettel, University Representative; Kimberly A. Hughes, Committee Member; Don R. Levitan, Committee Member; Joseph Travis, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring Age and Early Skill Acquisition in Space Fortress
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Differences in Cognition, Behaviors, and Strategy Use

mods:mods.mods:abstract: As individuals age, multiple facets of cognitive and physical capabilities decline. Alongside these general changes, the strategies older adults choose to implement in a given task play a proportionally greater role, acting as a compensatory moderator in performance outcomes. Unfortunately, in the same instance, older adults have been found to have a reduced set of strategies to select from, further inhibiting performance outcomes. There is promise, however, in the implementation of training interventions to assist older adults in improving performance on complex tasks. The current study was interested in investigating the feasibility of applying the expert performance approach, derived from the methods by which experts attain the pinnacles of performance, as a form of training for older adults that would be learning a novel complex perceptual-motor task. To do so, data was collected on older and younger adults who played an hour of Space Fortress (SF), a research tool originally designed explicitly for the study of learning and strategy use. In general, age-related declines in fluid intelligence and processing speed were found but not for spatial ability. Older adults performed worse in SF in general, but these differences were only significant for the Points and Speed subscores. Older adults also accumulated significantly less efficient behavior when utilizing the joystick to pilot the player's ship, holding input commands twice as long as their younger counterparts. Strategy selection was identified using a novel application of cluster analysis. Through this method, it was found that older adults were not using the optimal strategy in SF and were falling into less advantageous patterns of behavior. These results showed that older adults represent a population that would benefit greatly from potential deliberate practice interventions.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Neil Charness, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Walter Boot, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Chris Martin, Committee Member; Michael Kofler, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Developing Numerical Methods and Optimal Boundary Conditions for Enhancing Electroconvection under AC Voltage

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Electroconvection has garnered significant attention due to its potential to enhance ion transport on polarized surfaces, thereby reducing the plateau region of the limiting current vs voltage curve. This dissertation explores the induction of electroconvection under both alternating current (AC) and direct current (DC) voltages, emphasizing the effects of surface patterning under the constraint of unipolar charge injection. While DC voltages significantly enhance ion transport by way of the electroconvection mechanism, facilitated by patterned surfaces, AC voltages present unique challenges. The alternating direction of the electric field under AC conditions complicates the creation and maintenance of stable convection cells, essential for effective electroconvection. This study examines how various pattern designs influence the dynamics of electroconvection across different AC frequency settings. Our analysis has shown that patterned surfaces substantially improve current production and flow velocity under AC conditions by mitigating the adverse effects of the electric field's alternating direction. We identified optimal pattern ratios that maximize current density, which marks a significant advancement in our understanding of electroconvection. The system's performance was rigorously evaluated at various frequencies and injection levels, with detailed comparisons drawn between patterned surfaces and homogeneous membranes. To address the computational challenges presented by the high stiffness of the governing equations, a novel adaptive time-stepping algorithm that combines finite difference and linear multi-step methods was developed. This algorithm has significantly enhanced the computational accuracy and efficiency of our simulations. Additionally, we have implemented Physics Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) for modeling, achieving promising results in 1D implementations, though extending these results to more complex 2D systems has highlighted additional challenges. This research not only advances our understanding of the mechanisms driving electroconvection but also opens new avenues for technological advancements in electrochemistry and materials science. It aims to optimize these systems for improved performance and efficiency, promising substantial benefits for various applications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
AC, cation-selective, Electroconvection, injection, patterned, voltage

Mark Sussman, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Kourosh Shoele, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Omar Faruque, University Representative; Nick Cogan, Committee Member; Feng Bao, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Building Relationships from Our Past and for Our Future
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Community Research as Reconciliation from within Métis Communities

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this dissertation, stories of Métis ways of knowing and being together and reconciliation have been interwoven together with stories of my own journey back home to my community in Western Canada to create practical results in and through a community-based research project. To do this work, I collaborated with Métis women across British Columbia, Canada, in a decolonizing and Indigenous community-led research project. Guiding this project are interweaving goals of fostering reconciliation within Métis communities by using a decolonizing methodology that goes beyond theoretical critique to produce practical results with and for Métis communities. Key questions guiding this research include those relating to how social scientific inquiry can benefit Métis communities, how Métis ways of knowing and cultural practices can contribute to reconciliation locally, and decolonizing possibilities for doing sport studies research as reconciliation. Taking these as guides, in the current study, I weave community-based methods and Indigenous perspectives together to envision decolonizing futures with and for our local communities. Rooted in Métis ways of being and being together, these methods of knowledge co-creation include collaborative, decolonizing, and Indigenous-led community-based methods, such as community consultations, as well as sharing and visioning circles. Towards practical results, the primary contributions of this dissertation project are collaborative developments of practical results for reconciliation from within Métis communities. For this, cultural resources materials, as well as action plans were co-created with Métis educators, artists, and community leaders. In addition to the primary contribution of practical implications for Métis communities, the current dissertation also outlines pedagogical implications, as well as scholarly implications for doing research as reconciliation from within the sport studies scholarship.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sport Management in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Joshua Newman, Professor Directing Dissertation; Ayesha Khurshid, University Representative; Hanhan Xue, Committee Member; Wenjie James Du, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Knowledge and Practice
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Investigating Factors Related to Preparing Teachers to Teach Reading

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Concern over continuing poor reading achievement in the U.S. has resulted in a focus on classroom reading instruction. However, due to the interaction effect between a child's characteristics and a teacher's instruction, as demonstrated by the lattice model of reading comprehension (Connor, 2016), identifying the causes of the issue is complex. Teachers require specialized knowledge in order to have the ability to tailor their instruction to their individual students, however, researchers have identified wide variations in this knowledge within teachers (Piasta, Soto Ramirez, et al., 2020; Moats and Foorman, 2003). As a result, methods and features of educator preparation programs are being examined as one possible source of variation in teachers' knowledge and ability to effectively provide reading instruction to their students. This dissertation aims to contribute to the extant literature in this area through an examination of what is known about the causal effects of educator preparation programs on teacher candidates' knowledge and skills to teach reading effectively. First, empirical research about the effects of educator preparation programs on teacher candidates' knowledge and skills was examined through a meta-analysis of the literature. Findings indicate that there a limited amount of research studies examining causal impacts of instructional methods used to prepare teacher candidates. Secondly, an examination of the relation between two commonly used instructional methods within educator preparation programs, tutoring and early literacy methods courses, and teacher candidates' reading-related content knowledge was also conducted using data that was generated as part of an already occurring educator preparation program. Both studies provide insight into future directions for research into effective methods of preparation for teacher candidates to teach reading.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Nicole Patton Terry, Professor Directing Dissertation; Donald Compton, University Representative; Sonia Q. Cabell, Committee Member; Laura Steacy, Committee Member; Katharine Pace Miles, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Assessing the Effectiveness of a Training Program for Voice Quality Ratings

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Purpose: The purpose of this study was to assess the effect of a training program on the accuracy and reliability of student perception in rating voice quality features of breathiness and roughness. It was hypothesized that students who completed a voice quality features training module as a mastery task would more accurately and reliably rate the breathiness and roughness in a set of voice samples. Methods: Voice samples used originated from the Voice Foundation's Perceptual Voice Qualities Database. All voices in the database were rated for severity of voice qualities of breathiness and roughness by trained listeners. As a result of problems in administering the training program, the post-test was not completed and the pre-test data was not analyzed. Training modules had a set file of 12 anchor voices with features containing varying degrees of severity for breathiness and roughness, in addition to normal breathiness and roughness. Participants could listen to anchor voices an unlimited number of times. Results: Within-subjects effects were analyzed using a 3x3 repeated measures ANOVA. Greenhouse-Geisser estimate was used to correct the degrees of freedom to more accurately analyze the data. Repeated measure ANOVA revealed no significant effects for task, module, or the interaction between task and module. Within-subjects contrast analysis revealed a significant quadratic interaction between task and module. Participants exhibited a trend for improved ratings for individual breathy and rough characteristics, however, there is wide group variability in the accuracy of ratings and time taken to complete the training modules. Discussion: Varying patterns across individuals may indicate differing levels of motivation. Future research can further evaluate the impact of extrinsic and intrinsic motivation on skill acquisition and professional competence when completing a training module to improve voice perception judgment based on interest, level and degree of voice experience, and self-efficacy following pre and post-tests.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
anchor file, Reliability, training module, Voice quality perception
Richard J. Morris, Professor Directing Thesis; Yunjung Kim, Committee Member; Kaitlin L. Lansford, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Grounding out

mods:mods.mods:abstract: "Grounding Out" is a collection of short fiction reflecting on and dwelling in the silent sufferings, dependencies, and desperate grasps for dignity of characters whose best days have been lived. A mother in the throes of dementia, an addict vaguely searching for the Gulf, a preacher who has lost faith. Characters with little hope for happy futures nor propensity toward nostalgia looking for just an ounce of happiness in the uncelebrated present. Aging toward death, melding into darkness.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Mark Winegardner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Thomas Joiner, University Representative; Bruce Horack, Committee Member; Trinyan Mariano, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Lived Experience of College Students with Bipolar Disorder as Explored through Narrative Art Making

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This master's thesis explores the development of two co-existing narratives. First, the design of a phenomenological study that sought to explore the in-depth lived experience of college students with bipolar disorder through an arts-based narrative and a verbal interview. The rationale for this design was a notable gap in research exploring the in-depth lived experience of the intersection between bipolar disorder, college education, and young adult development. The original study was designed to recruit five college students from Florida State University with bipolar disorder to create an arts-based narrative book that portrayed significant parts of their experience of living with bipolar disorder in college followed by an open-ended oral interview. The use of art in narration supports exploration of these internal experiences. The second narrative explored is the experience of a master's student attempting to study the experience of members of her own population and the fit of Disability Justice and Narrative Interpretivist frameworks within broader systems. The change in the purpose of the study was due to the lack of participant data. The methods that occurred include the researcher's art-based personal reflection of the experience was well as the composition of additional conversation surrounding Disability Justice and Narrative Interpretivist perspectives. Future research with this population may benefit from the integration of Narrative Interpretivism and Disability Justice perspectives to best explore the lived experience of this population as well as the experience of master's students conducting research on their own population.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Art Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
art therapy, book making, college students, disability justice, narrative interpretivism, young adult development
Nancy Gerber, Professor Directing Thesis; Barbara Parker-Bell, Professor Directing Thesis; David Gussak, Committee Member; Sara Scott Shields, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Creating Community for College-Aged Generation Z through the Design of Baptist Church Interiors

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Interior Architecture and Design

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Christians believe that the perfect design of community and togetherness came after Creation was complete when there was perfect harmony between God and human beings. In the Garden of Eden, Adam and Eve existed in community with one another and with God, living as God had initially intended. In the early church, which began shortly after Jesus ascended into Heaven, Jesus' disciples were never apart from one another; they shared meals, belongings, and times of prayer (ESV Bible, 2001, Acts 2:42-47). This constant connection not only strengthened their personal relationships, but it also fostered a deeper and more intimate relationship with God. Today, prominent theologian Donald S. Whitney states that the structure of the church has fallen away from this perfect design that God had originally intended for humans (Whitney, 2013). A lack of intimate togetherness is seen in church environments across the United States today, as more individuals are not connecting with others in their churches. Cliques have been formed, attendance has fallen due to lack of personal investment and connection, and people are left unknown, unseen, and disconnected from a place where community and engagement should be abundant (PEW Research Center, 2021). The intentional design of a church environment provides users with a space where social connection with others and spiritual experiences are fostered and enhanced. Church environments can and should engage individuals in a spiritual experience with God and aid in building community with others, yet collected literature and research argues the opposite is taking place. The connection between Generation Z, spiritual spaces, and the potential for socialization within church interiors is under-researched despite several overlapping connections of design theory, human experience, and church environments. Because of this potential that church environments hold, it is important that the interior space not be neglected but is rather designed intentionally and with purpose.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Interior Architecture and Design in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
Steven Webber, Professor Directing Thesis; Jim Dawkins, Committee Member; Terry Londy, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Advances in Nanomaterial Engineering for Electrochemical Biosensing and Electrocatalysis Applications

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Nanomaterials and electrochemistry are two highly interrelated fields that have achieved significant advancements in recent years, due to their synergistic potential. Nanomaterials offer highly advantageous properties for electrochemical applications such as electrochemical sensing and electrocatalysis, including enhanced surface area, biocompatibility, electrical conductivity, and high catalytic reactivity. This thesis aims to encompass the development of controlling gold nanostructure morphology for electrochemical aptasensing technology and to assess carbide nanomaterials for meeting industrial requirements as active and stable oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts. The first part of this thesis in Chapter 3 focused on the preparation of gold nanostructured surfaces to enhance the performance of electrochemical aptasensors. Nanostructuring gold surfaces through various electrodeposition techniques allowed precise control of gold morphology features, impacting surface area enhancement, aptamer packing density, sensor signal change, stability, and sensitivity. This exploration of gold morphology effects on electrochemical aptasensor performance aims to finely optimize miniaturized sensors for future applications such as in-vivo sensing and in-vitro cellular studies. The second part of the thesis in Chapters 4-6 focused on studying the OER electrocatalytic behavior of monometallic (Fe, Co, Ni), bimetallic (FeCo, FeNi, CoNi), and trimetallic (FeNiCr, FeCoNi) nanocarbides. The feasibility of low-cost, stable, and highly active anode materials for efficient OER is critical for improving the performance of electrocatalytic water splitting for chemical energy storage applications. The thermodynamic and kinetic requirements for the OER are the main limiting factors in producing hydrogen, the desired product. Carbon-based materials are widely used in the electrolyzer and fuel cell industries as anode and cathode materials, yet research is lacking on how to enhance catalytic efficiency with the use of multimetal tuning and understanding the effects of unstable oxide formation for long-term use. Thus, this part of the thesis aimed to explore the role of Fe in tuning carbide catalyst activity and stability for multimetallic compounds, particularly the effects of Fe oxide on catalyst degradation.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Robert. A. Lazenby, Professor Directing Dissertation; Steven Lenhert, University Representative; Michael G. Roper, Committee Member; Qing-Xiang Amy Sang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sarcomeric Mutation Studies to Understand the Fundamental Basis of Cardiac Muscle Regulation and Pathogenesis of Cardiomyopathies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: According to the CDC, around 209.6 deaths per 100,000 habitants are associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the United States of America. Inherited cardiomyopathies represent ~30% of CVDs. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM), and arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) are the most common classifications of inherited cardiomyopathies. HCM affects 1 in 500 individuals with CVD and is associated with hypertrophy of the left ventricle (LV) and decreased LV chamber. DCM affects 1 in 250 individuals with CVD and is related to LV dilation and the LV chamber's increase. Both HCM and DCM are disease that directly affects cardiac muscle mechanics and promote changes that affects the hemodynamics for the heart. The cardiac muscle is formed by bundles of muscle fibers. These muscle fibers are assembled by aggregations of cardiac muscle cells that connect at the structural level; the sarcomere comprises these cardiac muscle cells or cardiomyocytes, the muscle cells' basic contractile unit. Thin and thick filaments mostly form the sarcomere. The interaction between thin and thick filaments is associated with muscle contraction, where myosin heads from the thick filament attached to actin in the thin filament to produce force. The thick filament is mainly formed by myosin, a protein from the myosin family that is associated with contraction in striated muscle (both skeletal and cardiac muscles). Myosin's heads elongate from their backbone to interact with actin. In the presence of ADP·Pi myosin strongly binds to actin and produces shortening of the sarcomere, translating into muscle contraction. Once ADP·Pi is released, the myosin heads detach from actin, and a new cycle starts. The thin filament is formed by bundles of actin, which forms the backbone of the thin filament. In addition, the thin filament has other Ca2+ regulatory proteins directly associated with triggering muscle contraction in the cardiac muscle. The troponin complex (Tn) comprises three subunits: Troponin C (TnC) or Ca2+ regulatory subunit. In striated muscle, this subunit is directly linked to inducing Ca2+ dependent contraction. Troponin I (TnI) is the inhibitory subunit, and Troponin T (TnT) is the subunit that attaches the troponin complex to tropomyosin. Tropomyosin (Tm) is a stranded protein that lies on the actin bundles and blocks the myosin binding sites on actin. The cycling between the myosin heads and the binding to the myosin binding site on actin is known as cross bridges. In cross bridges cycling, myosin has two stages: "Super relaxed State," or SRX, where myosin is folded back to the thick filament backbone, and is not able to interact with actin, and the "Disordered Relaxed State," or DRX, where myosin head can interact with ATP and trigger the cross bridges formation. During the development of this dissertation, we will focus on specific variants that led to cardiomyopathies. Previous studies have identified variants that lead to HCM, such as β-myosin heavy chain (MYH7) and cardiac myosin-binding protein C (cMyBP-C). Also, other proteins that have been associated with DCM are Titin (TTN) and troponin T (TNNT2), to mention some proteins. On the projects developed during this dissertation, we will inquire on rare variants that lead to HCM or DCM and their impact on cardiac muscle physiology. Our first project investigates a variant of unknown significance on α -actinin 2. α-actinin 2 is a cross-linking protein located on the Z-disc. The Z-disc is an anchor structure in the sarcomere that allows the interaction of thin and thick filaments. A868T variant on α -actinin 2 has been reported to be of uncertain significance in the development of disease; however, during the development of this project, our group presented clinical, structural and mechanical data that suggest that the A868T variant induces an HCM-like phenotype. This project provides inside data that support the A868T variant as a pathological variant, which could help clinicians better assess patients in the clinical setting. In addition, this project supports the importance of the Z-disc structure for processes such as muscle contraction, which is typically linked to thin and thick filaments, and likewise, how alterations of the Z-disc can be detrimental to muscle contraction. Our second project studies the inhibition of a kinase as a potential therapeutic for treating HCM. A new mouse model was developed during this project, which had an A8V variant on cTnC and a conditional knock-out of cardiac Myosin Light Chain Kinase or cMLCK. cMLCK inhibition has been associated with structural changes that lead to dilation of the LV; however, our experimental mice with an A8V variant develop an HCM phenotype. Our hypothesis for this project was to reverse the HCM features of our experimental mice by using the basis knowledge of inhibition of cMLCK. In this section of the dissertation, we will only discuss RNAseq data, which suggests that our experimental mice present a recovery in cardiac transcriptomics that can be attributed to the inhibition of cMLCK. In addition, we discuss some canonical pathways that showed importance in our experimental group and how these pathways are essential for cardiac muscle physiology. Our data suggest that inhibition of cMLCK could potentially be used as a therapeutic target on HCM phenotypes. Our final project investigates the physiological role of Ca2+-binding sites III and IV of cTnC. For this project, our group created two knock-in (KI) mouse models, one with a mutation in Ca2+-binding site III or D105A variant and a second mouse model with a Ca2+-binding site IV variant or D141A variant. These mouse models D105A and D141A have a mutation on the first amino acid (aspartate) of the Ca2+-binding site III and IV which had been showed to be crucial for the stability of Ca2+ binding. Our goal for this project was to understand at a molecular level how Ca2+-binding sites III and IV on cTnC function in in vivo settings. Preliminary data from our mice models have shown that D105A and D141A variants induce DCM-like phenotype. This suggests that Ca2+-binding sites III and IV are pivotal in muscle contraction physiology. This dissertation section is still in progress, and some of the project's structural, molecular, and mechanical functions are underway. Integration of projects. These three projects reflect the importance of the sarcomere's different parts to maintain cardiac muscle dynamics. The different projects in this dissertation have allowed us to integrate clinical, basic, and translational research in the cardiac field. Projects like our α -actinin 2 have allowed us to integrate the basic structural knowledge better to understand the disease's clinical presentation. Our cMLCK project will enable us to use the basic understanding of the sarcomere and implement them as possible target therapy. Finally, our Ca2+-binding sites III and IV project is helping us understand the fundamental basic of cTnC.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
alpha-actinin 2, cardiac muscle, Cardiomyopathy, muscle mechanics, muscle regulation, troponin-C
Jose Renato Dias Oliveira Pinto, Professor Directing Thesis; Prescott Bryant Chase, University Representative; Judy Delp, Committee Member; Gloria Salazar Aranda, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Photoproduction of K0K0 with the GlueX Experiment

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this dissertation, we study photoproduction of $K^0\bar K^0$ through the $K_SK_Lp$ and $K_SK_Sp$ final states with the GlueX Phase-I (GlueX-I) data set.We measure the spin-density matrix elements (SDMEs) and differential cross section of $\phi(1020) \to K_SK_L$ to better understand photoproduction of light vector mesons. A mass independent Partial Wave Analysis (PWA) of the $K_SK_L$ and $K_SK_S$ meson spectrum below 2~GeV is also undertaken to study the meson spectrum with $\boldsymbol{J^{PC}} = \mathrm{even^{++}\ and\ odd^{--}}$. The $\phi(1020)$ differential cross section is measured at $E_\gamma = 8.2-8.8~\mathrm{GeV}$ and $-t = 0.15-1.00~\mathrm{GeV^2}$.The differential cross section is well described by an exponential decay with slope $4.44 \pm 0.01~\mathrm{GeV^{-2}}$ and the integrated cross section is determined to be $295.7 \pm 0.4~\mathrm{nb}$, only statistical uncertainties are quoted. Both measurements are consistent and far more precise than the previous measurement by Ballam et al.~\cite{slac_vectors}. The $\phi(1020)$ SDMEs were measured in nine bins of $-t$ in the same range. % We find the SDMEs are consistent with s-channel helicity conservation (SCHC) in the limit $-t \to 0$. At low $-t$, we find the data were consistent with s-channel helicity conservation, SCHC, i. e. the only non-zero SDMEs were $\rho^1_{1-1} = -\mathrm{Im}(\rho^2_{1-1}) = 1/2$. At higher $-t$, the SDMEs deviate from SCHC and the measurements indicate this is due to natural parity exchange since we observe that the SDMEs are consistent with zero unnatural exchange. We also find that the contribution from helicity double-flip amplitudes is consistent with zero. The measured SDMEs are in poor agreement with theoretical predictions put forward by JPAC~\cite{jpac_sdme}. These measurements will serve as input to refine models of production processes, which will be essential for the interpretation of possible signals of exotic mesons in GlueX. Analysis of the spectrum above the $\phi(1020)$ indicates the presence of at least three particles at $\sim1.50$, $\sim1.75$, and $2.20$~GeV.We employ simple parametrizations of the resonance line shape based on relativistic Breit-Wigner functions considering cases with and without interference. The resonance at $\sim1.50$~GeV is not identified as any specific resonance, but could be due to interference between the $\rho(1450)$ and $\omega(1420)$. Our models favor the resonance at $\sim1.75$~GeV as the $X(1750)$ rather than the $\phi(1680)$. We find that introducing a third Breit-Winger into the models improves the fit quality with the $\chi^2$/ndf going from 1.75 to 1.59 and 1.41 to 1.18 for models without and with interference respectively. A PWA of the $K_SK_L$ spectrum indicates that the spectrum is consistent with exclusively spin-1 contribution up to $\sim1.6$~GeV. Above $\sim1.6$~GeV we find evidence for a small spin-3 contribution. We also find that the spectrum predominantly positive reflectivity up to $\sim1.6$~GeV, after which the spectrum becomes a nearly equal mix of both. The $K_SK_S$ system shows a rich spectrum with multiple resonance structures but is more statistically limited than the $K_SK_L$ system.Modelling the line shape we find evidence at greater than $10\sigma$ level in favor of a resonance at $\sim1.75$~GeV. The model parameters suggest this resonance is the $f_0(1710)$. The PWA of the $K_SK_S$ system was inconclusive. However, using a small set of amplitudes suggests that the spin-2 contribution to the spectrum is primarily in the range $1.2-1.6$~GeV, where $f_2(1270)$, $a_2(1320)$ and $f'_2(1525)$ are expected.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Sean Dobbs, Professor Directing Dissertation; Martin Bauer, University Representative; Paul Eugenio, Committee Member; Simon Capstick, Committee Member; Mark Spieker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Parameter Estimation Techniques for Nonlinear Biological Models

mods:mods.mods:abstract: One of the primary focuses of mathematical biology is using models to understand the dynamics of and make predictions about biological systems. An important component of making accurate models is estimating parameters. However, we must often estimate these parameters from sparse or noisy data sets, making accurate estimation challenging. Additionally, many biological models are nonlinear in nature, which further enhances the difficulty of parameter estimation. In this work, we investigate two novel parameter estimation methods applied to two different biological models. First, we develop a modified version of a regularized predictor-corrector algorithm aimed at stable low-cost reconstruction of infectious disease parameters. This method is applied to a novel compartmental model for COVID-19 that accounts for vaccination and immunity loss (from both vaccinated and recovered populations). Numerical simulations are carried out with synthetic and real data for COVID-19 pandemic during the delta variant wave. Next, we expand a novel nudging algorithm to reconstruct parameters within the nonlinear term of a mathematical model. Using the logistic growth equation as a case study, we show analytically and computationally that the algorithm converges. We test the algorithm with both noisy and sparse observations as well as with the combination of both noisy and sparse observations. While the algorithm is highly sensitive to the combination of both noisy and sparse observations, it shows promising results for immediate forecasting applications. Both of the parameter estimation techniques shown have lower computational costs than standard parameter estimation methods such as least square methods. The development and study of these parameter estimation methods is important for developing a more systematic and methodological approach to choosing parameter estimation tools for biological models.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bacteria Modeling, Biological Models, Disease Modeling, Mathematical Modeling, Parameter Estimation
Nick Cogan, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Aseel Farhat, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Richard Bertram, Committee Member; Adrian Barbu, University Representative.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Role for Sarcospan in NLRP-3 Inflammasome Activation

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Inflammation is an important component of the immune system, and its role in disease prevention and progression depends on the duration of its activation. Acute inflammation serves as a protective mechanism against stimulants and pathogenic invasions, where it aids in determining the site of infection and tissue damage, attracts different types of innate and adaptive immune cells to the site of injury, and induces cell death to prevent pathogen spreading. However, the prolonged presence and persistence of stimulants and pathogens is accompanied by a consistent activation of inflammatory pathways, thus leading to a chronic state of inflammation. This can cause tissue damage and the development of systemic inflammatory diseases. One important component of the innate immune system that has been associated with inflammation is the NLRP-3 inflammasome. Its acute activation prevents pathogen spreading, and its excessive activation damages surrounding cells and tissues and can cause systemic inflammatory diseases. Various regulators of innate immune pathways have been discovered. However, other regulators are yet to be identified. One protein that emerged as a promising regulator of innate immune pathways is sarcospan, a transmembrane protein that is a crucial member of the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC). Here, we aim to investigate the role of sarcospan in innate immunity and systemic inflammatory disease development. To examine sarcospan and innate immune activation global SSPN-deficient mice were utilized. Young (3-4 months old) mice were used with 12 wild type (WT) and 12 SSPN-/- young (3-4 months old), male C57BLJ mice were weighed, euthanized and their tissues were collected to explore potential phenotypical and morphological differences between the tissues of these mice. Tissues were weighed and adjusted to the body weight of each mouse. SSPN-/- mice had a greater average body weight than WT mice, which was accompanied by a higher mean white adipose tissue (WAT) weight. Phenotypical differences that can be attributed to pathology were observed in SSPN-/- kidneys and spleens, with no differences in their average weights. Darker pigmentation of SSPN-/- spleens were observed in 46% (5 out of 12 mice) of SSPN-/- mice, which can be associated with either melanosis or hemorrhage. None of these phenotypes were seen in WT mice. To assess immune system capacity, bone marrow derived macrophages (BMDMs) from both genotypes were isolated, cultured, and allowed to differentiate for seven days. Red bone marrow cells were isolated and SSPN-/- mice were found to have higher cell counts of these pluripotent cells. This suggests immune dysregulation in SSPN-/- mice and potential capacity to generate higher immune cell counts. This in turn may drive sustained inflammation in SSPN-/- mice. It was shown in previous studies that BMDMs from SSPN-/- mice exhibited heightened responsiveness to innate immune ligands including lipopolysaccharide (LPS), a cell wall component, leading to heightened expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines. To assess NLRP-3 activation through the canonical pathway, fully differentiated WT and SSPN-/- BMDM were treated with LPS and nigericin, and the extent of activation was assessed by readouts including imaging and immunoblotting. The results show a higher expression of NLRP-3 and IL-1β in SSPN-/- BMDMs independent of p-NF-kB activation. Confocal imaging of immunofluorescent stained BMDMs were used to characterize the expression of SSPN and compare the numbers of ASC specks formed in WT and SSPN-/- BMDMs without treatment, with LPS, LPS and nigericin, and nigericin alone. SSPN expression was assessed in WT BMDM (SSPN+/+, sarcospan abundant, SSPN-/-, sarcospan-deficient). A higher frequency of ASC speck formation was reported in SSPN-/- BMDMs when compared to WT BMDMs after LPS and nigericin treatment. In conclusion, the heightened inflammatory phenotype in SSPN-/- mice that is thought to be caused by dysregulation of innate immune pathways increases NLRP-3 activation, which was evidenced by higher incidence of ASC speck formation after LPS and nigericin treatment. This can explain the noticeable pathological phenotypes that was reported in SSPN-/- tissues.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science in Exercise Physiology.
Chronic Diseases, Inflammation, Innate Immunity, NLRP-3 Inflammasome, Sarcospan
Michelle Parvatiyar, Professor Directing Thesis; Gloria Salazar, Professor Directing Thesis; Bradley Gordon, Committee Member; Robert Hickner, Committee Member; Justin La Favor, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding the Role of ATRX (Alpha-Thalassemia X-Linked Mental Retardation) in Maintenance of Chromatin Architecture

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The ATRX (alpha-thalassemia X-linked mental retardation) gene codes for a multifunctional protein, that is an ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler that assists in the deposition of histone variant H3.3 in telomeric and pericentromeric heterochromatin. Mutations in the ATRX gene are found in patients with the rare genetic disorder ATRX syndrome, resulting in a severe developmental disease that primarily affects human males, characterized by severe intellectual disability, microcephaly, and seizures. ATRX is known to bind the repetitive regions to maintain genomic stability for regions such as ribosomal DNA, minisatellites, telomeres, and pericentric heterochromatin. However, little is known about the consequence of the complete loss of ATRX on chromatin dynamics and the chromatin remodeling function of ATRX in nucleosome organization. Here, we knocked out the ATRX gene utilizing CRISPR/Cas9 in Retinal Pigment Epithelial cells (RPE1), a female cell line, to determine the impact ATRX loss has on global gene expression and chromatin marks, using X-chromosome inactivation (XCI) as a model. We found that lack of ATRX causes dispersion of the repressive heterochromatin marks histone H3 trimethylated at lysine 27 (H3K27me3) and histone H2A ubiquitinated at lysine 119 (H2AK119Ub). The ATRX knockdown cells also exhibited decompaction of inactive X-chromosome (Xi) and caused the appearance of new intense intranuclear chromatin foci with H2AK119Ub staining. Additionally, we employed an MNase (Micrococcal Nuclease) based assay to monitor genome-wide changes to nucleosome occupancy and sensitivity near transcription start sites (TSS) in both RPE1 and male human colorectal carcinoma cell line, HCT116. Nucleosomal occupancy around TSS maintains a similar profile in the ATRX-deleted cells, although the average occupancy was significantly reduced. However, nucleosome sensitivity showed an unexpected pattern of major genome-wide dispersion. Our results indicate an additional role of ATRX in genome organization beyond the known function of maintaining genome stability.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Jonathan H. Dennis, Professor Directing Dissertation; Olivia Mason, University Representative; Karen M. McGinnis, Committee Member; Henry W. Bass, Committee Member; Jian Feng, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Examining the Efficacy of the Computerized Anxiety Sensitivity Treatment in a Guided, Group Format

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Although existing treatments for anxiety are efficacious in reducing clinical anxiety, most anxious individuals do not receive them. Recently, brief interventions have been developed which often employ the use of technology to overcome issues facing traditional evidence-based treatments. Despite their advantages, these interventions also face significant feasibility issues and are underutilized. Adapting these brief interventions to be administered in guided, group formats may be a strategy for effectively resolving these issues and improving their feasibility. The current study aimed to evaluate this by modifying the brief Cognitive Anxiety Sensitivity Treatment (CAST; Schmidt et al., 2014) to be administered in groups with the guidance of a clinician. We hypothesized that CAST would be regarded as highly acceptable, would significantly reduce anxiety sensitivity when compared to a control intervention, and would retain its mechanism of action on internalizing symptoms such that reductions in anxiety sensitivity (AS) would mediate reductions in symptoms of anxiety and depression. We recruited 57 participants in preexisting groups and groups consisting of individual participants to be randomly assigned to the CAST or control condition with assessments at pre-intervention, post-intervention, and 1-month follow-up. Multilevel linear mixed effect models were conducted to examine whether treatment condition predicts reductions in AS. Direct and indirect effects of intervention condition on internalizing symptoms through changes in AS were examined using regression and mediation models. Results suggest that this "Group CAST" is acceptable and efficacious in reducing AS. Trending findings suggest that group CAST may exert force on internalizing symptoms via similar mechanisms observed in previous versions. Results support a new framework for improving the application of brief digital mental health treatments.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Anxiety, Anxiety Sensitivity, Digital Treatment, Group Treatment, Mental Health, Treatment
Norman B. Schmidt, Professor Directing Thesis; Jesse R. Cougle, Committee Member; Jon K. Maner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Metric and Categorical Properties of Hypergraphs with Applications to Ecological Data

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Hypernetworks, sometimes called hypergraphs, generalize the concept of a graph by allowing edges to join any number of vertices, gaining the ability to capture multi-way relationships in data. This hypernetwork representation can therefore maintain structure that standard graphs lose in various types of biological systems like gene regulatory systems, protein complex interactions, and ecological competition food webs. Optimal transport has been employed to develop distances for the use of comparing networks. We take some of these distances from the the network setting and extend them to the hypernetwork setting. The first distance has a structure similar to that of the well-known Gromov-Hausdorff distance and we will examine various lowers bounds based on invariant properties or based on persistent homology. Additionally, we will investigate various methods for transforming hypernetworks into graphs to see what information can be retained with respect to this distance. The second will be more akin to the Gromov-Wasserstein distance and we will explore the "graphification" techniques for this distance and delve into the categorical properties of the functors these graphifications induce. Finally, we will consider an ecological application of hypernetworks with the bacteria populations of water samples for both visualization and analysis of connections between species and environmental factors.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Category Theory, Hypergraph Matching, Hypergraph Metrics, Hypergraphs, Hypoxia, Optimal Transport
Thomas Needham, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Mascagni, University Representative; Martin Bauer, Committee Member; Monica Hurdal, Committee Member; Washington Mio, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Person Centered Planning during Transition for a Young Adult Who Uses AAC

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Limited research has considered the goals and priorities of young adults who use augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) as they transition out of school. As person-centered planning is the foundation of the field of communication science and disorders, understanding the process when working with young adults with complex communication needs is essential to practice ethically and effectively. This case study details the process of person-centered assessment and treatment planning over a 7-month period for a young adult with developmental disabilities who uses AAC. The study implemented four phases focused on person-centered care: pre-treatment interview, assessment, treatment, and post-treatment interview. The pre-treatment interview consisted of a conversation with the participants to understand their history and goals. After assessing my participant's strengths and weaknesses in communication, a treatment plan focusing on literacy and self-advocacy was developed in collaboration with her and her communication supporter. Although we did not see significant gains in literacy skills during sessions, the participant reported using literacy skills outside the clinic. In addition, after introducing the participant to an online chat for people who use AAC, she has increased her self-confidence communicating with unfamiliar people using a perception scale to self-reflect on her experience. The post-treatment interview revealed that the participants felt supported over the course of the study and found that all aspects of person-centered care were implemented.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the School of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
augmentative and alternative communication, person centered, transition, young adult
Michelle Therrien, Professor Directing Thesis; Andrea Barton-Hulsey, Committee Member; Shannon Hall-Mills, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On the Sensitivity of Precipitation Phase to Temperature

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The phase of precipitation, i.e., solid (snow) or liquid (rain), is a crucial property in weather forecast, satellite precipitation retrievals, and modeling. The shift of precipitation phase from solid to liquid will alter surface energy balance, affect water resource management, and increase risks of natural hazards. In recent decades, consistent decreasing trends of the snow-to-precipitation (S/P) ratio have been reported across various regions. However, a global view of the changes in the rain-snow partitioning has not been established. Further, current phase classification methods that are crucial for the estimation of the S/P ratio exhibit limited performance. Though studies have explored the dependence of the conditional probability of snow on surface meteorological variables (e.g., temperature, relative humidity), the physics of the phase transition in the falling process has not been fully understood and well incorporated into the phase partitioning methods. Therefore, it is crucial to quantify the sensitivity of the precipitation phase to temperature to improve our quantitative precipitation estimation as well as to better study the response of hydrological and radiative components to climate change. In this dissertation, we explored the sensitivity of precipitation phase from two perspectives: one from the physics perspective, emphasizing the phase transition from solid to liquid when temperature and atmospheric energy vary, and the other from the climate change perspective, analyzing the trends in the precipitation phase partitioning and quantifying the magnitudes of change of the snow-to-precipitation ratio in response to 1℃ of temperature warming. We first investigated the number of occurrences of rain and snow events using land station and shipboard synoptic present weather reports from 1978 to 2019. We computed the global means and trends of annual precipitation frequency and the ratio of snow events to precipitation events (SE/PE ratio). Results show that when averaged over all qualified land stations and ocean grids, the annual rain frequency, annual snow frequency and the SE/PE ratio all have an increasing trend. Moreover, the trend of SE/PE ratio shows a strong latitudinal dependence. At the mid and low latitudes in the Northern Hemisphere, the SE/PE ratio has a decreasing trend. In contrast, at high latitudes, the SE/PE ratio has an increasing trend. To better predict precipitation phase, we developed a phase classification scheme based on the upper-level melting energy (ME) and refreezing energy (RE), which is proportional to the area enclosed by the temperature profile and the 0℃isotherm. We performed least square fitting and linear discriminant analysis to derive phase separation functions using observed surface and sounding data in North America. We provided separation functions for snow conditional probabilities ranging from 30% to 80% for various applications. Compared to a previously published (Probsnow) method, our energy method achieves comparable performance for Type 1 soundings with one near-surface melting layer, and significantly improve the phase classification scores for Type 2 soundings with an aloft melting layer and a near-surface refreezing layer. We innovatively combined surface ice-bulb temperature with the ratio between the melting and refreezing energy to represent Type 2 profiles. For Type 2 soundings, our energy method improves the Heidke skill score (HSS) from 0.25 to 0.47 and reduces false alarm rate by 0.47 compared to the Probsnow method for 50% threshold. By applying the physically based method, we improved accuracy and HSS, and reduced false alarm rate for more than two thirds of the evaluation stations across the North America. The locations with large improvements feature higher fractions of Type 2 soundings, confirming the importance of correctly classifying precipitation phase for these complicated precipitation types. Finally, we tested the application of the new method in satellite snowfall retrievals in the North America, and showed the differences it would bring as compared to the Probsnow method. With the improved phase classification method, we will be able to explore the sensitivity of the precipitation phase to temperature at a global scale. In our final study, we applied the energy method to classify precipitation phase for CloudSat CPR and GPM DPR to retrieve snowfall and rainfall amounts respectively. After validating the applicability of the energy method globally by comparing to the Probsnow method, we computed the climatology of the snow-to-precipitation ratio (S/P ratio) at 1° by 1° resolution. The climatological S/P ratio exhibits large spatial variability over the Northern Hemisphere (NH) compared to the Southern Hemisphere (SH) due to the land-ocean contrast and the large variations in elevation. As elevation increases, the maximum sensitivity of the S/P ratio to temperature increases slightly, from -3.7%/℃ for grids below 1500 m to -4%/℃ for grids above 3000 m. A deeper look into the snow season characteristics shows that when grouping the grids by annual median temperature and depletion season temperature difference, the sensitivity of the mean or median S/P to temperature is the largest over ocean and over the high latitudes and Tibetan Plateau while small over the mid-latitudes. However, neither the elevation nor the snow season length explains the large variability of the relation between the S/P ratio and temperature (S/P-T relation). We finally developed the "sensitive zone" theory and revealed the non-linearity and variability of the S/P ratio temperature sensitivity based on the grid's annual cycle of S/P ratio and temperature. The sensitive zone is the temperature range within which 1℃ of temperature warming would lead to a large decrease in the S/P ratio. When the temperature reaches the lower boundary of the sensitive zone, the decreasing rate of the S/P ratio accelerates, peaks at the sensitive temperature, and then starts to mitigate. The sensitive temperatures are generally between 0℃ and 2℃, but are warmer than 5℃ over high-elevation mountains, and colder than -2℃ over mid-latitude low-elevation regions. The width of the sensitive zone is small for the ocean and the Tibetan Plateau, indicating the S/P ratio will drop dramatically within a small range of temperature. The large width of the sensitive zone in the mid-latitudes indicates that the S/P ratio in the mid-latitudes is prone to 1℃ of temperature warming within a larger range of temperature.
