The sensitivities based on current temperature climatology show a more organized pattern than the maximum sensitivities, with a band of strong sensitivities around 50°N and 60°S. In the NH, the mid-latitudes around 50°N have entered the sensitive zone and been warmer than the sensitive temperature with the S/P ratio sensitivity decelerating, while the high latitudes around 60°N haven't reached the sensitive temperature thus experiencing accelerating sensitivities of the S/P ratio. By perturbing the temperature climatologies, we revealed that the mid- to low latitudes reach their sensitive temperature earlier than the high latitudes. The S/P sensitivities would strengthen in the high latitudes and the Tibetan Plateau and weaken in the mid-latitudes if the temperature continues to warm. The sensitive zone theory reveals that both temperature climatology and the temperature extremes can affect the S/P ratio temperature sensitivity. The theory can partially explain the latitudinal pattern of the trends in SE/PE ratio. Since the sensitive zone is wider in the mid-latitudes and the warming trends are larger, the mid-latitudes reach the sensitive zone earlier, thus experience large sensitivity of the precipitation phase to temperature. However, the theory cannot explain the increasing trends of the SE/PE ratio as we assumed a monotonic decrease of the portion of snow amount in precipitation amount with a warming temperature. It could be attributed to the different meaning of the SE/PE ratio to the S/P ratio. In this dissertation, we revealed the changes in the phase partitioning (SE/PE ratio) from observations, developed a novel phase classification method based on physical processes to improve the rainfall and snowfall estimation, and developed a theory to reveal the non-linearity and variability of the sensitivity of the S/P ratio to 1℃ of temperature warming. The novel energy-based phase classification method can be applied to satellite snowfall retrievals, hydrological modeling, weather forecasting, etc. And a better understanding of the sensitivity of the precipitation phase to temperature will better prepare us for a more resilient future.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Guosheng Liu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Weikuan Yu, University Representative; Ming Cai, Committee Member; Vasubandhu Misra, Committee Member; Zhaohua Wu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Smart Building Energy Management Systems Using Meta Heuristic Approach with AI-Based Load Forecasting

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Energy management is the procedure of systematic monitoring, optimization, and control of power consumption units to reduce the cost of operation. As the power system is heading towards modernization with microgrids, smartgrid, bi-directional power flow, etc, it is important to optimize the operation of the microgrid, smartgrid, and their components. This research report presents an in-depth literature review of different energy management controllers and control strategies of microgrid and their components, e.g., load forecasting, electric vehicles, and power consumption load. Load forecasting is an essential element in a power grid. It not only maximizes the utilization of power generation but also helps to maintain and operate the grid reliably. A combination of machine learning and Artificial Intelligence based methods are used to predict load. The Proposed method is applied to predict day-ahead load forecast for the New England Independent System Operator (NEISO) data sets considering historical data, dry bulb, and dew point temperature. The results show that the proposed model has higher mean absolute percentage errors than other methods in almost all cases. Electric vehicles are gaining popularity over conventional fossil fuel-based vehicles due to their low carbon footprint. More electric vehicles and fast charging stations will be a part of the smart power grid. A novel electric vehicle (EV) scheduling method based on graph search techniques has been presented in this report. To determine the optimal solution for cost minimization, the proposed algorithm considers the uncertainty of the real-time price (RTP) of power and battery degradation costs. The proposed technique's performance is evaluated using test systems that include solar generation, electric load, and an EV with a vehicle-to-grid (V2G) grid connection. The simulation process takes into account a variety of charging rates, including standard, fast, and supercharging. Several test cases for household and workplace EV charging and discharging show that the proposed method outperforms popular heuristic optimization methods, such as particle swarm optimization and genetic algorithms by 3\% to 5\%. With the increasing changes in our traditional power system, the building load management system (BLMS) has become an essential tool for prosumers to manage their power consumption efficiently and conveniently. In this paper, a reference point-based non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (also known as NSGA-III) is proposed combined with a neural prophet-based forecasting model to find the optimal solution for multi-objective BLMS. The two objectives of BLMS are to minimize the cost of operation and the discomfort cost of the user. To implement the proposed method, a BLMS is modeled consisting of three different types of load based on their operation, energy storage, electric vehicle, and renewable energy resource (RES). The results from the proposed method demonstrate significant savings, around 13\%-18\%, over time while maintaining user satisfaction for both residential and commercial buildings. A comparison analysis with other meta-heuristic methods shows that the proposed method provides the best optimum solution. Lastly, a real distribution feeder model with additional building energy system components is modeled on a digital real-time simulator using a reduced model approach. The results obtained from offline and real-time simulations are almost identical validating the efficacy of the method in field applications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Md Omar Faruque, Professor Directing Dissertation; Sastry Pamidi, Committee Member; Simon Foo, Committee Member; Juan Ordóñez, University Representative.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Substance Using, Misusing, Recovery Identity Formation among College Students

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This research focused on how college students integrated their substance use into an aspect of their self-concept and are thereby influenced by prevention and intervention campaigns or alter their substance using behaviors. The primary goal of the dissertation was to better understand how college students constructed their substance use, misuse, and recovery as contributing to their self-identity. The secondary goal was to identify mechanisms needed to provide college students a full continuum of care in forming a healthy substance using identity. To these ends, the dissertation first identified and explained the process by which substance using, misusing, and recovery identities are acquired among college students. Accordingly, I explored the mechanisms higher education institutions can and ideally should leverage, to provide such care and mitigate harmful substance use among college students. Importantly, research findings informed and facilitated the development of a model for empirically testing multiple prevention, intervention, and recovery programs that can effectively be adopted by higher education institutions. Outcomes included uncovering how collegiate recovery programs increase their likelihood for successfully impacting the health, wellness, and academic outcomes (e.g., GPA and retention) of students.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
College Student Development Theories, Collegiate Recovery Programs, Identity Formation, Recovery, Student Affairs
Lara Perez-Felkner, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael D. Giardina, University Representative; Cameron Beatty, Committee Member; Annie Wofford, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Effects of Means Restriction on Virtual Reality Suicide

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Means restriction interventions are often cited as a best practice for suicide intervention; however, our understanding of their effectiveness comes primarily from correlational and predictive studies, which preclude causal inferences about their direct effects. Further, little is known about what factors may influence the efficacy of means restriction. One possible factor is an individual's anticipated consequences of suicide (i.e., anticipated avoidance of something unpleasant). To address this critical gap in knowledge, the present study used a validated virtual reality (VR) suicide paradigm to experimentally examine the causal effects of means restriction and the anticipated consequences of suicide on subsequent virtual suicidal behavior. We hypothesized that desirable anticipated consequences (e.g., being told that engaging in VR suicide would allow one to avoid a future stressor) would drive virtual suicidal behavior, but that this process could be disrupted by increasing the effort required to access the necessary means to engage in virtual suicide. We tested this prediction by randomizing 217 participants across four conditions. As predicted, the anticipated consequences manipulation caused a large increase in VR suicide rates. Also consistent with our hypotheses, increasing the effort required to engage in virtual suicidal behavior when the anticipated consequences of suicide were highly desirable produced significantly lower rates of virtual suicide. These findings serve as a first step toward establishing a causal link between means restriction and suicide and lend further empirical support to the hypothesis that the anticipated consequences of suicide may represent a primary cause of suicidal behavior.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Sciences.
cause, experiment, means restriction, suicide, virtual reality
Jessica D. Ribeiro, Professor Directing Thesis; Thomas E. Joiner, Committee Member; Elizabeth A. Plant, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: 6 June 2020 Western U.S. Derecho

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study examines a rare derecho that formed in the western United States. During the morning hours of 6 June 2020, a complex of severe thunderstorms formed in southeastern Utah. These storms organized into a northeastward-propagating line that produced severe winds over a large swath of eastern Utah, northern Colorado, eastern Wyoming, southeastern Montana, western Nebraska, western South Dakota, and southwestern North Dakota before finally weakening. The total path length was approximately 1030 km (640 mi). A total of 339 severe wind reports (67 damage and 272 measured, including 44 significant severe gusts), 12 severe hail reports ranging from 2.5 to 4.4 cm (1.00 to 1.75 in.) diameter, and 2 tornado reports related to the derecho were recorded by the Storm Prediction Center. The maximum wind report was a 49 m s-1 (96 kt) gust at Winter Park, CO. The derecho is especially notable since only two other derechos have been documented west of the Great Plains, and none have successfully crossed the Continental Divide. This research investigates the meteorological factors that contributed to the formation, persistence, and intensity of the derecho, including synoptic-scale patterns and mesoscale influences. Results show that the 6 June 2020 event was a progressive-type derecho forced primarily by an unseasonably strong shortwave trough, with an accompanying southwesterly jet stream present at mid and upper levels. A channel of low- to mid-level moisture extending northward into the Four Corners region from the subtropical Eastern Pacific also was evident. The resulting unstable and highly sheared environment was quite favorable for strong deep convection to develop over southeastern Utah. The discrete cells that initially formed quickly grew upscale into a squall line. The line propagated to the northeast across the Rocky Mountains and into the northern Great Plains during the afternoon and evening hours, passing through at least three other distinctly different environments. Over northeast Utah, northwest Colorado, and southern Wyoming, very strong shear was present, but temperatures were remarkably cool and instability was weak. Over eastern Wyoming, eastern Colorado, and western Nebraska, inverted-V soundings were commonplace with moderate instability and shear. Finally, over South Dakota and North Dakota, strong shear was accompanied by strong instability due to much higher low-level moisture. Despite these differences and the weak instability along much of the derecho's track, the derecho was able to maintain itself throughout these regions likely due to the strong shear and mid-level winds. Results suggest that downward momentum transfer from the mid- and upper-level synoptic-scale jet was likely responsible for much of the damaging winds, especially in the cooler region. Thermodynamically generated downdrafts due to evaporation of precipitation were likely important in the formation region as well as the dry region, while other mesoscale processes such as a rear inflow jet were likely important in severe wind production in the moist region.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Henry E. Fuelberg, Professor Directing Thesis; Robert E. Hart, Committee Member; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Industrial Restructuring in Rural America
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Immigrant Household Industry Participation Before and during Covid-19

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Rural areas have experienced dramatic economic and demographic change over the past half-century. Since the 1970s, globalization trends have moved manufacturing industries away from rural areas and sometimes outsourced their labor to other countries, while agricultural industries have increasingly used technological advances that have lessened the need for workers (Flora et al. 2015). Industrial restructuring patterns that became notable in the 1990's also moved many "newer" jobs in specialized and high-paying industries away from rural areas (Center on Rural Innovation 2022; Muro 2020). Concurrently, these trends have led to shrinking economic opportunities within much of rural America and high levels of out-migration among native-born rural residents (Flora et al. 2015). Despite these trends, an increase in foreign-born in-migration to these areas started in the 1990s and continues today (e.g., Farmer and Moon 2009; Lichter and Johnson 2009). More recently, the COVID-19 pandemic created widespread disruptions to employment in the U.S., but little attention has been given to how these disruptions have affected rural areas or the immigrant workers who live there. This two-article dissertation uses American Community Survey data to provide a descriptive picture of industrial prevalence by nativity status in both urban and rural areas five years before COVID-19, and Current Population Survey data to investigate the onset of COVID-19 and its implications for rural workers (U.S.- and foreign-born) participating in Retail and Hospitality industries and Professional industries. In addition to providing a novel analysis of rural immigrant labor by industry, I find evidence of regional shifts in rural workers' participation in retail and hospitality work by nativity status during the COVID-19 years. Moreover, this research highlights the enduring importance of race/ethnicity for rural labor opportunities. These findings extend the literature on rural immigrant well-being by examining labor and industry trends across spatial contexts and build on existing industrial restructuring and segmented assimilation theories.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Kathryn H. Tillman, Professor Directing Dissertation; Christopher J. Coutts, University Representative; Karin L. Brewster, Committee Member; Patricia A. Homan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Chromosome Dynamics and Genome Organization in Mouse Male Meiosis
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Single Cell Analysis

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Meiosis is a critical process in gametogenesis for sexually reproducing organisms. During spermatogenesis, genome organization undergoes significant changes as primary spermatocytes undergo two rounds of division (meiosis I and II) to produce four genetically diverse haploid spermatids. This process halves the chromosome number and ensures genetic variation in the resulting sperm cells. A key feature of meiosis is homolog pairing, which promotes recombination essential for genetic diversity and species survival. Despite the long-standing discovery of homolog pairing, many mysteries remain regarding the factors and chromosomal interactions that facilitate this process. Bulk Hi-C studies have revealed the dynamic higher-order chromatin structures (TADs and Compartments) that chromosomes adopt as they progress through meiosis. However, the finer scale spatial relationships and physical proximity are often obscured due to the averaging nature of population Hi-C. In this study, we obtained cells from male F1 hybrid mice at various stages of meiotic progression, including the less-studied interkinesis phase, an intermediary phase between meiosis I and II. We performed single-cell Hi-C on these cells to capture chromosome dynamics at the single-cell level. By ordering cells based on their short- and long-range cis interactions, we categorized them into two groups: compacted meiotic prophase cells and decompacted cells, both showing distinct intra-chromosomal contact profiles from each other. Using haplotype phasing, we resolved intra- and inter-genomic interaction profiles. Coverage patterns along homologs alone enabled us to distinguish cell types and understand the zygosity of specific chromosomal regions. This was particularly beneficial for interkinesis cells and spermatids, providing detailed insights into the types and counts of crossover events per chromosome. Diploid contact maps from single cells offered a comprehensive understanding of cell-to-cell variability within each cell type. The added 3D visualization from our high-resolution haplotype-resolved models revealed the varied nature of pairing conformations between chromosomes and between cells. Distance matrices generated from these 3D models uncovered a surprising and previously unseen conserved pattern of proximal interactions between homologs across different cells. This finding was unexpected given the typically varied pairing conformations of chromosomes. These conserved proximal interactions suggest the possibility of homologs beginning pairing at nucleation points, similar to the button model proposed in Drosophila. Alternatively, these conserved points in mammals might act as directors of crossover events. These findings uncover a novel feature of homolog pairing in mammals with significant biological implications, poised for further exploration and understanding.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Peter Fraser, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Henry W. Bass, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Alan R. Lemmon, University Representative; Jonathan Hancock Dennis, Committee Member; Jian Feng, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Aggravation and Verbal Aggression among Low-Income Mothers and Child Internalizing Problems
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Cross-Lagged Longitudinal Study

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Parents have major influences on child wellbeing, including the development of internalizing symptomology in their children (Gawlik & Melnyk, 2022). Furthermore, the emotional impact between parents and their children could be reciprocal (Maccoby, 2003). In this study, I examined the reciprocal association between maternal aggravation and child internalizing symptoms from childhood to adolescence, mediated through maternal verbal aggression. Based on the theoretical perspectives of family socialization theory (Kalmuss & Seltzer, 1989), family systems theory (Bowen, 1966), and related literature, I hypothesized bidirectional influences between maternal aggravation and child internalizing symptoms from childhood to adolescence (H1). I further hypothesized that maternal verbal aggression would mediate these reciprocal associations (H2). To test these hypotheses, a sample of approximately 5,000 mothers across four waves from the Future of Families & Child Wellbeing Study (FFCWS) was utilized. A cross-lagged autoregressive model was conducted. Results suggested that for mothers, in general, maternal aggravation and verbal aggression were reciprocally related. Regarding "parent" effects, maternal aggravation was related to child internalizing problems directly and longitudinally, but not through verbal aggression. For "child" effects, child internalizing problems were directly related to later maternal aggravation, but not through verbal aggression and only existed during early stage of development. Taken together, the findings suggested stronger evidence of "parent" effects than "child" effects and direct effects than mediating effects. Findings from this study have important implications for family researchers and practitioners regarding parenting and child internalizing symptoms.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Adolescents, Aggravation, Children, Internalizing, Mothers, Verbal Aggression
Ming Cui, Professor Directing Thesis; Lenore McWey, Committee Member; Qiong (Joanna) Wu, Committee Member; Lyndsay Jenkins, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Comorbidity and Trauma Characteristics as a Function of Chronic and Remitted PTSD
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Population-Based Study Using the Hitop Classification of Mental Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Globally, over 70% of adults are exposed to one or more potentially traumatic events over the course of their lifetime (Benjet et al., 2016). However, only a minority of individuals who experience a traumatic event will develop Posttraumatic Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD; Kilpatrick et al., 2013). PTSD as a diagnostic disorder is traditionally designated using a binary "diagnosis" or "no diagnosis" approach, and related conditions are evaluated in the same manner. This traditional "present" or "absent" approach to pathology fails to take into account PTSD symptom course beyond meeting threshold DSM-5 minimum diagnostic criteria and can be a limiting approach to pathology. In actuality, there are multiple discrete outcome trajectories that can result after exposure to a traumatic event that the DSM diagnosis vs. no diagnosis approach cannot adequately illustrate (Bonanno, 2004; Galatzer-Levy et al., 2018). Aside from a resilient response (i.e. no lifetime PTSD) the two most frequently observed response trajectories to trauma exposure that confer symptoms include recovery after a period of experiencing symptoms (i.e. remitted PTSD) and prolonged endurance of chronic symptoms (Galatzer-Levy et al., 2018). For the present study, we utilized the Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Factors-III (NESARC-III), a large, nationally-representative sample, to investigate psychiatric comorbidities, socio-demographic determinants, trauma characteristics, and treatment-related behaviors as a function of PTSD chronicity. We divided the trauma exposed sample (N = 23,707) into three symptom trajectory path groups: Resilient (N = 21,488), Remitted (N = 560), and Chronic (N = 1,659) and examined group differences using both a traditional, categorical approach to psychopathology (diagnosis vs. no diagnosis) and a transdiagnostic, hierarchical framework constructed on a gradation of increased covariation; the recently-developed Hierarchical Taxonomy of Psychopathology (HiTOP; Kotov et al., 2017). Consistent with hypotheses, the traditional approach revealed that the Remitted group was more highly correlated with a greater number of comorbid disorders than the Resilient group, and Chronic PTSD was associated with a greater number of comorbid disorders than the Resilient trajectory path and the Remitted path when examined via discrete diagnoses. Participants who identified childhood sexual abuse as their worst trauma type were at significantly greater odds of developing chronic PTSD than never develop a threshold-level PTSD diagnosis over the course of their lifetime, and those with adult sexual assault as their worst trauma type also more likely to develop Chronic PTSD than belong to the Resilient group. Contrary to study hypotheses, neither childhood sexual abuse nor adult sexual assault were significantly differentiated odds between belonging to the Chronic PTSD vs. Remitted PTSD. In terms of HiTOP analyses, the Chronic group exhibited a greater number of psychiatric criteria per spectra and subfactor compared to the Remitted and Resilient groups. Additionally, the Chronic group exhibited a greater number psychiatric spectra in the fear, distress, and substance abuse subfactor, compared to the Remitted and Resilient groups. Taken altogether, the modern, HiTOP approach appeared to provide a more nuanced, comprehensive conceptualization of the differences between trajectory groups compared to the dichotomous diagnostic systems approach. Results from the present study uncovered comorbidities associated with PTSD using a chronicity-graded perspective and both traditional and transdiagnostic approaches. Downstream, study findings may help identify individuals at risk for greater levels of post-trauma clinical distress and impairment, and could ultimately aid in developing targeted treatment and prevention efforts. Future studies may wish to examine a longitudinal sample in order to explore the development of symptom trajectory paths over time and within the context of a timeline of co-occurring diagnoses and events.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Chronic PTSD, HiTOP, PTSD, Remitted PTSD, Resilient, Trauma

Jesse R. Cougle, Professor Directing Dissertation; David W. Eccles, University Representative; David S. March, Committee Member; Christopher J. Patrick, Committee Member; Richard K. Wagner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Massive Spin-Clock Transitions in Molecular Lanthanide Qubits

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Molecular lanthanide (Ln) complexes are promising candidates for development of next-generation quantum technologies. High-symmetry structures incorporating integer spin (non-Kramers) Ln ions can give rise to well-isolated crystal field (CF) quasi-doublet ground states, i.e., quantum twolevel systems that may serve as a basis for spin-qubits. Recent work has shown that by carefully tailoring the coordination environment around the Ln ion, avoided Zeeman-crossings, or spin clock transitions (SCTs), can be introduced within the ground doublet, leading to significantly enhanced coherence times. This is because the decoherence processes related to magnetic noise are eliminated up to first-order at the SCT, as the dependence of the spin-qubit transition frequency, f, on the applied magnetic field, B vanishes dfdB = 0 . However, second-order effects d2fdB2 from magneticnoise will still result in a loss of coherence. One possible strategy to limit second order effects is to increase the energy gap Δ between the qubit basis states, since near the SCT gap, d2fdB2 ∝ 1Δ. Motivated by the potential to improve coherence times in spin-qubits, this thesis presents a series of high field electron paramagnetic resonance (HF-EPR) spectroscopy studies of molecular Ln complexes, where the idea of producing larger SCT gaps in the ground-doublet of Ln complexes is explored. New results begin in chapter 2, with HF-EPR studies performed on two HoIII complexes possessing pseudo-C4 local coordination geometries. HF-EPR methods are used to precisely measure the SCT gap within the ground quasi-doublet, obtaining values of: Δ = 116 GHz and Δ ≃ 250 GHz respectively. These SCT gaps are significantly larger than the SCT previously reported in [Ho(W5O18)2]9− (abbreviated HoW10) of Δ = 9 GHz. The larger SCT gaps are attributed to the local ∼ C4 symmetry, which maximizes the contribution of the fourth-order CF terms and therefore efficiently mixes the states for which ΔmJ = 4n where n is an integer. Additional far-infrared magnetospectroscopy (FIRMS) and complete active-space self-consistent field (CASSCF) studies are performed to determine the energy gaps to the lowest-lying excited states above the ground doublet, allowing further constraint of the CF parameters. For the Δ = 116 GHz compound, the ground quasi-doublet was found to be mostly composed of the symmetric and anti-symmetric combinations of mJ = ±8 wheres for the Δ ≃ 250 GHz compound, there were four low-lying states comprising a ground-quartet, which were mixtures of mJ = ±3 and mJ = ±4. 14 Chapter 3 then describes results from a HF-EPR study on a metal-organic framework (MOF) containing HoIII metal-ion clusters. In this complex, the HoIII ion is locally coordinated to eight oxygens in a distorted pseudo-D4d geometry. Angle dependence measurements were preformed, revealing a four-fold rotational symmetry in the magnetic anisotropy. This is attributed to the two molecular orientations in the unit cell, which are related by a rotation of 90o, an assessment that is confirmed by x-ray diffraction measurements. The results of the angle dependence study are used to locate each of the two molecular symmetry axes, and a frequency dependence of is subsequently performed. Fits of the frequency dependent spectra are used to accurately determine the SCT gap of Δ = 54 GHz. The SCT gap is appreciably larger in this sample than in HoW10, which is attributed to the increased distortion of the local coordination geometry away from perfect D4d symmetry, further lifting the degeneracy of the ground state quasi-doublet. Chapter 4 covers a topic unrelated to SCTs, with a HF-EPR study the lanthanide complex Bisphthalocyaninato dysprosium [DyPc2]0 in the structural Pnma phase. This study is still relevant to quantum information science however, as the Pc2 ligand offers a way to couple lanthanides to surfaces, allowing the unpaired radical carried by the ligand to mediate interactions between the normally isolated 4f electrons and their environment. The goal of this study is then to investigate the nature of the coupling mechanism between the delocalized radical and the unpaired 4f electrons on the DyIII ion. Angle dependent EPR spectra are presented, showing an anisotroic signal from the radical, indicative of coupling between the radical and DyIII ion. Simulations of the angle dependence data are used to estimate radical-lanthanide coupling strength Jex at −0.041 cm−1 which is much weaker than the value obtained for [TbPc2]0 of Jex at −0.147 cm−1 (here the negative sign represents ferromagnetic coupling). There is also strong evidence of intermolecular interactions, which were absent in previous studies of [TbPc2]0.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Stephen Hill, Professor Directing Dissertation; Mykhailo Shatruk, University Representative; Nicholas Bonesteel, Committee Member; Irinel Chiorescu, Committee Member; Alexander Volya, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Framework of an Infrastructure Performance Model Based on the Concepts of Civil Integrated Management (CIM)

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The recent rise in the applications of advanced technologies in the sustainable design and construction of transportation infrastructure demands an appropriate medium for their integration and utilization. A relatively new concept of Civil Integrated Management (CIM) is such a medium, which enhances the development of digital twins for the infrastructure, and embodies various practices and tools, including the collection, organization, and data management techniques of digital data for transportation infrastructure projects. As transportation projects increase in complexity, various CIM tools and functions can be implemented to ensure quality, on-time, and on-budget project delivery. CIM methods and tools have the potential to improve the performance and predictability of a project, from early stages like scoping, and surveying, through design and construction, to the latest stages such as operations and maintenance. Asset management for transportation infrastructure refers to the systematic process of maintaining, upgrading, and operating physical assets cost-effectively. It encompasses the planning, design, construction, maintenance, and rehabilitation of infrastructure assets such as roads, bridges, tunnels, water supply systems, and other public facilities. The objective of an effective asset management practice is to ensure that these assets deliver their intended service levels over their lifecycle while minimizing costs and maximizing performance, safety, and reliability. This process involves data collection, condition assessment, performance monitoring, risk management, and the implementation of strategies to optimize the allocation of resources for maintenance and renewal activities. The costs associated with asset management related tasks for highway systems constitute significant portions of a state's general expenditures. The arrival of modern techniques for predicting pavement performance has motivated agencies to develop accurate, efficient, and intelligent models for forecasting the pavement deterioration. Performance modeling involves relating pavement condition, surface distresses, and structural properties to a variety of predictors—including material properties, traffic loading, and environmental factors—through mathematical or machine learning expressions. However, considering the numerous critical predictors and their complex interrelationships, developing an effective predictive model for pavement performance is a challenging task. This study addresses the challenge by developing various machine learning models analyzing LTPP databse. The dissertation presents an extensive exploration into the development implementation of CIM workflow, emphasizing the integration of collected information across various phases. The review study identifies the need for a geospatial model-based asset management system for transportation infrastructures. It further highlights the importance of integrating IoT technologies with modeling techniques to create a digital twin framework—a dynamic, interactive model that represents the physical and functional characteristics of infrastructure assets throughout their lifecycle. Despite challenges such as modeling complexity, technology investment, and data privacy, the integration of GIS, BIM, and Artificial Intelligence (AI) within asset management systems holds the potential to improve infrastructure's structural integrity and long-term performance through automated monitoring, analysis, and predictive maintenance during its lifespan. Additionally, various aspects of GeoBIM implementation framework is discussed including data acquisition, modeling, and analysis steps, highlighting the importance of comprehensive data utilization from design, construction, and maintenance phases. By integrating life cycle information gathered from various phases of an asset, this research has demonstrated that existing infrastructure performance models can be improved considerably to assess its performance. To overcome this challenge, this dissertation aims to explore various machine learning algorithms, namely, Random Forest, Extra Trees, XGBoost, and novel neural networks, which were developed to identify the most significant factors influencing AC cracking from thirty potential input variables. These features have been collected from the Long-Term Pavement Performance (LTPP) database provided by the Federal Highway Association (FHWA) comprising of material type and properties, environmental factors, traffic, and design and construction specifications. Additionally, a GeoBIM framework was developed that replaces the existing milepost strategy of DOTs by employing a smaller segmentation using linear referencing to store digital information concerning asset performance as well as construction and material specifications. Moreover, this study found out that the quality of construction and rehabilitation changes, captured through the material testing, were amongst the most important features affecting pavement performance. This study illustrates the practical application of the developed models in forecasting wheel path cracking for U.S. 1 highway, demonstrating their potential as powerful tools for infrastructure asset management. The dissertation concludes the dissertation by summarizing the findings and proposing future research directions. This chapter demonstrated the transformative power of AI utilizing a text-to-image deep learning model for generating infrastructure conceptual design, highlighting an innovative application of AI in transportation projects. The chapter highlights the successful development and validation of the GeoBIM framework and its machine learning components, emphasizing their potential to transform transportation infrastructure management. A recommendation for further research into real-time data integration, automated condition assessment, and the application of IoT and AI technologies to enhance the predictive capabilities of CIM systems is discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
John Olusegun Sobanjo, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michael Duncan, University Representative; Eren Erman Ozguven, Committee Member; Juyeong Choi, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Adult Attachment, Mindfulness, and Individual Anxiety
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Longitudinal Mediation Approach

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Insecure attachment styles have been linked to a higher risk of anxiety and affective disorders. This link is further underscored by the high prevalence of adults experiencing anxiety symptoms. While past research has suggested that mindfulness may elucidate the well-established association between adult attachment orientations and individual anxiety symptoms, there remains a limited understanding within the context of romantic relationships. Grounded in Family Systems Theory (FST) and Attachment Theory (AT), this longitudinal study explored the associations between attachment orientations and individual anxiety as mediated by mindfulness. The research aimed to elucidate temporal associations among these variables in 105 heterosexual couples undergoing systemic therapy over eight treatment sessions, at three time points (T1 = Session 1, T2 = Session 4, T3 = Session 8). Direct and indirect path analysis, employed via the Actor-Partner Interdependence Mediation Model (APIMeM), suggested that there were significant intra- and interpersonal direct associations. The female partner's anxious attachment at T1 was negatively associated with her mindfulness at T2. The male partner's anxious attachment at T1 was negatively associated with the female partner's mindfulness at T2. Females' anxious and avoidant attachment at T1 was negatively associated with male partners' anxiety at T3, suggesting a possible adaptive and relational efficacy feature of insecure attachment, in which anxiously or avoidantly attached females at the start of therapy had partners who exhibited low levels of individual anxiety by session 8. Neither male nor female mindfulness at T2 mediated the association between attachment anxiety and avoidance at T1 and individual anxiety at T3, intra- or interpersonally, which suggested a continued need to examine the temporal associations of mindfulness in romantic relationships, particularly in clinical contexts. This study expanded upon existing research that highlights interdependent internal processes in romantic couples and affirmed previous findings indicating that mindfulness is connected to the dynamics of romantic relationships. Findings have implications for research development through integrating FST and AT to examine temporal associations of internal processes in romantic relationships. Additionally, there are clinical implications for the practice of marriage and family therapy (MFT) through the use of attachment and mindfulness-based strategies to treat intra- and interpersonal processes observed in couples therapy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
anxiety, anxious attachment, avoidant attachment, couples therapy, longitudinal, mindfulness
Qiong Wu, Professor Directing Dissertation; Shengli Dong, University Representative; Lenore M. McWey, Committee Member; Jonathan G. Kimmes, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Experimental Techniques to Study Low-Lying Proton Resonances in 26Si and 11C

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This work details an investigation of the impact of the 25Al(p,γ)26Si reaction on the synthesis of galactic 26Al. Aluminum-26 is observed indirectly through gamma-ray astronomy and is a probe into the ongoing nucleosynthesis in the galaxy, as well as the frequency of Core-Collapse Super- novae. The 25Al(p,γ)26Si reaction directly impacts the 26Al yield, as it bypasses the population of the 26Al ground state. An experiment effort using the transfer reaction, 2H(25Al,26Si)n, was per- formed at Florida State University's RESOLUT radioactive beam facility to study near threshold proton resonances. The resonance spectrum and corresponding cross sections were obtained with better precision than in previous measurements. Spectroscopic information were determined using DWBA Calculations. The astrophysical implications associated with the improved proton resonance strength are discussed. Utilizing a similar, but improved experimental apparatus a second experiment was performed to investigate an important near threshold proton resonance in 11C. Located just 10 keV above the proton separation energy, situated in the center of the Gamow window, this resonance determines the low energy reaction rate. In light of the observed discrepancy found in the 11B/10B ratio between the solar abundance and that found in the Galactic Cosmic Ray Spallation, an investigation into the destruction of 10B was performed. The 2H(10B,11C)n reaction utilized the RESONEUT setup to measure triple coincidences that include the transferred neutron and the particle decays from 11C→7Be+4He. Results and implications are presented.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Ingo Wiedenhöver, Professor Directing Thesis; Henry E. Fuelberg, University Representative; Sergio Jesus Almaraz-Calderon, Committee Member; Alexander Volya, Committee Member; Peter A. Hoeflich, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Unveiling Gendered Stereotypes in Esports
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Exploring the Influence of Stereotype Beliefs, Conformity to Masculine Norms, and Experience on Biased Perceptions of Female Gamers

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Female gamers in eSports often face significant challenges, including sexual harassment, entrenched stereotypes, and pervasive sexist perceptions. This study aimed to delve into the development of gendered stereotypes within the eSports community. Specifically, it proposed an experimental approach to assess how stereotype beliefs, conformity to masculine norms, and prior experience in eSports influenced perceptions toward female gamers. Furthermore, this study investigated whether disclosing a gamer's gender biased the audience's perceptions regarding their competence. To achieve this, an experiment was conducted in which participants were randomly assigned to watch a gameplay video clip from the popular game "League of Legends," featuring either a male or female gamer. The experimental conditions manipulated the gender disclosure of the gamer to evaluate its impact on competence assessments. By analyzing the differences in these evaluations, the study sought to identify and measure the biased perceptions that emerged when the gamer's gender was revealed. The findings of this research showed that people would evaluate female gamer less competence compared to male gamer, despite the identical game play. Moreover, this study found that conformity to masculine norms and eSports experience all contribute to the stereotypes against female gamers. This study contributed significantly to understanding the factors that fueled gender stereotypes in eSports. Moreover, the insights gained were instrumental in developing strategies to promote inclusivity and equality within the gaming community, thereby fostering a more supportive environment for female gamers. This research underscored the importance of addressing gender biases and aimed to pave the way for more equitable treatment and representation of women in the rapidly growing eSports industry.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
eSports, eSports experience, Female gamer, Gender, Masculine norm, Stereotype
Sindy Chapa, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Arienne Ferchaud, Committee Member; Katherine R. Dale, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Bilingual Kindergarters' Performance on Spanish and English Literacy Screeners
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Predicting End-of-Year English Word Reading

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Bilingual Kindergartners' Performance on Spanish and English Literacy Screeners

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The purpose of this study was to investigate whether performance on Spanish and English early literacy screeners predict end-of-year English word reading abilities in bilingual kindergarteners. This study specifically sought to identify the most effective predictors and combinations of subtests. Seventy-seven Spanish-English bilingual kindergarten students in the southeastern United States participated in the study. Participants completed Spanish and English language and literacy screeners, administered by trained proctors using iPads. Key findings revealed that English subtests were more strongly correlated with end-of-year English word reading than Spanish subtests, except for Spanish word reading, which emerged as one of the most significant predictors. A dominance analysis identified English blending, letter-sound fluency, and Spanish word reading as the three most dominant predictors, consistently explaining variance in English word reading across various regression models. A quantile regression analysis further revealed that English blending was the most relevant predictor at lower quantiles, while Spanish word reading was more significant at higher quantiles of reading performance. These results highlight the effectiveness of English subtests in predicting English word reading abilities, while also demonstrating the enhanced model accuracy when including Spanish word reading as a predictor. Overall, the study discusses considerations within and between languages in early literacy assessment, emphasizing the interconnected nature of bilingual literacy skills.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bilingual, Early identification, Language, Literacy, Reading, Screening
Hugh Catts, Professor Directing Dissertation; Donald Compton, University Representative; Carla Wood, Committee Member; Kelly Farquharson, Committee Member; Lisa Fitton, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Prison Personnel and Workplace Social Capital

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
College of Criminology and Criminal Justice

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Scholarship suggests that correctional personnel play an integral role in the daily life of incarcerated persons (IPs). They influence life in prison for IPs and social order. At the same time, they may be affected by prison conditions. Indeed, prison work has been shown to be among the most challenging types of occupations and to contribute to higher levels of stress, suicide, and other adverse outcomes. Yet, much remains unknown about the factors that enable personnel to successfully navigate these conditions and, in turn, experience less stress and have greater job satisfaction and positive views about their work environment, including IPs. This dissertation examines workplace social capital (WSC) and its effects on prison personnel. The broader goal is to contribute to research and scholarship on the factors that influence prison personnel experiences and the impacts of correctional work on them, and, in turn, the potential role that these experiences and impacts may have on IP experiences and correctional systems. More specifically, it examines WSC among prison personnel, including who has WSC and its potential effects on personnel stress and views about their work, IPs, and the prison system. To this end, the dissertation draws on quantitative data from a study, "The Impacts of Restrictive Housing on Inmate Behavior, Mental Health, Recidivism, and Prison Systems and Personnel," to address the following interrelated research questions. First, what is the prevalence of WSC among prison personnel and, second, what factors are associated with WSC? Chapter 4 of the dissertation explores both of these questions by examining the prevalence and predictors of WSC. Third, does WSC influence the employment experiences and perceptions of individuals who are employed within the corrections system? Chapter 5 of the dissertation examines the effects of WSC on prison personnel's perceptions of IPs, perceived job stress and satisfaction, and perceptions of the correctional system. Fourth, does WSC influence the experiences and perceptions of individuals who are employed within restrictive housing (RH)? Chapter 6 examines whether working within RH amplifies the effect of WSC on prison personnel perceptions and experiences. This dissertation presents findings from the analyses and then discusses their implications for theory, research, and policy.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Criminology and Criminal Justice in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Correctional Officers, Prison, Prison Work, Workplace Social Capital
Daniel P. Mears, Professor Directing Dissertation; Melissa Radey, University Representative; Carter Hay, Committee Member; Joseph A. Schwartz, Committee Member.
