mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Exploring the Experiences and Job Satisfaction of SLPAs and Supervising SLPs
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Exploratory Mixed Method Design

mods:name.mods:namePart: School of Communication Science and Disorders

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The use of speech-language pathology assistants (SLPAs) in service delivery has garnered increasing interest in speech- language pathology, particularly due to the ongoing shortage of qualified speech- language pathologists. This study aimed to investigate the experiences of SLPAs and supervising SLPs, along with the factors contributing to their job satisfaction. Employing a sequential mixed methods design in two phases, qualitative data was initially collected through semi-structured interviews with six SLPAs and six supervising SLPs. Thematic analysis revealed six major themes from SLPA transcripts: a) relationship with supervising SLP and supervision, b) challenges, c) supports, d) attitudes towards the role of SLPAs, e) preservice training, and f) leaving. Four major themes emerged from SLP transcripts: a) supervisory experience, b) challenges, c) supports, d) perceptions on the role of SLPAs. In the second phase, qualitative findings informed the development of a survey protocol to examine the relationship between state regulation category, SLPAs' years of experience, hours of direct supervision per month, and their job satisfaction ratings. Additionally, we examined the relation between state regulation category, and supervising SLPs perspectives on SLPAs impact on caseload and workload on their job satisfaction. Of the factors examined only SLPAs' years of experience emerged as a significant predictor of job satisfaction. Additionally, discrepancies between qualitative and quantitative findings regarding job satisfaction were identified and discussed. Findings also highlighted the importance of time in the working relationship between SLPAs and supervising SLPs, as well as the complex interplay between the integration of SLPAs and broader systemic issues within the field of speech-language pathology. Implications of these findings and directions for future research are also discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication Science and Disorders in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Job Satisfaction, Mixed Methods, Speech-Language Pathologists, Speech-Language Pathology Assistants
Carla Wood, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lindsay Dennis, University Representative; Mollie Romano, Committee Member; Erin Bush, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Study on Deep Learning Models for Real World Applications

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Due to the tremendous success of deep learning, it has become a crucial component in everyone's life. Many researchers are trying to improve the performance of these deep learning models, but because of the huge amounts of data that are being generated and as the data is very diverse, it has become a huge problem for them. Expert suggestions or labels are used to label them, but it would take lot of time and cost. To address this issue, we have developed an active learning algorithm that identifies the appropriate unlabeled samples and labels them effectively, and in case of multiple oracles different smaller models are used to pick the cost-effective annotator. But in general, even when the models are working perfectly, in some cases these models could fail abruptly. To address this issue, we train a meta-model whose goal is to predict whether a base deep neural network will succeed or fail in predicting a particular data sample, by observing the base model's performance on a given learning task. Apart from these two studies, we have also focused on forecasting the behavior of elderly people based on their data captured in a study using a fusion-based deep learning architecture with various domain adaptation techniques. For these three projects, we used three different natures of datasets with various experiments to validate their performance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Active Learning, BERT, Deep Learning, Domain Adaptation, Fusion Model, Meta Model
Shayok Chakraborty, Professor Directing Thesis; Guang Wang, Committee Member; Xiaonan Zhang, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Early Replication Control Elements Are Developmentally Regulated Genetic Determinants of Replication Timing and Require Transcription Factor Activity

mods:mods.mods:abstract: During S phase, chromosomes are replicated in a defined temporal order called the replication timing (RT) program. RT programs are evolutionarily conserved, cell-type specific, and particularly resistant to a wide-range of protein depletions, knockdowns, knockouts, and inhibitors, suggesting tight and extremely robust control. However, the mechanisms controlling RT have remained elusive for >60 years. We previously reported large (>30kb) deletions that, when combined, cause a domain-wide shift from early- to late-replicating that is concomitant with a loss of all gene transcription and A- to B-compartment switch, but those deletions contained many different chromatin features that make those changes difficult to interpret and uncouple. Here, we show that the previously-reported elements B and C in the Dppa2/4 domain are dependent upon Oct4, Sox2, Nanog co-binding sites and independent of transcriptional control, while the sequences at A remain a mystery. Further, we show that sequences derived from the Dppa2/4 domain carry the information required to promote early RT by inserting a bacterial artificial chromosome containing Dppa2/4 domain sequences into a late-replicating domain, and then further show that the ectopic insertion is developmentally regulated like the endogenous site, suggesting that RT is controlled by DNA sequence and that these elements work as enhancer-like elements for replication initiation in a cell-type specific context. Next, we predicted active ERCEs in neural precursor cells based on publicly-available NPC ChIP-seq data and show that deletions of these elements cause delays in RT similar to the phenomena observed at the Dppa2/4 domain, confirming developmental control of replication timing cis-elements. Lastly, we use a wide-range of inducible-degron cell lines and commercially-available small-molecule inhibitors to interrogate ERCE function genome-wide. These results suggest that ERCEs are intimately intertwined with developmental regulation of transcriptional networks, although their functions can be separated from transcription in specific contexts.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
cis-element, differentiation, embryonic stem cells, replication timing, transcription, transcription factor

Hank W. Bass, Professor Directing Dissertation; Michelle N. Arbeitman, University Representative; Jonathan H. Dennis, Committee Member; Peter Fraser, Committee Member; Karen M. McGinnis, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Multi-Modal Continuum Model-Based Design for Soft Robotics

mods:mods.mods:abstract: We present novel measurements and analysis of bio-inspired swimming and climbing gaits for long slender organisms and robots. Analysis and experimental results for a lamprey-inspired wall climbing gait. We present this gait on the wall climbing segmented robot Trident. We compare two existing fluid modeling results on Trident in the water. We present computational and hardware results for a soft continuum swimming and climbing robot SLIDER. A novel model is developed to capture both structural and fluid based on nonlinear beam theory and Lighthill's large-amplitude elongated body theory. Governing equations are developed and a computational model to solve them is proposed. Results of the computational analysis are compared against hardware results. This fluid-structure model is used to optimize the tail morphology and feedforward control pattern of the SLIDER robot.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mechanical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Bio-Inspiration, Dynamics, Fluid Structure Interaction, Optimization, Robotics, Soft Robotics

Jonathan Clark, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Kourosh Shoele, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Rodney Roberts, Committee Member; Christian Hubicki, Committee Member; Juan Ordóñez, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Development of Assays for the Identification of Virulent Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia Coli Strains

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a diverse Gram-negative, rod-shaped, facultatively anaerobic, and non-sporing bacterium belonging to the family Enterobacteriaceae. Strains of E. coli can be found in the environment and the intestinal microflora of mammals. While many E. coli strains have developed an essential mutualism relationship in our colonized gastrointestinal tract, some have evolved with the ability to cause diarrheal disease in humans. Diarrheal disease-causing strains are categorized as intestinal pathogenic Escherichia coli (IPEC). IPEC can be further classified into five phenotypes: enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC), enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC), enteroaggregative Escherichia coli (EAEC), Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), and Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC). While Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) are interchangeably in scientific literature. However, based on the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), STEC is defined as strains that harbor the stx gene that produces Shiga toxins but may not carry other virulent genes. Similarly, EHEC is defined as strains that harbor the stx and intimin (eae) genes (FAO, WHO, 2018). Strains that have both these genes are considered virulent, while strains that have only one or neither are considered potentially avirulent. Virulent strains with stx and eae are responsible for significant foodborne outbreaks, are a major foodborne pathogen implicated in red meat outbreaks, and are considered adulterants in beef products. On the contrary, potentially avirulent strains are not considered a significant concern for the red meat industry. Currently, MLG 5.03 is the standard method for the detection of virulent strains. However, this method suffers from high false-positive rates. The false-positive test results arise from this method as it uses separate primer pairs to detect stx and eae independently within a sample. The presence of multiple avirulent strains or other background genera that may also contain stx or eae found in meat samples result in the false detection of strain(s) containing both of these genes. The purpose of this study will be to initially standardize and validate four high-resolution melt (HRM) assays, followed by a conversation of these assays to industry-friendly hydrolysis probe (HP) assays for the differentiation of potentially virulent strains of EHEC serogroups belonging to O26, O103, O111, and O121. The designed primers and probes will target a conserved single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) located on the serogroup-specific fnl1, wbdK, wbtD, and vioA genes of O26, O111, O103, and O121, respectively. The assays will be validated using pure cultures strains from Canada, France, Switzerland, and the United States, laboratory-inoculated beef and spinach samples, laboratory fractionally inoculated ground beef samples, and DNA samples from the federal red meat surveillance program. This study will provide significant insight into the accurate identification of E. coli strains present in tested samples. The work will allow the food industry to continue preventing foodborne outbreaks while increasing the volume of raw food products brought to the market.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Adulterants, Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC), High-Resolution Melt, Real-time PCR, TaqMan, USDA
Prashant Singh, Professor Directing Dissertation; Kathryn Jones, University Representative; Ravinder Nagpal, Committee Member; Stephen Hennigar, Committee Member; Jamel Ali, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Influence of microRNA-21 on Vascular Function Following a Long-Term Atherogenic Diet

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Atherosclerosis, an inflammatory disease of the arterial wall, is often identified as the major cause of cardiovascular disease (CVD). This disease of the arteries, resulting in the hardening and narrowing of the arterial lumen, is characterized by endothelial dysfunction, the accumulation of modified lipids, inflammatory cells, and plaque build-up. Obesity, Type 2 diabetes, smoking, and hypertension lead to an increase in vascular fibrosis and stiffening of the artery and therefore, increased risk of cardiovascular events. To avoid the progression of vascular stiffness and CVD, detecting vascular stiffness early on may play a critical role. This early detection allows for the necessary treatment and lifestyle interventions, which may assist in reducing risk factors associated with CVD. Vascular stiffness, or loss of elasticity in blood vessels, can be used as an independent early marker of atherosclerosis and predictor of cardiovascular events such as heart attacks and strokes. In addition to assessing vascular stiffness, this study will also investigate the role of microRNA-21 (miR-21) on female mice. miR-21 is a small non-coding RNA molecule that functions by binding most commonly to the 3' untranslated region (UTR) of the complementary sequences in messenger RNAs (mRNAs). miR-21 acts like an emergency brake for inflammation and may help prevent atherosclerotic plaques and therefore, the progression and development of CVD. The results of this study highlight the protective role inhibiting miR-21 has. The results showed the wild-type atherogenic diet group had the highest blood pressure while the miR-21 knockout atherogenic had the lowest blood pressure. Overall these findings suggest miR-21 knockout reduced body mass and body fat percent, which also aided in suppressing blood pressure in response to the atherogenic diet. Additionally, the protective role of miR-21 was also observed when checking vascular reactivity of the carotids, aortas, and mesenteric arteries highlighting a therapeutic target for regulating arterial compliance.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Justin LaFavor, Professor Directing Thesis; Michael Delp, Committee Member; Daniel Machin, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Strategic Candidate Selection and Minority Representation

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: How do parties negotiate strategies that trade off experienced candidates for diversity? On the one hand, parties are strategic in nominating candidates: those with more experience are placed in higher positions on party lists. On the other hand, evidence from minority representation in national governments emphasizes parties' efforts to enhance diversity to attract votes. However, we do not know how parties navigate potential tradeoffs between experience and diversity. In my dissertation, I propose a model in which two parties must select a combination of candidates based on their level of experience and diversity status to create a list. Subsequently, voters then vote for one of the parties following their preferences. I examine whether the parties' strategic incentives might be strong enough to prioritize their preferences, even when not aligned with the voters. I argue that some institutions make these tradeoffs more salient, even leading parties to reduce their diversity efforts. The formal model is included in Chapter 2. I examine these theoretical results with two empirical tests, one developed in Chapter 3, and one in Chapter 4. First, I use an original dataset of legislative party lists in Italy from 1993 to 2022 to examine whether and how parties modify their candidate selection strategies based on the type of electoral rule and the presence of a quota. Second, I run both an incentivized laboratory experiment and a survey experiment replicating these strategic dynamics. My findings suggest that parties are strategic in weighing the value of diversity and experience when selecting candidates and creating party lists. This has important implications for understanding parties' strategic incentives when they attempt to diversify their membership and face a potential trade-off when selecting diverse yet less experienced candidates.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Christopher Reenock, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Jens Großer, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Deana Rohlinger, University Representative; Amanda Driscoll, Committee Member; Ana Catalano Weeks, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Performance Analysis and Evaluation of Reduced-Precision Computation on the Tendral Statistical Interpolation System (T-Sis) for Ocean Modeling

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation researches the performance analysis and evaluation of applying reduced-precision computation on the Tendral Statistical Interpolation System (T-SIS) for ocean modeling. It addresses the overarching research question: how to evaluate and test if reduced, numerical precision computation for a domain specific, geophysical scientific data assimilation software can produce comparable results to full-precision. It is a reference for designing and evaluating reduced-precision experiments for a domain specific application to test if the scientific results will still be valid if the software is reengineered to take advantage of the energy-efficient architecture of hardware accelerators. The results of evaluating reduced-precision on T-SIS for ocean modeling Version 1, an optimal interpolation data assimilation (DA) scheme, and Version 2, a unique implementation of a Gaussian Markov Random Fields (GMRF) DA scheme, are presented. The reduced-precision experiments, assimilating a single day of observations, produce similar results for the global domain and the non-uniform, chaotic, ocean currents in the Gulf of Mexico domain compared to the full-precision simulations. The final experiments test the resiliency of running the reduced-precision data assimilation with the HYbrid Coordinate Ocean Model (HYCOM) on a temporal series, multi-year hindcast and using the output to train a Machine Learning (ML) ocean prediction model. The results of the reduced-precision data assimilation and ML experiments show they can produce comparable results to the full-precision for multi-day ocean forecasts with real-world, sparse, noisy observational data. The restart period for the reduced-precision forecast is an important factor for minimizing the divergence of the simulation from the full-precision runs; however the ML training and prediction is not affected by the restart period. The seasonal variation in the observational data also affects the forecast error in both the reduced-precision and ML experiments. In conclusion, the reduced-precision computations in the T-SIS data assimilation for ocean models produces comparable results to the full-precision simulations for both benchmark and operational runs for different model resolutions and assimilating a time-series of variable observational data. Implementing the reduced-precision data assimilation software and using the framework to test and evaluate the science on hardware accelerators will be key to harnessing the performance gains provided by new generation architectures.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Gary Tyson, Professor Directing Dissertation; Linda DeBrunner, University Representative; David Whalley, Committee Member; Xin Yuan, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Influence of Linguistic Input Complexity and Language Learners' Individual Differences in Working Memory and Language Aptitude on Second Language Writing Performance

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Second language (L2) writing has been determined to be influenced by what is read, with language learners tending to borrow words and short phrases from input texts while writing (e.g., Wang & Wang, 2015). This phenomenon is referred to as lexical alignment. Only one empirical study has investigated the influence that the linguistic complexity of reading materials has on L2 written alignment. Peng et al. (2020) found that reading more linguistically complex materials resulted in significantly lower reading comprehension scores, yet it had no significant influence on lexical alignment. Peng et al.'s study also found that participants who had read the simpler version of a text tended to write more words than those who had read the more complex text. While researchers have hypothesized that cognitive individual difference variables may influence L2 written alignment (Wang et al., 2021), no research has empirically investigated the influence that working memory or language aptitude may have on L2 written alignment. This dissertation study builds on existing alignment research by investigating the influence that linguistic complexity of a read text has on L2 written alignment in an integrated writing task, as well as whether and how reading comprehension, working memory, and language aptitude covary and interact with what is read and what is written. Reading comprehension was measured using a 15-question multiple choice test. Working memory was assessed using a 75-item operation span test (Li & Roshan, 2019). Language aptitude was evaluated using individual LLAMA subtest scores (Meara & Rogers, 2019). One hundred thirty-four Colombian undergraduate students majoring in foreign language education were recruited from their English language courses. Participants were assigned to one of three groups using block random assignment to ensure that all groups shared similar English language proficiency. Treatment across groups varied by the lexical sophistication, lexical diversity, and syntactic complexity of the text they were assigned to read as part of an integrated writing task. One treatment group read a text that was modified to be linguistically similar to texts encountered in their English textbooks and participants in another treatment group read a simplified version of the text. The control group read a Spanish translation of the simpler text. Participants in all three groups completed a reading comprehension test and then wrote their responses to a prompt relevant to the reading topic. Participants' writing was evaluated for alignment, syntactic complexity, accuracy, lexical complexity, and fluency (CALF). Each of these components of participants' writing was compared using ANCOVA analyses with interaction effects to determine whether and how covariates influenced participants' L2 writing differently in the three conditions. Results indicated that significant alignment occurred in both treatment groups, with 98-99% of the words produced by participants also appearing in the text they had read. No significant between-group differences in alignment or CALF were uncovered. Reading comprehension was found to be a significant predictor of all three measures of accuracy employed in this study. Working memory significantly interacted with the grouping variable with higher working memory scores corresponding with higher alignment in the simple treatment condition and lower alignment in the complex treatment condition. LLAMA D, the aptitude subtest associated with listening for new words, had a significant and negative main effect on error rates in participants' writing, therefore positively influencing written lexical, morphosyntactic, and overall accuracy. LLAMA E by group interaction approaching significance was also uncovered pertaining to written fluency, indicating that participants with higher scores on the sounds and symbols aptitude test who had read the simple version of the test had significantly greater fluency than their peers who shared a similar aptitude score but read the text in Spanish, the participants' L1. LLAMA F, a measure of grammatical inferencing ailities, was a significant negative predictor of lexical and overall error rates. Findings are discussed with consideration for previous alignment research and theories of language learning.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
alignment, individual differences, L2 writing, language aptitude, task complexity, working memory
Shaofeng Li, Professor Directing Dissertation; Yanyun Yang, University Representative; Phil Hiver, Committee Member; Alysia Roehrig, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Career Readiness, Career Commitment, Dysfunctional Career Thoughts, and Career Locus of Control among College Student Athletes

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study used the Career Thoughts Inventory (CTI; Sampson et al., 1996b), Career Decision Making Readiness Scale, (Osborn et al., 2022), the Career Locus of Control Scale (CLCS) (Trice et al., 1989), and the Commitment to Career Choice scale (Blustein et al., 1989) to examine the relationships among dysfunctional career thoughts, career readiness, career locus of control, and career commitment among a population of college student athletes. The sample included current college student athletes (N=97). The CTI was used to measure dysfunctional career thoughts, specifically, decision-making confusion and commitment anxiety. The CDMR scale was used to measure career readiness including capability and complexity. The CLOCS was used to measure internal and external career locus of control. The CCCS was used to measure career choice commitment, specifically vocational exploration and commitment. Pearson's product correlation found both significant and non-significant relations between each of the variables. Multiple regression analyses found significant relationships among all variables except the complexity scale of CDMR. A discussion of the findings is offered, which includes examination of the results and possible limitations. Implications for theory, research, practice, and policy are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Debra Osborn, Professor Directing Dissertation; Barbara Parker-Bell, University Representative; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member; Laura Reid Marks, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Obeah and Dancehall in Jamaica and Its Diasporas
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Modes of Agency and Identity in Shapeshifting

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In this thesis, I seek to create a framework to understand how in Jamaica, colonial legacies persist in the contemporary period to reproduce a form of Afrophobia which conditions the demonization and villainization of Afro-Jamaican heritage traditions, and to chart how in the neo-colonial period, individuals in their formations of personhood, and efforts toward social mobility contend with such forms of Afrophobia. I map the genealogy of two of the most popular yet denigrated African derived practices in Jamaica, Obeah and Dancehall. Obeah is a set of ritual technologies often conflated with witchcraft which individuals employ to heal, perform divination, and to reach goals, and Dancehall is a Jamaican born music genre and subculture which is a central part of Jamaica's economic sector, providing employment for many of Jamaica's disenfranchised underemployed. Despite the significance and pervasiveness of these practices, religious communities along with Political and social elites disparage both Obeah and Dancehall, identifying them as low class, and attributing them as the demise of Jamaican society. In response to such demonization, individuals who strive to project an impression of respectability, hide that they participate in such practices, opting instead to embrace values coded as Christian, elite, moral, respectable, white, and European. Through so doing, individuals traverse poles between African-derived rituals, Africa, and Blackness, on one hand, and Christianity, Europe, and whiteness on the other. Persons therefore never exist with one static identity, but hold, and alternate between multiple identities to adopt to fluctuating, and unstable conditions in ways that enable them to socially climb, and escape marginalization. I refer to this process as "shapeshifting," the ability to appear as one thing then, at will transform into another. I identify shapeshifting as a form of embodiment, where in which individuals strategically alternate these often-opposing identities to maintain respectability. Christians for example, work Obeah despite claiming it goes against God and publicly condemning it, and many pastors allegedly hold vocations as Obeah specialist. Furthermore, individuals identify Jamaica's African inspired religions with Obeah, while practitioners deny such claims to seem more respectable, even while their practices mirror Obeah since they too are African derived. The spears of Obeah and Dancehall converge given that individuals have attributed the success of popular Dancehall artists to Obeah. Artists historically have not embraced such accusations, however, interestingly, a new generation of artists have begun to feature Obeah in their music, claiming it helps them gain success in extra-legal activities such as scamming. I highlight that this cultural expression provides social commentary on the state of poverty and underemployment in Jamaica which has made crime as the only avenue out of poverty for Jamaica's disenfranchised youth. Furthermore, I argue that artists who publicly endorse Obeah as a technology for social advancement despite its stigma are engaged in a form of decolonization. This paper draws on data gathered through archival research, social media analysis and multi-sited ethnography in south Florida, Queens New York and virtual platforms such as Zoom.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Religion in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
Joseph Hellweg, Professor Directing Thesis; Martin Kavka, Committee Member; Micheal J. McVicar, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Biological Information Extraction by Fine-Tuning Large Language Models

mods:mods.mods:abstract: 1. Text mining Drug-Protein interactions using an ensemble of BERT, sentence BERT and T5 models. In this work, we trained an ensemble model for predicting drug-protein interactions within a sentence based on only its semantics. Our ensembled model was built using three separate models. In all models, we further improved performance using data augmentation. Our best model achieved an F-1 score of 0.753 on the BioCreative VII Track 1 test dataset.2. Name entity recognition and relation extraction for the LITCOIN challenge. The NCATS LitCoin challenge aims to address the time-consuming process of manually reading through biomedical papers to understand relationships between entities. Name Entity Recognition and Relation Extraction are critical tasks in this field, and pre-trained models like BERT, RoBERTa, and PubmedBERT are utilized. We achieved Jaccard score of 0.633 on this challenge. 3. The BioRED track at BioCreative VIII focuses on identifying, categorizing, and evaluating the interaction relationships and novelty of relationships between biomedical entities in text. We utilized BERT and large language models like ChatGPT and Llama 2. Our best model achieved an F-1 score of 44.55%. 4. Extracting chemical-disease relations: this project focuses on the task of automatic extraction of chemical-disease relationships from biomedical literature. In this section, we describe our approach to data pre-processing like entity name masking and data augmentation, and training the BERT model.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Jinfeng Zhang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Xiuwen Liu, University Representative; Adrian Barbu, Committee Member; Wei Wu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Non-Fermi Liquid Behavior in a Model of Fermi ARCS and Pseudogap and Supersymmetry in Quantum Hall Edges

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This thesis investigates three topics in strongly correlated electronic systems using various analytical approaches. In Chapter \ref{ch:non-fermi}, We investigate a modified solvable model with interactions similar to the Hubbard model. These modifications reveal deviations from Fermi liquid behavior in electron self-energy, relevant to the non-Fermi liquid phenomena observed in underdoped high-temperature cuprate superconductors. Introducing a real-space Hubbard interaction results in incoherent quasiparticle excitations, we present a novel mechanism for non-Fermi liquid behavior. In Chpater \ref{ch:susy}, We explore supersymmetry (SUSY) in the edge theory of the Moore-Read state, a candidate for non-Abelian topological order in quantum Hall systems. We demonstrate $\mathcal{N}=(1,0)$ SUSY when bosonic and fermionic edge modes share the same velocity and show that SUSY is spontaneously broken through edge reconstruction, leading to a massless Goldstino mode. Furthermore in Chapter \ref{ch:interface}, we examine the differences between edge and interface states in quantum Hall systems. We highlight how the string-like nature of interfaces alters the low-energy excitation spectra compared to pinned edges. Through theoretical and numerical analyses, we study the interface between Laughlin quantum Hall states.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Kun Yang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Nicholas Bonesteel, Committee Member; Jianming Cao, Committee Member; Jorge Piekarewicz, Committee Member; Wei Guo, University Representative.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: T-Adaptive Discriminant Analysis for High-Dimensional, Heavy-Tailed, Vector and Tensor Data

mods:mods.mods:abstract: In contemporary scientific studies, the data collected for classification becomes increasingly complex as technology advances. In my dissertation, we mainly tackle the two following challenges arising from the data: 1) When the data is in the form of a high-dimensional vector, and the data is heavy-tailed or contains non-ignorable noise or outliers; 2) When the heavy-tailed, noisy data is in the form of high-dimensional tensor. My dissertation introduces novel classification methods that address the two concerns mentioned above, making advances in statistical classification in the presence of complex big data. In Chapter 2, to address the first challenge, we introduce a t-adaptive discriminant analysis model (TADA) for the classification of heavy-tailed high-dimensional vector data. Linear discriminant analysis (LDA) is one of the most important classifiers. However, its normality assumption is inadequate in modeling the ubiquitous heavy-tailed data. To tackle this challenge, we propose a robust generalization of LDA by using the t-distribution. Under this probabilistic framework, we reveal a surprising fact that the Bayes' rule has a nonlinear form for which the popular sparsity assumption is inapplicable. Consequently, it is impossible to accurately estimate the Bayes' rule in high dimensions. To bridge this gap, we instead consider the optimal linear classifier, which turns out to resemble the LDA rule on the population level. This result partially explains the well-known fact that LDA remains a competitive classifier on a wide range of datasets where the normality assumptions are unlikely to hold. Then we propose a robust estimate for this classifier that is convenient to implement, with almost no additional computation cost to achieve resistance against outliers. Theory confirms that our classifier has an optimal convergence rate with only finite second-moment conditions. Numerical results also exhibit the favorable performance of our classifier. In Chapter 3, we continue to tackle the second challenge and introduce a new discriminant analysis method for heavy-tailed tensor data using tensor t-distribution (TTDA). Analysis of tensor data, a.k.a., multi-dimensional arrays has gained great popularity because this more complex form of data has emerged from various contemporary scientific fields. In real-world tensor data, we often encounter large noise or outliers caused by the nature of certain scientific fields, sensor failures, or other system errors, rendering heavy-tailed data. The existing tensor classification methods that are capable of handling such large noise or outliers typically rely on low-rank techniques. An alternative to low-rank techniques is to consider the tensor distribution. However, there are fewer studies about tensor distribution beyond normality. To address the above concerns, we develop a new tensor discriminant analysis model, referred to as TTDA, to capture the heavy-tailed noise. TTDA can be viewed as a tensor generalization of the probabilistic framework introduced in Chapter 2. We pose a simple definition of tensor t-distribution on the data and develop the classifier, estimation, and prediction process based on this probabilistic framework. Specifically, a linear form optimal classifier is established that can enable sparsity and variable selection through the discriminant coefficient tensor. We also provide a tuning-free estimation process that yields robust estimations of the tensor t-distribution parameters, followed by the reduce-and-classify prediction procedure. We examine the classification performance of this method with simulations under various scenarios and a real-world dataset.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Discriminant analysis, Heavy-tailed data, High-dimensional classification, Linearity, Sparsity, Tensor data analysis
Qing Mai, Professor Directing Dissertation; Xiuwen Liu, University Representative; Elizabeth Slate, Committee Member; Joshua Loyal, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Commognitive Analysis of Two Discursive Learning Environments
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Exploring Students' Discourse Regarding the Derivative Concept

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Despite the standardization of calculus education as a Calculus and Analytic Geometry course after the 1950s, curriculum updates have been slow to penetrate the undergraduate mathematics classroom practice, taking decades to manifest. Common struggles with the teaching and learning of calculus, such as relying on a procedural understanding of calculus topics, echoed those documented in the literature and highlight a common challenge for many students. The derivative, one of the central ideas of the calculus curriculum, remains difficult for some students to conceptualize due in part to its multifaceted nature and the manner in which mathematics is taught at the undergraduate level (e.g., a lecture model, which stands in contrast to more active learning models that are more familiar to students in secondary school settings). The Calculus Reform Movement of the early 1990s initiated various curriculum changes and promoted experimentation with active learning strategies, particularly those that place mathematical discourse at the forefront of the activities, to address these challenges. With the implementation of these discursive learning environments in mathematics classrooms across the country, this prompted my investigation into the derivative-based mathematics that students were learning and the ways in which they were learning such concepts in two specific discursive learning environments at a large research-intensive university in the southeastern United States. Resulting from a commognitive analysis, I present the cases of two highly different activities, fostering both explorative and performative routines among students which led them to draw upon varying aspects of mathematics to reason about the derivative concept. Implications highlight aspects of students' discourse of the derivative concept, such as leveraging only the productive and correct components of a metaphor to reason across contexts. Additionally, this research illuminates the role of documentative routines in discursive learning activities and suggests that instructors should be attentive to the affordances and constraints of such routines. Thus, curriculum designers should adhere to specific goals for discursive learning activities and incorporate routines that promote awareness of processes across the multifaceted classroom discourse and facilitate meaningful documentative routines which serve not only as an assessment but also as a tool to carefully attend to students' sense-making.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Mathematics Education in the School of Teacher Education in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Christine J. Andrews-Larson, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Emily C. Plummer Catena, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Monica K. Hurdal, University Representative; Lama Z. Jaber, Committee Member; Courtney R. Simmons, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Process-Knowledge-Informed Combinatorial Search to Accelerate Process Discovery with Limited Experiments

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Shortening lead time is beneficial as it enhances both profits and productivity in the industry. Lead time can essentially be broken down into (1) production time, the duration required to complete the production of an order, and (2) calibration time, the duration spent in determining the parameter setting for the machine to produce the part with good quality. Calibration time affects how fast the parameters can be found that can achieve the ideal production time. To reduce production time, this thesis focuses on identifying parameter combinations over different locations on the produced parts. Traditionally, such a location-dependent combinatorial search involves a huge search space. For instance, planning 3D printing speed over different printed paths can lead to more than hundreds of thousands of possible speed-path combinations, especially when printing a large part. For combinatorial search at such a massive scale, traditional methods, such as statistical design of experiments or metaheuristics-based search leading to extensive testing, are still not sufficient to cover representative combinations. This dissertation (Chapter 2) proposes a process-knowledge-driven combinatorial search strategy to effectively reduce the search space. Specifically, process knowledge identified from empirical relationships or physical knowledge can be utilized to localize the search for parameter combinations over a limited number of potential regions, thereby reducing the search space in the location-dependent search. This approach is demonstrated in extrusion-based 3D printing by compensating for the infill error while ensuring good quality during high-speed printing. To reduce the calibration time, this dissertation discussed two strategies: (1) a cloud-based learning framework that reduces the user's experiments by leveraging the data from other processes (Chapter 3) and (2) sequential combinatorial experimentation to optimize parameter settings progressively when historical data from other sources are unavailable (Chapter 4). Chapter 3 developed a pre-training and fine-tuning framework to reduce experimental efforts on the end user by transferring pre-trained knowledge from cloud service providers. State-of-the-art transfer learning based on domain adaptation anticipates products and processes bear significant similarity. For instance, cloud printers and end-user's printer should produce a similar shape, which may not be always practical. The proposed method transfers knowledge based on the common empirical process-performance relationships observed from data, thereby enabling the knowledge transfer among more distinctive processes, such as different printing geometries in 3D printing applications. This strategy allows users to leverage contributions from the pre-trained model to reduce data collection efforts for fine-tuning models. The cloud-learning process is demonstrated through pretraining models for the error compensation based on printing different geometries on cloud printers and fine-tuning the end-user's model with limited experiments. In addition, the study also addresses the challenge of printer selection when pre-training the model. Chapter 4 improved Bayesian optimization (BO) to comprehensively cover combinatorial inputs over time within limited experimental runs. However, BO and its recent updates did not address a decision-making problem of allocating limited experimental runs that can cover (1) inputs representing the larger search space for identifying the best combination and (2) replicates for estimating input-dependent variation for each input combination, while capturing the degradation effects. This dissertation utilizes process knowledge to remove the degradation effect from the data and then proposes an empirical hierarchical Bayesian model to capture a common structure in the replicates across all input combinations. The learning of such a common structure can help reduce the necessary experimental runs to estimate input-dependent variability. This method is validated through the simulation of a chemical extraction process based on real experimental data from previous studies. Overall, this dissertation establishes a methodology of utilizing empirical process knowledge to cope with a large combinatorial search in engineering experimentation given limited experimental runs. The results demonstrated its significant potential in searching for ideal combinations among large candidates, with broad applications in new material discovery or manufacturing process development.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Hui Wang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Steven Lenhert, University Representative; Tarik Dickens, Committee Member; Lichun Li, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Compassion for Couples
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: An Initial Evaluation of an Online Self-Compassion Training for Couples

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Human Development and Family Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Stress is often a shared experience between both partners in a couple due to how it can adversely impact couples functioning and relationships (Neff & Karney, 2017). This study grew out of a desire to present options to couples following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has been linked to declines in relationship quality (Haydon & Salvatore, 2022). This study focused on testing the efficacy and feasibility of the online Compassion for Couples (CFC) training program. The CFC training is a novel training adapted from the empirically tested Mindful Self-Compassion program (Neff & Germer, 2013). CFC was developed to train couples in compassion for self and others, focusing on the individual, the partner, and the relationship. The present study utilized a longitudinal, quantitative design, collecting pre- and post-test dyadic data from treatment and control group couples. Preliminary findings indicated that treatment group couples experienced greater improvement in self-compassion between the pre-test and post-test as compared to the control group. Further, relationship satisfaction scores also differed significantly between the treatment and control groups, revealing that the control group was more satisfied on average than the treatment group. Overall, male and female participants reported satisfaction with the training and that they found it helpful. Methodological suggestions for improving attrition rates have been explored. A full-scale study is feasible, especially with adaptations to current recruitment procedures and funding.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Human Development and Family Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Compassion, Compassion Intervention, Couples, Dyadic, Relationship Satisfaction, Self-Compassion
Thomas Ledermann, Professor Directing Dissertation; Deborah Ebener, University Representative; Gregory Harris, Committee Member; Jonathan Kimmes, Committee Member; Lenore McWey, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Dynamic Visuospatial Support for Mandarin Tone Learning in a Language-Driven Game

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Dynamic visuospatial support (DVS) is an effective tool for helping people learn linguistic tones (Hannah et al., 2017, Zhen et al., 2019, Morett et al., 2022), and learn words with these tonal categories (Baills et al., 2019, Morett et al., 2015). Progress in the field of embodied cognition and learning has led to recent emphasis on the pitch gesture (PG), a hand gesture representing the pitch movement of a tone spatially. However, some non-embodied DVS, like a red dot tracing the same pitch movement, has shown comparable tone learning benefits to PGs (Morett et al., 2022), leaving the role of gesture embodiment unclear. Moreover, how much of a human agent is visible in DVS varies among recent studies (head+hand, torso+hands, head+torso+hands)—through a learning and media theory lens, this agent embodiment could have a significant learning impact. In this dissertation, I explore the role of embodiment further through a 2x2, pretest-posttest learning intervention study. During 90–120 minutes of typing-based gameplay, 68 adult naive learners of Mandarin Chinese viewed a total of 60 DVS videos, which conveyed the pronunciation of 15 2-syllable vocabulary items, and represented linguistic tone in 1 of 4 ways: (1) a human agent with a hand gesturing, (2) invisible agent with a visible hand gesturing, (3) a still human agent with a red dot gesturing, and (4) no agent with a red dot gesturing. Assessments measured pre- and posttest tone recognition for 1- and 2-syllable nonce words, and posttest word recall of the vocabulary items. First, an interaction effect of gesture embodiment and agent embodiment for word recall revealed that learners benefited significantly more when DVS was either fully embodied or fully non-embodied, than when partially embodied. Findings suggest that the word learning benefit of high embodiment in a DVS agent outweighs other cognitive hindrance introduced by the agent, in line with principles for pedagogical agents from media theory (Mayer, 2017). Conversely, findings reinforce the notion that the visuospatial metaphor is a powerful word learning scaffold, comparably effective to embodied DVS, and more effective than DVS with compromised embodiment. Second, non-significant differences in tone recognition learning gains between conditions suggest that the scaffolding of tone category learning is not sensitive to embodiment effects in the same way as word learning. Post-hoc tests showed significant positive correlation between gameplay progress and word recall, suggesting that using the vocabulary items for problem solving means was particularly helpful for participants. In light of the findings, I suggest educators and designers use highly embodied or fully non-embodied DVS when supporting tonal word learning, especially in hands-on L2 problem solving activities, like digital games.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Embodied Cognition, Game-Based Learning, Language Learning, Learning Sciences
Fengfeng Ke, Professor Directing Dissertation; Carolina González, University Representative; Allan C. Jeong, Committee Member; Kenneth Bret Staudt Willet, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Differences in Die-Offs
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Investigating Variation in Infection Patterns and Virulence across the Landscape in an Oyster-Parasite System

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Mass mortality events from aquatic disease can devastate animal populations, alter ecosystems, and threaten economies, yet identifying the extent and drivers of these events is challenging. Observed mortality of eastern oysters (Crassostrea virginica) due to Dermo disease (caused by the protozoan parasite Perkinsus marinus) exemplifies these challenges: levels of disease vary across space and time, and the percent of the population dying from infection is often difficult to estimate. Here, I review and outline future goals regarding the study of the interaction between eastern oysters and P. marinus. I use ecological theory to generate hypotheses about how variation in infection rates or virulence are altered by processes at the individual, community, and landscape scale, which in turn drive differences in oyster mortality. I test some of these hypotheses using disease monitoring data from Apalachicola and Chesapeake Bay oyster populations, which are thought to experience low versus high levels of disease-induced mortality, respectively. First, I find that Chesapeake oysters likely become infected at smaller sizes than in Apalachicola, suggesting infection pressure may be higher. Second, I find that residing in an intertidal environment, and previous parasite establishment, may increase Dermo infection probabilities but the mechanisms remain unclear. Third, I find that co-infection, increases in temperature, and decreases in dissolved oxygen are associated with increased infection intensities. Finally, my work provides a guiding framework for understanding disease-induced mortality in systems of management concern.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Host-Parasite, Marine Disease, Oyster, Perkinsus marinus

Tara E. Stewart Merrill, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Michael H. Cortez, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Daniel K. Okamoto, Committee Member; Thomas E. Miller, Committee Member; Kimberly A. Hughes, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Characteristics of Mini Supercells in the Midwest

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Mini supercell thunderstorms are similar in structure to traditional supercells, but they are smaller both vertically and horizontally. Despite their diminished spatial dimensions, mini supercells can produce severe hazards although the hazards typically are less intense than those of their larger counterparts. These storms commonly occur in tropical cyclones (TCs), but they also occur over land, particularly over the Midwest United States. Research on land-based mini supercells is limited relative to TC-related counterparts, with previous work consisting mostly of individual case studies. This research examines the environmental and radar-derived characteristics of 21 land-based mini supercells located in the Midwest region of the United States. Results are compared to previous studies of both traditional and land-based mini supercells. Environments of the 21 cases are assessed using data from the High-Resolution Rapid Refresh model (HRRR). The mean environment of the dataset exhibits high shear (0-6 km shear > 20 m s^(-1)) and low buoyancy (surface-based CAPE < 1000 J 〖kg〗^(-1)). This finding is mostly consistent with results of previous studies of land-based mini supercells, but there is some disagreement involving some parameters such as 0-3 km SRH. Outlier cases in this study indicate that mini supercell environments may be more variable than previously thought. Radar-derived characteristics of the mini supercells are assessed using WSR-88D data. Results generally are consistent with previous research on land-based mini supercells. However, values of rotational velocity (Vrot) are smaller than those reported for traditional supercells. Conversely, values of azimuthal shear are comparable to those of traditional supercells. Subsequently, shear-related warning thresholds are found to be more useful than thresholds utilizing Vrot for land-based mini supercells. The spatial dimensions of our mini supercells are found to be comparable to previous mini supercells. However, some outlying echo tops are very low. Results from this study hopefully will improve forecasters' ability to identify favorable environments for these storms and to warn appropriately when they occur.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Henry E. Fuelberg, Professor Directing Thesis; Robert Hart, Committee Member; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Covid-19 and Elections as Triggers of Racially Motivated and Extremist Crime
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Temporal Analyses of Hate Crime in Slovakia

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Criminology and Criminal Justice
College of Criminology and Criminal Justice

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Historically, hate crime research has been relatively nonexistent in Central and Eastern Europe. Yet, this region and others in the West, increasingly witness violent incitements and targeted attacks against minority communities, largely owing to significant democratic backsliding and rising immigration levels. The Slovak Republic, therefore, provides an interesting setting for bias crime evaluation. This thesis evaluates the impacts of two important events – pandemics and elections – in generating racially motivated and extremist crimes in Slovakia. The nation's interrelation between migration, race, socioeconomic status, and social identity offers several important and potential drivers of bias-motivated violence. Applying data from the Ministry of Interior of the Slovak Republic and the Statistical Office of the Slovak Republic, the present research suggests four main outcomes related to hate crimes across Slovak regions. First, the COVID-19 pandemic did not show any hate crime effects unless conditioned by employment and immigration status. This signifies that the pandemic, once conditioned, did influence hate crime rates in Slovak regions with high levels of immigration and low male employment rates. Second, the interactive effects of the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and immigration and employment rates were delayed. Third, data indicates that extreme right parties matter, wherein the more they are perceived as legitimate, such as receiving higher electoral vote-shares, the higher the bias crime rate. Hence, there is a vital emphasis on extreme right support, legitimization, and mobilization in effecting Slovak political outcomes and hate crime incidence. Lastly, high immigration rates strengthen the effect of vote-shares on bias crime. While this thesis was unable to definitively provide causalities of COVID-19 and extreme right electoral support on hate crime in Slovakia, the analyses indicate several important markers of a potentially hostile social environment that is conducive to hate crime occurrence.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the College of Criminology and Criminal Justice in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Criminal Justice Studies.
COVID-19, Elections, Hate Crime, Pandemics, Right-wing, Slovakia
Sylwia J. Piatkowska, Professor Directing Thesis; Marin R. Wenger, Committee Member; Brendan Lantz, Committee Member.
