mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Dynamics of Open Research Data Repository for Health Sciences in Universities
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Three-Paper Dissertation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This study explores multiple aspects of practices of opening and sharing health research data in university environments, including current trends, platforms, policies, and perceptions. This study consists of three papers: Paper 1: Exploring Policy Design Recommendations for Health Research Data Repositories that Promote Openness and Sharing: A Systematic Literature Review Paper 2: Adoption Patterns and Characteristics of Health Research Data Repositories in U.S. Universities Paper 3: Investigating the Practices and Preferences of Health Scholars in Opening and Sharing Research Data The first paper explores current trends and discussions on health research data repository policies that support openness and sharing through a systematic literature review. This study follows the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) approach in systematically gathering, selecting, and analyzing previous studies related to open research data repository practices and policies in the health sciences. This study selected 74 relevant articles to understand the current literature about open health data repositories. The first study's findings indicate that most articles analyzed policy documents and conducted in-depth case studies of repositories. These studies primarily focused on the United States, which emerged as the most-studied country in this field. This study suggests ten crucial recommendations that should be addressed in designing and developing health research data repository policy: standardization; data access, security, and protection; ownership and intellectual property rights; privacy and confidentiality; data acquisition and curation; data quality; training and user support; incentives and sanctions; transparency; and trust and trustworthiness. These recommendations can be used as policy design and evaluation metrics when developing health research data repositories. The second paper investigates the diffusion of health research data repositories implemented within U.S. (United States) university environments. This study uses Rogers' diffusion of innovation theory, focused on the timings of the implementation and events that influence the initiation of health research data repositories in U.S. universities. The unit analysis of this study is universities' internal units, including laboratories, libraries, and research teams, since a university can have more than one repository, and multiple universities and laboratories can manage a repository. This paper collects data on the initiation timing of health repositories through data entries indexed by re3data.org and by exploring the websites of the repositories. The second paper illustrates the adoption pattern of health research data repositories presented in an S-curve from 1987 until 2022. Several national events and policies potentially influenced some universities to implement health research data repositories, including NIH (National Institute of Health) data-sharing policies and policies that rule out the increase in public access to funded research. The study also shows the termination of health data repositories and its reasons that should be taken into account by relevant stakeholders if the main goal is to preserve research data as long as they can in a sustainable health research data repository. The third paper investigates health science researchers' perceptions of opening and sharing research data and the motivating and demotivating factors for engagement in open health data repositories. A total of 362 health science scholars in U.S. universities participated in an online questionnaire. Descriptive and inferential statistical analyses were conducted, including frequencies, cross-tabulations, descriptive ratio statistics, and the non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis Analysis of Variance. The study reveals that health scholars share data primarily with colleagues in their institution or project. They exhibit a lower tendency to engage in open research data practices through repositories and journal supplements. Motivating factors and challenges influencing researchers' decisions to open and share data were identified. Privacy and confidentiality concerns were major barriers, especially for scholars working with human-related data. Disciplinary variations and differences between funded and non-funded researchers were observed. Resources, policy compliance, and requirements were significant factors driving scholars to open and share data. The study provides insights for policy development to promote openness and sharing of health research data. This study results in a comprehensive understanding of open health big data within university environments. In addition, this study can help universities to decide the direction of big health data and open health research data policies.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Information in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
health data sharing, health research data, open health data, research data management
Lorri Mon, Professor Directing Dissertation; Frances Stokes Berry, University Representative; Besiki Stvilia, Committee Member; Charles C. Hinnant, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Influence of Influencers on Appearance Comparison and Eating Disorder Risk in College Women

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Social media has been linked to increased eating disorder (ED) risk by exposing users to thin-idealized content posted by celebrities and peers and triggering appearance comparison. Social media influencers post idealized content on social media to advertise for external companies under the guise of being relatable, therefore representing a new source of influence for social media users. Influencers combine the relatability of peers with the thin appearance of celebrities, thus embodying potentially harmful qualities of both groups. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the potential deleterious effects of viewing influencer content on appearance comparison and eating pathology in high-risk groups such as college women. The current study utilized an experimental design where college women (n = 354) were randomly assigned to view images depicting 1) peers (n=89); 2) influencers (n=88); 3) celebrities (n=90); or 4) travel (control condition; n=87). Participants completed pre and post self-report measures of ED risk factors, measures of state and trait appearance comparison, and a behavioral measure assessing dietary restraint. For the behavioral measure, participants ordered a hypothetical dinner from Panera restaurant, and caloric and macronutrient contents of participants' intended food consumption were calculated as a continuous measure of dietary restraint. We examined between-group differences in momentary changes in ED risk factors and caloric and macronutrient contents of participants' intended Panera consumption. State appearance comparison was examined as a potential mediator for the effect of condition on ED risk, and trait appearance comparison was examined as a potential moderator for the effect of condition on momentary ED risk ratings. Participants' momentary anxiety decreased whereas their ED cognitions and urge to exercise increased following all conditions. Viewing images of celebrities caused greater increases in participants' momentary ED risk factors compared to viewing control images. No significant differences emerged for viewing influencers' or peers' images. State appearance comparison partially mediated the effect of celebrity vs. control condition on specific ED risk factors. Viewing FSU peer images had a greater effect on post-intervention specific ED risk factors for those high in trait appearance comparison. Participants' Panera order did not differ across experimental groups. These results reveal the complexity of how social comparison impacts the effect of social media images on ED risk factors and suggest that influencer images may be no more detrimental than other types of images one might encounter on social media.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor in Philosophy.
body image, eating disorders, influencers, Instagram, mental health, social media
Pamela K. Keel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Dawn Carr, University Representative; Norman B. Schmidt, Committee Member; Jesse Cougle, Committee Member; Jon Maner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Microtubule Nucleation, Post-Translational Modifications, and Minus-End Maintenance in Drosophila Melanogaster

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Using Drosophila melanogaster as a model, this dissertation explores microtubule dynamics in vivo to understand the mechanisms of microtubule nucleation, post-translational modifications, and minus-end proteins at various microtubule organizing centers (MTOCs). The -Tubulin Ring Complex (-TuRC) is the major microtubule nucleator of eukaryotic cells. Its function is best understood in its essential roles in cell division. The core components of the -TuRC, called Gamma-tubulin Complex Proteins (GCPs, or Gamma-Ring Proteins/Grips in Drosophila), are highly conserved across Eukaryotes. Strikingly, the composition and organization of GCPs in the -TuRC from recent CryoEM structures from various organisms are similar, suggesting the -TuRC is a preferred nucleation method throughout evolution. This dissertation dissects a unique -TuRC in Drosophila comprised of variant GCP paralogs, referred to as t-Grips, and its specialized role in spermiogenesis. We show that t-Grips acquired a unique and distinct function, as replacement of t-Grips with Grips or vice versa is insufficient to rescue mutant phenotypes. Additionally, t-Grips form a complex separate from the canonical -TuRC in the testes. t-Grips are absent from centrosomes but localize to mature sperm tails, where they play a critical role in developing structural resiliency in the specialized mitochondria during spermiogenesis. In the absence of t--TuRCs, mitochondria become fragile and fragment under stress causing sperm tails to break. Tubulin post-translational modifications (PTMs) convey the functional specificity of microtubules by modulating how microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs) interact with microtubules. The complex effects of PTMs on tubulin and microtubule functions have collectively been referred to as the "tubulin code". Our understanding of how TTLL enzymes modify tubulin largely relies on in vitro data. To understand tubulin PTMs in vivo, we have developed a screen to assess which modifying enzymes are vital to various cellular functions in Drosophila. The screen revealed 5 essential TTLL enzymes: TTLL1B, TTLL3B, TTLL4B, TTLL6B, and TTLL12. I further show that TTLL6B is the major glutamylase in the testes and that TTLL4B has a potential novel target. Microtubule minus-end proteins regulate the organization of microtubules in cells. Here we develop a screen by targeting them to the surface of the mitochondria of cultured cells to determine their requirements in organizing MTOCs.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Timothy L. Megraw, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hong-Guo Yu, University Representative; Yanchang Wang, Committee Member; Robert Tomko, Jr., Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Constellation of Stories
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Liminality and Transition in the Experiences of Graduate Student Instructors

mods:mods.mods:abstract: My dissertation is a project that gives voice to marginalized graduate instructors in the fields of Rhetoric, Composition, Writing Studies, and Linguistics by exploring their diverse literacy practices and experiences. Using semi-structured interviews informed by decolonial and anti-racist methodologies, I collected critical incidents from 26 graduate students who self-identify as embodying subject positions typically overlooked or marginalized within their fields. Their critical incident narratives highlight the memorable moments and encounters that have influenced their development as learners, researchers, and professionals. The stories collected through my research offer insight into how our current disciplinary and programmatic practices influence their experiences inside and outside the institution. In this way, my project contributes to ongoing conversations surrounding anti-racist, decolonial research methodologies and equitable labor practices, exploring ways to increase access, inclusion, and diversity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Critical Incident Technique, Graduate Student Instructors, Phenomenology
Michael Neal, Professor Directing Dissertation; Davis Houck, University Representative; Rhea Lathan, Committee Member; Elias Dominguez-Barajas, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Relationship between Social Norms, Social Media, and College Alcohol Outcomes

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This paper aimed to examine the influences of alcohol use among college students. The primary goal of this paper was to explore the roles of perceived descriptive norms and perceived injunctive norms of alcohol use and social media use on personal alcohol use behaviors and the related consequences in college students. The present study found that social media use positively influences each perceived social norm. Further, both perceived social norms mediate the relationship between social media and alcohol use. However, only perceived descriptive norms mediate the relationship between social media use and alcohol-related consequences. Implications and limitations are discussed.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
alcohol-related consequences, college, descriptive norms, injunctive norms, social media, social norms
Deborah Ebener, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lenore McWey, University Representative; Debra Osborn, Committee Member; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Faster yet Safer
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Logging System via Fixed-Key Blockcipher

mods:mods.mods:abstract: System logs are crucial for forensic analysis, but to be useful, they need to be tamper-proof. To protect the logs, a number of secure logging systems have been proposed from both academia and the industry. Unfortunately, except for the recent KennyLoggings construction, all other logging systems are broken by an attack of Paccagnella et al. (CCS 2020). In this work, I build a secure logging system that improves KennyLoggings in several fronts: adoptability, security, and performance. The key insight for performance gain is to use AES on a fixed, known key. While this trick is widely used in secure distributed computing, this is the first time it has found an application in the area of symmetric-key cryptography.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Computer Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Authentication, Blockcipher, Cryptography, Linux kernel, MAC, System security
Viet Tung Hoang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Shuyuan Ho Metcalfe, University Representative; Xin Yuan, Committee Member; Mike Burmester, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Pride and Prejudice
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: The Dual Effect of Wolf-Warrior Diplomacy on Domestic and International Audiences

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: China has shifted its foreign policy from careful diplomacy to "wolf warrior diplomacy" (WWD). This dissertation asks: What are the domestic and international consequences of China's "wolf warrior diplomacy" (WWD)? I argue that WWD constitutes a form of ingroup/outgroup discourse, encompassing pride rhetoric, humiliation rhetoric, and defamatory rhetoric. WWD increases the Chinese public's support for their government. However, foreign audiences are likely to view WWD as aggressive and threatening; as a result, WWD has dual effects, increased security for the regime at the domestic level and heightened tensions at the international level. I first employ machine learning models to analyze the usage of Chinese diplomatic discourses over the past two decades. The results of these models indicate a significant increase in the usage of wolf-warrior rhetoric, particularly since 2012 when President Xi Jinping assumed power. To examine the dual effects of WWD, I conducted preregistered parallel experiments, in which I presented identical sets of survey vignettes to Chinese and American citizens. The results show that WWD significantly increases the Chinese public's support for their government. However, this diplomatic rhetoric also antagonizes the U.S. public and bolsters their support for aggressive foreign policies toward China. These findings contribute to our understanding of the dual effects of authoritarian diplomacy in the global arena where national leaders face a trade-off between domestic stability and international instability.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Political Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Diplomacy, Public Opinion, Survey Experiment, Text Analysis, US-China Relations, Wolf-Warrior Diplomacy
Mark Souva, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jonathan Grant, University Representative; Kai Quek, Committee Member; Kelly Matush, Committee Member; Dotan Haim, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Unveiling the Dynamics of Community Resilience

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation investigates the interplay between community-based and non-government organizations, governmental strategies, and media in fostering community resilience across the United States, South Korea, and the Philippines. It explores how these entities collaborate to enhance community responses to various challenges, mainly focusing on their roles during crises and how they influence public outcomes. The first study examines the role of community-based organizations in South Korea in utilizing media to strengthen community networks and enhance social cohesion. By employing qualitative methods such as case studies and interviews, the research explores how these organizations leverage media to amplify marginalized voices and mobilize community support, thereby fostering greater community resilience. The findings reveal that effective use of media by community organizations not only increases their outreach and impact but also plays a crucial role in advocating for social change. The study emphasizes the necessity for policymakers and community leaders to support media-centric initiatives that facilitate community engagement and advocacy, enhancing the overall fabric of social cohesion. The second study focuses on the dynamics of social vulnerability management in the Philippines, particularly examining the collaborative governance models between government and community-based organizations during disaster management. This study uses grounded theory, taking an abductive approach to analyze several types of archival data. The findings highlight how active engagement and collaboration lead to more inclusive and equitable disaster management practices. It demonstrates that integrating collaborative governance into disaster management policies can significantly improve the handling of social vulnerabilities, urging the development of policies prioritizing social equity and community involvement in the decision-making process. The final study investigates how media in the United States frames the COVID-19 vaccine, with a specific focus on minority issues. Utilizing Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, the study conducts a content analysis of news articles to quantify framing and sentiment trends. This study showed the disparity between the sentiment scores and the statistical test results. It implies that policymakers should understand both the apparent and underlying impacts of media coverage on public opinion and use comprehensive analytical methods to discern real impacts from perceived trends. It suggests that public health officials and policymakers work closely with media outlets to ensure that health communication is balanced, comprehensive, and accurately represents all community segments' concerns, thereby effectively supporting public health objectives. This dissertation contributes significantly to the field of public administration by highlighting the importance of community engagement and the strategic use of media in promoting resilient and equitable community responses. Theoretical, methodological, and practical implications drawn from the studies provide valuable insights for enhancing community engagement and improving disaster response and public health strategies. Future research could expand upon these findings to further explore the effectiveness of these strategies in different contexts and over more extended periods, potentially offering more generalized solutions to global challenges in public administration and community management.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
David G. Berlan, Professor Directing Dissertation; Tisha J. Holmes, University Representative; James E. Wright II, Committee Member; Hongtao Yi, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Stick-Breaking Bart Models for Ordinal Regression and Conditional Density Estimation

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Following the pioneering research conducted by Chipman et al. (2010), the utilization of Bayesian Additive Regression Trees (BART) model has proliferated significantly across a multitude of domains. BART's inherent versatility and robustness contribute to its wide application in diverse scientific contexts. The continuous improvements to its methodology enhance BART's functionality, robustness, and adaptability to complex analytical challenges, further bolstering its acceptance and efficacy. Addressing the limitations of traditional parametric models for ordinal data scenarios, we propose a Bayesian nonparametric tree ensemble model, the Continuation-Ratio BART. This model flexibly estimates ordinal categories' probability distribution, demonstrated by favorable results in simulation and empirical studies. We also extend our research to tackle hurdles associated with predictor-dependent density estimation by constructing a Probit Stick-Breaking Process (PSBP) with BART model. Our work provides resilient and adaptable approaches for ordinal data analysis and conditional density estimation, offering robust alternatives to canonical parametric models and inviting further innovation in those data science areas. We anticipate these advancements will broaden our methods' applicability, sparking novel insights across diverse fields.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Antonio Linero, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Fred Huffer, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Qian Zhang, University Representative; Debajyoti Sinha, Committee Member; Andrés Felipe Barrientos, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Mediation Analysis in Neuroimaging and Geospatial Studies

mods:mods.mods:abstract: As a crucial tool in neuroscience, mediation analysis has been developed and widely adopted to elucidate the role of intermediary variables derived from neuroimaging data. Typically, structural equation models (SEMs) are employed to investigate the influences of exposures on outcomes, with model coefficients being interpreted as causal effects. While existing SEMs have proven to be effective tools for mediation analysis involving various neuroimaging-related mediators, limited research has explored scenarios where these mediators are derived from the shape space. In addition, the linear relationship assumption adopted in existing SEMs may lead to substantial efficiency losses and decreased predictive accuracy in real-world applications. To address these challenges, we introduce a novel framework for shape mediation analysis, designed to explore the causal relationships between genetic exposures and clinical outcomes, whether mediated or unmediated by shape-related factors while accounting for potential confounding variables. Within our framework, we apply the square-root velocity function to extract elastic shape representations, which reside within the linear Hilbert space of square-integrable functions. Subsequently, we introduce a two-layer shape regression model (2SRM) to characterize the relationships among neurocognitive outcomes, elastic shape mediators, genetic exposures, and clinical confounders. Both estimation and inference procedures are established for unknown parameters along with the corresponding causal estimands. The asymptotic properties of estimated quantities are investigated as well. Both simulated studies and real-data analyses demonstrate the superior performance of our proposed method in terms of estimation accuracy and robustness when compared to existing approaches for estimating causal estimands. We also extend the linear relationship between exposure and mediators in 2SRM to a nonlinear version and consider the dependency of the relation between exposure and a mediator on both time and covariates. Although the causal effects can be affected by the interaction effects between exposure and confounders, it is difficult to capture in a mediator model. Some function-on-scalar models with functional responses and scalar covariates have studied the dynamic relationship between the functional responses and covariates or the relationship between the functional responses depending on the time and some covariates, but the interaction effects between exposure and confounders could not be found. To explore the dynamic effects of the single index including the dynamic confounders and how it affects the direct and indirect effects, we propose a dynamic functional mediation model. It allows us to quantify the indirect effects at an individual level, so that enables the comparison of the indirect effects between subjects. The simulation studies evaluate the performance and validity of the proposed model with the estimation and inference procedures for causal estimands using the wild bootstrap method. Both the direct effect and dynamic indirect effects from real-data analysis make it possible to consider the individual properties compared with the models ignoring the dynamic interaction. We apply our approach to country-level datasets with an adjustment of the dependency between countries by estimating the spatial dependence. Thus, the pathways of individual indirect effects from exposure to outcome through the geospatial mediator can be investigated without linear assumption and dependency issues.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Chao Huang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Richard Nowakowski, University Representative; Eric Chicken, Committee Member; Debajyoti Sinha, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Investigating Nutrient Uptake and Plankton Community Composition
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: A Comparative Study between Regions of the Gulf of Mexico, Eastern Indian Ocean and Southern Ocean

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Nutrient uptake dynamics, which are strongly influenced by plankton community composition, are an important aspect of pelagic food webs and biogeochemical cycles. For instance, in oligotrophic oceanic regions picoplankton dominate and have the ability to uptake nutrients even at low ambient concentrations, while in frontal mixing zones, complex nutrient co-limitation patterns and their interplay with light can alter plankton community structure over relatively small spatial scales. We begin this dissertation by investigating the oligotrophic Gulf of Mexico in Chapter 2, where we quantify primary productivity, nitrate and ammonium uptake rates throughout the water column. This chapter aims to determine the nitrogen sources that support this region, incorporating depth-resolved and diel sampling techniques. Our findings indicate that phytoplankton in the Gulf of Mexico rely heavily on regenerated production of ammonium to support primary production, characterized by low f-ratios and minimal diel variability in nitrate uptake, along with consistent high ammonium uptake throughout day and night. We applied a data assimilation method (Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo) to constrain nutrient and light utilization dynamics by taxon-specific phytoplankton using our field measurements. The resulting parameters defined unique niches for Prochlorococcus, Synechococcus, diatoms, dinoflagellates, and prymnesiophytes. In Chapter 3, our study transitions to the oligotrophic Argo Basin in the eastern Indian Ocean, where we combine approaches used in Chapters 2 and investigate in-situ and shipboard incubations of primary production, nitrate and ammonium uptake coupled with carbon-based biomass estimates of pico-, nano- and microplankton in order to determine the depth-resolved nitrogen sources and dominant plankton groups that support this region. Our findings aligned with what was found in Chapter 2 in the Gulf of Mexico, where picoplankton, particularly Prochlorococcus and heterotrophic bacteria, were the biomass dominants. Primary production and phytoplankton specific growth rates declined with increasing depth (~4-fold to the deep chlorophyll max (DCM)), with no vertical pattern in biomass or particulate organic carbon (POC) with depth, suggesting light limitation likely plays a role at the DCM. Nutrient limitation is evident in this region with average peaks of nitrate uptake occurring at the DCM and ammonium uptake in the upper euphotic zone. High nutrient recycling, highlighted by a low f-ratio (0.004 to 0.21) and high ammonia uptake in the euphotic zone (15-fold higher than nitrate uptake) emphasizes the importance of nutrient recycling and the microbial loop in this region. In Chapter 4, our investigation moves to the Subtropical Convergence Front, a unique region in the Southern Ocean where subtropical and subantarctic waters converge to create a dynamic mixing zone that can support high plankton biomass and productivity. Here we use a combination of biomass estimation methods, including epifluorescence microscopy, flow cytometry and FlowCam, in order to determine depth-resolved variations in pico-, nano- and microplankton abundance and carbon based biomass in the euphotic zone, while examining vertical size-specific changes in carbon to chlorophyll a (C:Chla), this data allowed the quantification of the living to total carbon ratio. We find that subtropical-influenced waters were dominated by nanoplankton with low macronutrients and high Chla concentrations and offshore subantarctic-influenced waters had higher macronutrients and lower Chla with picoplankton dominated biomass in offshore regions, but microplankton-dominance in a coastal region. The subantarctic-influenced region had 2-fold higher C:Chla values due to a variety of environmental factors, including nutrient limitation and community structure. Significant primary production and rapid recycling by a strong microbial loop is evidenced by the living:total carbon ratio, which suggested that 67% of total particulate organic carbon in the euphotic zone of this region is attributed to live plankton and that non-living detritus comprises the remaining ~1/3. This dissertation highlights the critical understanding of nutrient uptake dynamics and carbon-based estimates of plankton groups in improving biogeochemical models for open-ocean ecosystems. Quantifying nutrient uptake is especially important in oligotrophic oceans that are vulnerable to a warming climate, as there will likely be an increase in stratification, which would reduce nutrient supplies from the subsurface to surface waters, hindering nutrient recycling and thus expanding oligotrophic regions throughout the oceans. Quantifying plankton community composition is equally essential, given plankton's significant role in driving marine photosynthesis, supporting marine food webs, and influencing ocean carbon uptake. The data presented in this dissertation offers valuable insights into the mechanisms and dynamics that drive marine pelagic food webs and biogeochemical cycles.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Ammonium Uptake, Community Composition, Nitrate Uptake, Pelagic Food Webs, Phytoplankton, Primary Production
Michael R. Stukel, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jeanette Wulff, University Representative; Sven A. Kranz, Committee Member; Angela N. Knapp, Committee Member; Olivia Mason, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Geneses and Geochemical Relationship of Forearc Basaltic Magmas in Cascadia Columbia Transect, Cascades Arc

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Typically arc magmatism is restricted to a narrow band semi-parallel to the trench, with the slab surface sits at 70- to 170-km depth (Gill, 1981; Syracuse & Abers, 2006). At the Cascadia Columbia Transect (CCT), the arc width is expanded towards both forearc and backarc. The Boring Volcanic Field, Indian Heaven Volcanic Field, and Mount St. Helens are three forearc volcanic fields in Cascadia Columbia Transect. Beneath the Boring Volcanic Field, the slab depth beneath volcanoes is estimated to be at only ~55 km (McCrory et al., 2012). The Cascadia Columbia Transect erupts variable magmas types including typical arc magmas: calc-alkaline basalt (CAB), basaltic andesite (BA), andesite (AND), and rhyolite (RHY). In addition, high-K magmas (HKCA), low-K magmas (LKT), and intraplate-type magmas (IPB) occur. As the overlying continental crust is 35-40 km thick (Syracuse et al., 2010), the thickness of forearc mantle is only 20 km. The variability of magmas in the transect is possibly related to the hot nature of the subduction zone, or unusual disturbance of the mantle thermal structure and/or mantle flow. To understand the underlying dynamics of magma generation beneath Cascadia Columbia Transect, I analyzed and compiled major element, trace element, and isotopic composition of Boring Volcanic Field, Indian Heaven Volcanic Field, and Mount St. Helens. The elemental and isotopic compositions of magmas are used to analyze and model the processes of magma generation in the mantle and evolution in the crust, including source mixing, melting peridotite, fractional crystallization, assimilation, and magma mixing. The most primitive magmas have distinct geochemical characteristics which indicates the primitive magmas are spatially separated during their ascent. All the three volcanic fields, overlap in isotopic compositions even for the primitive magmas. Though there are scattering in the isotopic compositions due to source heterogeneity, the trace elemental composition of Mount St. Helens basalts can be reproduced by mixing of more primitive Boring volcanic magmas and basaltic andesite. The three volcanic fields thus are proposed to have same mantle genesis with different extents of heterogeneity. Their sources (endmembers) are modeled by a three-component source mixing model involving a depleted background mantle, a sediment melt, and an eclogite melt from the mafic part of the slab. The model uses estimated source composition of the LKT magmas from ~6% of melting, to constrain the enrichment in the slab components. The source of the LKT magmas are the background mantle and this component is considered to be ubiquitously present. The level of enrichment of the other two components is determined by the trace element and isotopic composition of the primitive members of a magma type. It is concluded that the slab components added to the background mantle are depleted in large-ion lithophile elements (LILE), but Ba and Sr are more enriched. The most enriched high-K calc-alkaline magmas are generated separately from other magmas, with components with isotopic compositions the same as used for the other magma-types, but different trace element compositions. The high-field strength element depletion in the calc-alkaline magmas and the absence of such depletion in the intra-plate magmas are explained by the slab straddling at a critical point where rutile is residual or is dissolved in the melt. The magmas from Boring Volcanic Field and Mount St. Helens both show convergent compositional trend from primitive magmas to basaltic andesites, and Indian Heaven magmas also display a smaller range in elemental and isotopic characteristics at this silica content. Andesites and more felsic magmas form a single trend with silica. The modeled fractional crystallization paths indicate primitive magmas cannot evolve to felsic magmas through fractional crystallization alone in all the three volcanic fields. Instead, mixing lines between primitive and more evolved magma compositions show assimilation is a significant process in making the felsic magmas. The absence of more felsic magmas at monogenetic volcanic fields are explained by shorter residence time in the crust and the lower volume of erupted magma. The unique characteristics of felsic magmas of Mount St. Helens and the adjacent volcanic fields excludes widespread lateral movement of magmas within the crust.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Boring Volcanic Field, Cascadia Columbia Transect, Indian Heaven Volcanic Field, Mount St. Helens, Sr-Nd-Hf-Pb isotopes
Vincent Salters, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric Hellstrom, University Representative; Munir Humayun, Committee Member; Ming Ye, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Mechanism by Which Zika Virus Induces Replication Fork Stalling and Cell Cycle Arrest

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus in the family Flaviviridae. Since being isolated from a rhesus macaque monkey in the Zika Forest of Uganda in 1947, only sporadic cases had been reported in Africa and Asia until 2007 when an epidemic occurred in Micronesia. A larger outbreak occurred in French Polynesia in 2013, from which a suspected link to an increased rate of Guillain-Barré syndrome was reported. The more recent 2015-16 ZIKV outbreak in the Americas saw the virus spread to over 70 different countries and a concurrent increase in microcephaly in babies born to infected mothers. Since ZIKV is linked to human neurological defects, the mechanisms behind its pathogenesis remain unclear. ZIKV infection in human neural progenitors triggers DNA damage and activates the ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM)/Chk2 DNA damage response (DDR) signaling pathway while simultaneously suppressing the ATM and Rad3-related kinase (ATR)/Chk1 signaling pathway, leading to cell cycle arrest which can retard brain development. During S phase, a potential collision between transcription and replication machineries makes transcription a major source of DNA replication stress. When the nascent RNA strand is inappropriately base-paired with the DNA template strand, leaving the non-template strand as single-strand DNA (ssDNA), a three-stranded DNA-RNA hybrid structure called an R-loop is formed which can interfere with replication fork progress if not resolved properly. Here we link the ZIKV-induced S phase arrest to replication fork stalling and R-loop induction. DRIP-seq revealed that ZIKV infection triggers the induction of R-loops in specific sites and the vast majority of these sites are present in the interferon-induced genes (ISGs). Bru-seq results further indicate that nascent ISGs transcripts are prone to R-loop induction upon infection. IFNAR1 KO reduced DNA damage response and S phase arrest, demonstrating a heretofore unknown role of IFN signaling in R-loop induction. Finally, overexpression of RNaseH1 partially relieved ZIKV-mediated cell cycle arrest. These data suggest that unscheduled expression of these ISGs, such as in the case of an infection, alters R-loop homeostasis and perturbs replication fork progression, leading to fork stalling and eventually DNA damage. Our study reveals a previously unknown connection between innate immunity and nuclear R-loop production which forms a new nucleic acid-based mechanism for cell cycle arrest. This newly identified nucleic acid-based mechanism expands our understanding of viral pathogenesis and may offer potential targets for therapeutic intervention against ZIKV infection and associated neurological complications.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biological Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Cell cycle, DNA damage, Interferon signaling, R-loop, Zika virus
Hengli Tang, Professor Directing Dissertation; Akash Gunjan, University Representative; Fanxiu Zhu, Committee Member; Yanchang Wang, Committee Member; Darin R. Rokyta, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Role of Construal Level in Perceptions of Distance within Social Relationships

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Feeling close and connected to loved ones helps to fulfill belongingness, relatedness, and intimacy needs. However, people face various real-life circumstances that limit the extent to which they feel close to a loved one. Construal level theory posits that thinking concretely (versus abstractly) is associated with closeness, which could undermine the impact of such circumstances. Nevertheless, experimental studies testing the effects of construal level on distance perception mainly involved inanimate or unfamiliar targets, whereas findings from several studies on close relationships, including a 12-day diary study reported here, suggested that an abstract rather than concrete construal was associated with closeness, perhaps because abstract construal activated relationship enhancing goal pursuit present only in close relationships. The follow-up study directly examined the role of target familiarity in the association between dispositional construal and perceived distance. In the lab, participants estimated their physical distance to both a loved one and a stranger, and then completed several other tasks estimating temporal, social, and hypothetical distance to their loved one. Findings failed to support the hypothesized association between construal level and factors conducive to maintaining feelings of closeness (target type or relationship length) on perceived distance to a loved one. Exploratory findings seemed to converge with traditional distance perception literature and highlight the association between abstract construal and psychological distance, and between concrete construal and psychological proximity.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Psychology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
construal level theory, friendship, psychological distance, romantic relationship

James K. McNulty, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jonathan G. Kimmes, University Representative; Elizabeth A. D. Hammock, Committee Member; Irmak Olcaysoy Okten, Committee Member; Jon K. Maner, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Adaptations of Arterial Function and Endothelial Glycocalyx to High-Sodium Diet in Mice

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Sciences

mods:mods.mods:abstract: INTRODUCTION: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the United States and excess sodium intake is a major contributor for CVD. A central feature of CVD is arterial dysfunction (i.e., elevated systolic blood pressure [BP], aortic stiffening, and endothelial dysfunction). Previously, we have shown that 12 weeks of high-sodium (HS) diet induces these arterial dysfunction phenotypes in genetically diverse, outbred UM-HET3 mice. Arterial dysfunction is suggested to be preceded by a deteriorated endothelial glycocalyx, which is a negatively charged gel-like structure bound to the luminal endothelium. Glycocalyx is hypothesized to buffer sodium cation in the blood stream, but excess blood sodium can in turn deteriorate endothelial glycocalyx. Indeed, we have previously shown that 12 weeks of HS diet deteriorates glycocalyx barrier function and decreases its thickness. However, the time course of HS diet-induced arterial dysfunction and glycocalyx deterioration remains elusive. Dietary sodium reduction has a well-established BP-lowering effect, but the reduction in BP is usually marginal. Other studies have also shown that HS-diet induced elevation in BP appears to be largely irreversible after HS diet withdrawal. It remains unknown whether the irreversibility exists in HS diet-induced arterial dysfunction and glycocalyx deterioration in UM-HET3 mice. In addition, we have previously shown that glycocalyx-targeted supplementation Endocalyx fully reverses age-related arterial dysfunction and glycocalyx deterioration in old mice, but the treatment effect of Endocalyx on HS diet-induced arterial dysfunction and glycocalyx deterioration remains unknown. PURPOSE: Therefore, we sought to determine the adaptations of arterial function and endothelial glycocalyx to HS diet consumption and withdrawal in UM-HET3 mice and explore the effect of Endocalyx as a potential therapeutic for HS diet-induced arterial dysfunction and glycocalyx deterioration. METHODS: Male and female UM-HET3 mice underwent 12 weeks of low-sodium (LS) or HS diet or 6 weeks of HS diet followed by 6 weeks of LS diet (HSLS) or 6 weeks of HS diet followed by 6 weeks of LS diet plus Endocalyx supplementation (HSLS+E). RESULTS: Firstly, we observed elevated urine concentration of sodium and potassium in HS compared to LS and HSLS mice (P<0.05), and they were at similar level in HSLS compared to LS mice (P>0.05). Systolic BP, diastolic BP, and heart rate as well as their respective diurnal variation, as measured by telemetry system, showed no difference between all group (P>0.05). Aortic stiffness, determined by aortic pulse wave velocity (PWV), was increased in HS and HSLS mice after week 2 compared to respective baseline and continued to increase through week 8 in both groups (P<0.05). Then, aortic PWV plateaued out after week 8 in HSLS group (P>0.05) but continued to increase through week 12 in HS group (P<0.05). Aortic PWV was higher in HS and HSLS compared to LS mice at weeks 4-12 and it became higher in HS compared to HSLS mice at week 12 (P<0.05). From week 0-6, Δ systolic BP, as measured by tail-cuff method, was higher in HS, HSLS, and HSLS+E compared to LS mice (P<0.05) but was similar between themselves (P>0.05). From week 0-12, Δ systolic BP was higher in HS and HSLS compared to LS and HSLS mice (P<0.05), but it was similar in HSLS+E compared to LS mice (P>0.05). From week 0-6, Δ aortic PWV was higher in HS, HSLS, and HSLS+E compared to LS mice (P<0.05) but was similar between themselves (P>0.05). From week 0-12, Δ aortic PWV was higher in HS, HSLS, and HSLS+E compared to LS mice (P<0.05), but it was lower in HSLS and HSLS+E compared to HS mice and lower in HSLS+E compared to HSLS mice (P<0.05). Aortic histology revealed that collagen content was higher in HS and HSLS compared to LS mice (P<0.05), but it was similar between HS and HSLS mice (P>0.05). Carotid artery endothelium dependent dilation was lower in HS and HSLS compared to LS mice (P<0.05), but it was similar in HSLS+E compared to LS mice (P>0.05). Endothelium-independent dilation was similar between all groups (P>0.05). Glycocalyx barrier function, as measured by perfused boundary region, was worse in HS compared to LS, HSLS, and HSLS+E mice (P<0.05), but it was similar in HSLS and HSLS+E compared to LS mice (P>0.05). Lastly, glycocalyx thickness was lower in HS mice (P<0.05), similar in HSLS mice (P>0.05), and higher in HSLS+E (P<0.05) compared to LS mice. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, HS diet only partially reverses the arterial dysfunction despite of a fully reversed glycocalyx barrier function and thickness in genetically diverse, outbred UM-HET3 mice. When HS diet withdrawal was combined with glycocalyx-targeted supplementation Endocalyx supplementation, it further reversed the HS diet-induced arterial dysfunction and glycocalyx deterioration in these mice. Taken together, these findings provide evidence that dietary sodium reduction when combined with treatment like Endocalyx can largely reverse the adverse adaptations of HS diet consumption in arterial function and endothelial glycocalyx, which may be a novel strategy to lower the risk of CVD in humans that consume a HS diet.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Health, Nutrition, and Food Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Understanding Processes and Outcomes of Collaborative Governance in the Fields of Sustainability and Smart Cities

mods:name.mods:namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This dissertation explores the mechanisms and impacts of collaborative efforts in addressing environmental challenges and advancing smart city initiatives. Through a trilogy of scholarly articles, this work delves into the nuanced dynamics of interlocal collaborations, community-engaged coproduction for energy efficiency, and the intricate landscape of citizens' value preferences in AI-driven public service delivery. Each article not only stands on its own merit by contributing unique insights into specific facets of collaborative governance but also collectively enriches our understanding of how these processes influence and are influenced by broader societal goals in sustainability and smart cities. The first paper addresses the relationship between the structural aspects of network positions and the procedural dynamics of collaboration, assessing their impact on environmental performance. While this article tackles the inter-governmental collaboration, the second and third papers focus on the citizen-government collaboration that emphasizes citizen coproduction and participation in public service delivery. Specifically, the second study assesses how local government initiatives can overcome barriers to participation in energy efficiency programs, thus promoting broader energy justice. The third study explores how citizens perceive and prioritize values in the deployment of AI in public services, emphasizing the need for governance that aligns technological advancement with democratic principles and public trust. Together, these articles forge a multidimensional narrative on collaborative governance, illustrating how different forms of collaboration and engagement can lead to sustainable outcomes and more responsive governance structures.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Automated Decision System, Citizen Coproduction, Collaborative Governance, Environmental Policy, Network Governance, Residential Energy Efficiency

Frances S. Berry, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Tian Tang, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Eric A. Coleman, University Representative; Daniel L. Fay, Committee Member; Hongtao Yi, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Estimating Accurate Gene Trees in the Presence of Intralocus Recombination and Genome Assembly of the Upland Chorus Frog, P. Feriarum

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Accurate gene trees are difficult to estimate with traditional methods due to the effects of recombination. New methods that co-estimate gene trees and recombination breakpoints function differently than the traditional maximum likelihood (ML) framework, and therefore have the potential to alleviate inaccuracies caused by recombination. However, the accuracy of gene trees produced by these methods has yet to be evaluated under a broad range of conditions. Using simulations, we studied gene tree accuracy in the presence of intra-locus recombination. Using a previously published model of human population history, we simulate the process of recombination along large sections of a genome to produce DNA sequence alignments. We varied three parameters that influence gene tree accuracy: recombination rate, population size, and substitution rate. We then compare the accuracy of gene trees estimated using different methodologies, including traditional maximum likelihood estimation of single and concatenated regions (FastTree), as well as more sophisticated co-estimation methods (Relate, Tsinger, and Rent+). We found that traditional approaches can only produce accurate gene trees in limited regions of parameter space; as the number of sites used to estimate a gene tree increases, recombination becomes more and more problematic. Some, but not all, of the co-estimation methods successfully circumvent this tradeoff and have the potential to produce accurate gene trees in broader regions of parameter space. These results indicate that by adopting co-estimation methods, systematists may be able to improve gene tree accuracy. For Chapter 2 of this dissertation, we generate a de novo chromosome scale genome assembly for Pseudacris feriarum with open source software and our own methods. The final assembly has a total of 4,007,244,081 base pairs and is 78.0% BUSCO complete (pre-polishing); 85.95% of the assembly is assigned to 12 large chromosomes. We generated a PacBio CLR-based contig assembly and then partially removed duplicated heterozygous regions from contigs using Purge_dups. We developed our own methodology to fully remove heterozygous sequence; we rely on ambiguous bwa-mem read mappings to identify duplicated heterozygous contig pairs. Open source software we used struggled to correctly join contigs into scaffolds using intermediate range linking data (Chicago), so we developed our own methodology that ensures joins are only made between contigs whose connections encompass a certain area. After Chicago scaffolding we use Hi-C linking data along with 3D-DNA to generate chromosome sized scaffolds. We finalize our assembly with misjoin correction, manual curation in JBAT, and polishing with Arrow. Lastly, we perform a set of analyses which highlight the strengths and weaknesses of the assembly we generated in Chapter 2. Specifically, we show that the assembly of P. feriarum is reasonably complete by finding a high proportion of previously identified and sequenced genomic elements within the assembly. Additionally, we find supporting evidence in chromosome and ortholog conservation that indicates the large-scale structure of the genome assembly is correct. We also verify that small scale orientation and ordering of sequence is likely correct by recovering exon and intron properties similar to other anurans through RNA transcript mapping. We visualized and tested uniformity for the following genomic elements: anchored loci, candidate speciation genes, telomeric motifs, and a repetitive motif of particular interest. We find anchored loci and candidate speciation genes could come from uniform distributions, telomeres are not positioned correctly, and a marker motif is widely spread throughout the genome but not uniformly distributed. Repeat annotation through RepeatMasker reveals there are only 175 unique and 830 total occurrences of repetitive regions larger than 10,000 bp.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Scientific Computing in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Genome Assembly, Phylogenetics, Pseudacris feriarum, Recombination

Alan R. Lemmon, Professor Directing Dissertation; Darin R. Rokyta, University Representative; Chen Huang, Committee Member; Emily C. Lemmon, Committee Member; Peter Beerli, Committee Member; Sachin Shanbhag, Committee Member.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Perceptions, Predispositions, and Previous Experiences
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: College Students' Attitudes Toward Rhetoric in a Required First Year Composition Course

mods:mods.mods:abstract: "Perceptions, Predispositions, and Previous Experiences: College Students' Attitudes Toward Rhetoric in a Required First-Year Composition Course" explores college composition students' attitudes about the course and key rhetorical concepts in their required college composition course(s) at Florida State University (FSU). The purpose of this study is to highlight students' understanding and knowledge of rhetoric, along with their attitudes toward key concepts, which could inform their performance in class and their ability to use rhetorical concepts in their writing beyond the classroom. Rhetoric is a fundamental concept in many composition courses at the college and university level, but especially prominent at Florida State University. This methodologically qualitative research study used a mixed-methods approach with two focus groups and five follow-up interviews. I conducted this study to observe the predispositions and assumptions students may make about the course and its key concepts in an attempt to comment on how these pre-existing and developing attitudes about rhetoric inform their understanding and even their performance within the context of a required composition class. Whether students explore rhetorical concepts at the high school level or if they are first introduced to them at the university level impacts their perceptions, attitudes, and applications of rhetoric. This study found that students are generally confident writers at the first-year composition level but when asked to define terms, they struggle. Their implied understanding and knowledge is seen through their statements and using these terms and concepts in context. At the very least, some students fail to see connections between this course and future writing while others can note concrete benefits. Ultimately, students' attitudes in the college-composition classroom vary, but they undeniably pull heavily from their previous high school, AP, dual enrollment, Cambridge AICE, and other unknown experiences to make assumptions on rhetoric.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of English in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Arts.
articulation, college composition, first year composition, predispositions, prior knowledge, rhetoric
Michael Neal, Professor Directing Thesis; Elias Dominguez Barajas, Committee Member; Rhea Estelle Lathan, Committee Member.
